narrative: On 07/07/2022, a virtual video Component II Orientation was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Vanessa Galvan and Lisa Slusher with Angie Smith, Program Director and Norma Garcia, Administrator. The following was addressed and discussed; the program expectation/review, overview of the first review letter submission, discussed the pending application and the additional items and updates needed,corrections needed for the Plan of Operation (POO) section, and Central Valley Star #1 transferring and associating employees in Guardian. The location of the Pre-licensing inspection will be conducted at 33340 Meadow Drive Springville, CA 93265, and Component III is scheduled for 08/16/2022 at 11:00 AM.

On 08/16/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Lisa Slusher and Vanessa Galvan travelled to the facility listed above. The purpose of the visit is to conduct a pre-licensing Facility Inspection. LPAs were met at the facility by Angie Smith- Program Director/Administrator, Norma Garcia- Facility Manager, Andrena Wiggins- Program Assistant/LCSW. LPAs toured the facility and observed the following listed below. 1. The facility has a staff room and is inaccessible to clients. Staff room has extra supplies of linens, personal hygiene products, and emergency food supply. 2. A medication room that stores the facility’s first aid kit. First Aid kit is complete with appropriate manual. The medication room stores all medications. LPAs observed a key locked cabinet with a locked medication box. 3. In the kitchen LPAs observed a fire extinguisher, a key locked drawer for sharps to be stored, kitchen chemicals/disinfectants in key locked cabinet, trash can with a lid, weekly menu, refrigerator temperature 36 degrees and freezer temperature 0 degrees. 4. The house has 5 bedrooms- 2 ambulatory and 3 non-ambulatory, single occupancy, all located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings and storage space. All rooms are equipped with fire alarms and trash can. 5. LPAs observed a sensory media room equipped with activities for sensory. 6. Chemicals were in a key locked cabinet. 7. Adequate storage space observed. CONTINUED ON PAGE 2...

CONTINUED FROM PAGE 1... 8. Dining room had a table with chairs to accommodate the number of clients. 9. Outdoor space observed. The outdoor space has plenty of outdoor space and equipped with a basketball court, garden, and outdoor furniture. 10. The outdoor of the home was free from hazard and obstructions. 11. Adequate food storage space observed. Perishable and non-perishable foods will be available before client are placed in the facility. 12. Facility has two full restrooms and 1 half restroom, all are operable. Facility is to ensure water temperature is maintained between 105 and 120 degrees. All restrooms are stored with hand soap, toilet paper, and paper towels. 13. Appropriate forms posted in the facility. 14. The temperature of the facility was a comfortable temperature of 76 degrees. 15. Licensee has a vehicle for use at the facility. When LPA returns, the vehicle including insurance and registration will be available for inspection. 16. Facility has a separate “annex” building that will be utilized for educational purposes and activities. 17. Facility is a delayed egress facility. The delayed egress is a 15 second delay. An alarm sounds as soon as the bar is pushed, and the gate opens at 15 seconds. The system requires a key turn by staff to deactivate the alarm. Fire clearance has been received from the Tulare County Fire Department. Overconcentration clearance has passed the time frame for county response. Agency will either associate staff through Guardian if able, otherwise a transfer request and copy of identification will be submitted for association.

On 12/15/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan traveled to Central Valley Star #1 in Springville, CA to conduct a post-licensing inspection. The facility was licensed on September 22, 2022. LPA were met at the facility by Administrator Norma Garcia and Program Assistant Andrena Wiggins. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following observations and checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. All required forms are posted. The temperature of the facility was a comfortable temperature of 73 degrees. All facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order and all fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. The kitchen has a full-size refrigerator and is operating at safe temperature. Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and food menu is posted. Knives and sharps are key locked and inaccessible to clients. Chemical, disinfectants, and cleaning solutions are key locked and inaccessible to clients. The dining room is equipped with large table and chairs accommodating of all clients. There are five bedrooms- two ambulatory and three non-ambulatory, single occupancy, all located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings and storage space. All rooms are equipped with a fire alarm and trash can. Individual beds were observed and appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. Facility has two full restrooms and a half restroom, all are operable. All restrooms are stored with hand soap, toilet paper, and paper towels. The facility has a sensory media room equipped with activity station and items. Facility has a medication room where medications are dispensed to clients. Medications are locked and inaccessible to clients. LPA observed medications are centrally stored. First Aid kit is stored in the medication room and is complete with all first aid items. The facility has a staff office and is inaccessible to clients. Staff office stores extra supplies of linens, personal hygiene products, and emergency food supply. Facility has a separate “annex” building that will be utilized for educational purposes and activities. CONTINUED ON PAGE 2...

CONTINUED FROM PAGE 1... Facility is a delayed egress facility. The delayed egress is a 15 second delay. An alarm sounds as soon as the bar is pushed, and the gate opens at 15 seconds. The system requires a key turn by staff to deactivate the alarm. A facility has two vehicles and two vans and are in safe operable conditions and provide adequate seating for all clients. There are no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. There are no bodies of water. LPA reviewed three client and two staff files. A review of staff files indicated that all facility staff have received child abuse index clearances and fingerprint clearances. Agency staff meet requirements of respective job descriptions. Agency Employs one Administrator, one Program Assistant, one Social Worker Supervisor, and thirty-four Psych Tech Assistants. Management staff will review the Disaster and Causality Plan and PMAR to maintain compliance with regulatory standards. There were no deficiencies issued today. A copy of this report was left with Norma Garcia at the conclusion of the inspection.

On May 17, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan traveled to the Central Valley Star in Springville, CA and met with Program Assistant Director, Andrena Wiggins. The purpose of today’s inspection is to conduct a case management regarding an incident report that was submitted to the department. The incident report disclosed by a reporting party that while Staff 1 (S1) (see LIC 811) worked at Central Valley Star on the Porterville Developmental Center grounds, S1 allegedly “cusses” at clients and “pulls clients’ hair.” Allegedly, S1 sent a video to the reporting party of a client who claims she is pregnant with god’s child. The reporting party is concerned about the welfare of the clients. The reporting party could not give specific dates nor client names. While reviewing the Facility Roster it was determined S1 does not have verification of obtaining a clearance or exemption and has worked in the facility without a current fingerprint clearance or exemption. On this date, a citation is issued in violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 03. section 80019(e)(1) Criminal Record Clearance. A civil penalty is assessed on this date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to Andrena Wiggins at the conclusion of the inspection.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Criminal Record Clearance 80019(e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working...in a licensed facility: (1) Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, S1 does not have a fingerprint clearance or exemption and has worked at the facility. This poses an immediate threat to the health safety or personal rights of clients in care. A civil penalty in the amount of $500 is assessed on this date.

investigation_findings: 13On August 31, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan conducted an unannounced follow up complaint inspection at Central Valley Star located in Springville, CA and met with Angie Smith, Program Director. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. The Department has investigated the complaint alleging Staff inappropriately restrained minor in care. During the investigation, Community Care Licensing (CCL) conducted confidential interviews and review of documentations. Based on the interviews and documents reviewed, it was determined that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is deemed unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted discussing this report and appeal rights. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provide to Lori Miller at the conclusion of the inspection.

met_with: Jennifer Phillips, Program Manager and Bruce Wexler, Senior Director
narrative:
On June 1, 2023 at 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore conducted an announced pre licensing inspection for a Community Crisis Home (CCH). LPA and LPM met with Jennifer Phillips, Program Manager and Bruce Wexler, Senior Director. Program Manager provided LPA and LPM a guided indoor and outdoor tour of the facility. The facility will serve two ambulatory and two non-ambulatory clients ages 12-17 years old. The facility is a four-bedroom and two-bathroom for client use. The facility consists of living room, kitchen, dining area, staff office, staff bathroom, reception area, therapy room, hygiene closet, laundry room and two space garage that will be used as a storage and client activity room. Bedroom one and two will serve ambulatory clients. Bedrooms three and four will serve non ambulatory clients. Bathroom one will be used for ambulatory client only. Bathroom two will be used by non ambulatory clients only. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bedroom. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. All beds were observed to have appropriate clean linens and mattress in good repair. There was adequate drawer and closet space for clients’ belongings. The living room and kitchen is set up as an open concept. The living room is furnished with couches, dining table with four chairs and a television. The kitchen was observed to be free from observable hazards. Sharps, cooking utensils, and silver wear will be maintained locked in kitchen draws and cabinets. Meal menu, activity schedule, house rules and daily schedule was observed on the refrigerator. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible in the laundry room where children will not have access. The medication cart is maintained locked in the staff office. First Aid kit was accessible and stored in the kitchen cabinet. CONTINUED....

A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility is a fenced perimeter with double locked doors at the entrance and delayed egress system. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Backyard contained two swinging benches and a gazebo. Art supplies, clay, and yoga balls were observed for children’s recreation time in the activity room. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order. The hot water temperature was measured in the kitchen and is currently 135.0 degrees. Applicants understands that the water temperature must be maintained within the regulation range of 105-120 degrees Fahrenheit. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. LPA observed the following items posted in the reception area Personal Rights, Emergency Disaster Plan, Facility sketch, house rules and ombudsman poster. The facility had the emergency intervention plan. The facility has operable automatic fire sprinkler system. LPM completed the component III Orientation and discussed Incident reporting, including incidents related to Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. Based on this inspection, the facility will need the following corrections: the water temperature must be maintained within the regulation range of 105-120 degrees, phone line to be installed, preservation of the medication requiring refrigeration and lid for recycling container. After corrections are completed. the applicant will notify LPA so another inspection can be completed. A Community Crisis Home shall not be licensed by the Department until the Certificate of Program Approval, granted by the Department of Developmental Services has been received in accordance with Health and Safety Code section 1567.80. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Jennifer Phillips, Program Manager

Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tana Kinder and Alyssa Burgess conducted an announced prelicensing inspection with the Licensee, Michelle Wagner on 8/9/2021 at 10:30 am at the facility. LPAs utilized the CARE Tool for the inspection. LPAs conducted the walk through of the facility with the Licensee and observed 4 bedrooms, 2 offices, 2 common areas, 2 bathrooms a kitchen, garage, laundry room, front yard and back yard. All spaces were were clean, sanitary, free of insects, and had unobstructed pathways. LPAs observed 7 days worth of non-pershable, food for 4 potential clients. The facility does not utilized protective separation rooms. All the bedrooms are furnished with a bed, dresser, night stand, closet and is well-lit. The grounds have a garden and recreation area with plenty of space for activities. There are no staff associated to the facility. There are currently no clients at the facility. There are (3) individuals associated to the facility; the licensee, administrator and clinical director. LPAs have observed the following that need to be brought into compliance before issuance of the license. LPAs have given Technical Assistance Advisories for the following: 1. The land line phone is set-up, but the land line is not hooked up. 2. The cilent bathrooms have a faucet with a button to deliver water that does not stay on long enough to deliver hot water. Additionally, the faucet angle/pressure makes the water splash out of sink and on person standing in front of sink. 3. Currently the propane tank is accessible. 4. The rug in the multi-purpose visit room shall have anti-slip material added underneath the rug. 5. No statement regarding back-up power/generator in the Emergency Disaster Plan. 6. Emergency Disaster Plan needs to address storage of medications, including medications that require refrigeration.

7. Facility will have one set of keys for evacuation with each of the following keys: facility vehicles, all client rooms, exit doors, cabinets, cupboards for supplies. 8. Facility needs to compile the Disaster Supply Kit to the specifications in their Program Statement, section Emergency Disaster Plan. Licensee will submit evidence that the above listed issues have been corrected to LPA Kinder before the license can be issued. LPA Kinder and Licensee Wagner agreed upon 9/10/2021 for the above items to be resolved by. Exit interview was conducted with Licensee Wagner and a copy of this report was emailed to mwagner@advancekids.com

LPA Kinder conducted a Post Licensing inspection on 12/29/2021 at 1130am. During this inspection, LPA Kinder inspected the facility interior and exterior which includes the following: · The facility is licensed for 4 placements and currently has 1 client · The facility vehicles (2) were inspected and clean and in good repair with insurance and registration · Facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair · Facility and outdoor area is free of safety hazards · Facility has enough perishable/nonperishable food for 1 client for 4/12 days · Toxic materials are inaccessible, locked in cabinet in laundry room · There are games and in-home entertainment including board and video games · Medications are locked and kept out of reach of children · Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide monitors are operable and there are fire extinguishers (3) fully charged · The facility has adequate personal hygiene supplies and linens for up to 4 clients · Personal Rights, Monthly Menu Plan, Emergency Exit Plan, and Disaster Plan are posted · 1 client file and medications were reviewed and 4 staff files were reviewed. - Water temperature was logged at 108.7 - First Aid Kit (3) were observed to be fully stocked an additional one is in one of the vehicles Based on the files and inspection, the facility appears to be in compliance with Title 22 Regulations. Permanent licensing is recommended at this time.

An annual required inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tana Kinder on 9/29/2022 with Facility Administrator. Community Care Licensing file, incident reports, facility roster, facility profile and complaint history were reviewed prior to visit at the agency. The licensing fees are owed on this date. This information was provided to the administrator. The Facility has a capacity of 4 and currently has 2 residents. There are 40 staff members associated to the license and 4 currently working at the Facility. LPA reviewed 4 staff files, all that were reviewed were complete and up to date. Staff files reviewed have required training hours, education, and fingerprint clearances. 3 youth files were reviewed. The youth’s needs and services plan/Individual Program Plan, Behavioral Plan (IBST) and quarterly reviews were complete and up to date. Immunization records were current. Medical consent forms were signed by authorized representative and current. Additionally, the youth’s files had a record of personal property. Personal rights, menu, license, and emergency exit plan were posted. The facility was inspected jointly with the Facility Administrator. LPA interviewed 1 client. There are 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. Each bedroom has a bed for 1 client, as the facility has single occupancy bedrooms. Three bedrooms had a firm mattress, with a bed cover, sheets, blanket, and pillows. One bedroom was being repaired as a client destroyed much of the room during a behavioral episode. The common area has couches and chairs to sit in, and a TV. The facility is in good repair. There are locked cabinets in the laundry room with cleansers and detergents. Additional linen if needed for the bedrooms and the bathrooms are kept in a hall closet. Client and staff files are in locked cabinets. The passageways from the front to the back of the facility are unobstructed. LPA observed the backyard and saw a patio table with chairs and play equipment for the clients. LPA observed enough perishable/non-perishable food for 3 clients for 4 days/3 weeks. Smoke detectors are in working order. There is a carbon monoxide monitor and 2 fully charged fire extinguisher. Sharps were kept locked in the kitchen. Additional sharps are kept locked in the laundry room.

The kitchen was stocked with plates, utensils and drinking cups sufficient for 4 clients. The garage is set up for the client’s to play ping-pong and do crafts. The clients’ hygiene kits were stocked. A fully stocked first aid kit is kept in the laundry room. LPA observed an emergency disaster kit for evacuation, kept in the garage. An exit interview was conducted and discussed with the Facility Administrator. No Citations were issued.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman and James Kreidler, Policy Analyst on 9/6/23 at 9am. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9(a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Stidman and Policy Analyst Kreidler met with Glenda Stanley, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed one child’s records on site at the facility. LPA interviewed five staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed no children currently prescribed psychotropic medication. LPA reviewed the client's psychotropic medication records LIC622B (PMAR) and observed the record for one client does not contain a separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed. During a record review for another client the Centrally Stored Medication and Destruction Record form LIC622 is missing the name of the client for all prescriptions filled 9/1/22–3/24/23 on page 1, 3/1/23, 5/2/23 -7/2/23 and 9/5/23 and the date started for all prescriptions filled 9/1/22-3/24/22 on page 1, 10/1/22-11/30/22 on page 2 and for five different medications on page 2, and 3/1/23 on page 1. There is no LIC622 form for Medications #1 (M1), #2 (M2), #3 (M3), and #4 (M4) filled 7/31/2023. The LIC622 on page 3 for the destruction of M2 filled 3/1/23 is missing the signature of the staff that destroyed the medication, the prescription number, the name of the pharmacy and the date of destruction. Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 84070(b)(13) Children's Records, 80075(k)(7) and 80075(l)(1) Health Related Services LPA Stidman was unable to complete the psychotropic medication inspection on this date and will conduct another inspection.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84070(b)(13) Children's Records (13) A separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to the child documenting all the following: (B) The date of the prescription. (H) Staff initials for each time a psychotropic medication is taken by a child, as an indication that they supervised the child self-administering their psychotropic medication. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: During a record review for client C1. LPA observed C1's psychotropic medication records does not contain a separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed. The record review for C2 PMAR’s for August and September 2023 for Medications #1 (M1), #2 (M2), #3 (M3), and #4 (M4) for all dosages are missing the current date of the prescription. The PMAR for C2 for August 2023 for M1 for the 8am dosage is missing staff initials for 8/21/23 which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.

80075(k)(7) Health Related Services (k) The following requirements shall apply to medications which are centrally stored: (7) The licensee shall ensure... a record of centrally stored prescription medications... includes the following: (A) The name of the client for whom prescribed. (H) Instructions, if any, regarding control and custody of the medication. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: During a record review for client C2 the Centrally Stored Medication and Destruction Record form LIC 622 is missing the name of the client for whom prescribed for all prescriptions filled 9/1/22–3/24/23 on page 1, 3/1/23, 5/2/23 -7/2/23 and 9/5/23 and the date started for all prescriptions filled 9/1/22-3/24/22 on page 1, 10/1/22-11/30/22 on page 2 for five different medications on page 2, and 3/1/23 on page 1. There is no LIC622 form for Medications #1 (M1), #2 (M2), #3 (M3), and #4 (M4) filled 7/31/2023. The PMAR for M1, M2, M3 and M4 for September 2023 has the incorrect month of August 2023.

80075(l)(1) Health Related Services Prescription medications which are not taken with the client upon termination of services, or which are not to be retained shall be destroyed by the facility administrator, or a designated substitute, and one other adult who is not a client. (1) Both shall sign a record, to be retained for at least one year, which lists the following: (A)Name of the client, (B) The prescription number and the name of the pharmacy. (C) The drug name, strength and quantity destroyed. (D) The date of destruction. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: During a record review for client C2 the Centrally Stored Medication and Destruction Record form LIC 622 on page 3 for the destruction of M2 filled 3/1/23 is missing the signature of the staff that destroyed the medication, the prescription number, the name of the pharmacy and the date of destruction which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.

narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman on 9/14/23 at 1:00pm. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9(a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Stidman met with Glenda Stanley, Administrator. LPA reviewed five staff personnel files on site at the facility. During the inspection the LPA observed deficiencies (see attached 809D), plan of corrections were discussed and appeal rights were provided. Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 84065(j)(3)(O) Personnel Requirements. During the inspection LPA observed three staff files did not contain documentation of training on oversight and monitoring of psychotropic medications for children.. LPA conducted exit interview with Glenda Stanley, Administrator. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Glenda Stanley, Administrator.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84065(j)(3)(O) Personnel Requirements.. Training must include but is not limited to the following topics: (O) Topics listed in Sections 84065(i)(3)(A) through (Z).This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based upon record review, the licensee did not ensure facility staff files for S1, S2 and S3 contain documentation of training on oversight and monitoring of psychotropic medications for children which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.

narrative:
On 9/28/23 at 10:13 a.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacqueline Carmona made an unannounced annual inspection using the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tools and met with Glenda Stanley, Community Crisis Home (CCH) Facility Manager. LPA toured the interior and exterior of the facility during the inspection today. The facility consists of 4 client bedrooms, which had all the furniture, linens and lighting as required. There is 1 bedroom used as a game room/ visitation room. LPA observed 2 bathrooms available to clients which were appropriately equipped with toilet paper, paper towels and running warm water as required. LPA observed that the shower and toilet were in working condition as required. The kitchen had a adequate supply of perishable and nonperishable food for the clients in care. LPA observed that the facility appliances, refrigerator, and freezer to be clean and function as required. LPA observed that sharps, disinfectants, and cleaning supplies were appropriately stored and were not accessible to clients in care. LPA observed a menu posted in the facility. LPA observed the laundry services available for the youth to complete their own laundry. LPA observed working carbon monoxide detectors and a fully charged fire extinguishers. LPA observed that the facility has a functioning telephone in the facility. The living room and dining room were free of obstruction and had furniture in good repair. The office used by the administrator and staff has locked cabinets for client’s files and a locked cabinet for medication. All the posting requirements were available in a visible area. First aid kits were fully stocked and available. LPA observed that the facility vehicle appeared to be in good operating condition. The back yard and front yard were free of debris and in compliance. There are no bodies of water located on the property. Currently the facility has 2 clients in care. LPA reviewed 2 client files and 5 staff files. A review of the staff files indicated the staff have current CPR and First Aid training. They also have DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse check clearances. The client’s file contained all required documentation. Continue to page 2

LPA interviewed 4 staff and 2 clients. A review of the Licensing Information System indicates the facility is current with their facility fees at the time of the inspection. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of report was provided to the CCH Facility Manager.

On 10/25/23 at 11:25 a.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jacqueline Carmona made an unannounced visit to the Community Crisis Home (CCH) to conduct a case management regarding the facility staff not having knowledge of Mandated Reporting Requirements. LPA met with Glenda Stanley, Facility Manager(who assisted with the inspection). The home is a one story. It consists of two living spaces, one dining room, one kitchen, four bedrooms (three client bedrooms), one bedroom used as a game room/visitation room, 2 bathrooms, a laundry room, an office for staff, and a conference room, A walk through was conducted during today’s inspection, the facility was observed to be in compliance. On 9/28/23 LPA Carmona conducted the facilities annual inspection. During the staff interviews, 3 out of 4 staff members were unable to answer questions regarding Mandating Reporting. On 10/10/23 LPA Carmona received staff members Mandated Reporting Training Log. An exit interview was conducted with Glenda Stanley, Facility Manager and a copy of this report was provided. There were no citations during today’s visit. This case management investigation is closed.

Confidential interviews also revealed that the alleged victim made a phone call around the time the incident was alleged to have occurred and there was no mention of the incident during the one-hour phone call. It was also revealed that the alleged victim was asleep and was awakened by the incident. Even though they could not see the perpetrator clearly, they were able to identify their voice, and the other staff members who were on shift during the time the incident was alleged to have occurred, but there were no witnesses who could confirm this information. Records reviewed also showed the list of all staff working during the shift when the incident was alleged to have occurred and the alleged perpetrator was not on the list of staff on that shift. Lastly, email received on 11/1/23 also revealed that the police report of the alleged incident is not available and cannot be produced. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided to Jessie Ward, Lead 1.
investigation_findings: 13On 11/30/23 about 3:25 PM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Uchenna Ajaero made an unannounced complaint investigation visit to deliver finding for this allegation. LPA Ajaero met with Jessie Ward, Lead 1 and informed her of the purpose of the visit. During the investigation, LPA Ajaero visited Kala House on 10/04/23 and met Glenda Stanley, the Facility Administrator. LPA Ajaero requested the following client and staff information: Client Roster, Staff Roster, Needs and Services Plans, Admission agreements, police report, emergency contact information for client and Case notes for the past six month. LPA Ajaero conducted confidential interviews with parties involve between 10/10/23 and 11/1/23. Based on interviews conducted during the investigation, the allegation that staff sexually abused a minor in care cannot be substantiated because statements given in one of the confidential interviews conducted 10/10/23 explained that the allegation could not have happened, because the alleged staff did not work the shift when the incident was alleged to have occurred.

narrative: On February 8, 2024 at approximately 09:15 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Farhaan Sarangi and Sara Lumen-Gonzalez arrived unannounced at Kala House Jr. for conducting a Case Management-Other inspection. LPA was greeted at the door by Lead RBT, Thaiesha Blake, and was granted access into the facility. During the opening of the complaint, LPAs toured the facility and made observations. Upon entry into the facility at 09:15 AM, LPAs observed the wooden fence neighboring the home has a hole in it. LPA Lumen-Gonzalez observed window screens that need attention and/or replacement. In addition, LPAs also observed the facility is in the process of conducting a storm cleanup. LPAs educated the Lead RBT regarding the importance of ensuring that the repair of the fence, cleanup and the replacement or repair of the window screens to ensure the physical plant is in good operation (See LIC 9102-Technical Violation). No deficiencies were cited during today's Case Management-Other inspection. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to the Lead RBT, Thaiesha Blake.

On March 5, 2024 at approximately 12:15 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Farhaan Sarangi arrived unannounced at Kala House Jr. for conducting a Case Management-Incident inspection. LPA was greeted at the door by Assistant Administrator, Anthony Driessen, and was granted access into the facility. During the Case Management-Incident Inspection, LPA reviewed the incident report with the Assistant Administrator and performed a file review. LPA requested the following: -Social Worker contact information -NOC shift staff member contact information Further investigation is needed. Exit interview was conducted at Kala House Jr. with Assistant Administrator, Anthony Driessen and a copy of this report was signed and given to the Assistant Administrator.

narrative: On March 25, 2024 at approximately 1:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Farhaan Sarangi arrived unannounced at Kala House Jr. for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Incident inspection. LPA was greeted at the door by Director of Residential Services, Shoa Johnson, and was granted access into the facility. During the Case Management-Incident Inspection, LPA toured the home on March 5, 2024 and March 25, 2024 and made observations. Facility was found to be clean with all exits free from obstruction. LPA observed sufficient perishable and non-perishable foods. Toxins and other hazardous items were observed to be stored and locked inaccessible to clients in care. LPA observed client bedrooms which were found to be appropriate during both tours. The incident which occurred on February 19, 2024 involved a client eloping from the facility and was on the neighbors property. LPA attempted to interview the client on March 19, 2024 and March 25, 2024, but was unsuccessful due to client denying to be interviewed. it was unclear when the staff shortage took place because no dates and times were provided. narrative: On May 13, 2024 at approximately 01:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Farhaan Sarangi arrived unannounced at Kala House Jr for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Other inspection. On September 10, 2024 at approximately 3:45 pm Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tatyana Shulz and Zaria Turner arrived at the above Community Crisis Home. LPAs were greeted by Patrick Scott Mahoney, Assistant Administrator who granted LPAs access. LPAs conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where LPA observed the following deficiencies. Broken window in clients bedroom. The work order was placed on 08/28/2024. Air conditioning units are easily accessible to clients in care. (See LIC 9102 TV) LPAs requested a copy of the work order to replace the window and also discussed the barrier needed around the air conditioning units to make it inaccessible to clients in care. This case management will remain open, until a follow up inspection is conducted to ensure the facility is in full compliance. On September 27, 2024 at approximately 9:00 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Zaria Turner and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez, made an unannounced visit with the purpose of conducting an annual inspection to the above Community Crisis Home. LPA and LPM met with Administrator, Chris Corss, and a walk through of the interior and exterior was completed. Physical Plant LPA and LPM conducted a walk though of the interior and exterior of the facility. The facility was clean, safe and kept free of obstruction. LPA and LPM observed the posting of License, Personal Rights, and Emergency Disaster Plan. The facility consists of four client bedrooms, two bathrooms, visitation/game room, kitchen, living room, dining room, staff room, office/conference room, and three car garage. Each client room is equipped with one bolted bed frame, closet, space for clothing and personal belongings. LPA and LPM observed two vacant bedrooms. Three bedrooms are equipped with bedding and one bedroom is equipped with a TV. The two bathrooms at the facility are equipped with working toilets and running water. The living room is equipped with a couch and a lounge chair, TV, and stuffed toys for clients in care. There are two closets with extra disinfectant products, hygiene products, and snacks for clients. There is a laundry room with a washer and dryer and cabinets above and below where extra linen, toiletries, feminine products, and cleaning supplies are kept and locked away. Disinfectants/cleaning solutions are inaccessible to clients in care and locked in one hall closet, under the kitchen sink, and in laundry room. Refrigerator temperature is at or below 45 degrees F. There is nonperishable food for one week and fresh perishable food for three days minimum. Sharp objects are locked in the drawer in kitchen and hall closet. There are containers to place leftover food. A working telephone is available at the facility. Continue summary of inspection on 809-C

Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are in working order. First Aid Kit fully stocked. Hot Water between 105–120-degree F. Fire Extinguishers are up to date and in working order. The toilets, bathtubs, and shower fixtures are in good repair. Soap and paper towels are available to clients in care. The facility is free of vermin. The backyard contains a double fenced in area with basketball hoop, table with benches, and basket for toys. The fenced areas are locked and inaccessible to clients in care. On the outside of the fence there are two gazebos with a lunch table, BBQ area, table and two chairs, and water heater that is locked away. There is an additional fenced area containing a gravel walkway, one gazebo, and swing. Outside of the double fence is an additional area containing a play structure for clients in care. There is a shed for the exposed well, enclosed space for water filter, two locked sheds for discarded materials, and a gated gardening area. There is no pool on the premises. The following domains were also reviewed during today's inspection, Physical Plant, Operation, Staff and Client Records. A total of four staff files and two client files were reviewed. LPA and LPM conducted four staff interviews and two client interviews. A review of the Licensing Information System indicates the facility is up to date on their facility annual fees. Several deficiencies and four Technical Violations (TVs) were assessed during today's inspection. (See LIC 809-D and LIC 9102 TVs) An exit interview was conducted with Chris Cross, Administrator, and a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided during today's inspection.

On October 28, 2024 at approximately 9:00 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Zaria Turner and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez arrived at the above Community Crisis Home. LPA and LPM were greeted by Chris Cross, Facility Administrator who granted LPA and LPM access. LPA and LPM conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where LPA and LPM observed the following deficiency (See LIC9012 TV): Broken pantry/cabinet door on October 23, 2024. Work order is currently pending and licensee will send a copy to LPA via email. On September 27, 2024 the following deficiencies were noted and are currently pending (TVs for the following deficiencies we're issued): Board minutes unavailable during inspection. Air conditioning units are easily accessible to clients in care Exposed circuit breakers on the right side of the facility is accessible to clients in care. This case management will remain open, until a follow up inspection is conducted to ensure the facility is in full compliance. An exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left with Chris Cross, Facility Administrator.

7 out of 11 interviews confirmed that staff attended medical appointments, provided meals, ensured health care needs were met, staff followed behavioral care plans, and supervised clients in care. In addition, LPA Turner was not able to qualify one client during the interview process, and was not able to obtain exact dates and times of incidents reported. During the investigation LPA Turner was informed that C1 was removed from the facility without prior notification. Staff was not aware of C1 being discharge. Staff advised LPA Turner that C1 lost personal belongings in bedding and no other clients or staff took belongings. It was also confirmed that appointments were missed due to mis-communication between the parties involved. It was confirmed by staff members that C1 was the one listening to inappropriate music in the facility. Staff denied that there was a lack of supervision in the facility while client was in care. Lastly, LPA Turner was notified by staff that C1 was provided snacks when RP randomly picked them up from the facility. Staff were unable to provide fully cooked meals before they left the facility. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.

met_with: Tegre Miles, Director Reyes Bonilla, Administrator
narrative: On 5/7/25 at 1PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins met with Applicant Mile High Director Tegre Miles and Facility Administrator Reyes Bonilla for the scheduled Component II face-to-face meeting. During the meeting, the following topics were discussed. Goal/Purpose of the Facility Basic Services and Planned Activities Needs and Services Plans Care and Supervision Policies Emergency Intervention Policies Emergency Disaster Procedures Reporting Requirements Background Clearance/Guardian Process At the conclusion of the meeting, LPA discussed that the prelicensing inspection will be scheduled upon receipt of the fire clearance. LPA thanked Director and Administrator for attending the meeting. A copy of this report was emailed to Director.

Licensing Program Analysts, (LPAs) Tana Kinder and Nino Sanders conducted an announced prelicensing inspection with the Administrator, Adlaine Alfonso on 8/24/2021. LPAs utilized the CARE Tool for the inspection. LPAs conducted a walk through of the facility and observed 5 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, 2 common areas, a large entry area, a kitchen with dining area, a garage converted into an office area for staff with locked cabinets that can store records. There is a locked medication room with a locked cabinet inside to store medications and a refigerator dedicated for medications that require refrigeration. LPAs observed a laundry room, a front yard and back yard area. All spaces were clean, sanitary, free of insects and had unobstructed pathways. LPAs observed 3/7 days worth of perishable/non-perishable food for 5 potential clients.The facility does not utilize protective separation rooms. All the bedrooms are furnished with a bed, dresser, nightstand, closet and is well-lit. The grounds have raised beds for a potential garden and plenty of space for recreational activities. LPAs observed 2 fully charged fire extinguishers, 2 working carbon monoxide monitors and working smoke detectors throughout the home that close the fire doors when triggered. There is a van for transport that is in working condition with current registration. No cameras are in use in the facility. Technical Advisories were issued. No citations were issued. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to the administrator.

LPA Kinder conducted a Post Licensing inspection on 1/20/2022 at 1100am with the Administrator. During this inspection, LPA Kinder inspected the facility interior and exterior which includes the following: · The facility is licensed for 5 placements and currently has 3 clients · The facility vehicles (2) were inspected and clean and in good repair · Facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair · Facility and outdoor area is free of safety hazards · Facility has enough perishable/nonperishable food for 3 clients for 4/12 days · Toxic materials are inaccessible, locked in cabinet in laundry room · There are games and in-home entertainment including board and video games · Medications are locked and kept out of reach of children · Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide monitors are operable and the fire extinguishers (2) are to date and fully charged · The facility has adequate personal hygiene supplies and linens for up to 5 clients · Personal Rights, Monthly Menu Plan, Emergency Exit Plan, and Disaster Plan are posted · 3 client files and medications were reviewed and 4 staff files were reviewed · Water temperature was logged at 109.5 · First Aid Kit (2) were observed to be fully stocked and one is in one of the vehicles

Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Tana Kinder conducted an unannounced case management inspection with the Administrator regarding 3 incident reports related to C1 dated: 1/22/2022,1/30/2022, and 2/1/2022. LPA reviewed the incident reports with the Administrator and discussed the issues related to C1 and C2. The Administrator provided information related to the incidents and how staff were addressing the issues to prevent future incidents from occurring. No citations were given and a copy of this report was provided to the Administrator.

An annual required inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tana Kinder on 11/01/2022 with Facility Administrator. Community Care Licensing file, incident reports, facility roster, facility profile and complaint history were reviewed at the agency prior to inspection at the facility. The licensing fees are current. The facility has a capacity of 5 and currently has 3 residents. There are 99 staff members associated to the license and 25 are not currently employed by the facility. The Administrator will disassociate the names from the roster. 5 staff currently working at the Facility. LPA reviewed 5 staff files, all that were reviewed were complete and up to date. Staff files reviewed have required training hours, education, and fingerprint clearances. 3 youth files were reviewed. The youth’s needs and services plan/Individual Program Plan, Behavioral Plan (IBST) and quarterly reviews were complete and up to date. Immunization records were current. Medical consent forms were signed by authorized representative and current. The facility was inspected jointly with the Facility Administrator. Personal rights, menu, license, and emergency exit plan were posted. There are 5 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, 2 common areas, kitchen, and dining area. There is a patio area outside, a basketball hoop in the front driveway, a trampoline with a safety net secured around it and a covered patio area on the front of the facility. Each bedroom has a bed for 1 client, as the facility has single occupancy bedrooms. The bedrooms had a firm mattresses, with a bed cover, sheets, blanket, and pillows. Each client had personal effects, including clothing in their bedrooms. The common areas have couches and chairs to sit in, and a TV in one of them. The facility is in good repair. There are locked cabinets in the laundry room with cleansers, detergents and other toxic materials. Medications are locked in the medication room. There is a separate refrigerator for medication in the medication room. Additional linen if needed for the bedrooms and the bathrooms are kept in a linen cart, kept in the family room. Client and staff files are in locked cabinets in the office, which is located in the garage. The passageways from the front to the back of the facility are unobstructed. LPA observed enough perishable/non-perishable food for 3 clients for 4 days/3 weeks. Continued...

The Facility has a hard-wired smoke alarm system. There is a carbon monoxide monitor built into the smoke detector system. LPA observed 2 charged fire extinguishers. The fire doors were tested and did not release. Hue and Cry was out in October 2022 and repaired the fire doors so they would release automatically. They will be scheduled to come to the Facility to repair the doors again on 11/7/22 so they close automatically on their own. They can be closed manually. Sharps were kept locked in the kitchen. The kitchen was stocked with plates, utensils and drinking cups sufficient for 5 clients. The clients’ hygiene kits were stocked. A fully stocked first aid kit is kept in the medication room. The water temperature from the front bathroom sink was 107.5 degrees. LPA observed an emergency disaster kit for evacuation, kept in a cabinet by the garage. An exit interview was conducted and discussed with the Facility Administrator. One citation was issued on a D page and a copy of the annual inspection report and appeal process was provided.

On 3/15/2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor conducted a case management phone call with the Administrator to follow up on an incident report received on 3/13/23 regarding lack of supervision. LPA Lor discussed the incident report and gathered further information. It was determined that another staff was on site during this incident. No citation was given and a copy of this document was emailed to the agency for their records. This case management investigation is closed.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Roberts conducted an unannounced inspection to the above agency on 10/3/23 at 10:00 a.m. to discuss the complaint allegation. LPA Roberts met with Shelita Majied, LCSW. LPA Roberts informed Ms. Majied that the complaint investigation included an initial 10-day inspection on 9/18/2023, where LPA conducted a file review and collected the following documents: Child 1 (C1)’s SIRs for the past 6 months, Child’s Needs and Services Plan and Staff Contact List. On 10/16/2023 at a subsequent visit, LPA Roberts collected Behavior Event Reports from C1’s school dated 8.30.2023. On 10.19.2023, LPA Roberts confirmed the Behavior Event Reports with the school. Behavior was witnessed and documented over a two-day period. File review was conducted on 9/19/23, and interviews were conducted between the dates of 9/19/2023 and 10/19/2023. Lastly, LPA Roberts was not able to interview C1 during the investigation due to his medical condition and being non-verbal. Based on LPAs record review and interviews conducted during the investigation process, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, meaning that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there are no witnesses, no specific dates/times when the incident took place. (Continued on LIC 9099-C)

narrative: On 11/20/23 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacqueline Carmona arrived to the above facility with the purpose of conducting an unannounced annual required inspection. LPA Carmona met with Adlaine Alfonso, Administrator and explained the reason for the visit. LPA Carmona asked for the census, and it was 3. During the inspection 3 clients and 6 staff were present. LPA Carmona conducted a walk through of the interior and exterior of the facility. The facility is a one story home that consists of 5 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, 2 common areas, kitchen, and dining area. There is a patio area outside, a basketball hoop in the front driveway, and a covered patio area on the front of the facility. The furniture throughout the common areas and bedrooms were in good repair. Each bedroom has a bed for 1 client, as the facility has single occupancy bedrooms. Each bedroom had firm mattresses with a bed cover, sheets, blanket, and pillows. The kitchen has a pantry and a refrigerator which were fully stocked with two days of perishable food and seven days’ worth of non-perishable food. Client and staff files are in locked cabinets in the office, which is located in the garage. The laundry room has a working washer and dryer. The bathrooms are clean, sanitary, and functioning with warm water temperature of 105 degrees. The front and back yard are clear and free of debris. LPA checked all fire alarms and carbon monoxide alarms, and they are fully functioning. The first aid kit (s) was fully stocked, and readily available. The fire extinguishers were fully charged. There is adequate lighting throughout the home. Clients live in a safe, healthy, comfortable home and are treated with respect. Overall, the home was observed to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPA Carmona completed the physical plant domain due to time restraint and will return at a later time to complete the rest of the CARE tool. Exit interview was conducted. No deficiencies cited during this inspection. A copy of this report was provided to Adlaine Alfonso, Administrator .

On 2/16/24 at approximately 5:08 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacqueline Carmona conducted a Case Management regarding an incident report received by the Department on 2/05/24. LPA contacted Adaline Alfonso, Administrator. The incident report disclosed abuse to a client from a staff member. The alleged staff was immediately removed from the floor and no longer providing care to clients after the incident. LPA Carmona gathered contact information for facility staff, Office of Protective Services commander and facility cellular phone number. An exit interview was conducted with Adaline Alfonso, Administrator and a copy of this report was provided. This case management investigation needs further investigation.

On July 31, 2024 Licensing Program Analaysts (LPAs) Tatyana Shulz and Sarina Buchannan arrived at the Community Crisis Home. LPA's were greeted by Administrator Adlaine Alfonso who granted LPAs access. LPAs conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where LPAs observed the following deficiencies: Several wholes in the laundry room door. The work order was placed on 7/25/2024. A broken window in the clients bedroom was boarded up. The work order was placed on 7/8/2024. A missing tank lid cover in the clients bathroom. The work order was placed on on 7/24/2024. LPA Shulz requested the work orders and dates the damage took place. This case management will remain open, until a follow up inspection is conducted in the near future to ensure the facility is in full compliance. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to the Administrator, Adlaine Alfonso.

On July 31, 2024 Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tatyana Shulz and Sarina Buchannan arrived at the Community Crisis Home. LPA's were greeted by Administrator Adlaine Alfonso who granted LPAs access. On July 1, 2024 LPA Shulz received a letter from Department of Developmental Services’ (DDS) stating that they completed the Semi-annual Monitoring Review Tool based on the visit conducted May 2, 2024 and May 29, 2024, at North STAR #2 Children’s Community Crisis Home. During the record review DDS staff noticed that some of the staff files were not current with First Aid/CPR training. During todays inspection LPAs reviewed 5 staff files at the facility and was confirmed that the First Aid/ CPR training's were current on the 5 files that were reviewed. No additional deficiencies were noticed during this file review. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the Administrator. No further investigation is needed.

On July 31, 2024 at 9:33am Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Tatyana Shulz and Sarina Buchannan made an unannounced inspection to close a case management that was initiated on 2/16/2024. The Department received an incident report on 2/05/2024 regarding physical abuse of a minor, minor was kicked, punched, and hit in the head with an object by a staff member. LPAs met with Administrator, Adlaine Alfonso who assisted with the inspection. On 2/20/2024 LPA Carmona was instructed by Commander James Dimmitt from the Department of Developmental Services (DDS), Office of Protective Services, to hold off on any further investigations from Community Care Licensing (CCL) in order to maintain the integrity of the legal case. On 7/1/2024 LPA Shulz received investigation documents showing DDS investigator findings. As well as information on the District Attorney’s decision to file charges against the staff member. Based on interviews conducted by DDS investigators with all parties involved including, eyewitnesses, and the minor, it was confirmed that the incident did take place. The facility has since removed the alleged staff from service as of 03/16/2024, plan of correction has been cleared during today’s inspection. LPA Tatyana Shulz obtained separation documentation for the staff member. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the Administrator. This case management investigation is closed, and the facility has been cited for Personal Rights 84072 (d)(1) (See LIC 809D).

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84072(d)(1)Personal Rights The licensee shall ensure that each child…is accorded the personal rights…To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect… This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observations and interviews conducted, the licensee did not ensure the safety of clients in care by allowing a staff member to physically abuse a client, which poses an immediate Health and Safety risk to persons in care.

narrative: On August 7, 2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tatyana Shulz and Sarina Buchannan arrived at the Community Crisis Home. LPAs were greeted by Ian Curzon, Senior Psych Technician who granted LPAs access to the facility. On July 31, 2024, LPAs conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where LPAs observed the following deficiencies: · Several holes in the laundry room door. The work order was placed on 7/25/2024. · A broken window in the client’s bedroom was boarded up. The work order was placed on 7/8/2024. · A missing tank lid cover in the client’s bathroom. The work order was placed on 7/24/2024. On August 6, 2024, LPA Shulz received pictures on the above areas indicating that all of the deficiencies have been cleared. On August 7, 2024, LPA Shulz and LPA Buchannan conducted a physical walk through of the facility to ensure that the deficiencies mentioned above have been rectified. LPAs noticed the screen on the new window was not installed. The window screen was on the premises and licensee will show proof of installation by end of day. LPA Shulz received pictures of the screen being installed for the new window on August 8, 2024 at approximately 4:01pm. This case management has been closed; no deficiencies were assessed because work orders were in place during the inspection on July 31, 2024. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator, Adlaine Alfonso .

On November 20, 2024, at approximately 9:45 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Zaria Turner and Tatyana Shulz, made an unannounced visit with the purpose of conducting an annual inspection to the above Community Crisis Home. LPA Turner and LPA Shulz met with Senior Site Technician, Ian Curzon, and a walk through of the interior and exterior was completed. LPAs conducted a walk though of the interior and exterior of the facility. The facility was clean, safe and kept free of obstruction. LPAs observed the posting of License, Personal Rights, and Emergency Disaster Plan. The facility consists of five bedrooms, two bathrooms, kitchen, living room, activity room, dining room, and office/garage. Each client room is equipped with one bed, bedding, a closet, and space for clothing and personal belongings. The two bathrooms at the facility are equipped with working toilets and running water. The living room is equipped with a table and chairs, two cabinets, one stocked with extra personal protective equipment (PPE) supplies, and one stocked with extra toys. There are two locked closets in the living room, one equipped with medical supplies, and one equipped with extra linen and cleaning supplies. There is one TV, a couch, a rocking chair, a dresser, and a bean bag chair in the activity room. There is a laundry room with a washer and dryer and cabinets where extra linen, toiletries, and cleaning supplies are kept and locked away. Disinfectants/cleaning solutions are kept in one hall closet leading towards the living room, under the kitchen sink, and in laundry room. Refrigerator temperature is at or below 45 degrees F. There is nonperishable food for one week and fresh perishable food for three days minimum. Sharp objects are locked in the drawer in the kitchen. There are containers to place leftover food. A working land line and cell phone are available at the facility for client use. Continue summary of inspection on 809-C

Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are in working order. First Aid Kit fully stocked. Hot Water between 105–120 degrees F. Fire Extinguishers are up to date and in working order. The toilets and shower fixtures are in good repair. Soap and paper towels are available to clients in care. The facility is free of vermin. The backyard contains a porch with a picnic table, outdoor table and lounge chairs, and an accessible ramp that wraps around the perimeter of the porch. Extending past the porch is a gated area that contains a small empty kiddy pool, basketball hoop, trampoline, and a small play structure that is secured to the ground. There are two locked sheds located in the front and back of the facility. One shed contains extra personal protective equipment (PPE) supplies, cleaning supplies, and paint. The other shed contains additional linens, bedding, beds, and decorative items. There are two family sized Chevy Express vans, one Chevy Volt sedan, and one Ford Fusion sedan located on the facility, used for transporting clients, that are all in good repair There is no in ground pool on the premises. The following domains were also reviewed during today's inspection, Physical Plant, Operation, Disaster Preparedness, Emergency Intervention, and Staff and Client Records. A total of five staff files and two client files were reviewed. LPAs conducted three staff interviews and attempted one client interview. A review of the Licensing Information System indicates the facility is up to date on their facility annual fees. A deficiency was assessed during today's inspection. (See LIC 809-D) An exit interview was conducted with Adlaine Alfonso, Facility Administrator, and a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided during today's inspection.

On July 11, 2025 at 11:38am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Tatyana Shulz made an unannounced visit to conduct a case management regarding DDS Semi-Annual Review that took place at the facility on May 13, 2025. LPA met with Administrator, Adlaine Alfonso who granted LPA access to the facility. Prior to the meeting DDS Monitor, Leah O’Meara conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where the Monitor observed the following deficiencies: · A container of expired evaporated milk was in the kitchen refrigerator. · A large sharp BBQ fork was unsecured in a kitchen drawer. · The outdoor shed located in an area accessible to consumers which contains cleaning supplies and chemicals was noted to be unlocked. LPA Shulz conducted a walk through of the facility and observed that the deficiencies noted on the May 13, 2025, inspection have been corrected. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided to Administrator, Adlaine Alfonso. The facility has been cited for Buildings and Grounds and Food Services on LIC809D. This case management inspection is closed.

All food shall be safe and of the quality and in the quantity necessary to meet the needs of the clients... All food shall be selected, stored, prepared and served in a safe and healthful manner.

narrative: On February 16, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michael Almaraz and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore met with applicant Oscar Mejia and Kim Royse via Microsoft teams to cover orientation component II. LPA and LPM went over revisions needed for the application prior to licensure. LPA and LPM gave a copy of the LIC 184, Notice of Incomplete Application and additional correspondence to assist with the revisions needed to the application. A copy of this report was emailed to Oscar Mejia.

On March 03, 2022 at 10:23 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michael Almaraz and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore began a pre-licensing inspection for a Community Crisis Home (CCH) license. LPA met with applicants Kimberly Hamilton-Royse and Oscar Mejia who led a tour of the home. The home was toured inside and out with the applicants. Applicants were applying for a maximum capacity of five clients. The home was approved for three non-ambulatory clients and two ambulatory clients ages 12-17-year-old. The home is a one-story residence with five bedrooms and three bathrooms. The home is set as: Bedroom #1 The room consist of a queen-size bed. It sleeps one ambulatory client- vacant. Bedroom #2 The room consist of a queen size bed. It sleeps one non-ambulatory client- vacant Bedroom #3 The room consist of a queen size bed. It sleeps one non-ambulatory client- vacant Bedroom# 4 The room consist of a queen size bed. It sleeps one ambulatory client- vacant Bedroom#5 The room consist of a queen-size bed. It sleeps one non-ambulatory client- vacant. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bedroom. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. Additionally, there was kitchen with a long island, a living room furnished with couches, an office, a medication room and a media room furnished with couches and a television. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were working properly. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will not have access. The medication will be stored in the medication room. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in the kitchen island drawer. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in a cabinet in the garage. (continued...)

First Aid kit was accessible and stored in the medication room. There were no guns or weapons as stated by Mrs. Hamilton-Royse. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be at 114 degrees. Applicants understands that the water temperature must be maintained within the regulation range of 105-120 degrees. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. Personal Rights, The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, house rules and ombudsman posters were posted in the kitchen by the garage door. The facility had the emergency intervention plan and COVID-19 mitigation plans were in place. Outside the facility, there was two patio areas furnished with couches, tables, and chairs. The backyard was observed to be clean and free of hazards. The facility had two delayed egress system on the front gate and the side gate. LPM and LPA verified and confirmed the delayed egress doors were functional during the inspection. LPM completed the component III Orientation and discussed Incident reporting, including incidents related to Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. Based on this inspection, the home is appropriate for a capacity of 2 ambulatory clients and 3 non-ambulatory clients. The request of License will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval and pending the Department of Developmental Services Certificate of Program Approval. A Community Crisis Home shall not be licensed by the Department until the Certificate of Program Approval, granted by the Department of Developmental Services has been received in accordance with Health and Safety Code section 1567.80. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to Kim Hamilton-Royse.

On December 13, 2022 at 9:01AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez conducted an unannounced visit at the facility. Due to printer malfunction, this report will be emailed to Clinical Social Worker Beverly Corona.
