met_with: Regional Director Cheryl Karran, Regional Deputy Director Elizabeth Steffens-Friedline, Administrator Danica Morrison
narrative: On 6/2/23 at 1PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a prelicensing inspection. LPA met with Regional Deputy Director Elizabeth Steffens-Friedline and Program Administrator Danica Morrison. The CARE inspection tool was used to complete this inspection. The facility and grounds were observed to be clean and in safe condition. The pool in the backyard is densely filled with soft bark and can be safely walked upon. The backyard activity space is open to the back of the facility and the rest enclosed by secure fencing. There are four bedrooms, with two cleared by a fire marshal for nonambulatory residents. The licensee will serve four residents, and each resident will have their own room. There are two accessible bathrooms maintained in sanitary condition. Beds have mattress pads, fitted sheets, top sheets, and covers. Each room has a dresser and a desk and is well lit. Chemicals are stored in locked storage spaces inaccessible to residents. The first aid kit was observed to be complete. The medication room has locked storage for separating and securing medications. The following areas require follow-up, which is anticipated to be complete by Friday 6/9/23: 1) Grievance procedures for residents and authorized representatives to file grievances with the administrator are not posted. Applicant agreed to post this in the facility by the phone. 2) Hot water measured above the permitted range. Applicant agreed to post a hot water caution sign above the sinks and lower hot water temperature until water measures within permitted range. Applicant has already prepared a temperature check log and will begin checking the hot water temperature and will submit evidence of water within range for three days. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Regional Deputy Director and Administrator, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 9/27/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a post-licensing inspection. LPA met with Administrator Danica Morrison and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA toured the facility site, inspected facility records, and interviewed one resident and two staff. Using the CARE Inspection Tool, no deficiencies were found. The facility is clean and organized. No hazards were observed in the outdoor or indoor activity spaces. The bathroom and kitchen spaces are maintained in sanitary condition. Staff are familiar with facility policies and procedures, and resident statements reflect quality care is being provided. Medication is safely secured, there is a large supply of food within date, and no chemicals or dangerous items were observed to be accessible to resident(s). Inspected files were complete and reflect that the resident care and treatment plans are being updated as required and that staff have background clearances to work at the facility. Beds have clean linens, and empty rooms are ready for future residents. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Danica Morrison, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 1/22/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a facility evaluation visit. LPA met with Facility Lead Mykiesha Peacock and informed of the purpose of the visit. During an investigation at the facility, LPA became aware of an area in which technical assistance may be beneficial. See LIC 9102 dated 1/22/24. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Lead Mykiesha Peakcock, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: 13On 1/22/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a complaint investigation visit in order to deliver investigation findings. LPA met with Facility Lead Mykiesha Peacock and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews, observation, and record review, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to provide the alleged violation did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Lead Mykiesha Peacock, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On 06/19/2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Mona Lam and Lisette Valenzuela conducted an unannounced annual/required inspection to listed facility. The facility is licensed for four residents, and currently in placement is one client. During this inspection, one staff was present in the home. LPAs toured the facility inside and out. The facility is single storied, and has four single occupancy bedrooms. All client bedrooms were equipped with comfortable furnishes which included ample storage space for clients’ belongings and twin sized beds. Client bathroom was clean and furnished with hygiene supplies for each client. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary. The kitchen was observed to be clean and free of hazards or chemicals. Sharps were located in a locked cabinet. The weekly menu was posted on the front of the refrigerator in the kitchen. Fire extinguishers are in working order, one is located in the kitchen and the other one is located in the garage office. Plastic bags were identified next to fire extinguisher in kitchen. LPAs advised removal of plastic bags. Garage contains locked storage of soaps and detergents. Pool in backyard was filled with bark. No bodies of water on the premises. All walkways were free from debris or hazards. LPAs observed broken closet in hallway. Administrator confirms there is a work order placed in to replace hallway closet. Linens are currently placed in a spare client bedroom due to hallway closet is broken. LPA Lam completed the Operation section of the required annual inspection using the CARE Tools. LPA Lam will return at a later date to complete the inspection. At this time, per Title 22 Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was printed and given to Administrator Imara Nakooka.

On 9/30/2024 at 10:21AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Shikya Belfield and Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced case management for the facility listed above. LPAs met with Program Administrator Imara Nakooka who facilitated the inspection. One other staff was present and no clients were present during the inspection. A physical inspection was conducted of the kitchen, four bedrooms, two bathrooms, staff office, garage, and backyard. The facility was clean and in good repair. During this inspection LPAs conducted a review of staff and client files. One client previously placed in the facility. Discharged as of 09/23/2024. LPA's interviewed facility administrator regarding the previously placed youth C1 ( see LIC 811 dated 9/30/2024). Due to client being discharged, LPA's did not have the opportunity to interview the client. LPA took photos of the facility inside and out. LPA's reviewed four staff files and one client file. During a walk through of the facility it was observed that there were no closets in the clients bedrooms. Case carrying LPA will follow up with the licensee regarding this possible violation however, at this time dresser storage was observed. LPA's observed a pool in the backyard if the facility however, the pool is not in use and has been filled with plant soil / tambark. LPA's requested copies of facility files. The inspection is being concluded at this time and further information will be requested as needed by the department. There were no violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Imara Nakooka and with Residential Director Terrance Harris.

met_with: DeMarcos Ayers - Assistant Director of Residential Services
narrative:
Control Number - 0001323-FN On 12/26/2024 at 11:30AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA)Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced case management for the facility listed above to follow-up on a submitted incident report (IR). LPA met with DeMarcos Ayers, Assistant Director of Residential Services. Five other staff were present and no clients were present during the inspection, but arrived toward the end of the visit. An Incident Report (IR) was submitted for an event that occurred on December 5, 2024. According to the IR, it was reported a staff member inappropriately grabbed a clients hair in retaliation to client pulling staff hair. During this inspection LPA conducted a review of staff and client files pertinent to the incident report. A physical inspection was conducted of the kitchen, four bedrooms, two bathrooms, staff office, garage, and backyard. LPA's observed a pool in the backyard if the facility however, the pool is not in use and has been filled with plant soil / tanbark. The facility was clean and in good repair. One Type A was cited under this visit which is in the other case management conducted on the same day.

LPA discussed where the facility is currently at with their internal investigation. Since it is still under investigation an update on where the Quality Control (QC) team is at with the investigation will be provided to the LPA. DeMarcos, ADRS provided LPA with copy of the email sent out requesting an update on the investigation. LPA also reviewed the staff under investigation of their recent completion of CPI and Ukeru training where a copy was also provided. A copy of all staff present at the facility during the date of the incident was also provided with their contact information. Body-checks administered that week were also provide to the LPA. Lastly three confidential interviews were conducted with the staff present during the incident. LPA was advised of the clients elevated behaviors and that an interview by (QC) regarding the incident has already been conducted with the client last week on 12/17/24 from investigator Brandon Patterson. The inspection is being concluded at this time and further information will be requested as needed by the department. There were was one violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, cited during this inspection listed in the other 809-incident conducted on this date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with DeMarcos Ayers, ADRS.

met_with: De Marcos Ayers - Assistant Director of Residential Services
narrative:

investigation_findings: 13On 12/17/24 at 9:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti made a visit to the facility to deliver complaint investigation findings for the investigation of the above allegation(s). narrative: Control Number - 0001443-FN On 1/24/2025 at 11:30AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA)Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced case management for the facility listed above to follow-up on a submitted incident report (IR). LPA met with Steven Toal, Program Administrator. Five other staff were present and two clients were present during the inspection. An Incident Report (IR) was submitted regarding an event that occurred on January 23, 2025. According to the IR, a medication was accidentally administered twice to a client. During this inspection, the LPA reviewed the client’s medication files related to the incident. A copy of the physician’s order for the administered medication, as well as the Medication Administration Record (MAR), was obtained. The administrator demonstrated full knowledge of the error and confirmed that appropriate follow-up procedures were implemented. It was also noted that Kamal Pathak, the psychiatrist, confirmed there would be no adverse side effects for the client due to the low dosage level. The administrator assured the LPA that the staff member responsible for the medication pass was removed from their duties until retraining is completed. Additionally, Director of Nursing Silvia Valdovinos Alcantar will review the descriptions on bubble packs and MARs to ensure they are clear and easily understood. There were was one violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, cited during this inspection. Please refer to the LIC809-D. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with Steven Toal, Administrator.

Control Number - 0001489-FN On February 20, 2025, at 10:14 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jonathan Medina and Hanako Primer conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the above-referenced facility to follow up on a submitted Incident Report (IR). LPAs met with Kristen Fox, Program Administrator. LPA's advised PA that the department needs to be notified in writing within 10 days of any change in the facility manager. An IR was submitted regarding an event that occurred on February 5, 2025. According to the IR, a client's confidentiality was allegedly compromised during a FaceTime call with a staff member. As a result, the staff member who placed the client on camera has been suspended pending an internal investigation. LPAs also gathered additional details regarding an IR dated January 14, 2025, which was updated on February 5, 2025 following the facility receiving additional details. This report involved an allegation of abuse of a client by a staff member. Through interviews, LPAs obtained further details on both incidents, which were documented on LIC812 forms. Contact information of Staff members involved in incidents was provided by PA and will be interviewed by LPA's over the phone. LPAs also reviewed 5 staff files for training relevant to the incident reports, including training on reporting requirements, mandated reporting, and personal rights. No violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6 were cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Kristen Fox, Program Administrator.

Control Number - 0001580-FN On March 14, 2025, at 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the above-referenced facility to follow up on a submitted Incident Report (IR). LPA met with Kristen Fox, Interim Program Administrator. During the visit, three staff members and one client were present. An IR was submitted regarding an event that occurred on March 12, 2025. According to the IR (C1) became upset with staff over her wake-up time and money for Starbucks. During the escalation, she intentionally placed her hand between a hot flat iron, causing a minor burn. Staff unplugged the device and later observed redness on her right hand. At a March 13, 2025, doctor’s appointment, Dr. Mary Joseph confirmed no treatment was necessary, and (C1) declined care. (C1s) mother, (P1), later disputed the report, stating (C1) told her the burn was accidental and expressing concerns about staff communication and behavior during the incident. During the visit LPA conducted an interview with Administrator to get more details on the incident to clarify the update on the incident report. LPA confirms proper follow-up procedures were conducted through review of shift-notes and interview. No violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6 were cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Kristen Fox, Program Administrator.

Control number - 0001595-FN On April 8, 2025, at 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the above-referenced facility to follow up on a submitted Incident Report (IR). LPA met with Imara Nakooka, Program Administrator. At the time of the visit, six staff members and one client were present. The IR was submitted regarding an incident that occurred on March 17, 2025. According to the report, Administrator Kristen Fox received a call from Client #1’s (C1) school notifying her that the client had received a 20-day notice due to excessive unexcused absences. The school also informed the administrator that C1’s last day of attendance would be April 4, 2025. During the visit, LPA conducted an interview with the Administrator to obtain additional information regarding the facility’s plan to ensure that C1 continues to receive educational services during and after the 20-day notice period. Administrator confirmed visits with schools are being done to find a new placement for (C1) and a copy of the IEP plan for (C1) will be sent to LPA once ready. No violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6 were observed or cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Imara Nakooka, Program Administrator.

Control Number - 0001695-FN On April 25, 2025, at 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the above-referenced facility to follow up on a submitted Incident Report (IR). LPA met with Aundre Christy, Assistant Program Administrator(APA). At the time of the visit, four staff members and two client were present. LPA conducted an interview with APA and one client. The incident report in review was submitted regarding an incident that occurred on April 22, 2025. According to the report, during an escalated state from the client (C1) during transportation staff had to get out the van to let (C1) de-escalate. In the process staff left a bubble pack medication in the car with the client and weren’t able to get back in the car. C1 stated they ate all the pills. C1 was placed on a 51/50 hold and taken to Contra Costa Regional Medical Center for evaluation. During the visit, LPA conducted an interview with the Assistant Program Administrator to obtain additional information regarding the incident. As a follow-up all staff is being retrained on how to transport medications, crisis communication, and de-escalation training's. Keys were confirmed to be in possession of staff while the incident took place, but C1 kept locking the door after each attempt to open. There was insufficient supervision during incident which led to C1 getting a hold and opening a medication bubble pack. Please refer to LIC809-D page. As a result of this incident, two deficiency were cited under the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Section 80075(k)(1) – Health Related Services and 80078(a) - Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. An exit interview was conducted, appeals rights discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Aundre Christy, Assistant Program Administrator.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80075(K)(1) Health Related Services (K)The following requirements shall apply to medications which are centrally stored: (1)Medication shall be kept in a safe and locked place...medication. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and interviews the staff did not ensure medication was kept in a safe and locked place, which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.

80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a)The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and interviews the staff did not ensure client was supervised during escalated state, which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.

narrative: On June 11, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted a visit to the facility to update the wording on the deficiency issued on June 6, 2025. LPA met with Erica Walker, Assistant Residential Director (ARD), and explained the purpose of the visit. After further review and consideration of the regulatory requirements for Community Crisis Homes, it was determined that specifying the staffing ratio in the Needs and Services Plan is not a requirement. However, the deficiency remains valid, as the Needs and Services Plans for the clients reviewed were incomplete. The wording on the LIC 809D was updated to reflect this clarification and was reviewed, signed, and approved by Erica Walker, ARD. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Erica Walker, ARD.

On 7/2/2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Will Ea made an unannounced visit to the facility for the purpose of conducting the facility’s annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Imara Nakooka, and informed the Administrator on the purpose of this inspection. The CARE Tool was used to conduct this inspection. LPAs reviewed the facility's plan of operations, client files, staff files, and conducted a walk through of the facility inside and out. During the facility walk through LPAs observed the facility to be maintained at a comfortable temperature, water from faucet was not hot due to a boiler issue reported that day, and a large outdoor activity space free from hazards. Admin Nakooka showed the maintenance issue log with the boiler issue logged today, and informed me their facility maintenance staff was scheduled to arrive later today to address the issue. A technical violation is being issued for lacking hot water. 2 of 3 clients declined to give entry to their bedrooms, the third client's room was equipped with a clean comfortable mattress, blankets, and pillows as needed, was decorated to the client's tastes, and contained sufficient storage for client's personal belongings. Food supply was labeled with dates in pantry and fridge, with sufficient fresh and durable grocery items. Fridge was observed to be stocked with sufficient groceries for tonight's dinner menu. Allowance balance was maintained for all clients and balance amount was correct. MAR, PMAR, and medication were locked in a staff office. Logs were complete and accurate. Sharps were kept in a locked cabinet in the staff supply room. All chemicals and cleaning agents were kept in a locked closet in staff room. Overall the facility appeared to be clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. (continued on 809C)

LPA Ea reviewed 3 of client records and 3 staff personnel files on site at the facility. All staff and client files were found to be complete and in good order. LPA Ea interviewed 3 staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. All clients declined to be interviewed, however they were observed to be wearing age appropriate clothing and of standard milleu. A copy of the facility's current LIC500, LIC309, and LIC610 were collected as part of the inspection. Overall, one technical violation was issued due to lacking hot water. A TV is being issued instead of a Type A citation, because the facility demonstrated that the issue was logged that day and maintenance was on the way to address the issue imminently. A copy of this report was provided to administrator Imara Nakooka along with a copy of the appeal rights. Imara's signature confirms their receipt and acknowledgement of the summary.

narrative: Control Number - 0002024-FN On August 5th, 2025 at 10:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Will Ea conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the above-referenced facility to follow up on a submitted Incident Report (IR). LPA met with Karla Advincula, Assistant Administrator(AAD), Erica Walker, Director of Client Services (DC1) and Terrance Harris, Director of Client Services (DC2). At the time of the visit, seven staff members and one client were present. The incident report in review was submitted regarding an incident that occurred on July 28th, 2025. According to the report, an AM shift staff member found a client wandering outside the facility unsupervised. The client had stated the NOC shift members were preoccupied with their phones and no one intervened when the client exited the facility. Later that morning, a different staff member had a verbal outburst with a client making the client feel unsafe. During the visit, LPA conducted an interview with AAD, DC1. and DC2 to obtain additional information regarding the incident. The staff involved was put on administrative leave immediately following the incident and their last day of employment is Thursday, August 7th, 2025. New policies regarding personal phone usage while on ratio have since been implemented, and secure storage lockers are in the process of being obtained to provide a secure storage location for staff while on duty. LPA requested and received a copy of the staff file of the involved staff member. Further investigation is required to resolve this case management visit. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Karla Advincula, whose signature confirms their receipt.

facility_name: YAI DAVIS RD. COMMUNITY CRISIS HOME (CCH)
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Tana Kinder conducted a pre-licensing, Component II meeting with Cheryl Karran on 2/3/2022 to review revision requests to the program design. The meeting was conducted using the video conference platform, Microsoft Teams. Section 3: Every box was checked. Do you truly see this program serving every type of need identified on the list? Have you had experience and training with every population identified? Section 4: Page 2: Other descriptions, for example, behavioral and/or medical assessments? NSP & IPPs. Page 5, Line 9: remove comma after Regional Center Staff. Page 5: includes Long Beach Aquarium as a possible activity, please remove and identify specific options in your area- what is in your community? Give names and locations of dining places, parks, gyms; etc. Page 6: Note: and parent- check with them also. Line 31 the sentence starts with “Ways.” Line 32 …not limited to (should not have colon(:). Line 33 as support (insert regulations) to the person’s needs. Line 36 codes and regulations. Line 39 ensuring. Page 7: Under dating line 5 physicals written 2# 5. Page 9: Please refer to local activities. Page 10: Are these optional? Aroma and meditation. Continued...

Section 5: Lists services for San Joaquin and Solano county. Also make sure the programs listed are available to Regional Center clients-use examples of vendored services if applicable. Section 6: Page 15: top- will family or legal guardian also be informed and included? Page 15, Line 3: Individual(s) *Attach a copy of the appointment history tracking form to this section. Page 16: First Aid Kit-you list some specific items. Make sure you have everything required by regulations. Page 17, 2nd paragraph, line 5: Add PMAR with MAR. 2nd paragraph, last sentence: Be specific-where are you going to store? Have a designated area assigned. Page 20: Expired Medication Disposal- Change locations to local area. Section 7: Page 21, line 1: Define vigorous background check. 2nd sentence vigorous. *If you use volunteers add information here regarding driving policy. *Address potential use of car seats or car restraint systems for younger/smaller clients. Section 8: Individual move-in agreement: Page 23, Bullet 7: What age group? Be more specific. Page 26, Initial Screening: Will you take county referrals or only Regional Center? Later it says only Regional Centers. Clarifying would provide consistency. Page 28, Line 2: “individuals (who) are…” Under admission meeting documentation: please add Personal Rights will also be reviewed and a copy will be provided (unless I missed where you cover that). Page 29: Will you be taking CSEC clients? Continued...

Section 9: Page 32, Bullet 2: remove the period (.) after the word following and perhaps use a colon (:) after “the plan of operation:” since you are listing the following information. Page 36, Line 1: remove the period (.) after “Individual Behavior. Supports…” Page 36: Who is responsible for completing the IBST? Section 10: Provide a detailed policy/procedure for removal of youth. Have a copy of the discharge plan/policy that would be signed by the parent/guardian in the child’s record in this section. Section 11: When are visits allowed? Are the designated times/days visits happen or times they do not happen (during groups at the facility, etc.)? Section 12: Please address: Curfews, dress codes, dating policy, completing homework (?). Gambling and betting?? Why is Personal Hygiene addressed here? There is nothing that says anything about rules in the narrative. Maybe Section 9? Section 14: Page 44: Why is that first (very long) sentence in this section? What are you trying to convey? Maybe it should be rewritten and put in Section 3? Page 44, Line 8, last word: Avoid(s), remove (s). Line 14: “When an individual is safely (restrained) no restraint. Line 16: “simultaneously are restraint” should be “are simultaneously restrained.” Page 45, paragraph 5, line 3: the last word, advise(d), paragraph 6, 1st sentence does not make sense. Already involved in Criminal Justice or preventing Criminal Justice involvement or additional Criminal Justice involvement? Continued...

Section 15: Incident Report Section, Bullet 1: Individua(l)’s Section 16: Do you have a grievance form for the client’s to access? Will you document the process if a client initiates a grievance? Where will this be kept? Section 17: Please edit the Policy and Procedures for Handling Children’s Funds to reflect a minor. For example, remove the examples that do not apply to children; tax credits, renter credit, gambling winnings, etc. Include parents in this section as it applies. Page 56, Bullet 8: remove cigarettes and perhaps some of the other examples listed on page 56 and 57 as they do not pertain to minors. Please address allowance and how that will be handled. Section 18: Page 61, 2nd paragraph, line 3: sense (of) ownership. Are there paid chores? Section 19: Page 62, 2nd paragraph, line 2: Individuals is (are). Last ling page 63: fitting (fit). Page 64, Bullet 6: similar substance is (will). 2nd Bold/underlined section: “If at any point the dishwashing machines … staff is (are). Section 20: Bullet 1, line 3: Rapidly change(s). Last bullet, line 1: “to be spend, (spent). Continued...

Section 21: What is peer partner position? If you don’t have it, do you want to eliminate? Otherwise, elaborate regarding the parameters for this position, including training, background check, etc. Should this be in Section 26? Section 22: QBMP/BCBA: “Several years of writing reports,” be more specific; 2-3 years? 3-4 years? Page 72, line after paragraph 3: “The success(ful) candidate must…” Section 22, 23 and LIC 500: Be consistent with job titles: Administrator/Program Administrator, RN/RN Consultant, etc. Section 24: Where will you track and keep documentation for each employee’s training. Add this information. Section 25: Don’t see Appendix VII, specifically LIC 309. Section 26: Should Peer Partners be included here? Where will you keep track of volunteer training? Section 27: Provide a copy of the lease. Sections 28: Please identify where the Main Shutoff Valve is located. Section 29: Please provide Board of Directors information. Continued...

Appendix II: Page 1, under Policy: “Upon admissions…” Page 1, last paragraph, line 4: “and so for(th).” Or so on?? Line 5: “developed by and DDS,” Page 2, Line 6: regarding a restraint not lasting longer than 10 minutes: How was that timeframe determined? If the client is still escalated, how will you end the restraint? Page 2, line 8: “child is safely restraint (restrained).” Page 2, Multiple Emergency Interventions: How do you determine adequate number of staff? In the training handbook, is there a minimum number of staff that are required? Do you need to take the size of the client and staff into consideration? Maybe defer to the protocol of the technique you are using and document that here. Page 2, last paragraph, line1: “or a compliant (complaint).” Page 3, Debriefing, Bullet 1: “Child who was restraint (restrained). Bullet 9: “Determining where (if)…” Page 4, paragraph 2, line 1: “CCH will report to the Department…” is the Department DDS, DSS or both? CCL? Appendix III: Financial Policy Page 1, paragraph 4, line 4: individual(‘)s file Page 2: Where is the bonding documentation kept? *This appears to have been written for an adult client population. Please review and revise for minors and their parents and/or representatives like CPS. There is policy regarding loans, paycheck stubs, etc. Is any amount of $200 going to be returned to the client’s parent or representative? Page 9: The list needs to reflect minors. Same with page 11 list of disallowed expenses.

facility_name: YAI DAVIS RD. COMMUNITY CRISIS HOME (CCH)
narrative:
Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Tana Kinder conducted an announced pre licensing inspection with the Licensee, Cheryl Karran on 5/10/2022 at 11:15 am at the facility. LPA conducted the walk through of the facility with the Licensee and observed 4 bedrooms, 1 garage that was converted into an office area , 1 common area, 2 bathrooms a kitchen, laundry room, sensory room and a locked medication room. All spaces were clean, sanitary, free of insects, and had unobstructed pathways. LPA observed 7 days' worth of non-perishable, food for 4 potential clients. The refrigerator was 36 degrees and the freezer was 0 degrees. The hot water from the sink was 106.1 degrees. The facility does not utilized protective separation rooms. All the bedrooms are furnished with a bed, dresser, night stand, desk/chair, closet and is well-lit. The front yard and back yard are fenced in with accessible gates. The grounds have a recreation area with a basketball hoop and plenty of space for activities. No cameras are in use in the facility. The backup generator is secured with fencing. The water well is secured with fencing. The water sprinkler system is enclosed with a lock. There is a locked shed for storage. The backyard is fenced off with extra yard on the other side that is not accessible to the clients at this time. There is an open garage like structure on the other side of the fence that is not accessible without unlocking the gate to the extra backyard. There are 9 staff associated to the facility and 3 in process. The licensee and administrator are associated to the facility. There are currently no clients at the facility. continued...

LPA has observed the following that need to be brought into compliance before issuance of the license. 1. The land line (2) phones need to be set-up. 2. Printer/Scanner has been ordered to upload all documentation for client and personnel electronic files. 3. Locked cabinet for any client or staff files that will be stored on site. 4. A posted copy of personal rights and 30 day menu. 5. Well water certificate needs to be kept at the facility and accessible at all times. 6. A facility vehicle will be rented by May 24th, 2022 until the leased vehicle arrives. LPA reviewed the following forms with the facility staff: An exit interview was conducted and copy for the report was provided.

facility_name: YAI DAVIS RD. COMMUNITY CRISIS HOME (CCH)
narrative: On 3/6/2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tana Kinder arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a case management visit related to an incident report dated 3/5/2023 related to a medication issue. LPA met with the Program Administrator, reviewed the incident report and conducted interviews. LPA discussed a violation that was identified during the course investigation dated on 3/5/2023. The allegation is that a foster youth missed a medication due to facility not having the prescription filled. The incident report and staff confirm the youth missed one medication due to staff not having the prescription refilled. Due to the above, the allegation is SUBSTANTIATED, meaning that the allegation is valid because a preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. Facility will be cited for violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division 6, regulation 80075 (a) Health Related Services (a) The licensee shall ensure that each client receives necessary first aid and other needed medical or dental services, including arrangement for and/or provision of transportation to the nearest available services. A copy of this report was provided at the exit interview. Refer to 9099D for Title 22 deficiencies cited.

facility_name: YAI DAVIS RD. COMMUNITY CRISIS HOME (CCH)
narrative:
An annual required inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tana Kinder on 6/13/2023 with the facility administrator. Criminal record clearances were reviewed, and the facility is in compliance. Community Care Licensing file, incident reports, facility roster, facility profile and complaint history were reviewed prior to visit at the agency. The licensing fees are current. The Community Crisis Home has a capacity of 4 and currently 2 residents. There are 7 staff at the facility on this date. LPA reviewed 4 staff files. The files that were reviewed were complete and up to date. Staff files reviewed have required training hours, education, and fingerprint clearances. 2 child files were reviewed. The child’s needs and services plan/Individual Program Plan, and quarterly reviews were complete and up to date. Immunization records were current. Medical consent forms were signed by authorized representative and are current. Additionally, the child’s file had a record of personal rights. The menu, license, and emergency exit plan were posted prominently in the facility. The facility will have the personal rights posted. The facility has a copy of the DDS personal rights form posted. The facility was inspected jointly with the program administrator. There are 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. Each client's bedroom has a firm mattress, with a bed cover, sheets, blanket, pillows and personal affects. The common area has couch and chairs to sit in, a TV and games for the clients. The facility is in good repair. Additional linen stored in the laundry room. Client and staff files are in a locked cabinet, in the garage/office area. The old client and staff files are also kept locked in the garage/office area in a locked cabinet. The passageway from the front to the back of the facility is unobstructed. LPA observed 1 locked shed in the backyard with supplies. The backyard has 1 piece of exercise equipment and a BBQ and a basketball hoop out front. LPA observed enough perishable/non-perishable food for 2 clients for 4 days/3 weeks. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide monitor are in working order. There are 2 fully charged fire extinguishers. Continued...

Disinfectants and cleaning solutions were in a locked cabinet in the laundry room and garage/office. Sharps were kept locked in a drawer in the kitchen. The kitchen was stocked with plates, utensils and drinking cups sufficient for 4 clients. The water temperature from the kitchen faucet was 106.2 degrees. Medication disbursement is logged and is cross reconciled with the bubble packs and the bottled medications are stored in a locked cabinet, in a locked room. The client's hygiene kits are stocked and kept in the garage. The first aid kit is kept in the medication cabinet and was missing scissors and tweezers. Exit interview conducted and discussed with the Program Administrator. Citations were discussed and issued, and a copy of the annual inspection report was provided.

narrative: On 10/4/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor conducted an unannounced case management visit regarding an incident report submitted to Community Care Licensing. The incident report was regarding suspected mold in the water well. LPA spoke with the staff who indicated that maintenance was contacted and the water well was cleared during a test. LPA observed the water to be cleared with no particles or mold. The staff explained the plan they have been implementing since the incident. The facility will email LPA a copy of the document once received by the maintenance company. An exit interview was conducted with the Lead RBT and a copy of this report will be emailed to the facility. This case management investigation is closed.

facility_name: YAI DAVIS RD. COMMUNITY CRISIS HOME (CCH)
narrative: Based on evidence obtained in witness interviews and in documentation reviewed, the allegations surround events that happened when 2 staff took 1 client on an outing to see the “Barbie” movie. (of note: the 2 clients who reside in this CCH require 2 staff to 1 client ratio). After the movie, the client wanted to call their friend. Staff requested the client place their call after they get home, take their medications and a shower. Client became escalated, screamed obscenities, ran down the street, one staff followed on foot, the other staff drove behind in the agency van, staff lost sight of the client, lead staff and law enforcement arrived, the child was located, law enforcement personnel encouraged the client to return home with staff, client attempted to run away from officers, the client was detained and taken to Lodi Memorial Hospital by law enforcement. In witness interviews, staff deny they have made inappropriate comments to a client and/or inappropriately disciplined the client, that staff were physically aggressive with client and that a client sustained an injury; the CCH facility documentation indicates the same. There is different information obtained in the evidence that a mandated reporter relayed: staff have made unkind/inappropriate comments when disciplining the client by kicking them, stomped on their feet, threw water at them, spit on them, made fun of the client’s relationship with their friend, staff were physically aggressive with a client, and that a client sustained an injury. Although the allegation that staff made inappropriate comments towards the client, staff inappropriately disciplined a client, staff were physically aggressive with a client, and that the client sustained an injury may be valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violations did, nor did not occur, therefore, the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. LPA conducted exit interview, provided appeal rights and delivered this report 11/21/2023.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Eunice conducted a complaint inspection to the above Community Crisis Home (CCH) on 11/21/2023, for the purpose of delivering investigation findings. The allegations state that staff made inappropriate comments towards the client, staff inappropriately disciplined a client, staff were physically aggressive with a client, and the client sustained an injury. LPA reviewed documentation from facility files to include: client’s needs and services plan, client’s face sheets, Valley Mountain Regional Center Special Incident Reports, All Client Activity, staff termination letter, YAI California Incident Investigation, and Online Complaint: 20231001-233625. LPA interviewed the Administrator, 2 current staff, and 2 former staff. LPA was unable to qualify the 2 clients in care to obtain substantive information. Additionally, LPA reviewed documentation from cell phone application (Behavior Agent) staff use to track daily activities of the clients, documenting maladaptive behavior, physical aggression or positive behavior, in real time, at times, moment by moment.

Community Crisis Home (CCH) and met with RBT Lead, Christian Thurman for the purpose of opening a complaint and delivering findings. During the course of the investigation, LPA Sarangi reviewed incident reports and other supportive documents. In addition, LPA conducted client interviews and conducted a facility tour during the investigation. Based on interviews that were conducted, an observation of the incident report and a facility tour, LPA learned that the facility heater is inoperable. According to the incident report, the facility has space heaters and a work order pending with maintenance has been completed. facility_name: YAI DAVIS RD. COMMUNITY CRISIS HOME (CCH)
narrative:
On January 26, 2024 at 11:00 AM, The Department met with Licensee for the purpose of an Informal Office Meeting to discuss areas of facility compliance. Attendees were: Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Farhaan Sarangi, Jacqueline Carmona, Sara Luman-Gonzalez, Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Rosa Rodriguez, Regional Manager (RM), Margo Castaneda, CDSS Staff Attorney, Erik Brunkal, Licensee, Cheryl Karran, HR Manager, Emily Ramos, Attorney Jake Reinhardt, Department of Developmental Services (DDS), Leah O'Meara, Catherine Knight and Angela Craven, Regional Center of the East Bay, Brooke Guerrero, Regional Manager at Regional Center of the East Bay, Jeff Nagafuji, Resource Developer with Regional Center for the East Bay, Heather Jacobs and DDS Angela Munoz. Areas of Concern: · Increase in number of complaints between both facilities (YAI East Tabor Rd and YAI Davis Rd.) primarily due to lack of staffing. Licensee acknowledges issues with staffing. The population that the facility serves requires a lot of attention. Licensee acknowledges that the clients they serve have a 2 to 1 ratio. HR Manager reports that there are four applicants going through the hiring process. Licensee reports that the house has been challenging regarding the culture in that home and the former facility staff. Licensee terminated previous employees that created a toxic work environment. Licensee has hired Prospective Administrator, Amber Palesi. Licensee reports having staff work double shifts. Licensee reports that the contingency plan put in place is sharing staff from other homes if staffing issues continue. New staff have been very good at picking up extra shifts. HR is adamant about visiting colleges, recruitment fairs and ongoing recruitment efforts. · Department of Developmental Services (DDS), Leah O'Meara advised that 80 hours of training is required for new staff and per diem staff that are new to YAI facilities. (Page 1 of 2)

· Licensee was reminded of Reporting Requirements as it relates to submitting incident reports timely. · Required records availability-Licensing needs to have access to records as per Inspection Authority. Protocol for providing documentation to Licensing agency; ensuring records are readily available and easily accessible to CCL during business hours. LPA, Carmona advised that the Internet connectivity issues being a concern. Licensee acknowledges that there have been struggles with the internet connectivity. Licensee uses two different internet providers and is currently exploring other options to remedy this issue. · Staff do not feel that they are properly trained on medication dispensing. Staff issues with dispensing medication and the changes around medication dispensing. Licensee acknowledges their multiple medication errors and has since hired a Registered Nurse to train staff on medication procedures and review the MARS for both facilities. · No authorized staff members delegated at the facility to sign licensing reports. Licensee plan is to ensure an Administrator or lead staff is always in the home should Licensing arrive to the home. · General upkeep of physical plant: General Window discussion on replacing windows in a timely manner Window Screens need to be in place and inspected regularly. Heating and AC in facilities. Licensee reports that there have been multiple windows being broken. Licensee acknowledges the property destruction and physical plant concerns. Licensee reports of putting in a brand new screens. Licensee reports that the heating has been fixed in the facility. Licensee reports that they have hired two maintenance staff for both facilities. Licensee will put in procedure for submitting work orders when maintenance issues arise upon the departments request. · Accessibility to all parts of the facility. Licensee reports that it is a lactation room. Licensee reports that the leads have all the codes. Licensee will submit a new facility sketch to address the lactation room and will ensure that lead staff have access when CCL comes for unannounced inspections. Licensee has requested the Program Director to be contacted if a room is not accessible. Support & Resources: Licensee requested a Technical Support Program Referral (TSP). Referral to CDSS Technical Support Program pending. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to the Licensee for signature.

facility_name: YAI DAVIS RD. COMMUNITY CRISIS HOME (CCH)
narrative: On May 7, 2024 at approximately 2:00 PM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Farhaan Sarangi and Tatyana Shultz made an unannounced visit to conduct a Case Management-Incident Inspection regarding an incident report received by the Department on 3/20/24 regarding inappropriate staff language directed at a client and inappropriate conduct of vaping and drinking around a client. Based on interviews conducted with all parties involved including, facility staff, client, Administrator, Regional Director, and internal investigation documents received, it was confirmed that the inappropriate language incident took place. As far as inappropriate conduct of vaping and drinking around a client, an internal investigation documents received could not be confirmed that the inappropriate conduct of vaping and drinking around a client took place. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator, Steven Toal, a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided to Administrator, Steven Toal. The facility has been cited for Personal Rights on LIC809D. This case management inspection is closed.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80072(a)(1) Personal Rights Except for children’s residential facilities, each client shall have personal rights which include, but are not limited to, the following: To be accorded dignity in his/her personal relationships with staff and other persons. This requirement is not met as evidenced by; it was confirmed by staff members that vulgar language was used towards C1. This posses an immediate Health and Safety and Personal Rights risk to clients in care.

investigation_findings: 13On June 14, 2024, at approximately 10:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Farhaan Sarangi arrived unannounced at YAI Davis Rd. Community Crisis Home (CCH) and met with Administrator, Steven Toal for the purpose of opening a complaint and delivering findings. During the investigation, LPA Sarangi reviewed the facility file at the licensing office, including the complaint history, criminal background check and facility personnel report summary. LPA conducted 8 confidential interviews with all appropriate parties between May 13 and May 22, 2024. Five out eight interviews denied the allegation and stated they didn’t witness nor hear or were present during the incident. facility_name: YAI DAVIS RD. COMMUNITY CRISIS HOME (CCH)
narrative: On July 31, 2024 at 2:15pm Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Tatyana Shulz and Sarina Buchannan made an unannounced visit to conduct a case management regarding an incident report received by the Department on 7/02/24 regarding a HIPPA violation when staff misplaced a client’s medical binder. LPAs met with Administrator, Steven Toal who assisted with the inspection. Based on interviews conducted with parties involved including, facility staff, Director of Quality, Compliance and Ethics, Regional Director, and internal investigation documents received, it was confirmed that the client’s medical binder has been misplaced and is still missing. According to interviews conducted the medical grab and go binder was misplaced sometime during the night (NOC) shift and the AM shift on 5/17/2024 while accompanying the client during their stay in the hospital. The binder wasn’t noticed to be missing until 6/18/2024 when the client had another upcoming medical appointment. The facility has since transitioned over to using tablets to store medical documents that are password protected and if misplaced can be cleared of all sensitive documents by the IT department. Plan of correction has been cleared during today’s inspection. LPA Shulz obtained training logs of the new medical grab and go procedures. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the Administrator. This case management investigation is closed, and the facility has been cited for Personal Rights 84072 (d)(38) (See LIC 809D).

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84072(d)(38) Personal Rights The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights…To confidentiality of medical and mental health records… This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observations and interviews conducted, the licensee did not ensure the safety of clients in care by misplacing the client’s medical binder, which poses an immediate Health and Safety risk to persons in care.

facility_name: YAI DAVIS RD. COMMUNITY CRISIS HOME (CCH)
narrative:
On September 17, 2024 at 1:00 PM, Regional Manager, Margo Castaneda, Licensing Program Manager, (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez and Licensing Program Analysts, (LPAs) Sarina Buchannan, Tatyana Shulz and Zaria Turner conducted a virtual meeting via teams. Present from YAI Davis Rd. Community Crisis Home is Cheryl Karran, Senior Regional Director/Licensee, Steven Toal, Program Administrator, Erika Barrios Botello, Program Administrator, Melissa Koren, Qualified Behavioral Professional, Terrance Harris, and Romer DeLa Cruz, YAI Staff. Present from Department of Developmental Services is Sunni Polani, Behavior Specialist II and Catherine Knight, Assistant Deputy Director. Present from Valley Mountain Regional Center is Chris Pillsbury, Quality Assurance Liaison. Present from Disability Rights is Colleen Yoder, Clients Rights Advocate. The purpose of the meeting is to discuss CCL's concerns regarding issues related to clients personal rights and to collaborate and problem solve together for the success of the program. The primary areas of concern discussed, and outcomes provided include the following: Clients Personal Rights Staff training on Circles Curriculum Program Statement update o It was discussed that Administrators and facility staff were not properly trained on how to respond the behaviors that were occurring between clients in care. In order to mitigate the risks of violating clients personal rights and behaviors reoccurring; staff will be properly trained on sexuality, personal rights, and how to respond to client behaviors. In addition, administrators will assess prospective clients during intake to ensure the appropriateness of placement. Lastly, staff will be educated on the behaviors of new clients to maintain continuity of care throughout placement. (continued on LIC 809-C)

o CCL confirmed that the facility has repurchased the Circles Curriculum on 8/29/2024 and is expected to begin implementation on 10/01/2024. Staff will be trained on the areas of the curriculum relevant to each clients needs. Administrators plan to develop a tool to assess staff competency after implementation. It was also confirmed that they will begin planning for the implementation process on 9/18/2024. o Facility Administration will work closely with CCL to review the program statement and determine if there are any additional updates needed or areas of noncompliance. Meeting was concluded. A copy of this report was emailed for signature to the provider.

facility_name: YAI DAVIS RD. COMMUNITY CRISIS HOME (CCH)
narrative: On September 20, 2024 at approximately 11:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan conducted an unannounced case management inspection to address the Circles Curriculum training at the above Community Crisis home and met with Romer John DeLa Cruz, who assisted LPA with the inspection. During the inspection at the facility on August 12, 2024 it was confirmed that the staff had no knowledge of the Circles Curriculum that was approved by CCL on the Program Statement. The department conducted a virtual meeting with the provider and it was confirmed by Cheryl Karran, Senior Regional Director that they have not been utilizing the circles curriculum due to it being misplaced. Community Care Licensing (CCL) confirmed that the facility has repurchased the Circles Curriculum on 8/29/2024 and is expected to begin implementation on 10/01/2024. Staff will be trained on the areas of the curriculum relevant to each clients needs. Administrators plan to develop a tool to assess staff competency after implementation. It was also confirmed that they will begin planning for the implementation process on 9/18/2024. Due to staff not being trained for a long period of time on Circles Curriculum, the facility is being cited for not following the Plan of Operation. (See LIC 809-D) Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided to the licensee.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so. the requirement is not met as evidenced by the facility failed to follow the Plan of Operation by not implementing Circles Cirriculum training for the staff. Which poses a potential health, saftey, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

facility_name: YAI DAVIS RD. COMMUNITY CRISIS HOME (CCH)
narrative: On January 9, 2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan made an unannounced case management inspection at the above facility and met with Romer DeLa Cruz, who assisted LPA Buchannan with the inspection. CCL received an incident report dated December 12, 2024 in which a client had missed their medication during an Urgent Care visit. LPA requested the following documentation: Medication Log for December 11th, 2024, staff medication training's, staff roster with contact information. LPA toured the facility and the facility was in full compliance. LPA conducted 3 staff interviews and attempted 1 client interview. Facility stated that they will conduct training's with staff on medication's and how to ensure clients do not miss them in an emergency. Facility has hired a Nurse and will communicate the procedures with them and the facility will ensure the their Leads are aware of the new procedures. This case management will remain open. Further investigation is need. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Romer DeLa Cruz, Lead RBT.

facility_name: YAI DAVIS RD. COMMUNITY CRISIS HOME (CCH)
narrative:
On January 29, 2025 at 11:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan made an unannounced follow up Case Management inspection at the above facility and met with Romer DeLa Cruz, Facility Administrator, who assisted LPA with the inspection. CCL received an incident report dated December 12, 2024 in which a client had missed their medication during an Urgent Care visit. Based on interviews conducted and documentation obtained LPA confirmed that the client had missed one dose of their prescribed medication during an incident that took place on December 11, 2024. LPA Buchannan was informed that prior to the medication error, the client had been having a series of behaviors which resulted in a head injury. LPA was informed that staff was concerned about following concussion protocol and transported the client to the Urgent Care. This resulted in staff forgetting to check the Medication Administration Record (MAR) to determine if the client had any mid-day medications. Staff stated that the client usually does not take a mid-day medication and therefore they did not check the MAR and/or grab the medication. LPA confirmed through documentation that the client was taking this medication for a 7-day period and the date of the incident was the first day they had started taking it. Additionally, LPA did not observe the client to miss any other doses of prescribed medications for the month of December 2024. LPA confirmed the Lead staff working this shift was aware that it is their duty to check the MAR form but had forgotten during this incident due to concern for the injury. The facility confirmed that that all Lead staff are assigned to check client medication during emergency situations. The facility conducted training's on emergency medication procedures on January 22, 2025. Facility has also hired a Nurse and will ensure the procedures are communicated with them and any newly hired lead staff. (continued on LIC 809C)

This case management that was initially open on January 9, 2025, is now closed. The facility is being issued a Technical Violation and not a citation this time due to the emergency incident taking place that day and for being an isolated incident. (See LIC 9102 TV) Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Romer DeLa Cruz, Facility Administrator.

facility_name: YAI DAVIS RD. COMMUNITY CRISIS HOME (CCH)
narrative: Based on evidence obtained and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process the above allegation is substantiated. It was confirmed that on at least one occasion the facility refused to transport a youth home from school. On 2/11/2025 at 10:00 AM school staff requested a client be picked up due to medical reasons and the facility refused to pick them up without a written request from the school. Also, the facility refused multiple requests on this day by school staff resulting in the client being left in the school office until 2:25 PM. Lastly, the plan of operation doesn’t state that the school is required to submit a request in writing prior to the facility picking up clients from school. Based on LPAs interviews which were conducted and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore, the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. The facility has been cited and a civil penalty of $250 has been issued for repeated violation within a 12 month period. (See LIC 809D) Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.
investigation_findings: 13On May 8, 2025 at 12:30 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan made an unannounced visit to deliver findings to the above Community Crisis Home (CCH) and met with Christian Thurman, Assistant Administrator. LPA conducted a walkthrough of the interior and exterior of the facility and no deficiencies were noted. Prior to the meeting LPA Sarina Buchannan conducted the 10-day inspection of the facility on 02/19/2025. LPA Buchannan requested the following documents: Staff Roster (LIC 500), Staff Contact information, Client Roster, Needs and Services Plans, Client Facesheet’s, related Incident Report, email communications, and Medication Records for Month of January and February 2025. LPA Buchannan conducted 11 confidential interviews between 02/19/2025-04/08/2025. (report continued on LIC 9099C)

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: (k) Plan of Operation The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: The facility refused multiple requests by school staff to pick up a youth in care citing that they did not provide a written request resulting in them being left in the school office from 10:00 AM until 2:25 PM. This procedure is not outlined as a requirement in the facility plan of operation.

When a facility... violates the same regulation subsection within a 12-month period, the facility shall be cited and an immediate penalty shall be assessed… a penalty of $50 per day, per cited violation, shall be assessed until the deficiency is corrected. This requirment is not met as evidenced by: There was a repeated violation within a 12-month period on 9/20/24 to 5/8/25.

facility_name: YAI DAVIS RD. COMMUNITY CRISIS HOME (CCH)
narrative:
Based on evidence obtained and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process the above allegations are substantiated. It was confirmed that on 07/25/2024 staff at the facility opened a minor’s mail without consent. Although the client was present while opening the package, the facility was unable to provide any evidence that the client consented to staff opening the package. It was also confirmed that staff did not safeguard minor’s personal items. On 7/26/24 a client had a watch gifted to them which was not working properly. The facility took the watch to get it fixed and once completed, it was handed to a staff member who kept the item with them for multiple days and did not notify the administrator. LPA confirmed that 3 out of 4 client Medication Administration Records (MARs) had medication errors that were not reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) timely. Also, on 2/20/25 the facility failed to report an incident in which a client had become escalated and injured them self, which resulted in the client needing a medical evaluation by the facility nurse. The facility failed to submit a 24-hour incident or a subsequent 7-day incident report for all incidents above. Finally, it was confirmed by incident reports submitted to CCL that the facility staff did not ensure minor's medication was given as prescribed by their physician. The medication errors occurred on the following dates with 3 different clients: 12/10/24, 12/13/24, 12/16/24, 1/02/25,1/04/25, and 1/06/25. Based on LPAs interviews which were conducted and record review, The preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore, the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.

Based on evidence gathered and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation, the allegations above cannot be substantiated because they were inconsistent statements throughout the investigation process. It was confirmed that on February 20, 2025, an incident took place in which a client’s door was closed while they became escalated. Facility staff observed, an injury on the client’s hand and a mark on the forehead but believed the forehead mark to be from a previous injury on 12/12/24. The facility nurse completed an in-person evaluation of the client and made the decision that it wasn’t an Urgent Care matter. LPA was also unable to determine that staff falsified minors’ records during the same incident due to there being no staff who witnessed the client’s behavior. In addition, LPA was unable to obtain any physical evidence that the client’s authorized representatives were not contacted in a separate incident on 2/24/25. It was also not confirmed that the facility staff did not prevent minor from committing self-harm behavior. An incident took place on 3/12/25, in which a client had become escalated resulting in a self-inflicted head injury. It was proven that facility staff used verbal escalation techniques prior to the behavior and Ukeru pads once the client began to injure them self. In addition, the investigation was unable to prove or disprove that the facility was in disrepair or not kept clean. During LPAs visit on 3/5/25 the facility was observed to be clean and in full repair. LPA was also unable to obtain specific dates in which facility was alleged to be dirty or in disrepair and all clients stated that the facility is cleaned on a regular basis. LPA also could not confirm that the facility staff did or did not provide adequate laundry services. 9 out of 11 confidential interviews stated that the facility staff do provide adequate laundry services. During LPAs visit on 3/5/25 it was observed that client’s laundry was clean and put away. In addition, LPA was unable to obtain a specific date or time in which staff did not provide laundry services to confirm or deny allegation. Also, LPA could not determine that transportation was not provided to minor in care. LPA was informed that there were initial issues with transportation on several occasions due to the client needing 2 staff and a driver, leaving the facility below ratio. However, LPA obtained documentation from the facility that showed the client did attend swimming classes on at least 14 occasions between 7/24/24 and 10/10/24. Continue to 9099-C

Lastly, LPA also could not prove that facility staff did or did not interfere with minors’ calls. 9 out of 11 interviews stated that facility staff allow the client to make confidential calls. LPA was unable to determine whether facility staff were disrupting phone calls to prevent client from making them or attempting to verbally redirect them while escalated during a phone conversation. Although the allegations may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.

LPA conducted a walkthrough of the interior and exterior of the facility and no deficiencies were noted. Prior to the meeting LPA Sarina Buchannan conducted the 10-day inspection of the facility on 03/05/2025. deficiencies.plan_of_correction: (d) (14) Personal Rights (d) The licensee shall ensure that each child... is accorded the personal rights...(14) to send and receive unopened mail unless prohibited by court order. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on evidence obtained and confidential interviews conducted it was confirmed that on 07/25/2024 staff at the facility opened a minor’s mail without consent by client in care, which posses a potential Health and Safety Risk to client in care.

(d) (9)(C)Personal Rights (d) The licensee shall ensure that each child... is accorded the personal rights... (9) To be provided with and allowed to possess and use... personal items... (C) Personal belongings, including items that were a gift to the child...This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on evidence obtained it was confirmed that the facility took the watch to get it fixed and once completed, it was handed to a staff member who kept the item with them for multiple days and did not notify the administrator which posses a potential Health and Safety Risk to clients in care .

(b) (1) (E)Reporting Requirements (b) Upon the occurrence... a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day...(1)Events reported shall include the following:(E) Any unusual incident...which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: LPA confirmed that 3 out of 4 client Medication Administration Records (MARs) had medication errors that were not reported to Community Care Licensing timely. Also, on 2/20/25 the facility failed to report an incident in which a client had become escalated and injured them self, which resulted in the client needing a medical evaluation.

(5) (B)Health Related Services (5)If the client's physician has stated in writing that the client is unable to determine his/her own need for nonprescription PRN... facility staff designated by the licensee shall be permitted to assist the client with self-administration...(B)Once ordered by the physician the medication is given according to the physician's directions. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on evidence obtained medication errors occurred on the following dates with 3 different clients: 12/10/24, 12/13/24, 12/16/24, 1/02/25,1/04/25, and 1/06/25, which posses an immediate Health and Safety risk to clients in care.

facility_name: YAI DAVIS RD. COMMUNITY CRISIS HOME (CCH)
narrative:
On 1/29/2025 at 11:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan made an unannounced visit with the purpose of conducting an Annual inspection to the above facility using the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tool. LPA met with Romer DeLa Cruz, Facility Administrator, and a walk through of the interior and exterior was completed. The facility serves up to 4 ambulatory female and male clients between the ages of 12-17 and 18-22 years old with an exception. Physical Plant Room 1 is a medication closet that has medical binders, posters for reporting Serious Incidents, and a locked cabinet with facility keys. Room 2 is a bathroom which has a toilet with a metal toilet tank cover, a working shower, and a trash can with a lid. Room 3 is a client bedroom with a full size mattress, 2 dressers, and a desk. Room 4 is a laundry room with a washer and dryer, and extra linens. Room 5 is a client bedroom with an Xbox, full mattress, and a dresser. Room 6 is the kitchen with a working stove, a food pantry, the facility phone, and chemicals locked under the sink. Room 7 is a living room with two tables, a couch, and a television. Room 8 is a bathroom which has a toilet with a metal toilet tank cover, a working shower, and a trash can with a lid. Room 9 is an activity room with board games, crayons, and 2 exercise balls. Room 10 is a client bedroom with a full size mattress, a play station 5, and a dresser. Room 11 is a staff office with client files, Davis Dollar store, staff refrigerator and freezer, sharps stored in a locked filing cabinet, and cleaning supplies. The 2 client bathrooms are located in the hallways and have water temperatures at 115 degrees Fahrenheit. The backyard is gated, has a shed, and is clear of debris. (continued on LIC 809C)(Page 1)

The following required documents were posted, License and Personal Rights. Disinfectants/cleaning solutions inaccessible to children in care. Refrigerator Temperature at or below 45 degrees F. Nonperishable foods one week and fresh perishable foods two days minimum. Menu present and posted in the kitchen area on the fridge. Working telephone are available at the facility. Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are in working order. First Aid Kit fully stocked. Medication centrally stored, locked/inaccessible to children. Hot Water between 105–120 degrees Fahrenheit. Fire Extinguisher up to date and in working order. Toilets wash basin, bath, and shower fixtures in good repair/no leaks/hot water temperature. Soap and Paper towels are available to clients. Bedrooms required linen and furnishings are fully stocked. Facility free of vermin. The following domains were also reviewed during today’s inspection, Operations, Disaster Preparedness, Staffing, Emergency Intervention, and Client Records. A total of 7 staff files and 4 client files were reviewed. LPA also conducted 4 client interviews and 3 staff interviews. A review of the Licensing Information System indicates the facility is not up to date on their facility. The facility fees which are due in the amount of 681.00 were due on 06/17/24. All the staff were fingerprint cleared and associated to the facility. Based on confidential interviews conducted no concerns for follow up were noted. An exit interview was conducted with Romer DeLa Cruz, Facility Administrator, and a copy of this report, and the Appeal Rights were provided to the facility.

facility_name: YAI DAVIS RD. COMMUNITY CRISIS HOME (CCH)
narrative:
Based on evidence obtained and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process the allegation above has been substantiated. 7 out of 10 confidential interviews stated that the facility is routinely out of ratio due to call outs. The licensee sends out incentive emails to other staff members to fill in the empty shifts, but the majority of the time leads and administration are filling in the gaps when possible. LPA received internal investigation documents stating that a client was left out of their 2:1 level of supervision ratio on April 13, 2025. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Title 22 regulations are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.

Based on evidence obtained and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process the allegations above cannot be substantiated due to conflicting statements. 8 out of 10 confidential interviews stated that they did not witness the alleged staff member throw a diaper at the client. 8 out of 10 confidential interviews also state that they did not witness the staff member speak inappropriately to the client in care by mocking their behaviors. Lastly, LPA was unable to speak to the client in care due to them being nonverbal. In addition, the preparator was not available to be interviewed after 3 attempts. There was not enough eyewitness testimony to either confirm of deny these claims. Although the allegations may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.

facility_name: YAI DAVIS RD. COMMUNITY CRISIS HOME (CCH)
narrative: On August 6, 2025 at 1:54pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Tatyana Shulz made an unannounced visit to conduct a case management regarding DDS Semi-Annual Review that took place at the facility on July 29, 2025. LPA met with Christian Thurman, Assistant Administrator who granted LPA access to the facility. Prior to the meeting DDS Behavior Specialist II, Sunni Polani conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where the Specialist observed the following deficiencies: · The cabinet door under the kitchen sink and the box containing cleaning agents was observed to be unlocked and their contents readily accessible. · One lower kitchen cabinet door would not remain closed. After closing the cabinet door, the cabinet door would open approximately one inch. LPA Shulz conducted a walk through of the facility and observed that the accessible cleaning solutions noted on the July 29, 2025, inspection has been corrected. The facility placed a work order for the cabinet deficiency on August 6, 2025. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided to Christian Thurman, Assistant Administrator. The facility has been cited for Buildings and Grounds on LIC809D. This case management will remain open until a follow up inspection has been conducted.
