Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with John Smith and staff of YAI Electric to conduct the pre-licensing evaluation. The following was observed. This is a 4 bedroom, 2 bathroom home located in a residential area of the City of Gardena, CA. One of the bathrooms is ADA compliant. There are no bodies of water, no fireplaces and no firearms on the premises. There are no security bars on windows. There is a fire extinguisher near the front door. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are working as required. There is a backup generator There is secure, locked space for medications, knives and household chemicals. There are complete first kits in the home and in the facility van. The facility van passed a visual check of headlights, brake lights, signal lights, windshield wipers, horn, seat belts and tires. The yard space is free of hazards There is space available for private visitations and client interviews. There is a back house that provides secured space for client and staff records,. Kitchen and bathroom fixtures are working as required. The stove and refrigerator are in good condition. The hot water temperature is within a safe range. The home is at a comfortable temperature. There are four bedrooms. Each bedroom has a twin bed with complete set of required linens and pillows. There is adequate closet space in each bedroom. All bedroom and household furniture is weighted for client safety. The following items are needed prior to license approval: Permanent or portable chests of drawers for each bedroom and window coverings for the bedroom windows.

During the course of investigating complaint # 34-CR-20230616113533, Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward became aware of a series reportable incidents involving C1 that were not reported to Community Care Licensing. The first incident occurred on 05/13/2023 at a city park when C1 impersonated a police officer and tried to handcuff a child in the park. This happened due to lack of supervision by the two staff that were supposed to be supervising him. One staff was reportedly on his phone and the other was playing basketball. The second incident occurred on 05/15/2023 when the Gardena Police Department arrested C1 and charged him with assault, false imprisonment and impersonating an officer. After he was charged he was released to the facility. The third incident occurred on 06/15/2023 when C1 became violent, destroyed property and was placed on a psychiatric hold after being informed that he was being terminated from Young Adult Institute. The final incident occurred when C1 was picked up from the hospital by the Gardena Police Department and arrested for the incidents of 05/13/2023. C1 never returned to the facility. The judge ordered him returned home to Sacramento County. The facility was cited under 80061(b)(1)(E), 84061(i) and 84065.2(b)(1). The administrator was informed of the licensee's appeal rights. Administrator Adedapo Ajibade provided copies of the letters of disciplinary action that were issued to Staff #1 and Staff #2 for failure to properly supervise Client #1

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Reporting Requirements: The licensee is to report, to the Department, any incident which affects the health, safety or wellbeing of a client. The licensee failed to meet this requirememt by not reporting a series of incidents that occured in May 2023.

Reporting Requirements: The licensee shall submit reports to the Department, using form LIC 624-LE or a report containing all the information required in LIC 624-LE, regarding any incident that involves law enforcement contact with a child residing in the facility The licensee failed to meet this requirement by not submitting a series of incidents that involved law enforcement contact with a client

Personnel Duties Child care staff shall provide supervision, protection and care of children individually and in groups at all times The licensee failed to meet this requirement when staff did not provide the required 1:1 supervision required by a client. This lack of supervision led to the client assaulting a child at a community park

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegations. LPA spoke to Staff #1, Staff #2 and Client #2. LPA also reviewed Client #1's Individualized Behavioral Support Plan (IBSP) and a related incident report made to Client #1's Regional Center. There were no related reports found in the Department's data base related to this incident. Both staff members denied that staff speaks inappropriately to Client #1. They also deny that staff spreads false information about Client #1 to outside agencies. Client #2 did not remember anything about Client #1 other than his name. As stated previously, Client #1 could not be reached. LPA found no inappropriate information in the ISBP or the Special Incident Report that was submitted to the Regional Center. Based on the available information, the above findings are both resolved as unsubstantiated.

13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegation. investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegations by speaking to staff who were in witness to the incidents and reviewing relevant documentation such as C1's Individualized Behavior Support Plan (IBSP), the internal investigation report conducted by the licensee. The licensee failed to meet this requirement when a staff person held the door closed so that Client #1 could not leave his bedroom.

narrative: On June 8, 2021 at 11am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin contacted the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management investigation. LPA spoke with FD and made her aware of the allegations surrounding the Case Management. In response to two incident reports submitted, dated 6/7/2021 regarding physical restraints (staff to client), and the amount of time allocated for a client to remain in the restraint. FD stated that there is no "written maximum time a client can be in a staff related restraint. The objective of this restraint is to keep the minor from harming self and others and to gradually transition the client to the least restrictive physical restraint i.e. a seated position free of physical touch by staff, when the client is deemed no longer a threat to themselves or others. During the time of the restraints, there is always a nurse present to assist and monitor the client to prevent physical injury and to verbally redirect the client to baseline. In the two Incidents on 6/7/2021, staff followed protocol correctly in both events and both clients were examined by the nurse after the restrain was completed and both were also provided with mental health assistance as well. Nothing further to report

narrative: On July 26, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst, LPA Donald Martin made an inspection visit to Star View Community Treatment Facility for the purpose of concluding a Case Management Investigation. LPA met with Michael Traylor, Facility Manger. The Department received a Special Incident Report Stating that C1 inserted objects into her vagina and had to have them removed by an OBGYN. LPA spoke with C1 and she stated that she is very depressed which makes her want to self harm. C1 feels like she needs more therapy and would actually like to go back to the PHF unit where she felt safe. LPA interviewed FM and he stated that the clients see the therapist twice a week and also receive additional positive reinforcement from the Direct Care Staff throughout the day. If clients show signs of self harm, their supervision will be upgraded to "Line of Sight" and possibly a one on one 24 hour care. C1 had a pelvic exam last week and has a follow up appointment scheduled next week to see the OBGYN.

narrative: Upon inspection and observation of additional client showers, LPA observed some markings on the shower floor and wall, which appeared to be mildew from trapped humidity when showering. LPA was unable to identify observed markings on the shower floor as mold. LPA provided evidentiary documentation of photos of the shower in the Neptune and Moon units. Documentary evidence revealed routine daily cleaning by facility housekeeping staff twice a day to manage and prevent mold growth. LPA obtained copies of daily housekeeping and cleaning logs. Documentary evidence, interviews, and statements obtained during the investigation process, did not corroborate the allegation, Staff does not ensure facility is kept free of pests. It was reported that there are ants in the common area of the units, however, confidential interviews and LPA observation did not reveal that there are ants in the common area or facility. Documentary evidence reflects monthly pest control services at the facility. LPA obtained copies of invoices for monthly pest control services at the facility. Based on the interviews conducted and documentary evidence, the information gathered did not produce corroborating evidence to support the allegations, Staff does not ensure facility is kept free of mold and Staff does not ensure facility is kept free of pests. LPA was unable to determine if the above said allegations occurred, therefore the allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. If any additional information is received, this complaint can be amended, and the finding can be changed. Based on the observations made during today’s visit, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Administrator.

narrative: On October 9, 2023 at 10am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility. The purpose of this visit is the continuation of the Annual Inspection conducted October 5, 2023. LPA was met by Program Director, Rodney Hall (PD) and allowed into the facility. Star View Community Treatment Facility has a capacity of 44 ambulatory (Complex Developmental Trauma) clients with an age range of 12-17. Star View also has Non-Minor Dependants on Exception basis only. LPA will review the Needs and Services plans and conduct Staff and Client interviews. LPA conducted 6 staff interviews and 6 client interviews. Although Needs and Services plans are only for LA County clients and there aren't many of those clients in the facility, LPA suggests facility conduct an In service staff training on Needs and Services Plans and discuss the things that are important in the plan. LPA also suggests to explain what the clients Treatment Plans are and how similar they are to Needs and Services plans. LPA suggests that facility hold a training on the Emergency Intervention plan for all staff. One client expressed a need for more therapy (in addition to the 2 30 minute sessions a week) and another asked for different hygiene products because her hair was falling out. LPA discussed these issues with PD and let him know who these clients were. No deficiencies were cited at the time of the visit.

On October 4, 2023 at 11am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin and Chief Deputy Director Claire Ramsey arrived at the above facility. The purpose of this visit is to conduct an Annual Inspection of the facility. LPA was met by Administrator, Kelly McMahon and allowed into the facility. Star View Community Treatment Facility has a capacity of 44 ambulatory (Complex Developmental Trauma) clients with an age range of 12-17. Star View also has Non-Minor Dependants on Exception basis only. The tour of the facility is as follows: Sun/Moon - 6 Bedrooms each have a shared bathroom. Bedrooms are fully furnished with two beds, separate cubbies for clients clothing storage. There is additional clothing storage under each bed. Time out room (separation room) laundry room, and Dayrooms are clean and in good repair. Nurse station that is fully stocked with First Aid Kits, locked cabinets and Medical Equipment. Staffing station has a sink, water dispenser, desk and three computers. There is a pay phone in the hallway for clients daily use. Clients do not have to pay to use this phone. There is another phone at the beginning of the unit also for clients use. This phone is used for Social Workers, Attorneys, Ombudspersons, etc. Note: There is a camera in the Dayroom, Timeout room and in the Hallways of each unit. No cameras shows a view inside of the actual bedrooms or bathrooms. Stars/Neptune - each Bedroom has a shared bathroom. Bathroom are all clean and in good working condition. Bedrooms are fully furnished with two beds, separate cubbies for clients clothing storage. There is additional clothing storage under each bed. Time out room (separation room) laundry room, and Dayrooms are clean and in good repair. There is a pay phone in the hallway for clients daily use. Clients do not have to pay to use this phone. Note: There is a camera in the Dayroom, Timeout room and in the Hallways of each unit. No cameras show a view inside of the actual bedrooms or bathrooms. (Report continued on LIC 809C)

Kitchen is clean and in good repair. Facility provides nutritious meals and snacks to all clients. Meal menu is posted and accessible. Refrigerator and freezer are fully stocked with food. Cabinets and pantry and fully stocked with the essential dry and non-perishable foods. All disinfectant/ poisons chemicals are properly inaccessible. Knives are properly locked and inaccessible to clients. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide are properly working. All fire extinguishers are full and have been currently inspected. First Aid kit is fully stocked with all the essentials. Water temperature is up to standards. All common areas of the facility are clean and in good repair. Passageways are clean and in good repair. All bodies of water are inaccessible. Pool is fenced and contains an operable self-latching door. Patio area and recreational area is clear of debris. Medications are properly stored and secure. Child's rights are posted and accessible to all clients. LPA reviewed 8 Client files and 6 Staff files. All files are up to date and all documents are accounted for. Details on the Confidential Names list (811). LPA reviewed Client files via Computer. All Staff training logs were current and up to date. LPA inspected 3 facility Vans. All vans had current registration and insurance. Each van was equip with registered fire extinguisher and First Aid kit. Each van was in good working condition. LPA will return within 5 days to review Needs and Services plans and conduct Staff and Client interviews. No deficiencies were observed or cited. Exit Interview was conducted and a copy of this report was signed and has been left with Administrator, Kelly McMahon.

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE
narrative: S1 attempted to use verbal redirection and offered C1 incentives to try to prevent C1 from swallowing the object. C1 did not cooperate and swallowed the object. Staff took appropriate steps to ensure C1’s safety by calling the ambulance. C1 returned to the facility on March 7th, 2020. Between March 7th, 2020 to March 9th, 2020, documentation of resident information log revealed inconsistencies on exactly when C1 was placed on constant eyesight. On March 9th, 2020, it was confirmed that C2 gave C1 AA batteries not knowing the reason why C1 wanted them. Per interviews, there were no witnesses to C1 swallowing the batteries on this day and C1 informed S2 on what occurred. LPA could not interview S2 after multiple attempts; however, documentation revealed that appropriate steps were taken by staff and C1 was taken to the hospital by the ambulance as soon as it was reported. Documents revealed that facility took steps of interventions to assist with the needs of C1. Child & Family Team Meeting notes revealed it was discussed for C1 to have an alternative placement due to her dangerous behaviors. On 03/05/2020, a request for an emergency removal of C1 was made due to her extremely unsafe behaviors almost daily that put herself and others at risk. It was indicated in the request for removal that despite having a 1:1 supervision, C1 was able to engage in serious self injurious behaviors and the facility was not able to keep her safe. Furthermore, per interviews, it was indicated that S3 gave C1 the vape pen that she had on March 4th, 2020 but S3 denied the allegation and LPA could not confirm how C1 obtained the vape pen. In addition, representative from Los Angeles County Department of Probation shared no concerns on how the facility handled both situations. Based on the information obtained and confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of the report will be emailed to the Unit Supervisor.
investigation_findings: 13On August 28th, 2020 at 3:00pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sethany Yem conducted a follow-up complaint tele-visit for Vista Del Mar CTF and spoke to Unit Supervisor Renee Capeloto. The purpose of the tele-visit was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegation. During the course of investigating the allegation for Staff did not provide adequate supervision to minor while in care, LPA conducted interviews with related parties and reviewed the following documentation: Special Incident Reports; C1’s Needs and Services Plan; Facility’s Internal Unusual Occurrence (UOR); Report for Safety hold, Hospitalization, injury or other Incidents; Resident Information Log; Hospital Discharge Notes; and Progress Notes for C1. Confidential interviews revealed that on the night of March 4th, 2020, there was only one female staff working the night shift and the male staff asked S1 to help assist with C1 because C1 was in the bathroom; males are not permitted to go in the bathroom with female clients. Per interviews, C1 was found in the bathroom vomiting with an object in her hand indicating to S1 that she is going to swallow the battery of a vape pen. Continue on 9099-C

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE
narrative:
On September 18th, 2020 at 12:15PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sethany Yem conducted a Case Management - Incident inspection tele-visit to Vista Del Mar Child & Family Services-Special Care to discuss a Special Incident Report (SIR) #718550, dated 09/10/2020; incident occurred on 09/02/2020. LPA spoke with Unit Supervisor Renee Capeloto. The SIR #718550 indicated that on 09/02/2020 at approximately 10:00AM, it was brought to the attention of staff that C1 was suspected of smoking marijuana. When confronted by staff, C1 reported receiving marijuana from a Delta-T staff, Staff 1 (S1). It was reported that S3 checked video footage to see if C1's allegation of receiving marijuana from S1 could be verified. After checking video footage, S1 was seen talking to C1 on two occasions but did not appear to give him anything. She was seen on camera opening C1’s room door. S3 spoke with S1 and informed her of the allegations. S1 vehemently denied bringing or giving any resident marijuana or anything illegal. S3 sent S1 home. It was reported that S3 contacted the Child Abuse Hot Line and reported the incident but was informed that due to C1 being 18-years-old that the incident did not warrant a new referral and that the information would be passed along as a note to CSW. On facility’s Resident Information/daily Log and the internal Unusual Occurrence Report for C1, revealed that the incident/ allegation was documented; however, facility failed to submit this incident as an SIR until LPA informed facility that this is a serious reportable incident and an SIR is deemed necessary for an incident that may result in health and safety hazards to clients. Continue on 809-C

LPA Yem interviewed pertinent parties. Although C1 and S1 denied the allegation to the LPA, the incident occurred on 09/02/2020 and facility did not report the unusual incident to the Department until 09/10/2020 after being contacted by LPA informing the facility of this concern. Based on the interview statements and documentation obtained, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Facility cited for Violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, Chapter 1, regulation 80061(b)(E) Reporting Requirements: (b) Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) (See Advisory Notes), a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours. In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) (See Advisory Notes) shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. (E) Any unusual incident or client absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. Facility failed to report and submit a Special Incident Report to the Department within the required time frame; SIR #718550 indicated that on 09/02/2020 S1 allegedly gave substance to C1 which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care. See 809-D A copy of this report and appeal rights will be emailed to the Unit Supervisor.

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE
narrative: Interviews revealed that C2 would bring illegal drugs to the facility and staff did do room searches and checked on C2 frequently for contraband. Additionally, interviews revealed that clients would bring in methamphetamine after coming back to the facility from a home pass, staff would conduct searches, and contrabands were not always found; in addition, no names of clients were confirmed besides C2. LPA could not determine how C2 obtained the substances due to inconsistent statements. Interviews indicated that C2 would get the substances when she would go on home pass. Department of Children and Family Services representative denied this claim because when the pandemic arose, visitations were limited. Documentation on Special Incident Reports revealed that around 02/18/2020 was the last known incident involving C2 having methamphetamine which was before visitations were limited. C3 confirmed C2 gave her substances; C3 was discharged from the facility since January 2020. C1 could not verify what timeframe the allegations occurred. LPA could not determine when or where C2 could have obtained the substances. Interviews revealed that staff was giving clients weed, vape pen, and wax pens but LPA could not verify if this it true due to no staff’s names given during this time frame. It was reported that clients have access to prescribed medication. Confidential interviews revealed that C3 confirmed C2 gave her a prescribed medication that was prescribed to C1. Documentation revealed that C2 got the prescribed medication from C1. C1 confirmed that she “cheeked” the medication while nursing staff was giving her the medication. C1 indicated that she didn’t think the clients were going to do something dangerous with it. C1 indicated that she was telling the heath center staff that she did not want to take the prescribed medication and the nursing staff crushed the medication so C1 couldn’t cheek it. On 01/01/2020, documentation revealed that C3 was hospitalized due to taking 11 of the prescribed medication. Staff immediately checked on resident C3 and called 911. C3 was cleared medically and assessed by PMRT. Nursing staff from the facility’s health center indicated that they have clients open their mouth wide, spread the mouth cheeks with their two index finger, left tongue up and down, flip top and bottom lips and speak before leaving medication window to make sure clients are not hiding medication in their mouths. LPA could not determine if there was a lack of supervision from staff due to staff taking appropriate steps with searching for contraband and nursing staff taking appropriate steps to try to prevent clients from hiding their medication in their mouths. Based on the information obtained during confidential interviews and inconsistent statements, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of the report will be emailed to the Unit Supervisor.
investigation_findings: 13On October 1st, 2020 at 5:30pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sethany Yem conducted a follow-up complaint tele-visit for Vista Del Mar – Special Care and spoke to Unit Supervisor Renee Capeloto. The purpose of the tele-visit was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegations. During the course of investigating the allegations for Youth are using illegal drugs in the facility and Youth have access to medications, LPA conducted interviews with related parties and reviewed the following documentation: Special Incident Reports; Clients Needs and Services Plan; C1’s Child and Family Team (CFT) Notes; Email Correspondenses; and C2’s Court Report. It was reported that C1 smoked a joint laced with meth. Staff and clients denied observing C1 using any substance at the facility; however, C1 confirmed she has used substances in the facility but not a joint laced with meth. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 obtained substances from C2. ContInue on 9099-C

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE
narrative: On January 13th, 2020 at approximately 4:40pm, it was reported that C1 was restrained by S1, S2 and S3 due to C1 scratching S1. S1, S2 and S3 denied the allegation of the restraint resulting in injuries. Confidential interview revealed that S1 allegedly pinched C1’s arm, while the restraint was conducted. Witness statements denied the allegation. Nursing assessment indicated there were no complaints of pain or injury at this time. LPA attempted to reach the observer (S4) which was present during the restraint for 01/13/2020 but S4 could not be reached after multiple attempts. On 03/20/2020 at approximately 9:55pm, it was reported that C1 was put into a restraint by staff members S5 and S6 and sustained bruises on her upper right hand, fingerprint bruises on her left arm and scratches on her left elbow. Documentation revealed that C1 spit on S1 and became physically assaultive towards S1. C1 denied being physical with S1. S6 denied the allegation of client sustaining an injury from the restraint and S5 could not be reached after multiple attempts. S7 was the observer of the restraint and denied seeing an inappropriate restraint or seeing marks or bruises on C1. Nursing Assessment dated 03/21/2020 indicated that C1 complained of having marks on her arm (fingerprints) not sure if was from last night or the day C1 was assessed; in addition, the assessment indicated that there were no complaints or pain and no further follow-up needed. Emergency Intervention Debriefing Form dated 03/23/2020 indicated that C1 reported injuries on 03/24/2020, including scrape on arm and bruising on shoulder and arm and nursing staff cleaned the area. The restraint incident occurred on 03/20/2020. No Photographs of C1 was obtained; however, the Debriefing took place on 03/23/2020. LPA could not determine if the marks and bruises were a result of the restraint or how C1 obtained the marks. LPA could not verify if C1 obtained any injury caused by a restraint due to inconsistent statements and no witnesses to this allegation. Furthermore, it was reported that a seclusion room has just a drain with no restroom and clients cannot come out to use the restroom. When asked if C1 was ever denied the restroom, C1 denied it. Clients that were interviewed also denied the allegation of staff denying them the use of a restroom. It was reported that clients can be in the seclusion room for up to 8 hours. Interviews revealed no confirmation on whether clients were placed in the seclusion room for up to 8 hours. LPA could not confirm if C1 obtained possible marks and bruises due to the restraints conducted or during the process of C1 struggling trying to get out of the restraints. Based on the information obtained during confidential interviews and inconsistent statements, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of the report will be emailed to the Unit Supervisor.
investigation_findings: 13On September 29th, 2020 at 4:20pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sethany Yem conducted a follow-up complaint tele-visit for Vista Del Mar – Special Care and spoke to Unit Supervisor Renee Capeloto. The purpose of the tele-visit was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegations. During the course of investigating the allegations for Facility staff restrained youth resulting in injuries; Facility staff pinched youth; and Facility staff denied youth access to a restroom, LPA conducted interviews with related parties and reviewed the following documentation: Special Incident Report dated 01/13/2020 and 03/20/2020; Nursing Assessments; C1’s Needs and Services Plan; C1’s Child and Family Team (CFT) Notes; Facility’s Crisis Situation Debriefing; Unusual Occurrence Report (UOR); Facility’s Post Restraint/ Containment Interviews for Staff; Emergency Intervention Debriefing Form (following restraint and/or escort) for C1; Staff’s ProAct Certifications. Conotinue on 9099-C

investigation_findings: 13On May 17, 2021 at 12:18pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Emelyn Sanchez P. conducted a follow-up complaint tele-inspection visit to Vista Del Mar Child & Family Services- Special Care and met with Jermaine Trottie, Unit Supervisor. The purpose of the visit was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegations. During the course of investigating the allegations for lack of supervision resulting in inappropriate interactions between minors and staff encouraged minor to not report an incident, LPA Sanchez P. conducted confidential interviews with related parties. After conducting the confidential interviews and reviewing the following documentation: Facility Internal Investigation Report, it was stated by facility staff that the allegations were false. Facility staff reported that the children were always supervised and were within six feet of them so a visual was maintained to ensure safety. Facility Staff who were present at the time of the alleged incident denied seeing any inappropriate touching or even talking among the two children. Facility Staff stated that unfortunately it was a “she said, she said” situation as the girls blamed each other. Report Cont. on LIC 9099-C.

investigation_findings: 13On July 23, 2021 at 12:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a follow-up complaint investigation and met with Kathy Williams, Youth Development Counselor Lead for the purpose of concluding and delivering investigation findings. The allegation was investigated by Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Investigations Bureau, Investigator Christine Ferris. On May 27, 2021, CCLD received claims alleging sexual abuse on minor resident, Client #1 (C1) by Staff Member #1 who allegedly kissed C1 on the chest and lips and leaving a "hickey" on child’s neck. Based on interviews and review of related Los Angeles Police Department report, the investigation did not provide enough evidence to substantiate sexual abuse against Staff Member #1. Interviews revealed C1’s statements to be inconsistent and C1 refused to provide any details upon questioning. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE
narrative: On September 28, 2021, at 8:00am Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Emelyn Sanchez P. and Olivia Rosas arrived at Vista Del Mar Child & Family Services-Special Care facility unannounced for the purpose of conducting a SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Case Management- Medication Inspection Visit. LPAs Sanchez P., and Rosas met with Amy Jafee, Director (See confidential name list LIC811 dated 09/28/21). LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas reviewed five (5) client files and three (3) staff files. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas conducted five (5) client interview and three (3) staff interviews. Currently there are eighteen (18) clients residing in the above facility. This is one story building located within a campus. There unit has three (3) wings, with each wing having eight (8) clients with (6) single beds and (1) double bed. The unit has a kitchen, bathrooms, medication dispensing station, conference room, seclusion room, and reception area. Outdoor space is free of obstructions. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas observed adequate staffing in the facility to provide care and supervision to children in care. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas also observed medication to be centrally stored, triple locked and inaccessible to clients and unauthorized staff members. The medication is stored in a separate building within the campus. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE
met_with: Facility Representatives, Mark Walker and Jermaine Trottie
narrative: It was revealed that on 06/13/2021, C1 stroked and orally copulated the penis of Client #2 (C2) in a room at the facility. Interviews and review of video footage confirm C1 and C2 along with two other clients were unsupervised by staff at the time the incident occurred, as the sole staff member who was in the room, momentarily left the room. The investigation further revealed that it was the suggestion of one of the other clients in the room that C1 orally copulate C2 to which C1 ultimately agreed after persistent request from that client. Although the act was not the request of C2, C2 did not refuse the act and pulled C2’s pants down to assist C1. It was revealed C1 felt pressured to perform the act on C2 and as a result, C1 later informed a staff member what happened. Local law enforcement was contacted by the facility. C1 acknowledged C1 willfully performed the act on C2 but indicated C2 held C1’s wrist while C1 performed the act. Per the video surveillance footage, the staff member on duty at the time left the room. C1 orally copulated C2 for approximately 3 seconds before the staff member returned to the room. Video footage indicates the staff member had left the room for approximately 30 seconds. Based on all information obtained during the investigation, the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. The Department has determined a lack of supervision contributed to sexual misconduct between C1 and C2 while in care. The allegation is deemed substantiated at this time and thus poses an immediate health, safety and personal rights risk of harm to children placed in care. The facility is issued a citation in accordance with the California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 5; Section 84172 (b) Personal Rights and Chapter 6; Section 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were discussed. A copy of this report, the Confidential Names List and appeal rights were provided to Facility Representative. (Continued on page LIC9099-D)
investigation_findings: 13On December 16, 2021 at 1:50 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver findings concerning the above-mentioned allegation. LPA Martin met with Mark Walker, Youth Development Counselor Supervisor and Jermaine Trottie, Unit Supervisor to discuss the investigative outcome. The investigation was conducted by Licensing Special Investigator Dennis Douglas of the Community Care Licensing (CCL) Investigations Bureau. On June 14, 2021, CCL received an allegation that Client #1 (C1) (see LIC811, dated 12/16/2021) was sexually assaulted by Client #2 while in care. Investigator Dennis completed the investigation which included confidential interviews with three Clients, staff members and review of related client files, Los Angeles Police Department Incident Report and review of corresponding facility surveillance video footage. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personal Rights: (b) The licensee shall ensure that every child admitted to a community treatment facility is informed and afforded the personal rights as specified in Sections 5325, … and the Welfare and Institutions Code… This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on interviews, review of records and video surveillance, Client #1 was pressured to perform oral copulation and masturbate Client #2 while in care at facility; thus, posing immediate risk to the health and safety of children in care.

Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on interviews, review of records and video surveillance, on 06/13/2021, Client #1 and Client #2 in addition to two other clients were unsupervised by staff at which time C1 orally copulated and masturbated C2; Thus, posing an immediate risk to the health and safety of children in care.

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE
narrative:
On April 8, 2022 at 9:00 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips arrived at the above facility unannounced for the purpose of conducting an Annual Required Inspection. LPA Phillips was met by Jermaine Trottie/ Youth Development Supervisor who granted access to the facility. VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE has a capacity of 18 ambulatory clients with an age range of 12-17. VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE also has Non Minor Dependants on Exception basis only. The tour of the facility is as follows: 1)Ocean (Girls)- Rooms 6 singles and 1 double , bathrooms, time out room (separation room) laundry room, and common areas area clean and in good repair. Rooms are fully furnished with two beds, separate cubby's and contains sufficient storage, space living in the room. Nurse station that is fully stocked with First Aid Kits, locked cabinets and Medical Equipment. Staffing station with a sink, water dispenser, desk and three computers. 2)Earth (Boys)- Rooms 6 singles and 1 double room, bathrooms, time out room (separation room) laundry room, and common areas area clean and in good repair. Rooms are fully furnished with two beds, separate cubby's and contains sufficient storage space for all clients living in the room. Nurse station that is fully stocked with First Aid Kits, locked cabinets and Medical Equipment. Staffing station with a sink, water dispenser, desk and three computers.

3)Sky (girls)- Rooms 6 singles and 1 double, bathrooms, time out room (separation room) laundry room, and common areas clean and in good repair. Rooms are fully furnished with two beds, separate cubby's and contains storage space for all clients living in the room. Kitchen is clean and in good repair. Facility provides nutritious meals and snacks to all clients. Meal menu is posted and accessible. Refrigerator and freezer are fully stocked with sufficient food. Cabinets and pantry and fully stocked with the essential dry and non- perishable foods. All disinfectant/ poisons chemicals are properly inaccessible. Knives are properly locked and inaccessible to clients. First Aid kit is fully stocked with all the essentials. Water temperature is up to standards. There are three seclusion rooms on the premises which were operable. The following activities are made available for the children: TV, game system, Netflix, Cable, books and board games. Telephones are operable. LPAs observed additional hygiene products in staff offices. Medications are stored in the Health Center All common areas of the facility are clean and in good repair. Passageways are clean and in good repair. All bodies of water are inaccessible. Pool is fenced and contains an operable self-latching door. Patio area and recreational area is clear of debris. Medications are properly stored and secure. Child's rights are posted and accessible to all clients. Facility meets posting requirements per regulations. No deficiencies were observed or cited. Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was signed and was left with Jermaine Trottie / Youth Development Supervisor.

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE
narrative: On April 21, 2022 at 9:35 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips and LPA Kuliema Calloway made an unannounced visit to VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE for the purpose of conducting a Case Management investigation. LPA spoke with YDC Supervisor Mark Walker and made him aware of the allegations surrounding the Case Management. The case management is in response to an incident report submitted and referral dated 04/02/2022 regarding Child #1 and Child #2 inappropriate touching in the Earth cottage. YDC Supervisor stated that common room has three sofas and one facing television. Staff #2 was cooking meal in kitchen area and monitoring youth. The incident happened while both Child #1 and Child #2 were sitting on two rows of sofas (one longer and one shorter both facing television) facing the television outside the line of sight of staff. Once Staff #2 observed the incident immediately separated residents and counseled Child #1 and Child #2. After Child #2 was made aware that there may be a police investigation Child #2 awol on 04/03/2022 and probation closed the bed on 04/06/2022. LPA Phillips and LPA Calloway spoke to Staff #2 stated followed facility protocol called West Los Angeles Police Department and officers came out and spoke with both Child #1 and Child #2. LPA Phillips and LPA Calloway requested copy of video footage of incident and Jermaine Trottie manager stated will email footage. No other details provided. Report will be emailed to Jermaine Trottie YDC supervisor. No deficiencies cited at this time.

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE
narrative:
On June 24, 2022 at 9:20 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a follow up Case Management investigation. LPA met with Renee Capeloto, Unit Director. Brief Summary: On 04/03/2022, the Department received a Special Incident Report stating that on 04/02/2022 Child #1 and Child # 2 were sitting on a couch in the Co- Ed Earth Unit. There are three couches with two facing forward towards the television and one couch to the side of television. Staff #2 is seen in the back of the room in the kitchen area preparing food. Child #1 and Child #2 are sitting a good shoulder space apart on the couch facing television. The video footage shows Child # 2 rubbing and touching Child #1's inner thigh. Child #2 is looking over shoulder back at Staff #2 and continues rubbing and touching Child #1. Staff #2 leaves the room with food to distribute to the other units. Child #2 can be seen on video taking hand of Child #1 and placing on private parts. No other staff were present in the Co Ed Earth Unit during this incident. Incident reports states that Staff interviewed Child #1 and Child #2, notified supervisor, moved Child #1 to separate living wing, called Child Abuse Hotline and police department. cont on 9099c.

During the investigation process, LPA reviewed Special Incident Report #8058401 viewed video footage, NSP for Child #1 & Child #2, requested police report, interviewed Unit Director, Staff #1, Staff #2 and Child #1. Statements were consistent that on 04/02/2022, at approximately 7:11 PM Staff #2 left Co Ed Earth Unit with Child #1 and Child #2 unsupervised sitting on the couch resulting in inappropriate touching. After interviewing Child #1 stated did touching due to bored and Staff #2 was cooking. Child #2 has been awol since incident and not available for interview. Based on the interviews and documentary evidence gathered, there was insufficient information to support lack of supervision. Facility is being Cited for 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. Based on the observations made during today’s visit, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Administrator

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE
narrative: restraints are conducted when clients in care pose imminent danger to self and others, staff have to be Pro-Act trained and two or more staff must conduct the restraint. There were no video footage to corroborate the incident due to complaint reported two or more months after incident. Staff #2, Staff #4 and Staff #5 all stated that Child #1 did not disclose reason for needing to make call @2 :30 AM and call was denied to due to phone policy. No calls are allowed after 10:00PM unless emergency. Child #1 did not state reason for call during interview. Staff #1, Staff #2, Staff #4 & Staff #5 all stated will intervene when an altercation occurs between resident for safety of residents. Staff #2 denied having inappropriate interactions with Child #1 and would not enter room without knocking. Staff #2 stated three staff were present during incident with Child #1. Staff #4 & Staff #5 confirm Staff #2 did not handle Child #1 in a rough manner or touch inappropriately. Based on the interviews conducted and documentary evidence obtained the information did not produce corroborating evidence to support the above said allegations. Due to inconsistent statements LPA Phillips was not able to determine if the above said allegations occurred, therefore the allegations are found to be Unsubstantiated meaning that although the allegations may have happened or is valid there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged incidents occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted, and copy of the report will be emailed to facility Jermaine Trottie/ Unit Supervisor.

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Dina Camara, Licensing Program Analyst Dahl Larios, and Licensing Program Manager Angela King conducted a case management inspection 11/08/22 at 11:35 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 25 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 17 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of 25 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 17 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated 11/08/2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments and youth case plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. Licensing Program Manager Angela King observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Maricela Morales, Quality Assurance & EHRS Manager.

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Raymond Canal, Licensing Program Analyst Dina Camara, and Licensing Program Manager Angela King conducted a case management inspection on 11/2/23 at 8:50 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 20 Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 10 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of 20 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 10 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 9/14/23). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, Annual Client Treatment Plans, and safety plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPM King observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Amy Jaffe.

Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to Jermaine Trottie/YDC Supervisor.

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE

Due to inconsistency in statements obtained during the investigation. Based on the observations made during today’s inspection, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to Jermaine Trottie/YDC Supervisor

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Raymond Canal and Licensing Program Manager Stephen Kim conducted a case management inspection on 9/26/24 at 11:00 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 26 Direct Care Staff and 7 out of 13 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of 26 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 13 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 9/26/24). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, Annual Client Treatment Plans, and safety plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPM Kim observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Unit Director Renee Capeloto and Quality Assurance Residential Manager Ana Solares.

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE
investigation_findings: 13On September 18, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Kenrick Ellis arrived at the above facility for the purpose of concluding the above complaint investigation. During the investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews with five staff members and five clients. LPA also reviewed Personnel Report (LIC500), client roster and video footage of the alleged incident recorded July 27, 2024. The interviews did not produce evidence to support the allegations. Interviews revealed inconsistent statements to suggest the allegations occurred. Statements and video evidence indicated that Staff 1 (S1) was not observed to engage in a physical altercation with clients in care. S1 was not observed demonstrating inappropriate forms of discipline. Statements and video evidence displayed Client 1 (C1) running towards S1 with a hydro flask and hitting S1 in the head multiple times. Statements and video evidence show clients in care obtain keyfob from staff and physically assault staff. There was no evidence of inappropriately restraining minors in care. Statements and video evidence indicated that S1 was assaulted by C1. There were no deficiencies cited per the California Code of Regulations or Interim Licensing Standards. Exit Interview was conducted with Jermaine Trottie, Administrator and a copy of this report was provided.

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE
investigation_findings: 13On November 12,2024 at 1:45 pm, Kenrick Ellis, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an unannounced visit to Vista Del Mar Special Care for the purpose of concluding a complaint investigation of the above allegations. LPA met with Renee Capeloto, Administrator and discussed the complaint allegations. A health and safety assessment was conducted. During the investigation LPA conducted six client interviews and five staff interviews, inspected kitchen areas throughout each cottage and observed food quality/quantity, experation dates, weeky food menus, and pictures of expired goods. Confidential interviews and LPA observations produced evidence to support allegations that expired food was served to children, and staff did not discard expired food items. Photographic evidence revealed expired food items present in facility kitchen and were available to children in care. Statements indicated that there are minimal systems in place to ensure that expired food is disposed in a timely fashion and unavailable to children in care. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80076(a)1. Staff does not ensure food of good quality is being served to children of care. Staff does not ensure expired food items are properly discarded from the facility. Violation details located on LIC809-D.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: (a) In facilities providing meals to clients, the following shall apply: (1) All food shall be safe and of the quality and in the quantity necessary to meet the needs of the clients. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Confidential statements and LPA observations indicated that staff does not ensure food of good quality is being served to children in care. Staff does not ensure expired food items are properly discarded from the facility.

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE
investigation_findings: 13On December 16th, 2024 at 12:13 PM, Kenrick Ellis, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) arrived at the above facility for the purpose of concluding a Complaint Investigation. LPA met with Jermaine Trottie, administrator. A health and safety assessment was conducted prior to entering facility. During the investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews with four staff members and five clients. LPA also reviewed Personnel Report (LIC500) and the client roster. Interviews did not produce evidence to support the allegations. Interviews revealed inconsistent statements, and no witnesses to suggest the allegations occured. Statements indicated that S1 and other staff members do not speak inappropriately to youth or demonstrate inappropriate forms of discipline. Statements indicated that Youth 1(Y1) was not denied meals provided by the facility. Statements indicated that children in care are provided breakfast, lunch, and dinner each day. Statements and observations indicated that children in care are also provided alternative meals to those that are provided and indicated on meal schedule. Statements indicated that Y1 was not pushed by a staff member. There was no information indicating when incident occurred and no reports of Y1 sustaining injuries. Statements indicated that children in care dispose of their food when done eating and there was no evidence of staff disposing of Y1 food. There were no deficiences cited at this time. Exit Interview was conducted with Jermaine Trottie, Administrator and a copy of this report was provided.

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE
narrative: Based on confidential interviews and documentary evidence, the investigation found a lack of proof to substantiate physical and or sexual abuse towards Y1 while in care at Vista Del Mar Child and Family Services-Special Care. Therefore, the allegation is determined Unsubstantiated. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview completed. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to Facility Representative.
investigation_findings: 13On January 14, 2025, at 1:10 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver findings concerning the above-mentioned allegations. LPA Martin met with Jermaine Trottie/Youth Development Counselor Supervisor to discuss the investigative outcome. On May 1, 2024, Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) received a complaint referral alleging sexual and physical abuse on Youth (Y1) who was reportedly a victim of sexual and physical abuse while in care. The allegation was referred to CCLD Investigations Branch for assignment. On May 3, 2024, LPA Martin met with facility representative, informed of investigation, and obtained requested facility and client records. Confidential interviews obtained from one youth, assigned county Social Worker and Facility Supervisor, and contact with the Santa Monica Police Department as well as review of related incident report, and review of related investigation report from the Department of Children and Family Services produced inconsistent statements as to the accounts of alleged physical and sexual abuse. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES-SPECIAL CARE
narrative: Documented facility incident report, dated 5/4/2024, reveals in part, Y1 was seen by facility nurse following an incident for which staff intervened to stop Y1 from physically attacking another peer. Y1 reported that Y1 hit the right side of Y1’s face on the wall. Upon assessment by the nurse at 8:45 PM, Y1 was observed with no injuries to the head or face areas. Later that evening at 9:30 PM, Y1 was seen by facility nursing staff, for superficial cuts on the face. At some point during medication distribution, Y1 requested a surgical mask from the nurse and proceeded to take out the nose strip of the mask to cut self on the face area. Superficial cuts were observed on Y1’s right cheek, left cheek and forehead areas. Nurse treated Y1’s injuries with no further incident. Based on confidential interviews and documentary evidence, the investigation found a lack of proof to substantiate that staff pushed Y1 causing injury while in care at Vista Del Mar Child and Family Services-Special Care. The allegation is determined Unsubstantiated as evidence obtained was not sufficient to substantiate the allegation. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview completed. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to Facility Representative
investigation_findings: 13On January 14, 2025, at 1:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver findings concerning the above-mentioned allegation. LPA Martin met with Jermaine Trottie/Youth Development Counselor Supervisor to discuss the investigative outcome. On May 6, 2024, Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) received a complaint referral alleging physical abuse by an unidentified staff on Youth (Y1) as youth was reportedly shoved against a wall by an unidentified staff member, sustaining injury as a result. On May 15, 2024, LPA Martin met with facility representative, informed of investigation, and obtained requested facility and client records. Confidential interviews obtained by CCLD Investigations Branch from one youth (Y1), assigned county Social Worker, one Facility Staff member and review of related incident report, as well as related investigation report from the Department of Children and Family Services produced inconsistent statements that a staff member pushed youth causing injury as accounts to the alleged incident changed multiple times during the interviews. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

narrative: On 7/28/22 at 1:13PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a random annual inspection at the facility. LPA met with Director/Administrator Tara Bartholomew and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including mask wearing and hand hygiene. LPA toured the facility and grounds with Director/Administrator. The facility is clean and organized, bathrooms and kitchen are sanitary, play spaces and toys were observed to be clean, in safe condition, and developmentally-appropriate, and the outdoor play area was free of obstructions. There are no bodies of water on the grounds. No dangerous items were observed, and per Director/Administrator, there are no firearms or weapons on the premises. The facility has four youth bedrooms, and all were clean and tidy. The facility has a waiver to have more than two beds in a room. The large bedrooms with five beds each currently have three beds in use in order to provide six feet separation between used beds. The toddler room also currently has three beds instead of five. Chemicals and medications are stored where inaccessible to youth. Room and hot water temperatures measured within permitted ranges, at 72 F and 113.5 F, respectively. Youth records were observed to be complete. Staff files reviewed reflected that staff had background clearances and were associated to the facility, had medical clearances to work in the facility, had valid first aid/CPR certificates, and had signed acknowledgements of mandated reporter status. Youth were observed to be engaged with staff in activities, and staff were attentive to youth needs. During incidents that occurred during visit, staff were responsive to each youth's needs and communicated well with other staff. There are no citations. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Director/Administrator Tara Bartholomew, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 09/23/2024 at 11:55 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brenda Rodriguez and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted a random annual inspection at the facility. LPA’s met with Program Manager, Gina McGlasson and informed her the purpose of the visit. LPA’s toured the facility and grounds with Program Manager. The facility is clean and organized, bathrooms and kitchen are sanitary, play spaces and toys were observed to be clean, in safe condition, and developmentally appropriate, and the outdoor play area was free of obstructions. There are no bodies of water on the grounds. The facility has four client bedrooms, and all were clean and tidy. Chemicals and medications are stored where it is inaccessible to the clients. LPA Rodriguez and LPA Medina reviewed four (4) client records. Client records were observed to be complete. LPA Rodriguez and LPA Medina reviewed three (3) staff files. Staff files reviewed reflected that staff had background clearances and were associated to the facility, had medical clearances to work in the facility, had a valid first aid/CPR certificates, and had signed acknowledgements of mandated reporter status. Clients were observed to be engaged with staff in activities, and staff were attentive to client needs. During incidents that occurred during visit, staff were responsive to each youth's needs and communicated well with other staff. The required Annual Inspection is complete. No deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted at 2:10 p.m., and a copy of this report was emailed to Director/Administrator Tara Bartholomew, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 01.29.24 Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Misty Valencia and Tina Thorn arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Lynn Woerner, Director .The purpose of the visit was to conduct a Required, Two year Annual Inspection of the facility. The last Annual inspection for the facility was on 09.12.19. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the Annual inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant, and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized,and maintained an acceptable room temperature. The facility is a home like setting, with 3 client bedrooms, a large open plan kitchen/dining area, and one locked staff office. Each client had a closet and dresser in good repair. Mattresses and bedding were observed to be clean. The backyard was free from hazards, safely fenced, with a variety of play equipment accessible to clients. LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hotline, client personal rights, and emergency disaster plan. The facility has 1 client bathroom and two staff bathrooms. All were observed to be clean and fully functioning. Smoke alarms were fully functioning and current and first-aid kits were available in a locked cabinet. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility currently has no clients, with a licensed maximum capacity of 6. Staff to client ratio is 1:3 LPA reviewed one staff file. Staff file had completed criminal record clearances and all required initial and annual training. All First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for staff. No Crisis care clients have been enrolled in six years. LPA interviewed one staff on site. No citations were given on this date. A Lic 9099 was provided to the Director An exit interview was conducted.

met_with: spoke on the phone with Lynn Woerner, Administrator
narrative: *Correction: This was not an office visit. This was a visit to the facility. On 01.23.25 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn attempted a visit for the purpose of an Annual Inspection. There was nobody at the facility when LPA Arrived. LPA spoke with Lynn Woerner, Administrator on the phone. LPA was advised that the facility closed and would reopen the next week.

On 12/15/20 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman and a HFEN Nurse conducted a Tele Inspection of the agency via Microsoft Teams with Rachel Hann Program Manager (PM). LPA observed the facility has hand sanitizer, gloves and masks available for staff and clients. PM stated the facility has always done daily temperature checks for the clients as part of the daily check in process. PM stated staff temperatures are checked and logged daily and staff wash their hands upon entrance. PM stated the facility has added COVID-19 questions to their initial intake questionnaire and parents/guardians call the facility and the staff assess if they have been exposed or have symptoms for COVID-19 prior to them entering the facility. PM stated the facility is checking staff and clients temperatures upon entrance and all staff and parents/guardian's sign in upon entrance. The facility has COVID-19 signs posted throughout the facility. The facility has a hand sanitizer dispenser at the entrance to the facility. The facility will move the staff and parents/guardian's sign in sheets by the front door to the facility. One client and five staff were present during the inspection. LPA and HFEN observed a staff demonstrate appropriate hand washing technique. PM stated staff assist clients as needed in hand washing. PM stated if a client develops symptoms of COVID-19 while in care the parent/guardian or emergency contact person is informed and the client is sent home and asked to quarantine for 10 days as a precaution or they can additional medical advice. The facility has approximately three to four clients per day. PM stated the toys used by clients are sanitized daily. PM stated if a toy has been in the mouth of a client it is removed and sanitized separately.. No follow-up is needed.

met_with: Rachel Hann, Program Manger and Cherelle Blufordcraving, Supervisor
narrative: On January 31, 2022 at 12:40PM License Program Analyst, Yuvi Diaz (LPA) conducted an announced annual inspection at the above facility. LPA met with Rachel Hann, Program Manger (PM), and Cherelle Blufordcraving, Supervisor. LPA toured the facility with the assistance of the Supervisor. Facility consisted of: one office for Case Manager, and Family Coordinator, one office for Supervisor, an area where the printer is and additional computer/ desk area, and one bathroom for staff use. There in one intake room, a lobby area where the entrance is. The entrance has all COVID posters up and COVID screening is done. The kitchen was clean and sanitary as well the as the dining room area. Kitchen pantry was stalked as well as the refrigerator. Facility has two playrooms both were clean and sanitary. There are three bedrooms. One room for infants and the other two rooms for non-infant children. Furniture was clean, sanitary, and in good condition. The back yard was free of hazards. There was a section for the infants and for the children to play with. In the backyard there is a storage with additional food, and emergency supplies. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide were working properly. Fire extinguishers were to date.The bathroom faucets/toilets all worked properly. All bedrooms had appropriate bedding, dresser and the necessary toiletries. First aid was located in an area were it 's accessible to staff. LPA reviewed 7 staff files and 5 client files. Staff files contained updated CPR/first aid cards, criminal clearance, and education. Client files contained, initial intake form, face sheet, medical consent form, parent rights, and personal rights. LPA also saw facility license, facility sketch, designation of facility responsibility, and emergency plan. No deficiencies were noted. Exit interview was conducted with Program Manager, and Supervisor. A copy of this report was emailed.

police report, nursery log dated 10/6/22, staff training log dated 9/28/22, staff meeting agenda dated 9/28/22, and new employment training logs. LPA Carmona conducted 17 confidential interviews between 12/7/22- 1/10/23 and 2 attempted interviews. Based on interviews conducted during the investigation process the allegations cannot be substantiated because statements given from 11 confidential interviews conducted from 12/7/22-1/3/23 corroborated that staff did not cause injury to C1 or hit C1. The facility had proper documentation of the injury in question on an injury report dated 10/06/22 which was signed at discharge. In addition, the facility also documented the injury on the nursery log dated 10/06/22. Lastly, there were inconsistent statements from interviews conducted on 12/5/22, 12/15/22 and 1/3/23. On 11/8/22 the facility staff met mandated reporting requirements and addressed concerns of reported previous incidents on 10/19/22. LPA Carmona was also not able to qualify C1 during the investigation process.
