investigation_findings: 13On 01/13/23 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacqueline Carmona conducted a complaint inspection to the above Crisis Nursery (CN) and met with Annette Jumper, Program Director for the purpose of delivering findings. During the investigation, LPA Carmona reviewed the agency’s file at the licensing office, including the complaint history, criminal background check, incident reports and facility personnel report summary. LPA also reviewed an email dated 10/19/22, pictures dated 11/08/22, intake documents dated 10/6/22, 10/27/22, 11/1/22, 11/3/22,11/8/22, injury reports dated 10/06/22 and 10/27/22,microsoft teams log dated 11/8/22, phone call log dated 11/8/22,LIC 500, facility work schedule dated week of 11/5/22-11/11/22, case notes dated 10/5/22, 10/6/22, 10/19/22,10/28/22,11/1/22,11/3/22,11/4/22 and 11/8/22, protective custody report dated 11/08/22,

narrative: On 7/24/23 at approximately 12:30 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jacqueline Carmona made an announced visit to conduct a case management regarding the facility not providing care and supervision to infants/children during the replacement of their outdoor deck. The Department received an email from the provider on 7/11/23 where it stated the facility will be having their outside deck replaced on 7/31/23. The project is estimated to take place from 7/31/23- 8/11/23. The facility will not having 3 exits available during the replacement of the deck outdoors. Due to the exits not being available the provider made the decision that there will be no care and supervision provided to infants/children effective by the end of the day 7/28/23 until the project is complete. LPA met with Rachel Hann, Program Manager during this visit and there were 6 children in care at the time. A walk through was conducted of the interior and exterior of the facility and it is in compliance. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Rachel Hann, Program Manager. This case management investigation is closed.

On 4/18/2024 at 9:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tatyana Shulz and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez made an unannounced visit with the purpose of conducting an annual inspection to the above facility using the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tool. LPA and LPM met with Rachel Hann, Program Manager and a walk through of the interior and exterior was completed. Physical Plant Room 1 is an intake counseling office. Room 2 is a supervisor office. Room 3 is a staff office/ copier/bathroom area. Room 4 is a case manager and family service coordinator office and file room which is inaccessible to clients. Room 5 is the kitchen/ washer and dryer area. Room 6 is the family room with couches. Room 7 is the first preschool room with two twin beds. Room 8 is the second preschool room with two twin beds. Room 9 is the infant room with 4 cribs and 1 emergency crib/ playroom/ nap room. There are three bathrooms, one located in the staffing area with working toilet, and running warm water with a temperature of 105 degrees. The other two bathrooms have a changing table, working toilet, and running warm water with a temperature of 105 degrees. All playrooms have sufficient activities for the children/infants, including books, age-appropriate toys, arts/craft materials and all furniture is in good repair. The backyard is gated, with two planter boxes, a large back deck and two playhouses covered by two large blue coverings with padded flooring and a grass area. The backyard is clear of debris and clean. There is a garage stocked with toys, gifts, nonperishable food, baby supplies, an extra freezer and an extra fridge, extra cleaning supplies, powdered milk for infants, and age-appropriate clothing and diapers. There is a 2019 Toyota Sienna in good working condition, properly maintained, lights, tires, registration/insurance and working seat belts and is available to transport clients if needed. Continue to LIC 809C

The following required documents were posted, License and Personal Rights. Disinfectants/cleaning solutions inaccessible to children in care. Refrigerator Temperature at or below 45 degrees F. Nonperishable foods one week and fresh perishable foods three days minimum. Menu present and posted in the kitchen area on the fridge. A working telephone is available at the facility. Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are in working order. First Aid Kit fully stocked. Medication centrally stored, locked/inaccessible to children. Hot Water between 105–120-degree F. Fire Extinguisher up to date and in working order. Toilets wash basin, bath, and shower fixtures in good repair/no leaks/hot water temperature. Soap and Paper towels are available to clients. Bedroom required linen and furnishings are fully stocked. Facility is free of vermin. The following domains were also reviewed during today’s inspection, Operations, Disaster Preparedness, Staffing, Client Records and Day Services. A total of 5 staff files, 5 children’s files and 1 volunteer file were reviewed. No out of compliance issues were identified for these domains. LPA also conducted 3 staff interviews and no concerns for follow up was noticed. A review of the Licensing Information System indicates the facility is up to date on their facility fees and all the staff were fingerprint cleared and associated to the facility. An exit interview was conducted with Rachel Hann and a copy of this report, and the Appeal Rights were provided to the facility, no deficiency cited.

Although the allegation may have happened or is valid there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did occur therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview was conducted, and Appeal Rights were discussed with Cherelle Blufoarcraving, Supervisor. A copy of this report and Appeal Rights were left at the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On September 17, 2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sara Luman-Gonzalez conducted an unannounced visit to the above agency to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation. LPA met with Cherelle Blufoarcraving, Supervisor and was granted entry. During the investigation, LPA conducted the 10-day inspection of the facility on May 24, 2024 LPA obtained C1’s file, Staff Schedule for the week of May 8, 2024, Staff Roster and Phone List. 6 confidential interviews were conducted between May 2024 and September 2024 by LPA Luman-Gonzalez. Based on LPA’s Interviews and records review, C1 was unable to be qualified during the interview process as well as they kept changing the physical details of the alleged perpetrator. Also, records show who was all scheduled during that time and none of them matched the first description provided by C1. Lastly, there no confirmed witnesses to the incident in question nor was there camera footage showing the alleged incident. (Cont. LIC9099C)

narrative:
On 06/16/2021 at 11:45 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Nino Sanders and Stephannie Verna arrived at the above facility to conduct an annual/required inspection. LPAs met with Rachel Hann, Program Manager and completed a walk-through of the facility. The facility serves clients age newborn through five years old. Currently there are three children enrolled in the program. The facility has 16 working staff including their Program Manager, Rachel Hann and Program Supervisor, Vinny Quach. The program maintains the staff and child ratio requirements. During the inspection LPAs observed there were two staff on shift, watching the three children. The crisis nursery is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. The facility has six bedrooms. The bedrooms have beds with good mattresses an linens, and closets and dressers which held extra linens and blankets. The furniture was in good repair. The bathrooms were clean and sanitary and the toilet and sink had accommodations, including step stools, for the children. The bathrooms included diaper changing stations, and extra supplies and diapers. The Program Manager stated that the diaper changing stations are cleaned and sanitized after each use. The evacuation plan and map are posted in multiple locations throughout the facility. Fire extinguishes are located in several locations within the facility, and are up-to-date. The smoke alarms were recently serviced by Cornerstone company, for the annual service. According to the invoice document, the date of service was conducted on 03/15/2021. The facility has a visitation room which has age appropriate toys and books for children and clients.

The offices are located at the entrance/lobby of the facility. Staff and client files are locked in locked filing cabinets located within the filing room. The facility license is posted in the lobby. Personal rights poster is posted in the hallway. The kitchen is clean and well organized. There are two days of perishable and seven days of non-perishable foods. Food supplies are labels. LPAs conducted an expiration date check, and foods were unexpired. Cooking items and utensils are plentiful. The weekly food menu is posted on the refrigerator. There are healthy and age-appropriate snacks available to the children. Medications are locked in locked box in the kitchen cabinet. LPAs observed medications are labeled with expiration dates. At this point the facility serves in-house Tylenol only, as needed. Expired medications are disposed by the the facility nurse, Candy Hernandez, at Sacramento Children's Home. The facility has a medication log that contains emergency forms of each child being served, and dates and times that the medication is given. There is a laundry room located near the kitchen. The laundry room is clean and sanitary and has a storage section which holds extra bathroom supplies, diapers and sanitary items. The hallway has extensive storage, which holds extra clothing and supplies for the children. The garage houses their main pantry, which includes food items, baby formula, cold and frozen food items, and extra storage which includes children's supplies, toys, clothing, diapers, and supplies for activities. The LPAs inspected the outside of the facility, which included an outdoor playground, nature walk area, outdoor rooms used for different purposes. The playground has infant swings, playhouse, playground, climbing gym, and outdoor toys. The ground is covered in rubber flooring for protection, and has a awning for sun protection.

The nature trail included stationary activity stations, children's garden plots, playhouses, small shed which held gardening tools, and locked storage bin which held paints. The outdoor rooms near the garage held the following: baby boutique which is used by clients to obtain baby clothing and items that they are in need of and according to Program Manager is off-limits to the children; jump room/gym for children filled with soft pads and age appropriate gym items; storage room for toys; teacher's supply room; and archive file room. LPAs inspected facility vehicle. Vehicle is in good working condition, has valid car insurance and tire pressure is suitable. LPAs reviewed six staff and three client files. The children's files contained admission documents, family and health information, emergency information and contact sheet, dietary requirements, documented daily needs, habits and routines of child(ren) and disciplinary methods used by the parent, signed consent forms. There is a signed copy of child's personal rights signed by the parent. The staff files contain proof of criminal record clearance, CACI clearance, health screening report and proof of negative TB test, valid first aid/CPR certification, and personnel record files. Staff have completed initial staff training requirements and are on track to complete 20 hours of annual training for the current year of employment. No title 22 regulations are cited on today's date. A copy of this report was e-mailed to Rachel Hann, Program Manager.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced annual continuation inspection at the facility and met with Program Manager/Administrator Rachel Hann, who assisted with the inspection. LPA reviewed two staff files, one lead staff file, one Case Manager file, and one Administrator file and found: All requirements were met. Job duties/descriptions were not in the staff files initially, however Administrator printed them out for LPA. All were signed by the staff. LPA advised Administrator to ensure these are kept in each staff file, which she agreed to. All staff reviewed were fingerprint cleared as required, are first aid certified as required, and met all training requirements. LPA interviewed two staff. Both staff were knowledgeable in Suspected Child Abuse reporting, the facility's goals, and evaluating the childrens' needs when they come to the facility. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and this report with her.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced annual inspection at the facility and met with Program Supervisor (PS) Vinny Quach, and Program Director/ Administrator (PD) Rachel Hann, who assisted with the inspection. LPA and PS conducted a walk-through of the facility. LPA observed a reception area, an intake room, one kitchen, one pantry, one dining area, five bathrooms, six bedrooms, two play areas, a backyard play area, backyard garden, two rooms of extra storage space for donated items, many closets with clothes and supplies, four staff offices, and an archive file room. LPA observed there to be an adequate amount of food of good quality at the facility for the clients. LPA observed the hot water to be non-functioning in one client bathroom, however in another client bathroom the hot water measured at 120.0 degrees Fahrenheit, which is within the required range of 105 to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. In the "Baby Boutique," bed frames were partially obstructing the pathway in and out of the room. The play furniture met all requirements, except for a geometric dome climbing structure, which is not anchored to the ground. There was a soft/squishy ground covering underneath the play equipment. LPA observed four children present, playing and then eating during this inspection. LPA observed extra clothing, bedding, and shoes for the children, all labelled. The toys were clean and in good condition, as well as stored appropriately. All cribs and beds met requirements. The Board has been meeting as required. The facility is conducting emergency drills as required. The Emergency Disaster Plan is up to date and has been reviewed annually as required.

LPA reviewed four client and four parent files and found: All requirements were met except, for two clients who are currently potty-training, there is no toilet training written plan as required. LPA found that the intake questionnaire is comprehensive in asking facts about the child and needs they have. No clients are on medication at this time. The parent files list the reason for placement, and time length of stay, as well as the Crisis Nursery's plan to resolve the crisis. LPA was unable to review staff files and conduct interviews on this date due to time. LPA will return on another day to complete the file review and interviews. On today's date, the facility is being cited for a violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 7.3, Personal Services - Section 86577(d). LPA has also issued three Technical Violation Advisory Notes, which are not citations. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report and appeal rights were printed and left with her.

On 3/18/2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) N. Sanders conducted a case management at the above facility for the purpose of discussing SB 1264 effective January 1, 2021. LPA spoke with Oscar Lopez, Operation Manager. The Senate Bill expands on Health and Safety Code 1565 and Interim Licensing Standards requiring facilities to meet various emergency preparedness provisions related to natural disasters and power failures. LPA advised that 1565 form LIC610 should be updated to reflect the new Health and Safety Code requirements. However, until the new form is updated, the facility will need to comply with the new requirements using their own format. The facility's new Emergency Plan must be submitted by May 1, 2021, 60 days from the Provider Information Notice (PIN 21-03-CRP) dated March 1, 2021. Below are the helpful link references: https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displaySection.xhtml?sectionNum=1565&lawCode=HSC https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billTextClient.xhtml?bill_id=201920200SB1264

On 10/13/2021, at approximately 5 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced case management inspection.of this facility. LPA was met by Administrator Heather Sleuter. The purpose of this inspection was to follow up on a reported COVID-19 Outbreak at the facility. Two child clients and a total of six employees tested positive for COVID-19 at various points in time since 10/01/2021. Neither of the children were Crisis Nursery clients as they had not had overnight stays--more appropriately, the children were clients of this provider's Child Care Program. In any case, a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility's physical plant was done--no deficiencies were observed. Client and staff records were also reviewed. The facility was temporarily closed as part of the response to the outbreak; a cleaning service, SERVPRO, was employed to do a COVID-19 cleaning; the plan is to re-open on Monday, 10/18/2021. At that point, all facility persons (staff and clients) who tested positive and/or exhibited symptoms would have passed the 14-day quarantine period. Per the administrator, staff who did not get a positive COVID-19 result would be required to show a negative result from the time period between today and 10/18/2021. No citations were issued as a result of this inspection. A copy of this report is being provided to Ms. Sleuter.

On 02/14/2022, at approximately 12 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this facility's Crisis Nursery. LPA was assisted by Executive Director Heather Sleuter with whom the Crisis Nursery operation was discussed; a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility's physical plant was done; four client files and five staff files were reviewed. There was signage pertaining to the facility's COVID-19 policy posted at the entrance; LPA was admitted into the facility after going through the appropriately implemented health & safety protocol. The crisis nursery has three designated client bedrooms, all of which are furnished sufficiently. In each bedroom there was a ceiling-mounted smoke or fire alarm. Fire or smoke alarms were also observed in the facility's common areas--the fire alarm system was tested and found to be operational. Fire extinguishers were inspected and were found to be placed at appropriate areas of the crisis nursery. On 01/24/2022, the Davis Fire Department did an inspection and cleared the facility, finding that "[a] reasonable degree of fire and life safety exists..." LPA observed that the common areas were clean and uncluttered; the egresses were unobstructed. All cabinets otherwise accessible to children were key-locked. Detergents and other potentially hazardous chemicals were stored and secured in storage areas inaccessible to children by themselves. Medications were also kept in locked containers, housed in secured cabinets. There was enough perishable food in the kitchen refrigerator to last at least three days; there was an additional refrigerator located in the garage which stocked more perishable items. Non-perishable food was observed in quantities sufficient for at least seven days--LPA did not observe any indications of expired, rotten, soiled, or damaged food items on hand. The backyard contained infant and toddler play structures, toys, and other activity items, all of which were in good working condition. No potentially dangerous areas or items were observed to be accessible to clients in care. Client and staff records were found to be securely filed; LPA reviewed and found the records to contain the required components including (for the children's records) a recent photograph for each child, identifying information (name, date of birth, sex/gender), names and contact information for authorized representatives, (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 809-C)

and managing healthcare providers, and (for the staff records) driver licenses or State-issued IDs, CPR/First Aid certificates, signed Statements Acknowledging Requirement to Report Abuse, documentation for Health Screenings (including TB test results), background clearances or exemptions, and documentation of training. No citations are issued as a result of this inspection. A copy of this report is being provided to the facility.

On 07/17/2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon, accompanied by Community Care Licensing (CCL) leadership Angela Carmack, Assistant Program Administrator, and Jennifer Scott, Policy Analyst, conducted an unannounced Random Inspection of this facility. CCL was met initially by Rosalinda Maria Gray, Program Coordinator, and was later joined by licensee Heather Sleuter who gave a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the Nursery's physical plant. The facility did not have any Crisis Nursery clients at the time of the inspection. There were no Building & Grounds deficiencies observed during the walk-through; the review for client and personnel files was started but not completed--a subsequent inspection is needed to finish this inspection. A copy of this report is being provided to the licensee.

On 07/18/2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon continued the Random Inspection of this Crisis Nursery. The review of remaining records and an interview with the licensee/administrator were done. The following were observed: The facility's license and emergency disaster plan were posted in a prominent and publicly accessible location. Meal menus were readily visible on the kitchen refrigerator. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions were kept in locked cabinets. The refrigerator and freezer temperatures were at 45 degrees and 0 degrees Fahrenheit respectively; there was a backup or overflow perishable foods storage unit in the garage; there was fresh/perishable foods and dried goods on hand as the facility had child care clients. There was a working telephone on premises; the facility had a carbon monoxide detector located in the hallway and a smoke detectors in each of the client rooms; there was a fully stocked first aid kit. Common rooms were available including a dining area kept free of clutter. There was a secured storage cabinet, within which a lockable box was kept for medications to be centrally stored. Bathroom facilities were observed to be in good working condition with hot water being delivered in temperatures within regulatory requirements. The nursery had wash stations where soap and paper towels were readily available. Two bedrooms were designated for the use of the overnight program and were found to be furnished appropriately: bed/crib fixtures were in good condition and sufficient linen was on hand. Five staff files were reviewed and found to have documentation of criminal record clearances as well as pediatric cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and first aid certificates. Since the crisis nursery had no clients, no client records were subject to review though technical assistance was provided on certain aspects of the expected record-keeping for children’s files. The crisis nursery was found to be in substantial compliance with Regulations, no deficiencies were issued as a result of this inspection. Exit interview conducted, and a copy of this report is being provided to the facility.

On June 2, 2025 at approximately 9:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tatyana Shulz made an announced visit with the purpose of conducting a closure inspection to the above facility. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator, Heather Sleuter and a copy of this report will be provided to the facility.

Room 12 is the Sixth Overnight Bedroom: Dolphin Theme was equipped as follows: Rocking Chair, 2 cribs, A dresser, Lamp, Rug, Closet stocked with clothing. Room 13 is the Laundry Room: Poppy Theme was equipped as follows: 3 washers, 3 dryers, A Sink, Folding table area, Storage cabinets. Room 14 is the Sick and Safe Room was equipped as follows: Toilet, Storage, Cabinet with diapers and gloves, Sink, First Aid Kit, AED Machine, Mini Refrigerator and a Chair. Room 15 is the Infant Nap Room: Bullet and Fireproof Room was equipped as follows: 5 cribs, A rocking chair, Cabinet, and Children’s Table. Room 18 is the Kitchen Area and Pantry equipped as follows: 2 full sized Refrigerators, Stove Top, Oven, Dish Washer, Microwave, 2 Sinks and Cabinet Space. The Pantry has cutlery, plates, baby formula, water, Similac, and Storage containers. Room 19 is the Staff Breakroom was equipped as follows: Full Size refrigerator, Sink, Cabinets, Table and chairs. Room 20 is the Shared Office Space for Staff was equipped as follows: 4 rows of desks and approximately 11 chairs, File cabinets, Desk phones. Room 21 is the Director’s Office was equipped as follows: 2 Desks, Computer Monitor, 2 Cabinets and 4 chairs. There are 9 bathrooms in total, 4 adult and 5 children’s bathrooms. All of them equipped with sinks, toilets, working water fixtures. The children’s bathrooms all have tubs and sinks equipped with bathing infants. All bathrooms are in full compliance, all children’s bathrooms have mini toilets, mini sinks, and mini bathtubs. The outside playground area is located in the center of the complex divided into two sections by a metal fence. The Preschool Playground section has a mini obstacle course, race car track, play structure, sandpit, storage cabinets, basketball hoop, and 3 mini picnic tables. On the Infant Playground section there is a play structure, a mini picnic table, a sandpit and games. All structures are fully secured to the ground and sit upon a patch of turf. There are water fountains disbursed throughout the playground areas with kid appropriate step stools. There are two cameras located in the playground area and there are 8 cameras around the outside of the facility and no cameras located inside. The water shut off valve and the electrical power shut off switch is located near the staff parking lot in the back of the facility. Heading towards the right of the facility is a storage shed with extra containers full of children’s supplies (clothes, bottles, toys) and extra attic space for needed storage. Connected to the storage shed is an extra room used for any additional storage needs. Next to the shed is a backup generator for the property. There is a trash enclosure located next to the bicycle storage area. There is an employee patio/break area with a bench, two tables and 8 chairs. The back of the property is surrounded by a metal fence separating the property from the next door residential complex, with a censored gate trigger and automatic locking gate. There is a pull up system for the fire department and the fire clearance was granted on 4/22/2025. There are a total of 6 fire extinguishers in working order throughout the facility. There are 4 fully stocked first aid kits at the facility. The facility is a one story property with no bodies of water on the premises. Disinfectants/cleaning solutions are inaccessible to children in care. Trash cans located around the facility have lids. Refrigerator temperature is at or below 45 degrees F. The facility is maintained at 70 degrees Fahrenheit. Hot Water between 105–120-degree F. Fire Extinguishers are up to date and in working order. Toilets, wash basins and shower fixtures in good repair, no leaks and there is hot water accessible. Bedroom required linen and furnishings are fully stocked. The facility is free of vermin. On December 15, 2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia met with Chief Executive Officer, Heidi Morgan and Administrator, Evony Garcia, for a prelicensing inspection. LPA discussed the following: Forms that the facility uses and will continue to use. Corporate organization - Including chain of command and roles of staff Written plans, policies or procedures that was submitted with the application. Administrator/Director qualifications and duties. 1. Facility grounds inspected. Grounds are clean and free from observable hazard. The facility does not have a swimming pool or any bodies of water. Firearms are not allowed on facility premises. 2. Adequate indoor activity space and materials observed, and outdoor activity space was observed. 3. Chemicals were appropriately locked. 4. Procedures for locked and centrally stored medications observed. 6. Adequate storage space observed. 7. Individual beds in good repair observed. A supply of extra linens available for bed changes. 8. The house is one story and has 4 client bedrooms, single occupancy. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Facility will add appropriate supply of foods upon placement of youth in the home. A supply of nonperishable foods were observed on this date. 10. Sample menu posted.

11. All appropriate forms posted within client view. 12. Dining room equipped with large table and chairs accommodating of all clients. 13. Facility has 2.5 restrooms for client use, all are operable. 14. Hot water measured 120 degrees on this date. Applicant is associated through Guardian and has been fingerprint cleared. Prior to accepting placement's, all staff must be fingerprint cleared and associated to the facility. Discussed Guardian process with the facility. Discussed Incident reporting. An initial report for all reportable incidents is to be made by the next working day to cclcenca@dss.ca.gov. A full report is to be remitted within 7 days and may also be made to the incident reporting email. After licensure, you will receive a letter notifying you of your assigned LPA, from the San Jose office. The application will be given to Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Carolyn Flynn, for review and licensure. Once approved by LPM, license will be issued and sent to Heidi Morgan. Initial license will be issued on a provisional basis, expiring one year from effective date. License will be valid for up to 4 male and/or female youth ages 8 through 17, two (2) can be non-ambulatory. A copy of this report was provided to Heidi Morgan.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Janeth Chavez, Gilbert Gutierrez, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Yan Yeung conducted a virtual office meeting via Microsoft Teams Meeting with Administrator, Susana Rodriguez for the purpose of a Component II and an orientation for Enhanced Behavioral Services Home program (EBSH) under GH. The purpose of the meeting is to discuss the pending issues needed for the application. The list of the items discussed were as follows: Application: LIC 503 Health Screening LIC 308 Designation of Facility Responsibility LIC 500 Personnel Report CCLD Orientation Certificate for Group Homes LIC 610C Emergency Disaster Plan for Children's Residential Program Statement Revisions needed: · Section 3 Purpose, Methods, and Goals-How will the services outcomes be implemented. · Section 4 Planned Activities/Use of Community Resources · Section 4 Planned Educational Activities & Services · Section 12 House Rules- #1 Each Resident is expected to participate in group activities and in therapy and if repeatedly refuse they may be discharged. Revise wording for the following house rules to avoid personal rights violation for the section on House rules, nutrition and chores so that the needs of the clients could be met. Page 1 of 2

#5 No smoking or drinking.in premise for staff and clients if over 18 #6 All residents are expected to conform to generally accepted standard of hygiene and appropriate dress. No excessively baggy pants, no colors or symbols, moderate makeup. #8 All cell phones and any other communication devices must be turned in at bedtime and will be returned in the morning on non school days and after school on school days. #13 No additional piercings may be obtained while you reside at the facility. #16 Residents are to clean their bedroom and put away all clothing before they leave for school. #21 Movies in the facility must be rated PG-13 or below Staff may authorize television if the program is educational or informative. · Section 18 Chores- #2 All residents must cooperate with chores. Section 21 Staff Schedule-need to show staff ratio SECTION 24 Inservice Training for Staff -provide mandatory training topics Section 15-Law Enforcement Involvement (Incident Reporting) -need to input the reporting requirement for law enforcement activities SB388. Pending Documents: 1. Approval Letter from DDS 2. Approval Letter from Kern Regional Center 3. CAIC clearances for Staff 4. Fire Clearance 5. Overconcentration Letter from City of Bakersfield LPA advised the Applicant that all revisions need to be submitted in two binders and scanned and emailed to Licensing by October 14, 2020. On 04/20/21 at 11:00 A.M, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Janeth Chavez conducted an announced Pre-licensing inspection and Component lll at the above facility address. This was a virtual inspection conducted via FaceTime. This facility will be an Enhanced Behavioral Support Home (EBSH) of Endless Possibilities Services Inc. LPA met Susana Rodriguez, who will be the Administrator for this facility. The Administrator provided a virtual tour to LPA of the facility. This is a one-story home that has 4 bedrooms and 4 bathrooms, laundry room and attached garage. Inside the home the following was observed: The staff schedule, Emergency Disaster Plan and Foster Youth Rights and facility menu was posted on the wall by the entrance area. The facility has a designated staff office located inside the home. There is a locking file cabinet, table and chair inside the staff office. There is a living room, dining and kitchen area. There were sofas and a TV in the living room and there were tables and chairs in the dining area. Each bedroom has one bed with beddings, linens, drawers and closet space for the clients' use. The first aid kit was observed to be new, complete and is in the kitchen area. The home has working telephones. There were working smoke/carbon monoxide detectors in the laundry room dining area, living room, hallway and in each bedroom. There were automatic sprinklers in the facility. The centralized heating and air were in working condition. All cleaning solutions were observed locked under the kitchen sink cabinet. All medication will be stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen area. All client and facility files will be stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office. There is a refrigerator, stove, kitchen utensils, plates and dinnerware in the kitchen drawers. The facility is ready to accept clients after the facility is licensed. Prior to today’s inspection the facility received fire clearance on 2/12/21. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was provided to the applicant.

An unannounced case management inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Janeth Chavez at the above-named facility on 02/15/2022 at 12:00 PM. This facility is a single-story home and consists of the following: Four (4) bedrooms, 2 full bathrooms, two (2) half bathrooms, formal living room area, 2 family rooms, leisure room, dining room, kitchen, one (1) staff office, attached garage, laundry room, front yard, backyard and swimming pool. LPA observed an in-ground pool located in the backyard. The pool is enclosed by an iron fence that is 66-inches high and does not obscure the pool from view. There are two gates that swing away from the pool area that lock with a key. However, the gates do not have a self-latching or self-closing device. The facility will be installing the self-latching/self-closing device on the two gates and a pool cover. The administrator will have the self-latching/self-closing and pool cover by March 1, 2022. LPA will conduct another inspection once the corrections have been made. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator, Susana Rodriguez.

On March 7, 2023 at 11:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Janeth Chavez, conducted an annual inspection to the facility and met with Susana Rodriguez, Administrator. The facility is a one-story home with four bedrooms and four bathrooms, staff office and attached garage. Currently there are two clients placed in the facility. At the time of LPA's arrival, there was one client sleeping in the facility. During the inspection, the administrator provided to LPA the roster of clients, Personnel Report, Emergency Disaster Plan & Emergency Drill log. Physical Plant: LPA observed the following: the posted license, emergency disaster plan, personnel schedule, client personal rights, and grievance procedure. The disinfectants, cleaning solutions, sharp objects are locked and inaccessible to clients. The facility maintains supplies of non-perishable foods for at least a week and fresh perishable foods for at least two days. Each bedroom has a single bed in good repair with clean sheets, linens, drawer space, and closet space. There are extra linens, adequate towels and hygiene supplies available for each client. Only one client sleeps in each bedroom. No bedroom is used for other purposes other than a bedroom. The window screens are in good repair and free of dirt. There are lights in all the rooms and throughout the facility. The faucets used by clients deliver hot water (114 degrees Fahrenheit). All medications are stored in the blue file cabinet and are locked with a key. There is a working telephone for clients to use. The first aid kit was complete and readily available. There are working smoke/carbon monoxide detectors in the facility. The delayed egress doors are properly working. All indoor and outdoor passageways are unobstructed.

This facility is a single-story home and consists of the following: Four (4) bedrooms, 2 full bathrooms, two (2) half bathrooms, formal living room area, 2 family rooms, leisure room, dining room, kitchen, one (1) staff office, attached garage, laundry room, front yard, backyard and swimming pool. LPA observed an in-ground pool located in the backyard. The pool is enclosed by an iron fence that is 66-inches high and does not obscure the pool from view. There are two gates that swing away from the pool area that lock with a key. The gates are self-latching. The pool meets state regulations. Staff Records At 01:00 PM, LPA reviewed three staff records. The staff records are available to LPA to inspect and audit upon request. All staff subject to criminal records review have been fingerprinted and cleared. There is documentation of the required education and experience requirements and training in the personnel file. Client Record At around 2:00pm, LPA reviewed two client records. All client records are available to LPA to audit and inspect upon request. The client records contain the required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, Individual Program Plan (IPP), medical assessment, safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables, personal rights forms, and medication administration records. During the time of inspection, LPA interviewed two staff and attempted to interview one client. There are no deficiencies cited during today's inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of LIC 809, LIC 809C & LIC 811s were provided to the administrator.

The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegation. There was no preponderance of the evidence to substantiate the allegation. So, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding this allegation. A copy of this complaint was emailed to the facility representative.
investigation_findings: On April 27, 2023 at 4:35 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, delivered the findings of a complaint investigation to the facility. The LPA met with the Lead Staff, David Lofty. On January 23, 2023, the Monterey Park Children's Residential Program (MPCRP), received a complaint with the above mentioned allegations. Confidential interviews were conducted that included, but were not limited to: the Administrator and two clients (see Confidential Names, LIC 811 Ref. #1 dated April 27, 2023) at the facility on February 1, 2023. The LPA conducted a telephone interview with the County Social Worker (CSW) on April 25, 2023. The LPA reviewed the clients Individual Behavior Support Plans and Special Incident Reports. The investigation revealed statements that Ref. #2 attempts to go into Ref. #1's bedroom and attack Ref. #1 and punch #1. There were no disclosures that Ref. #2 threw a shoe at Ref. #1 and the staff did not intercede. Ref. #2 denied the allegation and denied getting into fights with Ref. #1. The investigation revealed that the clients do not share a bedroom. It revealed that staff are CPI trained and separate the children when they are having differences. It revealed that law enforcement is called when necessary. The CSW has no concerns about the facility at this time.

narrative: On July 29, 2024, at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Gilbert Gutierrez and Brent Lockhart conducted a case management inspection to check on the physical plant of the facility and met Lead Staff Supervisor, Travis Bates. The facility is a one-story home with four bedrooms and four bathrooms, staff office and attached garage. Currently there are two clients placed in the facility. Physical Plant LPAs together with Lead Staff Supervisor toured the facility inside and out. LPAs observed the following: the posted license, emergency disaster plan, personnel schedule, client personal rights, and grievance procedure. The disinfectants, cleaning solutions, sharp objects were locked and inaccessible to the clients. The facility has non-perishable foods for at least seven (7) days and perishable foods for at least two (2) days. Each bedroom has a single bed in good repair with clean sheets and linens and at least three (3) drawers and closet space for the client's clothing. Only one client sleeps in a room. There were extra linens, towels, and hygiene supplies in the cabinet(s). No room commonly used for other purposes was being used as a bedroom. There were lights in all the rooms and throughout the facility. The faucets for children's use deliver hot water within temperature allowed by regulations. All medications were stored locked in the cabinet. There was a working telephone. The first aid kit was complete. The smoke/carbon monoxide detectors and delayed egress doors were tested and in working order. The video cameras were focused only on the common areas of the facility. All indoor and outdoor passageways were unobstructed. At the time of the inspection, LPAs observed the gate of the pool fence does not self-close. A deficiency citation was issued at the time of the inspection. A copy of the LIC 809, LIC 809D, and LIC 811s were provided to the facility representative.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Building and Grounds: Fences shall be at least five-fee high and shall be constructed so that the fence does not obscure the pool from view. The bottom sides of the fence shall comply with Division1, Appendix Chapter 4 of the 1994 Uniform Building Code. In addition to meeting all of the aforementioned requirements for fences, gates shall swing away from the pool, self-close and have a self-latching device located no more than six -inches from the top of the gate. Pool covers shall be strong enough to completely support the weight of an adult and be placed on the pool and locked while the pool is not in use.

narrative: The Following Allegation was reported: 1. The staff are using an inappropriate form of punishment with minors in care. The Staff (S1, S2, and S3) denied the allegations, stating that all team members are trained in trauma-informed care and understand the importance of creating a safe and healthy environment within the group home. They explained that during behavioral incidents, staff utilize verbal redirection and provide positive reinforcement on a daily and weekly basis, implementing a point system where clients can earn points every forty-five minutes for demonstrating appropriate behavior. The Staff asserted that they have neither seen nor heard of any staff member denying clients water or using it as a form of punishment. Instead, they highlighted that staff actively encourage hydration, awarding clients points for each glass of water consumed, which can be exchanged daily or at the end of the week for various special privileges, including outings to their favorite restaurants. Furthermore, the account given by C2 corroborated the above information, indicating that they are receiving adequate support from the staff and feel safe residing in the facility. The statement obtained from CSW affirmed that they have no concerns regarding the care and supervision provided to their client, and their client has not reported any incidents of misconduct by the facility staff. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegation(s) are determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation(s) may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation(s) occurred, therefore, the allegation(s) are found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the STRTP Administrator. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was left with the Group Home Administrator Assistant.
investigation_findings: 13On April 4, 2025, at 11:12 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Winston Moroney conducted a complaint inspection at the above group home and met with the Group Home Administrator Assistant Karina Lopez. The inspection aimed to deliver the findings regarding the complaint allegation(s). This investigation encompassed a thorough examination of various records, including the children's needs and services plans, medical documentation, incident reports, restraint logs, and interviews with three staff members: S1 on November 15, 2024; S2, S3 on November 18, 2024; 1 of 2 Clients C2 on November 18, 2024, ( No statement was obtained from C2 due to declining to be interviewed), and 1 Kern County Social Worker (CSW) on December 17, 2024. (Refer to Confidential Names Form LIC 811, dated April 4, 2025.)

narrative:
On January 24, 2025, at 11:30 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla conducted an unannounced Annual/Required inspection at Endless Possibilities II, an Enhanced Behavioral Supports Home (EBSH). LPA met with Brianna Hendrick, Co-Administrator. During this inspection, a tour of the facility was conducted, and LPA reviewed the following domains in the Compliance And Regulation Enforcement (CARE) Tool: Physical Plant, Operational Requirements, Disaster Preparedness, and Emergency Intervention Plan. LPA also attempted to interview one (1) client. Physical Plant: The license is posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions are locked under the kitchen sink and sharps are locked in the kitchen. Facility has non-perishable foods for at least one week and perishable foods for at least two days. Facility provides at least three(3) meals per day. Medications are centrally stored and locked in kitchen. All kitchen, food preparation, and storage areas are kept clean and free of rodents and other vermin. Facility has one or more carbon monoxide detectors in the facility. Facility provides basic laundry services. Room temperatures are maintained at 73 degrees F. The hot water temperature was within the required range. All toilets, hand washing and bathing facilities are maintained in safe and sanitary operating condition and meet the requirements. All clients have their own bedroom. All beds are in good repair; equipped with good springs and a clean mattress; and supplied with pillows which are clean and in good repair. Facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. Overall, facility is clean, safe sanitary and in good repair. Operational Requirements: Facility maintains a current, written plan of operation that meets licensing standards. Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. Facility maintains and implements written complaint procedures. Continued on next page...

Disaster Preparedness Plan: Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drill at least every month for each shift. The drills are documented, and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. Emergency Intervention Plan: Facility maintains a monthly log of each use of manual restraints that contains all required information. The log is available for review by the Department upon request. LPA observed documentation of Emergency Intervention Training and on-going training. During today's inspection, the EBSH was issued two (2) type B deficiencies (see LIC809-D) and four (4) Advisory Notes/Technical Violations (see LIC9102TVs). An exit interview was conducted A signed copy of this report, LIC811 Confidential names list dated 01/24/25, LIC809-D, LIC9102TVs, and appeal rights were provided to Brianna Hendrick. A follow-up is required to complete inspection.

On February 26, 2025, at 10:45 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla conducted an unannounced follow-up inspection at Endless Possibilities Services II for the purpose of concluding an Annual inspection. LPA met with Brianna Hendrick, Co-Administrator. During this inspection, LPA reviewed the following domains in the Compliance And Regulation Enforcement (CARE) Tool: Clients Records, and Staffing Records. LPA interviewed one staff. Staffing Records: LPA reviewed three staff records. The staff records are available to LPA to inspect and audit upon request. All staff subject to criminal records review have been fingerprinted and cleared. There is documentation of the required education and experience requirements and training in the personnel file. Clients Record: LPA reviewed two client records. All client records are available to LPA to audit and inspect upon request. The client records contain the required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, Individual Program Plan (IPP), medical assessment, safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables, personal rights forms, and medication administration records. One deficiency and three technical advisories were issued during this inspection. See LIC809-D and LIC9102-TA pages. Exit interview conducted. A signed copy of all licensing reports were provided to Ms. Hendrick. Appeal rights explained and provided. No further follow-up required.

narrative:
On August 19, 2025, at 9:38 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Angelina Garibaldo conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection at Gogian House Enhanced Behavioral Support Home (EBSH). LPA met with licensee Mary Watson, Chief Executive Officer, David Bernstein and Administrator Annamaria Ramos toured the home. Physical Plant This facility is in a quiet residential community. The facility consists of bedrooms (4) bedrooms, (2) bathrooms, (1) half bathroom, kitchen, Living room, office, a 3-car garage, and a backyard. Overall, LPA observed the home back yard to be sanitary and in excellent condition. Passageways are free from obstruction. Facilities smoke and carbon monoxide were tested and in working order. Facility has delayed egress system installed on front and back yard gates. Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies The home has toilets and wash basins for clients' use. Client bedrooms were observed to be clean, orderly, and contained full beds and desks. LPA observed clean pillows, bed sheets and blankets. The client’s bedroom has an adequate closet and drawer space to accommodate the client’s clothing and personal belongings. Knives are kept in a locked drawer in the kitchen and cleaning supplies in a locked cabinet under the sink in the kitchen. Additional supplies, linens, emergency supplies and water are kept in locked cabinets in the garage.

Heath Related Services and Record Keeping The medications will be stored in a locked cabinet off the dining room. First aid kits were available for review, one located in a medication station, and two located in the garage. Client files will be kept in locked cabinets in the hallway; staff files are maintained at the main facility headquarters. The purpose of the inspection was to discuss an Incident Report (SIR) submitted to the department on June 3, 2025. Staff have started Ukeru restraint training and will submit completion notification to LPA Medrano via email. LPAs were also informed the staff (S1) involved in the incident has been terminated. Additionally, Regional Center was provided with a Plan of Correction. Ukeru was implemented on June 22, 2025, and policy is to use Ukeru first. LPAs also discussed adding detail to incident reports. There were no deficiencies cited on this date. A copy of this report was provided to Julia Sanchez at the conclusion of the inspection.

facility_name: HEALTHY YOUTH AND FAMILIES HOME,INC,BARSTOW PLACE
narrative: On this date a Case Management Inspection was conducted to review the physical property and identify any issues that might need to be addressed and to review the Program Statement (PS) and the list of corrections. The physical plant was toured the issues identified are as follow: Delayed Egress to be completed and a possible second Delayed Egress door to be added on the west side yard. Also, a booster pump was installed to increase water pressure as specified by initial fire inspection. Delayed egress will be evaluated by fire inspection to determine if approved. The yard has a secured pool, propane and well area a secured yard area to be later applied as a possible animal area for clients use. The house was toured and all major construction has been completed. Interior to be furnished, toiletries, linens and non perishables items to be obtained. A complete pre licensing inspection is tentatively scheduled for Monday 8/8 at 8:00. The current submission of the PS which was submitted on 08/04/25 was reviewed. The review of corrections was discussed and each regulation to be addressed was reviewed. The format of the review and the expectations of meeting regulations was addressed. On todays visit we worked off of paper copies, electronic copies will be provided by email. If any questions about the review arises Allen has been asked to contact LPA for clarification.

On October 8, 2020, LPA Raissi conducted an announced initial complaint tele-inspection to open a complaint investigation regarding the allegations listed above this report. LPA met with, Administrator, Rowena Caling Nguyen (S1) via Facetime. During the tele-inspection visit, the administrator and LPA Raissi toured the facility at 2:30pm-2:40pm. LPA Raissi advised for the facility to remove the Lysol spray (in entry area). Per the administrator, this is only for staff to disinfect before coming into the facility. LPA reminded that all cleaning supplies should be locked, administrator immediately removed the Lysol disinfectant spray and reassured this LPA that they will not leave the Lysol disinfectant spray out. LPA Tran interviewed Staff (S2) on 12/23/2020 as a follow up. S2 had verified the hazardous Lysol item was placed on the Personal Protection Equipment (PPE) check-in station for staff to use. But since the complaint was created, the Lysol is always placed in a locked cabinet near the PPE station. Staff can access when needed. Based on LPAs Raissi and Tran’s observations and interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation, “Hazardous items are accessible to clients” is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. A deficiency was cited (Type A) for the allegation above this report on the attached 9099-D. Administrator immediately removed and locked the hazardous/toxic item, Lysol disinfectant spray. An exit interview was conducted, plan of correction was discussed, appeal rights discussed and provided, and a copy of this report was given to Administrator, Rowena Caling Nguyen, whose signature acknowledges receipt.

During this investigation LPA AmyLe Tran conducted interviews with eight Direct Support Staff from morning, day, and night shift. Interviewed Direct Support Staff S1-S9 (S2 on 11/17/2020 and 12/23/2020, S3 on 11/17/2020, S4 on 11/18/2020, S5 on 11/25/2020, S6 on 11/30/2020, S7 on 11/30/2020, S8 on 12/01/2020 and 12/04/2020, and S9 on 12/09/2020) – Administrator (S1 on 10/08/2020 and 12/02/2020) of the Helping Hand facility. Based on interviews, correspondence from Helping Hands representatives and observations by LPAs Raissi and Tran, the allegations of, “Facility has inadequate diapering supplies”, “Facility has inadequate food supply”, “Facility has inadequate cleaning supplies”, are unsubstantiated. The evidence as follows; On October 8, 2020, LPA Raissi conducted an announced initial complaint tele-inspection to open a complaint investigation regarding the allegations listed above this report. LPA Raissi met with, Administrator, Rowena Caling Nguyen (S1) via Facetime. During the tele-inspection visit, the administrator and LPA Raissi toured the facility at 2:30pm-2:40pm. The facility had more than enough food, diaper and cleaning supplies based on the visit’s observation by LPA Raissi. All food groups were incorporated. On October 8, 2020 LPAs Raissi and Tran obtained pictures from the facility administrator of Personal Protection Equipment (PPE) supplies, food supply, diaper supply, and cleaning supplies, ceiling fan in every room; the facility had more than enough supplies mentioned. On October 14, 2020, LPAs Raissi and Tran received a total of (30) receipts from the following stores (Costco, Walmart, Target, Ocean Market, Manila Oriental Supermarket, Great Oaks and Fresco Market) from Administrator, S1. LPA, Raissi and Tran reviewed listed receipts, includes Costco (19 receipts), Walmart (2 receipts), Target (1 receipt), Fresco Supermarket (2 receipts), Manila Oriental Market (2 receipts), Ocean Supermarket (1 receipt) and Great Oaks (1 receipt) dated from July 13, 2020 through October 7, 2020. Receipts for facility includes the following items: Cleaning supplies (Clorox wipes, swifter wet, detergent, toothpaste, etc.), variety of fruits, vegetables, meats, dairy, snacks, bread, and frozen food. All food groups were incorporated and there were enough cleaning supplies purchased for the facility. The receipts obtained were consistent with LPA Raissi’s tele-inspection observations and photos.

Based on LPA Tran observations and interviews which were conducted and recorded, Deficiencies were NOT cited for the allegations shown above this report. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was given to Administrator, Rowena Caling Nguyen, whose signature acknowledges receipt.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80087: (g)(1) Disinfectants, cleaning solutions... that could pose a danger if readily available to clients shall be stored where inaccessible to clients. Storage areas for poisons... shall be locked. Based on LPA observations and interviews with staff, the licensee left out Lysol disinfect spray (toxic item) unlocked to children in the facility on 10/08/2020 in the entry living room area. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.

narrative:
Based on a review of documents and interviews; The complaint allegation(s) of “unlicensed healthcare professional providing licensed healthcare duties and tasks” and “facility not providing enough staff to meet the needs of the client in care”, are Substantiated. Evidence for the allegation, “unlicensed healthcare professional providing licensed healthcare duties and tasks” as follows: Based on five (5) out of five (5) interviews conducted by this LPA. All five (5) persons interviewed (S1-S5) stated that G-tube feeding for Client 1 (C1) has been administered by unlicensed healthcare professionals. All five (5) out of five (5) persons interviewed stated that G-tube feeding was only administered by an unlicensed professional in rare instances, when C1 had aggressive behaviors; C1 would take the G-tube out or act aggressively towards the staff members when wanting additional feeding; C1’s aggressive behaviors include: spitting, kicking, and physically hitting. Three (3) direct care staff (S3-S5) interviewed by this LPA stated that they were trained by a licensed professional Registered Nurse (RN) on how to administer the G-tube feeding. Three (3) direct care staff (S3-S5) stated that they did not administer the medications by G-tube and that G-tube medications were only done by a licensed professional RN. During the course of this investigation, the Restricted Health Condition Care Plan for C1 (dated, February 14, 2020) was reviewed by this LPA. The document states that G-tube feeding must be administered by a licensed professional only. Based on a review of documents and interviews with five (5) out of five (5) EBSH representatives; The complaint allegation of, “unlicensed healthcare professional providing licensed healthcare duties and tasks” is Substantiated. Deficiency (Type-A) cited on attached document (LIC 9099-D). (9099-Continued)

Evidence for the allegation, “facility not providing enough staff to meet the needs of the client in care” as follows: Based on a review of documents and interviews with three (3) out of five (5) staff members there have been instances were only two staff members supervised C1. Based on documents reviewed, the preplacement appraisal record (LIC 603, dated 02/18/2019) states that the facility shall maintain a ratio of four (4) staff members as a requirement for the supervision of C1 solely, due to the safety of the client and others at all times. Per S1, three (3) to four (4) staffing ratio for the supervision of C1 was acceptable; Since C1 only works with certain preferred staff members. S1 provided email correspondence (email, dated 02/17/2021) from the San Andreas Regional Center (SARC), which confirmed that three (3) to four (4) preferred staff is acceptable for the supervision of C1. Based on three (3) out of five (5) interviews conducted by this LPA, all three (3) persons interviewed (S3-S5) stated that there has been a two (2) to four (4) staffing ratio for the supervision of C1. Therefore, the complaint allegation of, “facility not providing enough staff to meet the needs of the client in care” is Substantiated. Deficiency (Type-B) cited on attached document (LIC 9099-D). Based on documents reviewed and interviews which were conducted by this LPA, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation(s), “unlicensed healthcare professional providing licensed healthcare duties and tasks” and “facility not providing enough staff to meet the needs of the client in care”, are SUBSTANTIATED. California Code Regulations, Title 22 Division 6 regulations were cited on the attached document (LIC 9099-D). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed. A copy of this report was given to the administrator.

During this investigation LPA Raissi interviewed five (5) EBSH representatives: Staff 1-5 (S1 – administrator [interviewed on 12/16/2020], S2 - House Manager [interviewed on 12/16/2020], S3 - Direct Care Staff [interviewed on 2/10/2021], S4 - Direct Care Staff [interviewed on 2/10/2021], S5 - Direct Care Staff [interviewed on 2/9/2021]). LPA Raissi reviewed the following documents (staff schedules [LIC 500], Needs and Services plan for C1, Behavioral Supports Plan for C1, Restricted Health Condition Care Plan for C1, Preplacement Appraisal for C1 [LIC 603], and email correspondences pertaining to this investigation.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84065.1 (b)(1) Additional Personnel Requirements for Specialized Group Home: (b) No person shall provide specialized in-home health care to a child placed in the home… unless (1) He/she is a licensed health care professional. Based on interviews and documents reviewed, G-tube feeding for C1 was administered by an unlicensed health care professional. Which poses an immediate health and safety risk to the resident in care.

84065.5 (c) Staff/Child Ratios: (c) If the children require special care and supervision because of age, problem behavior or other factors, the number of on-duty childcare staff shall be increased. Based on interviews and documents reviewed, the facility violated Staff/Child Ratios by not providing a three (3) to four (4) staffing ratio for the supervision of C1. Which poses a potential health and safety risk to the resident in care.

narrative:
On February 28, 2022, at 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vaishali Singh-Sood conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required inspection. LPA Singh-Sood met with Administrator, Rowena Caling Nguyen, of Helping Hands Home For Children and both toured the facility, inside and out. The Group Home is licensed to serve four clients, ages 13-16 years. Currently in placement are four clients. During the inspection only two of the clients were present, and both were non-verbal. This facility is a one story house, consists of 4 client bedrooms and 2.5 client bath. LPA Singh-Sood observed at the time of this inspection, the facility to be clean, safe, and sanitary. All fire alarms, and carbon monoxide detectors were in good working condition, and the fire extinguisher is current. This LPA reviewed the staff and client files, medication logs, and they had the necessary forms. The files are kept locked to ensure confidentiality. Food supply, linens and fire extinguisher were observed. There is sufficient perishable food for over two days and nonperishable food for over seven days. Toxins and sharps are properly stored. Medication storage and procedures were also reviewed. The following documents are posted in the facility: facility license, emergency disaster plan, facility sketch, menu, activity calendar and personal rights. The hot water temperature was at (Hall Bathroom 117 degrees). According to the Administrator, there are no weapons, and/or bodies of water at the facility which meets title 22 regulations. There are currently no exceptions on file, and there have not been any deficiencies cited in the past year. A review of Licensing Information System on February 28, 2022 indicates that all facility staff are associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI, and child abuse index check clearances.

Due to COVID 19, this LPA asked about the facility having enough supplies, and proper PPE equipment. This LPA also made sure the facility is following proper hand washing etiquettes, posting signs, and proper protocols regarding anyone going in and out of the facility. The facility advised they have been following all protocols, and have not had any positive cases in the past month. LPA discussed with administrator Caling-Nguyen that some of the clients forms were not signed by authorized representatives. Administrator Caling-Nguyen states there is a plan in place to replace to ensure all paperwork is signed by authorized representatives as soon as possible. There were no Title 22 deficiencies observed at today's inspection. However, an Advisory Note was given for the paperwork that is missing signatures. As such, an exit interview conducted with Ms. Caling-Nguyen and a copy of this report was emailed at 3:30 PM.

On June 11, 2021 at 8:30am, Licensing Program Analysts, (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez and Janeth Chavez conducted an annual required inspection at the facility and met Registered Behavior Technician (RBT) Lead Elsa Montes who gave the LPAs the tour of the facility inside and out. Administrator Mary Watson arrive shortly. The facility is a one-story home with 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. Currently, there are 3 placements in the home. The facility tour inspection started at around 8:45am. LPAs observed the following: The perishable foods enough for at least 2 days consumption and non-perishable foods enough for at least 7 days consumption of the clients stored in the kitchen cabinets and refrigerator and in the garage cabinets and freezer; the facility license, staff schedule, Emergency Disaster Plan and Foster Youth Rights posted in the dining area. There is also a Client Personal Rights posted in the patio area. Each bedroom has one bed with clean beddings, linens, drawers and closet space for the clients' use. There were extra linens and towels stored inside the hallway cabinet. One of the rooms is being used as study room of the clients. There were smoke/carbon monoxide detectors that blinks green in the dining area, living room, hallway and in each bedroom. There were fire alarms and automatic sprinklers also observed in the aforementioned areas in the facility. The water temperature was checked using a digital thermometer and registered 111 degrees Fahrenheit in the first bathroom and 112 degrees Fahrenheit in the second bathroom; within the temperature allowed under Title 22 Regulations. The thermostat control of the centralized heating and air conditioning shows 68 degrees inside the facility. All cleaning solutions were observed locked inside the under-sink cabinet and in the garage and all sharp objects were locked in a drawer in the kitchen. All medications including the First aid kit were stored in a locked cabinet in the living room. The client files were stored in a locked cabinet under the medication cabinet. The LPAs observed the delayed egress doors were working; RBT entered the codes on the keypads and going out through the door on the side of the home and entering through the front door of the home. There were no obstructions observed in the hallways and passageways. The inspection of the building and grounds ended at around 10:30am. Continued to next page...

LPAs reviewed a total of 10 staff and 3 client records. The file review started at 10:45pm and ended at 12:30pm. Out of 10 staff files reviewed, only one staff has no RBT certification and still in the process of getting the RBT certification. The client records were complete with the required authorizations/signatures. An exit interview was conducted and copy of the report was provided to the administrator. No deficiency citations issued at this time.

On June 9, 2022 at 9:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez, conducted an annual/required inspection to the facility and met Dorothy Gonzalez, Administrator. The facility is a one-story home with four bedrooms and three and a half bathrooms, a staff office and attached garage. Currently there are four clients placed in the facility. At the time of LPA's arrival, no client is present. During the inspection, the administrator provided to LPA the roster of clients, Personnel Report, Emergency Disaster Plan, Emergency Drill log and Board Meeting Minutes. Physical Plant LPA started the inspection at about 9:15am. LPA together with staff Jessica Sanchez toured the facility inside and out. LPA observed the following: the posted license, emergency disaster plan, personnel schedule, client personal rights, and grievance procedure. The disinfectants, cleaning solutions, sharp objects are locked and inaccessible to clients. The facility maintains supplies of non-perishable foods for at least a week and fresh perishable foods for at least two days. Each bedroom has a single bed in good repair with clean sheets and linens three drawers and closet space. There are extra linens, adequate towels and hygiene supplies. Only one client sleeps in a room. No room commonly used for other purposes is being used as a bedroom. The window screens are in good repair and free of dirt. There are lights in all the rooms and throughout the facility. The faucets for client’s use deliver hot water (114 degrees Fahrenheit). The fireplace has cover for client's safety. All medications are stored locked in a cabinet. There is a working telephone for clients to use. The first aid kit was complete and readily available. There are working smoke/carbon monoxide detectors in the facility. The delayed egress doors are working. All indoor and outdoor passageways are unobstructed.

Staff Records At 10:15am, LPA reviewed six staff records. The staff records are available to LPA to inspect, audit upon request. All staff subject to criminal records review have been fingerprinted and cleared. There is documentation of the required education and experience requirements and training in the personnel file. One Direct Care Staff (DCS) who has a long experience working with children with developmental disability has not gotten the Registered Behavioral Technician (RBT) certification since hired for this facility but still trying to pass the exam. Licensee is providing support to the staff and also actively trying to hire qualified individuals. Client Record At around 1:00pm, LPA reviewed four client records. All client records are available to LPA to inspect upon request. The client records contain the required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, Individual Program Plan (IPP), medical assessment, safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables, personal rights forms, and medication administration records. : LPA interviewed 2 staff. During the time of inspection, only one client was interviewed. The other client was non-verbal. A technical advisory was issued at the time of the inspection. A copy of the LIC 809, LIC 809C LIC 811s were provided to the administrator.
