On April 3, 2024, at 1:30 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez conducted an unannounced case management inspection to the facility and met Assistant Executive Director, Mary Watson. The inspection was a follow-up to the report received by the Department that the facility has staff not yet certified as Registered Behavioral Technician (RBT). The Department received a report that there were five staff of the facility that are not yet RBT certified. Three out of the five staff not yet certified were within their initial 12-month employment. The remaining two were employed for over 12 months and already outside of the regulatory compliance. Section 89965 (b)(2) Personnel Requirement- The licensee shall ensure that each direct care staff person meets the following qualifications: Become a Registered Behavior Technician within twelve (12) months of initial employment. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the LIC 809, LIC 809D and LIC 811 were provided to the Assistant Executive Director. A deficiency citation was issued at the time of the inspection.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall ensure that each direct care lead staff person meets the following qualifications: Personnel Requirement: Become a Registered Behavior Technician within six months of initial employment,

narrative:
On June 19, 2024, at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez, conducted an annual/required inspection to the facility and met Administrator, Dorothy Gonzalez. There are four (4) clients placed in the facility. During the inspection, LPA requested for the Personnel Report, Client Roster, Emergency Disaster Plan and Board Meeting Minutes. Physical Plant LPA together with Lead Registered Behavior Technician (RBT) Sanchez toured the facility at around 9:15 AM. LPA observed the following: the posted license, emergency disaster plan, personnel schedule, client personal rights, and grievance procedure. The disinfectants, cleaning solutions, sharp objects were locked and inaccessible to the clients. The facility has non-perishable foods for at least seven (7) days and perishable foods for at least two (2) days. Each bedroom has a single bed in good repair with clean sheets and linens and three (3) drawers and closet space for the client's clothing. Only one client sleeps in a room. There were extra linens, towels, and hygiene supplies in the cabinet(s). No room commonly used for other purposes was being used as a bedroom. The window screens were in good repair and free of dirt. There were lights in all the rooms and throughout the facility. The faucets for the children's use deliver hot water. All medications were stored locked in the cabinet. There was a working telephone. The first aid kit was complete. The smoke/carbon monoxide detectors and delayed egress doors were tested and in working order. All indoor and outdoor passageways were unobstructed. Client Record LPA reviewed four (4) client records. All client records were available upon request. The files contain the required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, Individual Program Plan (IPP), medical assessment, safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables, personal rights forms, and medication administration records.

Staff Records LPA reviewed six (6) staff records. All staff subject to criminal records review have been fingerprinted and cleared. There is documentation of the required education and experience requirements and training in the personnel file. The staff meet the required qualification and/or experience requirements. LPA interviewed two (2) staff and one (1) client. A copy of the LIC 809, LIC 809C LIC 811s were provided to the administrator. No deficiency citation issued at the time of the inspection.

On April 30, 2025, at 9:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez, conducted an annual/required inspection to the facility and met Dorothy Gonzalez, Administrator. The facility is a one-story home with four bedrooms and three and a half bathrooms, a staff office and attached garage. Currently there are three (3) clients placed in the facility. At the time of the inspection, no client was present. LPA received a copy of the client roster, LIC 500 (Personnel Report), and Emergency Disaster Plan and reviewed the Emergency Drill log and Board Meeting Minutes. Physical Plant LPA together with the Lead Registered Behavioral Technician (RBT), Jessica Sanchez toured the facility inside and out. LPA observed the following: the posted license, emergency disaster plan, client personal rights, and grievance procedure. The disinfectants, cleaning solutions, sharp objects were locked and inaccessible to clients. There were supplies of non-perishable foods for at least a week and fresh perishable foods for at least two days. Each bedroom has a single bed in good repair with clean sheets and linens and three drawers and closet space. Only one client sleeps in a room. No room commonly used for other purposes is being used as a bedroom. There was extra linens, adequate towels and hygiene supplies in cabinets. The window screens were in good repair and free of dirt. There were lights in all the rooms and throughout the facility. The faucets in clients' bathroom deliver hot water (116 degrees Fahrenheit). The fireplace has cover for client's safety. All medications are stored locked in a cabinet. There is a working telephone for clients to use. The first aid kit was complete and readily available. The smoke/carbon monoxide detectors and delayed egress doors were in working order. A back-up emergency generator was observed in the backyard, available in case of power failure. All indoor and outdoor passageways were unobstructed..

Client Record LPA reviewed three (3) client records. All client records were available upon request. The files contain the required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, Individual Program Plan (IPP), medical assessment, safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables, personal rights forms, and medication administration records. Staff Records LPA reviewed five (5) staff records. All staff subject to criminal records review have been fingerprinted and cleared. There was documentation of the required education and experience requirements and training in the personnel file. The staff meet the required qualification and/or experience requirements. LPA interviewed two (2) staff. A copy of the LIC 809, LIC 809C LIC 811s were provided to the administrator. No deficiency citation issued at the time of the inspection.

On July 08, 2021 at 10:00 AM Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez and LPA Shanae Pharaoh arrived at Merakey-Amanda Enhanced Behavioral Support Home (EBSH). LPA's and LPM met with applicants Administrator Leslie Carter, Assistant Director Alex Brummer and Director Michelle Cozad who led a tour of the home. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct the pre-licensing inspection. The home was toured inside and out with the applicants. Applicants are applying for a maximum capacity of four clients. The home was approved for 2 ambulatory clients and 2 non-ambulatory clients clients age 1-17. The home is a one-story residence with four bedrooms and two bathrooms. The home will serve four clients between the age of 12-17 years old. Bedroom #1 The room consist of a full-size bed, dresser, night stand, and closet space. It sleeps one client- vacant. Bedroom #2 The room consist of a- full-size bed, dresser, night stand, and closet space. It sleeps one client- vacant Bedroom #3 The room consist of full-size bed, dresser, night stand, and closet space. It sleeps one client- vacant Bedroom# 4 the room consist of full-size bed, dresser, night stand, and closet space. It sleeps one client- vacant. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than one child shares a room. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. There is sufficient linens, blankets, towels and pillows. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were working properly. There are two fire extinguisher's in the home, one is located by entrance and one in living room, and both have a current inspection tag. Office will remain locked and staff/client files will be kept on site. Camera's were observed only in common areas. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medication will be locked in hallway cabinet.

Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in a cabinet in the garage. In locked garage there is an extra refrigerator, washer/dryer, emergency supply back pack and extra PPE. There is a lockbox for refrigerated medications. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in the locked kitchen cabinet. First Aid kit was accessible and had all required items including the thermometer. There were no guns or weapons as stated by administrator. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be at 105 degrees. Applicants understands that the water temperature must be maintained within the regulation range of 105-120 degrees. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. Personal Rights, The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan and visitation policy were posted. The backyard was observed to be clean and free of hazards. The facility has two doors with 30 seconds delayed egress. LPA verified and confirmed the delayed egress doors were functional during the inspection. The facility had the emergency intervention plan and emergency evacuation procedures in place. LPM completed the component III Orientation and discussed Incident reporting, including incidents related to Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. Based on this inspection, the home is appropriate for a capacity of 2 ambulatory clients and 2 non-ambulatory clients. LPA observed there was a pool located in the rear of the home. The pool will be covered and applicant will provide pictures of proof the pool has been filled-in, in order to complete the pre-licensing. Once completed, the request of License will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval and pending the Department of Developmental Services Certificate of Program Approval. An Enhanced Behavioral Supports Home shall not be licensed by the Department until the Certificate of Program Approval, granted by the Department of Developmental Services, has been received in accordance with Health and Safety Code section 1567.62. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to applicant this date

On July 28, 2022 at 09:15 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez conducted an unannounced inspection of Merakey-Amanda Enhanced Behavioral Support Home (EBSH). LPA met with Administrator Samantha Chavez and Program Representative Nicole Massie. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct a required annual inspection. The home was toured inside and out. The home is set up for 2 ambulatory clients and 2 non-ambulatory clients clients age 1-17. The home is a one-story residence with four bedrooms and two bathrooms. The current census is two clients between the age of 12-17 years old Bedroom #1 The room consist of a full-size bed, dresser, night stand, and closet space. It sleeps one client- vacant. Bedroom #2 The room consist of a full-size bed, dresser, night stand, and closet space. It sleeps one client (C1). Bedroom #3 The room consist of a full-size bed, dresser, night stand, and closet space. It sleeps one client- vacant. Bedroom# 4 the room consist of a full-size bed, dresser, night stand, and closet space. It sleeps one client (C2). Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than one child shares a room. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. There is sufficient linens, blankets, towels and pillows. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were working properly. There are two fire extinguishers in the home, one is located by entrance and one in living room, and both have a current inspection tag. Office is maintained locked and staff/client files are kept on site. Camera's were observed only in common areas. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medications are locked in hallway cabinet.

Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in a cabinet in the garage. In locked garage there is an extra refrigerator, washer/dryer, emergency supply back pack and extra PPE. There is a lockbox for refrigerated medications. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in the locked kitchen cabinet. First Aid kit was accessible and had all required items including the thermometer. There were no guns or weapons as stated by administrator. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be at 110 degrees and maintained within the regulation range of 105-120 degrees. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. Facility has a work order for repairs being conducted that includes replacing door frames, two bed frames and kitchen cabinets. All required postings were visible: Personal Rights, The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan and visitation policy were posted. The backyard was observed to be clean and free of hazards. The facility has two doors with 30 seconds delayed egress. LPA verified and confirmed the delayed egress doors were functional during the inspection. The facility had the emergency intervention plan and emergency evacuation procedures in place. LPA inspected the physical plant, operational requirements, disaster preparedness, emergency intervention plan and reviewed two of two client files (C1-C2) (see confidential name list, LIC811, dated 07/28/2022) and six of six staff files (S1-S6). LPA conducted three of three staff interviews (S1-S3) and 0 of 2 client interviews (C1-C2). Based on record review, the licensee did not comply as one (C2) of two clients (C1-C2) did not have a copy of the current court order, or written authorization of child's parent or guardian, for each psychotropic medication; and one (C2) of two clients (C1-C2) did not have the results of an examination for communicable tuberculosis and other contagious/infectious diseases which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care. The facility is being issued a citation in accordance with the Title 22, CCR 84070(b)(12) and CCR 80069(c)(1). See LIC809-D dated 07/28/22 for the cited deficiency. An exit interview was conducted, and this report, appeal rights and LIC 811 was reviewed with Program Representative Nicole Massie and a copy of this report was provided.

narrative: On December 08, 2022, at 10:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA's) Eduardo Barragan and Lucero Jauregui went to Merakey-Amanda and met with Nicole Massie, Program Administrator, to assess a Civil Penalty. LPA Barragan conducted a record review on the staff schedule with LPA Chamaine Linley on December 07, 2022, and LPA's noted that there were five staff that did not have a criminal record clearance prior to working at the facility. LPA's reviewed the dates the staff members worked and reviewed Guardian to ensure that staff did not have a criminal record clearance and they didn't. LPA Barragan requested copies staff roster, and asked for any supporting documents the facility may have. Nicole Massie, Program Administrator confirmed that (S1-S5) had been working at the facility. LPA's Barragan and Jauregui are administering five civil penalty's during this visit. The facility is being cited for the violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, regulation 80019(e) Criminal Record Clearance. Record review confirms S1, S2, S3, S4 and S5 have worked in the facility without a criminal record clearance. An immediate civil penalty is being issued for $500. An exit interview was conducted with Nicole Massie, Program Administrator. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Nicole Massie, Program Administrator

narrative: On September 15, 2022, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that the staff is not trained to care for clients. It was reported that clients have been outside of the facility and staff cannot de-escalate the clients. It was reported that C1 had a bat and hit the staff with the bat and the following day C1 had access to a pipe and attacked the staff. Based on confidential interviews and records revealed C1 has a history of aggressive behavior. Confidential interviews and records reviewed revealed that C1 hit S3 with their hands, S3 fell down and C1 attempted to hit S1 with their arm. Confidential records revealed S4 and S5 had not been trained on the facility’s approved Emergency Intervention Training until after the incident occurred. Confidential interviews and records reviewed staff members were not hit with a bat or pipe during this incident. Based on confidential interviews, records reviewed, and the facility’s program statement, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met regarding the allegation that staff is not trained to care for clients. This posed a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to C1 in care, the facility will be cited for violating Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, 89965(i). Personnel Requirements. An exit interview was conducted and appeal rights were discussed with Nicole Massie, Facility Administrator. Due to printer malfunction, a copy of this report, along with the LIC 811, and appeal rights will be emailed to the Facility Administrator. A signed copy of this report will be kept in the Facility file.
