This requirement is not met as evidenced by: The facility did not train S4 and S5 in

narrative: Documents reviewed indicated that the work orders have taken months to fulfill. Confidential interviews and observations revealed there are cabinets with no doors in the kitchen, broken windows and holes in the wall covered with plywood. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that facility is in disrepair and facility is unkempt are SUBSTANTIATED because the preponderance of evidence has been met. This posed an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care, the facility will be cited for violating Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 07. Physical Environment, Buildings and Grounds 80087 (a)The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. An exit interview was conducted, and plan of corrections was developed with Nicole Massie, Administrator. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Nicole Massie, Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On May 25, 2023, at 8:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui conducted an unannounced complaint inspection. The purpose of the inspection is to deliver the findings for the above allegation. LPA Jauregui met with Nicole Massie, Administrator. LPA Marisol Lopez conducted an inspection of the facility on March 3, 2023, and no deficiencies were noted. During the investigation, LPA Lopez obtained list of work orders and conducted five staff interviews (S1-S5). LPA Adrian Mendez conducted one staff interview and one client interview (S1, C1) and LPA Jauregui conducted record review of Amanda Lane Work Orders. On March 15, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received the allegations that facility is in disrepair and facility is unkempt. Confidential interviews revealed C1 has behaviors and engages in property destruction daily where it has become difficult to keep up with repairs. Confidential interviews revealed there is only staff conducting maintenance at the facility. CONTINUED....

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Buildings and Grounds (a)The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. This requirement was not met based on: Based on observations, confidential interviews, and record review, the facility had cabinets with no doors in the kitchen, broken windows and holes in the wall covered with plywood, and work orders delayed, which poses an immediate health and safety risks to persons in care.

narrative: It was stated that C2 was not provided dental care. Confidential interviews revealed C2 was taken to the dentist by biological mother on 9/27/22, however, there was no follow up appointment for wisdom teeth removal. Confidential interviews and documents reviewed revealed that staff took C2 to an appointment to receive a wisdom teeth consultation till 2/09/23; It was unclear to the delay of the appointment. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that staff are not competent to provide the services necessary to meet C2’s needs while in care may or may not have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Nicole Massie, Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On June 13 2023, at 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui conducted an unannounced complaint inspection. The purpose of the inspection is to deliver the findings for the above allegation. LPA Jauregui met with Nicole Massie, Administrator. LPA Marisol Lopez conducted an inspection of the facility on November 3, 2022, and no deficiencies were noted. During the investigation, LPA Lopez obtained incident reports, current client roster and staff roster with contact information, conducted one staff interview (P1) and one client interview (C1). LPA Adrian Mendez conducted one staff interview and one client interview (S2, C1) and LPA Jauregui conducted one client interview (C2), one staff interview (S2), and document review of C1 and C2s dental records. On October 31 ,2022, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received the allegation that staff are unable to meet the needs of minor(s) in care. CONTINUED....

narrative: Confidential interviews indicated C1 needs assistance wiping, getting dressed, and to shower. Confidential interviews indicated when C1 is done using the bathroom, staff wipe until C1 no longer allows them to. Confidential interview indicated C1 allows staff to wipe as much as C1 can tolerate. Confidential interviews indicated C1 walks away and that means that C1 no longer wants to be wiped. Confidential interviews indicated staff would try again with wiping until C1 allows them to. Confidential interviews indicated staff wipe until the wipe is no longer dirty. Confidential interview indicated showers are offered by turning on the shower and guiding C1 to it. According to confidential interviews, sometimes staff’s attempt works, and other times it does not. Confidential interviews indicated rashes and redness are common on C1. Confidential interview indicated C1 gets a rash on the inside of their thighs. Confidential interview indicated they have observed C1 get a rash after sprinting. Confidential interviews indicated staff apply ointment the best they can to address the skin irritation. Confidential interview indicated it can get difficult for staff to apply ointment in that area due to C1 not following direction, walking around while staff make attempts, and C1 bending over for only a few seconds. Confidential interview indicated C1 sometimes allows staff or sometimes pushes them away. Confidential interview indicated the facility asked to use moisture barrier cream for rashes, however, according to confidential interview, staff were denied by C1’s authorized representative. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that facility staff did not ensure minor's hygiene needs were met may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this signed report and appeal rights were provided to Elizabeth Gauci.
investigation_findings: 13On March 24, 2025 at 10:53 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui arrived at the facility unannounced and met with Elizabeth Gauci to discuss the investigative finding for the allegation noted above. LPA Jauregui and LPA Abby Saeteurn conducted an inspection of the facility on August 14, 2024, and no deficiencies were noted. During the investigation, LPA Jauregui interviewed six staff (S1-S4, S8-S9), one witness and two San Diego Regional Center Representatives. C1 was unable to be interviewed due to their limited verbal abilities. Pertinent documents were obtained. On August 12, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received allegation that facility staff did not ensure minor's hygiene needs were met. It was reported that during a visit, C1’s relative noticed C1 had feces stuck to their groin area. It was reported that C1 was not properly wiped and that C1’s skin appeared irritated and red. CONTINUED....

narrative:
It was reported that staff did not maintain accurate records. It was reported that S4 is not accurately documenting incidents. Confidential interview indicated C1’s initial Individual Behavior Support Plan (IBSP) contained incorrect information regarding C1’s previous placements. Record review confirmed C1’s previous placement and is in accordance with C1’s Individual Behavior Support Plan (IBSP). It was reported that staff did not administer medication as prescribed. It was report that staff is not administering the correct dosages of medication to C1. It was reported that C1 had an adverse reaction to a medication given causing C1 to shake and have vocalization. Confidential interviews indicated medication is administered by one staff member and verified by a second staff member. Confidential interviews indicated medication has been administered correctly. Confidential interview indicated C1’s medication was changed by a medical professional, which resulted in C1 having a change in their body posture and movement. Confidential interview indicated there was a follow up appointment and C1’s medication was changed. It was reported that staff did not seek medical attention for minor in a timely manner. It was reported that C1 had an episode due to administration of an incorrect dosage of medication, and staff did not seek medical attention. Confidential interviews indicated that C1 has seizures that are documented. Record review indicated staff are to call for emergency services if the seizures last longer than 5 minutes or more seizures in a 30-minute time frame. The investigation did not yield evidence that C1’s seizure lasted longer than 5 minutes or that multiple seizures occurred within 30 minutes. It was reported that licensee did not ensure that facility phone was operable for minors in care. It was reported that the phones remained inoperable for more than four days and staff did not return phone calls. Confidential interviews indicated there is a phone located in the staff office in the common area of the facility. Confidential interviews indicated there are unexpected power outages where the landline and wi-fi is down. Confidential interview indicated the phone line has been down up to 24 hours at a time, and if clients want to use the phone during an outage, clients have personal cell phones that can be used if necessary. CONTINUED.....

Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, the allegations that staff did not maintain accurate records, staff did not administer medication as prescribed, staff did not seek medical attention for minor in a timely manner, and licensee did not ensure that facility phone was operable for minors in care, may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this signed report and appeal rights were provided to Elizabeth Gauci.
investigation_findings: 13On July 1, 2025 at 10:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui arrived at the facility unannounced and met with Elizabeth Gauci to discuss the investigative finding for the allegations noted above. LPA Jauregui conducted an inspection of the facility on September 27, 2024, and no deficiencies were noted. During the investigation, LPA Jauregui interviewed five staff (S1-S3, S5-S6). LPA attempted to interview C1 but was unable to obtain a statement due to child’s limited verbal abilities. Pertinent documents were obtained. On September 20, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received allegations staff did not maintain accurate records, staff did not administer medication as prescribed, staff did not seek medical attention for minor in a timely manner, and licensee did not ensure that facility phone was operable for minors in care. CONTINUED....

narrative:
On July 18, 2025 at 8:40 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui conducted an inspection of the facility. LPA met with Joey Rios, Lead Direct Support Professional who provided LPA with an indoor tour of the facility. LPA met with Nicole Massie, Administrator who provided and outdoor tour of the faciliy. The home is set up for 2 ambulatory clients and 2 non-ambulatory clients clients age 1-17. The home is a one-story residence with four bedrooms and two bathrooms which is set up as followed: Bedroom #1 The room consist of a full-size bed, dresser, night stand, and closet space. It sleeps one client (C2) Bedroom #2 The room consist of a full-size bed, dresser, night stand, and closet space. It sleeps one client and currently vacant. Bedroom #3 The room consist of a full-size bed, dresser, night stand, and closet space. It sleeps one client and currently vacant. Bedroom# 4 the room consist of a full-size bed, dresser, night stand, and closet space. It sleeps one client (C1). Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than one child shares a room. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. There is sufficient linens, blankets, towels and pillows. There are two fire extinguishers in the home, one is located by the entrance and one in the living room, and both have a current inspection tag. Office is maintained locked and staff/client files are kept on site. There are 4 cameras in common areas of the facility, and 5 in the exterior of the facility. CONTINUED....

All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in a cabinet in the garage. In locked garage there is an extra refrigerator, washer/dryer, emergency supply back pack.. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in the locked kitchen cabinet in a lock box. Medication is maintained in the staff office and staff office is inaccessible to clients. First Aid kit was accessible and had all required items. There were no guns or weapons as stated by administrator. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be at 112.6 degrees and maintained within the regulation range of 105-120 degrees. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. All required postings were visible: Personal Rights, The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, and Facility Policies. The backyard was observed to be clean and free of hazards. The facility has two doors with 30 seconds delayed egress. LPA verified and confirmed the delayed egress doors were functional during the inspection. The facility had the emergency intervention plan and emergency evacuation procedures in place. LPA inspected the physical plant, operational requirements, disaster preparedness, emergency intervention plan and reviewed two of two client files (C1-C2) (see confidential name list, LIC811, dated 07/18/24) and five of five staff files (S1-S5). LPA conducted two out of two staff interviews (S2-S4) and 0 of 2 client interviews (C1-C2) due to the clients limited verbal abilities. Based on today's inspections there are no deficiencies cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this signed report and LIC 811 was provided to Nicole Massie, Administrator. .

It was reported that staff did not comply with reporting requirements. It was reported that the facility failed to report seizures within a 24-hour agreement period. It was also reported that the facility did not report C1’s injuries from falls. Confidential interview indicated seizures have been reported via telephone to the client’s authorized representative within 24 hours and emergency services have been contacted if C1 needed to be transported to the hospital. It was reported that staff did not ensure the facility was free from pests. It was reported that there was an ant infestation in the facility with black ants crawling on the wall and in client bedrooms. Confidential interviews indicated during the summer there were issues with ants entering the facility. Confidential interviews indicated the issue was addressed by pest control. Record review indicated the facility has a contract with pest control which serviced the home to address the ants. It was reported that staff did not provide minor with drinking water. It was reported that there was no water provided to clients to drink, and kitchen cabinets were locked due to client behaviors. Confidential interviews indicated C1 has a water bottle to take on van rides. Confidential interviews indicated staff offer C1 water throughout the day. Confidential interviews indicated kitchen cabinets were locked for safety at times when a client had behaviors engaging in property damage in the kitchen. Confidential interviews denied water being denied to clients. It was reported that staff did not provide information to minor’s authorized representative upon request. It was reported that medical information was not provided to C1’s authorized representative when requested. It was reported that information could only be provided by the Administrator. Confidential interviews indicated Direct Support Professionals were allowed to provide information relative to events that occurred during their shift to avoid providing inaccurate information. Confidential interviews indicated that, although information was not provided or required to be provided upon request, information was provided to C1’s authorized representative by the end of the day. CONTINUED.....

Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, the allegations that staff did not comply with reporting requirements, staff did not ensure the facility was free from pests, staff did not provide minor with drinking water, and staff did not provide information to minor’s authorized representative upon request, may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this signed report and appeal rights were provided to Elizabeth Gauci.

It was reported that the battery in C1’s communication device would be dead with no way of charging it. Confidential interviews indicated that C1’s clothes were accessible; however, C1 chose not to use them. Confidential interviews indicated C1’s communication device is was always accessible to C1. Record review indicated that staff were to charge C1’s communication device overnight and make it accessible to C1. Confidential interview indicated there were times when C1’s communication device was not charged overnight, and the device was not available for use by C1 because the battery was dead. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation that staff withheld minor’s personal belongings is SUBSTANTIATED because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. This posed potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to youth in care. The facility is being cited for violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5 Article 06. Continuing Requirements 84078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. [SEE LIC9099D]. An exit interview was conducted and Plan of Corrections was developed with Elizabeth Gauci and Nicole Massie, Administrator. A copy of this signed report, LIC9099D and appeal rights were provided to Elizabeth Gauci. .
investigation_findings: 13On July 1, 2025 at 11:16 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui arrived at the facility unannounced and met with Elizabeth Gauci and Nicole Massie, Administrator to discuss the investigative finding for the allegations noted above. LPA Jauregui conducted an inspection of the facility on September 27, 2024, and no deficiencies were noted. During the investigation, LPA Jauregui interviewed five staff (S1-S3, S5-S6). LPA attempted to interview Client 1 (C1) but was unable to obtain a statement due to child’s limited verbal abilities. Pertinent documents were obtained. On September 23, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received allegations staff did not comply with reporting requirements, staff did not ensure the facility was free from pests, staff did not provide minor with drinking water, and staff did not provide information to minor’s authorized representative upon request. CONTINUED...

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (b) The licensee shall provide those services identified in each child's needs and services plan and in the individualized health care plan for each child with special health care needs as necessary to meet the child's needs. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed the licensee did not ensure that communication device to be operable to 1 of 2 clients in care (C1), which posed a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to person in care.

narrative:
A pre-licensing inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tana Kinder on 1/23/2023 with the facility Administrator. Criminal record clearances were reviewed, and the facility is in compliance. Community Care Licensing file, incident reports, facility roster, facility profile and complaint history were reviewed prior to visit at the agency. The licensing fees are current. The EBSH Facility has a capacity of four. There is 1 staff member associated to the Merakey-Justamere license and 44 associated to the Walk of Life-Justamere license. There are 2 clients residing at the facility under the Walk of Life-Justamere License. There were 5 staff working at the EBSH Facility at the time of the inspection. LPA reviewed 1 staff file, which was complete and up to date. The staff file reviewed had required training hours, education, administrator certification and fingerprint clearance. Personal rights, menu, Walk of Life-Justamere License and emergency exit plan were posted. The facility was inspected jointly with Teja Ordonez-Phillips, facility Administrator of the EBSH Facility. There are 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. Each client's bedroom had a firm mattress, with a bed cover, sheets, blanket and pillows. Additionally, there is a sensory room for the clients to play in. The common area has couches and chairs to sit in, a TV and an in-door basketball hoop game for the clients. The facility is in good repair. There are cabinets in the laundry room with additional linen if needed for the bedrooms and the bathrooms. Additionally, each bedroom also has extra linen available. Client and staff files are in locked cabinets, in a locked office. The passageways from the front to the back of the facility are unobstructed. LPA observed 2 locked sheds in the backyard with facility supplies and client belongings and 1 locked shed with toys/equipment for the clients. LPA observed enough perishable/non-perishable food for 2 clients for 4 days/2 weeks. Smoke detectors are in working order. There is a carbon monoxide monitor and 2 fully charged and current fire extinguishers. continued...

Disinfectants and cleaning solutions were in a locked cabinet in the laundry room. Sharps were kept locked in the office. The kitchen was stocked with plates, utensils and drinking cups sufficient for 4 clients. The water temperature from the bathroom faucet was 113.7 degrees. Medication disbursement is logged using the program, Quick MAR and is cross reconciled with the bubble packs and bottles medications are stored in. The client's hygiene kits were stocked and stored in a locked cabinet in the bathroom. A fully stocked first aid kit is kept in the staff office. The back fence between the garden and the shed was missing slats and will be replaced. The fertilizer and paintings in the shed for the clients to access their toys will be moved to the storage shed at the back of the grounds. A box or other system/location will be implemented to store extra monthly medications separately from the medications that are currently being used. Exit interview conducted and discussed with the facility Administrator. A copy of the pre-licensing inspection report was provided to the Administrator.

On September 20, 2023, at 1:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Shalisa Stiger made an unannounced visit to conduct a case management regarding an incident report received by The Department on 09/15/2023 regarding medication error resulting from an on site visit from Department of Developmental Services. LPA met with the Administrator who assisted with the inspection. The facility consists of 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. Each client's bedroom has a bed, dresser and closet space for belongings. The common area has couches and chairs to sit in, a TV and sensory rooms for crafts and activities. The facility is clean and in good repair. Client and staff files are in locked cabinets, in a locked office. The passageways from the front to the back of the facility are unobstructed. LPA observed perishable/non-perishable food for clients and the facility will do a grocery run today. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions were in a locked cabinet under kitchen sink. Sharps were kept locked in the office. Medication is stored and locked in the medication office. Lastly, LPA Stiger observed the backyard consisting of a basketball hoop, sitting areas, and musical sensory equipment. The backyard was clean and free from debris. LPA Stiger observed medication(s) and MAR documentation corrections. LPA observed the medication timeframe showing 8am-8pm on bubble packs and correction was made in log. The Administrator advised LPA Stiger the LVN will receive documentation training by Alta region. Additionally, lead staff is due to be re-trained in Medication passing and signing by 9/22/2023 and all staff will be re-trained in medication on 9/27/2023. The facility wrote an incident report and submitted it to the Department on 9/13/2023. LPA Stiger observed and obtained a copy of the SIR. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the Administrator. This case management investigation is closed.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Eunice conducted a Post Licensing inspection to the above Group Home and met with the above named individual. LPA observed the following items posted: - Personal Rights - Emergency Disaster - Exit signs - Foster Care Bill of Rights - Facility Sketch with emergency exit routes identified This Group Home (GH) has 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms; one bathroom is used for non-ambulatory clients. This GH has an office space, this office space is equipped computers, a copier, desks, chairs, locking cabinets, paper and usual office supplies (pens, paper, etc.). The home has a working telephone. During today's visit there are 3 children placed and this facility employes 20 staff. The staff to child ratios are: 2 to 1 for one client, and the two other clients have 1 to 1 supervision. The kitchen is clean, there is a menu binder, cups, plates, and cook ware. The Administrator indicates staff utilize Ukeru pads in an emergency; LPA observed 8 of them throughout the home. The program allows restraints, but no child placed currently needs/or has been restrained. Additionally, the program can accept children with special health care needs and those with incontinence; one child uses a wheel chair. Client and staff files are kept in locked cabinets to maintain confidentiality. There are three emergency exits, a first aid kit, and 2 fire extinguishers. There are 2 living rooms where children/families can interact. The furniture is in good repair and clean.

LPA obtained a roster of staff. LPA obtained a LIC 500 and ensured individuals listed are fingerprint cleared using the Guardian database. LPA obtained Ms. Phillips' Administrator Certificate and interviewed staff and children. LPA reviewed children Medications are properly stored, locked and logged onto a medication form. This home has two sensory rooms with soft pillows, furniture, kinetic sand, lights, etc. This facility has a non ambulatory wheel chair with big soft wheels so a client can go onto grass, sand and rocks. This facility meets Interim Licensing Standards mandates and is clean safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPA recommends the facility obtains permanent license with management approval.

met_with: Lead RBT, Lawrence Williams Administrator, Teja Ordonez-Phillips
narrative:
On April 4, 2024 at approximately 09:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Farhaan Sarangi arrived unannounced for the purpose of conducting a Annual/Required inspection. LPA was greeted at the door by Lead RBT, Lawrence Williams, and was granted access into the facility. Administrator, Teja Ordonez-Phillips arrived 1 hour later. During a file review, LPA observed that the Administrators Certificate expired on March 24, 2024 (See LIC 9102-Technical Assistance). Administrator is in the process of renewing the Administrators Certificate and showed proof to the LPA. Clients were not present at the facility during this Annual/Required inspection. Clients were at their respective educational institution. LPA and Lead RBT, Lawrence Williams toured the facility at 09:15 AM. LPA observed the facility to be clean and at a comfortable temperature with all exits free from obstruction. During the tour, LPA observed that 2 of 2 fire extinguishers are not up to date (See LIC 9102-Technical Violation). LPA inspected 4 of 4 rooms and found those rooms to be appropriate. LPA observed linens on beds. The following documents were posted: License, Personal Rights, and Emergency Disaster Plan. Currently the facility has 2 ambulatory clients and 1 non-ambulatory client in care. LPA observed that the one non-ambulatory client is residing in Room #3. There was a sufficient supply of both perishable and nonperishable foods as required by Title 22 Regulations. Food stored in the kitchen refrigerator were properly stored as per regulations at the time of the inspection. There was a supply of cleaners, hygiene products and paper products available for clients. All bathrooms designated for clients in the common areas at the facility were supplied with individual paper towels and hand soap dispensers. Bathrooms were equipped with necessary grab bars, and non-slip floors/mats were present. A tour of all clients bedrooms were conducted, and bedrooms inspected have lighting and appropriate furnishing. Facility medication room at the facility was locked and inaccessible to clients in care. Toxins, hazardous items and sharps are inaccessible to clients in care. First Aid kit was inspected and found to be appropriate during the inspection. All client medication orders and medication administration records were reviewed and found to be appropriate during the review. (Report continued on LIC 809C)

LPA reviewed a sample of staff files. Staff files consisted of: Criminal record clearances, Active First Aid Certificate, Job title/qualifications, and training hours which were verified during this Annual/Required inspection. LPA reviewed Client Records which consisted of: Needs and Service plan, Individual Behavior Support Plan, Physician Assessment Report, Admission Agreements, Personal Rights, Medical Consent Forms and the Individual Program Plan (IPP) provided by Alta California Regional Center. Medical history were updated. P & I was reviewed. LPA and Administrator observed that the 1 of 3 client P & I records were not up to date. The amount of money balance should be $685.68 as reflected in the P & I. Administrator counted the money which only contained $125.68. (See LIC 809D and LIC 812-Observation/Photo dated for April 4, 2024). During the record review, a Non-Ambulatory client record revealed that a in-home health care nurse attends to the clients needs on a part-time basis. The in-home health agreement was secured in the clients file, reviewed and found to be appropriate. LPA requested the following documents to be sent: LIC 500- Personnel Report LIC 308- Designation of Responsibility LIC 309- Administrative Organization LIC 400- Affidavit regarding Client Cash Resources Most up-to-date Liability insurance Control of Property Register of Clients Annual Continuation will be conducted at a later date and time which will include Staff interviews and client interviews, Emergency Disaster Plan review and Emergency Interventions will be discussed at a date and time. Deficiencies cited from the California Code of Regulations. Appeal Rights were given. Failure to correct the deficiency and/or repeated deficiencies within a 12-month period may result in Civil Penalties. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was signed and given to the Administrator.

On May 28, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sara Luman-Gonzalez arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting a case management inspection. LPA arrived and was greeted outside by staff member Velma. Once inside, Alisya Bowles, Lead II (S1), greeted LPA and invited them to set up at the dinner table. S1 informed that two clients were present in the home. LPA observed five to six staff, as two had left with a client during LPA's visit. LPA reviewed all four (4) clients records and Staff training(s) pertaining to clients conditions. LPA observed the following: 1 out of 4 did not have a Needs and Services Plan within 30 days of placement(See LIC 9102 TV), 4 out of 4 No Dental information was observed on the face sheet and no contact information was found throughout the clients files (See LIC 9102 TV), LIC622B's for 3 out of 4 clients were not completed correctly (See LIC 9102 TV). LPA observed the staff training regarding each individual client and how to meet their needs. LPA inquired with S1 if this was done as a hands on training or online. S1 stated that it was done via online. LPA inquired about the individuals who were not present at the time of the training, S1 stated that they would cover this training with those individuals in the all hands meeting as some already have approved leave. LPA reviewed these violations with S1. These changes will be discussed during a meeting and changes will be implemented. Written certificate of these changes will be sent in to LPA by June 11, 2024. An exit interview was conducted and Appeal Rights were printed and discussed with Staff.

Of the three clients interviewed, one reported snack was not provided consistently, one reported snacks were provided too often, and the third reported that snacks were accessible, but another client would eat all the snacks. While the kitchen fridge was temporarily broken, clients needed staff assistance to access the spare fridge in the locked garage. During the facility inspection, LPA observed sufficient food and large boxes of snacks accessible to the clients. Regarding the allegation of: Staff did not ensure that facility refrigerator is repaired,18 confidential interviews reported that the refrigerator in the kitchen broke, but the facility had an extra refrigerator in the garage where all the perishable food was stored. The new refrigerator was ordered, and it was shipped in 3 days. All 18 interviews reported that although the clients didn’t have access to a refrigerator in the facility, they had access to the refrigerator in the garage. LPA observed the newly replaced kitchen fridge, as well as the back-up fridge in the garage. Regarding the allegation of: Facility does not follow the required ratio for minors in care, consistent statements were made during interviews that when the facility is out of ratio, a staff is asked to stay late or come in early. Staff leads are the floaters and are to assist with supervision when short staffed to maintain ratio. Leads will report to the Administrator and the Administrator will make calls to staff from other facilities and upper management to ensure ratio is maintained. LPA reviewed the staff schedule and observed ratio to have been maintained. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews, and record reviews, although the allegations may have happened, or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violations did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report and LIC-9099C were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights were provided.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sara Luman-Gonzalez arrived unannounced at the facility on this date for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA met with Malia Iulio, Shift Lead. LPA Vue conducted the complaint investigation. LPA Vue opened the investigation with the facility on 04/30/2024 and conducted a Health and Safety Inspection. During the course of the investigation, LPAs Vue and Thorn conducted eighteen (18) confidential interviews, including 13 current and former staff, and 3 clients. LPA Vue reviewed records from the facility including most current Needs and Service Treatment Plan or IPP, prior complaint history, and Serious Incident Reports. LPA also reviewed additional records such as Staff Schedule, Staff Contact Information, Client Safeguarded Cash Resources Records, and LIC 500. During interviews conducted and records reviewed regarding the allegation of: Facility does not allow minors to have access to food, statements provided were inconsistent. There was no concern reported of the provision of meals. (Cont. on LIC 9099C)

narrative: One client out of three interviewed, alleged they were restrained ten times and the restraints were not warranted. Upon review of the Serious Incident Report submitted about the three restraints, LPA found the restraints were properly documented and reported, and followed regulatory procedures, to maintain the safety of the client and other clients present. Based on LPA’s interviews which were conducted and records reviewed, although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violation did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and appeal rights were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sara Luman-Gonzalez arrived unannounced at the facility on this date for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA met with Malia Iulio, Shift Lead. LPA Aleza Ruiz conducted the complaint investigation. LPA Ruiz and LPM Hillary Hall opened the investigation with the facility on 6/14/2024 and met with Teja Ordonez-Phillips, Administrator. During the course of the investigation, LPA and LPM interviewed three current staff. LPA reviewed records including: Placement Roster, Training logs, Serious Incident Reports, and Needs and Service Plans/Individualized placement plans for clients. LPA also reviewed prior complaint history including 13 current and former staff interviews and three client interviews. Interviews with staff were inconsistent regarding the details of an incident where a client was restrained three times in one day. Record review indicated a total of three restraints were documented for one client, and zero for the other three clients, which was corroborated by staff interviews. (Cont. on LIC 9099C)

narrative: On 07/21/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon initiated this EBSH's (Enhanced Behavioral Supports Home) Annual Inspection and was assisted by Direct Support Professional Leads (DSP) Grandison Luke and LaDonya Reed--a tour of the interior and exterior grounds of the facility's physical plant was given and direct-care staffers were interview. This annual inspection is to be continued at a later time.

On the matter of lack of intervention to mitigate self-harming (including accessibility to a metal backscratcher), sufficient records of a client’s medical condition were found, along with statements from staff, that should’ve reasonably informed the appropriate care and supervision that staff should have provided to the client— the client’s wounds worsening could reasonably be attributed to having given access to a potentially harmful object. As for staff not following a minor’s care plan, records indicate that there was insufficient compliance to the plans nor was there enough follow-up done by healthcare professionals that the facility has on staff. Based on LPA’s review of records and interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore the above allegations are found to be Substantiated. CCR (California Code of Regulations) Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6 Section 80078(a) and Chapter 5, Article 6 Section 84078(b) are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. A copy of this report is being provided to the facility along with the Appeal Rights; exit interview conducted.

LPA confirmed the receipt of, and reviewed, an incident report submitted by the facility regarding the client in question—in the report, a date as early as 03/30/2025 was referenced in which the client was taken to a medical facility for assessment of a wound. The report indicated that the authorized representative was notified of events having to do with the seeking of medical care from that date up to the date of hospitalization. However, due to the nature of the wound’s progress, earlier communication could have been made by the facility with the authorized representative and/or individuals attached to the case. Not enough corroborating evidence was found to support the allegation that the facility did not ensure a minor attended school; the interviewed client, themselves, stated that there was “never a problem going to school,” and that a bus picked the youth up regularly. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur; therefore, the allegations are Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility
investigation_findings: 13On 08/15/2025, at 2:15 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this Group Home to deliver the findings of, and close, the complaint investigation. LPA met with Administrator Harrisha Willis and Lead DSP LaDonya Reed and the following report was discussed: On 04/21/2025 LPA initiated the complaint investigation into allegations that 1) Staff did not prevent minor from self harming, 2) Staff did not prevent minor from having access to a harmful object, and 3) Staff are not following minor’s care plan. Multiple onsite inspections were conducted throughout the course of the investigation wherein interviews were conducted in-person with staff and youth. Additional interviews were conducted with clients’ family members and other personnel attached to the clients’ cases. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. "The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs." This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and a records review, the facility failed to provide the appropriate level of care and/or supervision to a client w/ compromised health conditions. This poses an immediate Health and Safety risk to clients in care.

Responsibility for Providing Care & Supervision. "The licensee shall provide...services identified in [the] needs & services plan & in the...health care plan...as necessary to meet the child's needs." This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and a records review, the facility failed to adhere to, and include, healthcare elements in a client's encompassing Needs & Services Plan. This pose an immediate Health and Safety risk to clients in care.

narrative:
Statements independently obtained from multiple interviewees, along with documented reports from involved service providers, corroborate repeat instances of staff sleeping while on shift and in ratio for the provision of care and supervision to clients. Based on LPA’s interviews and a records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore, the allegation is found to be Substantiated. California Code of Regulations (CCR) Title 22, Div. 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Section 84065.2(b)(1) is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report is being provided to the facility along with the Appeal Rights.

The referenced client had purportedly purchased a vehicle with their own money in a transaction that was done during an approved outing. Not enough evidence was found to reasonably hold the facility accountable for not being able to advise the client against engaging in such a transaction. Regarding a possible reporting requirement deficiency, not enough information was available to support there being a reporting non-compliance within the context of staffing decisions that the facility made. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur; therefore, the allegations are Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 08/15/2025 at 3:30 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this Group Home to deliver the findings of, and close, the complaint investigation. LPA met with Administrator Harrisha Willis and Lead DSP LaDonya Reed and the following report was discussed: On 04/21/2025 LPA initiated the complaint investigation into an allegation that Facility did not provide the appropriate level of care and/or supervision. Multiple onsite inspections were conducted throughout the course of the investigation wherein interviews were conducted in-person with staff and youth. Additional interviews were conducted with clients’ family members and other personnel attached to the clients’ cases. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personnel Duties. "Child care staff shall perform the following duties: Supervision, protection and care of children individually and in groups at all times." This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and a records review, facility staff were directly observed by multiple outside individuals, and on more than one occasion, appearing to sleep while on duty. This poses a potential Health and Safety risk to clients in care.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman and LPA Shoua Xiong made an announced tele-inspection Pre-Licensing visit to the facility on 2/25/2021 at 12:30 PM and met with the Administrator - Chanese Thompson and the Regional Director - Virginia Gabby. This inspection was conducted virtually via Microsoft Teams due to COVID-19 restrictions. LPAs inspected the facility inside and outside and observed the facility is a single story, four-bedroom home that will accommodate four clients. The home is equipped with cooking utensils, dishes, pots and pans, sitting furniture, TVs and Game Boards. The kitchen has a microwave, toaster, and a house phone available for the clients. Sharps were observed to be locked in a drawer and cleaning solutions locked in a cabinet. LPAs observed a dining table that sits six comfortably. LPAs observed the smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detector are hardwired to the home and are combined together. LPAs observed the smoke detectors are located in the living room, hallway and in each bedroom and all are functioning properly. LPAs observed there are two fire extinguishers that has been serviced within the last 12 months. LPAs observed each bedroom has a full-size bed with mattress protector, mattress pad, sheets, pillows and comforter on the beds and there are extra sheets, pillowcases, comforters and blankets available for each bed. Each bedroom has a nightstand with a lamp, dressers, and closets containing hangers and a laundry basket for each client. LPAs observed the facility has hygiene supplies for each client and extra hygiene supplies. LPAs observed the facility has a locked cabinet and a locked refrigerator to store medications. LPAs observed the facility sketch, disaster plan, sample menu, LIC500 and activity schedule are all posted. The facility also has Client Personal Rights and COVID-19 related posters throughout the home. LPAs observed that the backyard contained two sheds. One of the shed was locked and observed to be used as storage. The second shed which was currently unlocked and empty will be used to store sensory activities and games for clients. LPAs inspected the facility vehicle van and observed it to be in good condition with current registration and proof of insurance. There were no observable safety concerns during this inspection. Exit interviews were conducted. LPAs are recommending the licensure of this facility effective 2/25/21. Due to technical difficulties, LPAs were not able to generate the Pre-Licensing report at the end of the inspection. On today's date, 2/26/21, technical issues were resolved, and LPAs were able to generate this report and provide a copy via email to both the Administrator and Regional Director. LPAs requested for this report to be signed and scanned back via email.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shoua Xiong conducted an announced tele-inspection visit to the facility on May 28, 2019. Due to COVID-19, this inspection was conducted via FaceTime. LPA met with the Administrator, Chanese Thomas, for the purpose of completing a follow-up Prelicensnig inspection. This facility is a single story, four-bedroom home that will accommodate four clients. The home is equipped with cooking utensils, dishes, pots and pans, sitting furniture, TVs and Game Boards. The kitchen has a microwave, toaster, and a house phone available for the clients. Sharps were observed to be locked in a drawer and cleaning solutions locked in a cabinet. LPA observed a dining table that sits six comfortably. LPA observed the smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detector are hardwired to the home and are combined together. LPA observed the smoke detectors are located in the living room, hallway and in each bedroom and all are functioning properly. LPA observed there are two fire extinguishers that has been serviced within the last 12 months. LPA observed each bedroom has a full-size bed with mattress protector, mattress pad, sheets, pillows and comforter on the beds and there are extra sheets, pillowcases, comforters and blankets available for each bed. Each bedroom has a night stand with a lamp, dressers, and closets containing hangers and a laundry basket for each client. LPA observed the facility sketch, disaster plan, sample menu, LIC500 and activity schedule are all posted. The facility also has Client Personal Rights posters on the wall. LPA observed a laundry room with locked cabinets which contained detergents. LPA observed that the backyard contained two sheds. One of the shed was locked and observed to be used as storage. The second shed which was currently unlocked and empty will be used to store sensory activities and games for clients. There is a sandbox in the backyard for clients to play in. There were no observable safety concerns during this inspection. LPA is recommending the licensure of this facility effective 5/28/211. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to the Administrator, Chanese Thomas.

Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to provide the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. No title 22 regulations were cited during today’s inspection. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report and appeal process was reviewed and provided to the Administrator and the Shift Lead DSP.
investigation_findings: 13On 11/02/2021 at 1130am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Tana Kinder conducted an unannounced inspection to deliver complaint investigation findings with a Shift Lead DSP. Prior to the meeting, LPA Kinder reviewed the agency’s file at the licensing office, including the complaint history, criminal background check, incident reports and facility personnel report summary. LPA Kinder conducted an inspection of the facility inside and out and no citations were issued. LPA conducted 10 confidential interviews between 8/30/2021-10/06/2021. LPA obtained and reviewed the following documents: 2 client IPPs, Staff notes for 2 clients for August 23-25, 2021, staff training for last 12 months, training documentation related to 2 clients and contact information for staff. The allegation is: Staff grabbed client's arm forcefully. Based on multiple interviews there is no corroboration for either the reporting party or the staff person accused of the allegation’s version of what occurred. The clients at the facility, at the time of the incident are unable to provide information regarding the allegation. The above allegation is determined to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Continued...

met_with: Jronesha Brown Shift Lead John OBrien Regional Director
narrative: On 2/10/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie conducted an unannounced inspection at 1:48 PM and met with Shift Lead (SL) Jronesha Brown and Regional Director (RD) John OBrien for a case management visit. LPA also spoke with Program Administrator by phone at (209)453-3867. LPA observed 4 individual bedrooms with dressers and closets for each client, two bathrooms with paper supplies and soap, three days of perishable foods and five days of non-perishables, locked medication cabinet and refrigerator. LPA also observed that outdoor shed was locked .Additionally, LPA observed three broken screens and fire extinguisher enclosures without plexi that occurred from behaviors by clients with open work orders. LPA requested Staff Emily Stephen"s ,Maricela Huerta's and Alexis Burrolla"s training records ,job descriptions and house orientation packets .LPA also requested House notes for three months. Documents will be emailed to LPA. Three staff interviews were conducted surrounding incident reports with medication error and AWOL of youth that is unable to self protect. A technical advisory was issued in regards to inability to contact facility and Program Administrator, (PA) on multiple occasions. LPA advised that it was necessary for the families as well as case workers and agencies to be able to reach facility at all times. It was suggested that a system be put into place that would allow the phone line to forward to a lead's phone line and that the PA has a cleared voice mail box so messages can be left. No citations were given during this inspection.

During interviews, C1 stated that S1 hits him and has sat on him on at least one occasion. C1 identified S2, S3 and S4 as witnesses. All staff including witnesses identified by C1 deny observing S1 placing her hands on C1. Two staff state that C1 can’t be restrained due to Individual Program Plan IPP. However, two staff (S2 and S6) corroborate that S1 sat on him. S2 stated that she observed S1 entering C1’s room and C1 running out of the room stating that S1 sat on him. S6 stated that C1 told her that S1 sat on C1. Additionally, S6 stated observing C1 hiding from S1 on several occasions. One staff out of 5 stated that C1 has been restrained one time. Two staff state that C1 can't be restrained due to Individual Program Plan (IPP). The Needs and Services Plan does state , "Due to Hevanne's heart condition, physical containment is not recommended." As a result of the information obtained and the confidential interviews conducted, the allegations that a minor was shoved in care and improperly restrained are substantiated. Based on the information obtained there is preponderance of the evidence to prove the facility staff shoved the minor in care and improperly restrained minor. On this date, the facility is being cited for the following violations of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5 found during complaint investigation conducted from 1/4/22- 2/9/22: Personal Rights 84072 (d) (11) and Needs and Services Plan 84078 (b) . An exit interview was conducted and a copy of appeal rights was left with the facility.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie conducted an unannounced inspection visit to the facility on 3/16/22, at 3:30 PM. LPA Goldie met with Jronesha Brown, DSP Lead, and explained the purpose of the visit was to deliver complaint investigation findings for the above allegations. LPA’s Connie Goldie and Jennifer Baca initiated the complaint on 1/13/2022 via a tele-visit inspection at 1:00 PM with S5. The LPA’s conducted a physical plant inspection of the facility and interviewed C1 and S5. Additionally LPA’s requested the following documents from the Program Administrator: Staff roster, Staff schedules 11//28/2021- 01/01/2022, 1 client's Individualized Behavior Support Plan , 1 client's Regional Center Individual Program Plan, 1 staff training log for past 12 months, all staff Pro Act Training Certificates and December 2021 incident reports. Throughout the course of the investigation, LPA also interviewed the following individuals: Reporting Party (RP), client (C1), staff S1, S2, S4, and S6. S3 was listed by client as a witness but, there wasn’t a staff by this name. The other clients in the facility are non-verbal and are unable to be interviewed.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personal Rights (d) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9, as applicable. In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: (11) To be free from physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and corporal punishment. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews conducted in the complaint investigation, licensee did not ensure that a foster youth was accorded personal rights to be free from physical abuse which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.

Providing Care and Supervision (b) The licensee shall provide those services identified in each child's needs and services plan and in the individualized health care plan for each child with special health care needs as necessary to meet the child's needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and interviews conducted, the licensee did not follow foster youth's Needs and Services plan by physically restraining youth therefore putting youth at risk due to a medical condition which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.

narrative: On 4/5/22, at 9:53 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie conducted an unannounced case management inspection and met with Merissa Corral, DSP Lead who assisted with the visit. Lead staff stated that 3 staff were present and the clients were all at school. LPA Goldie did a walk-through of the facility with lead staff that began in the living room area at 9:57 AM. LPA Goldie observed Covid19 check in area with an assessment sheet and thermometer, a well-lit living room with seating available for 6 people. We proceeded to the hallway at 10:00 AM where LPA Goldie observed clear pathway and thermostat set at 69 degrees, 4 bedrooms with dresser and closet space, laundry area with functional washer and dryer, cleaning supplies locked up and inaccessible, two bathrooms with towels and soap. At 10:03 AM we entered the kitchen, lead staff unlocked cabinet under sink with inaccessible cleaning supplies, sharps also locked up. LPA Goldie observed 2 days of perishables and five days of non-perishables, a dining area with seating for six , and a family room with activities available. At 10:06 AM we toured the backyard. LPA observed screens in good repair, backyard free of debris and two locked sheds. Shed 1 held surplus cleaning supplies and shed 2 contained BBQ and filters. Three staff interviews were conducted which began at 10:19 AM and ended at 11:33 AM. No deficiencies were cited today. An exit interview was conducted with Jronesha Brown DSP Lead II staff at 12:10 PM.

On 04/22/2022, at 4:15 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie met with Chanese Thomas, Program Administrator (PA) for the purpose of delivering findings on case management investigation. LPA Goldie conducted a tour of the facility with Chanese Thomas, PA at 4:25 PM LPA Goldie observed living room space with seating for residents and visitors, kitchen with 2 days perishables and 5 days non-perishables, dining area with bench seat for two and 3 chairs, well lit and comfortable temperature, four individual bedrooms with clean linen on the bed, dresser and closet with additional linen, two bathrooms with soap and towels,( Client showering in bathroom 1 at time of tour) and laundry room with locked cabinetry to store cleaning supplies. The tour proceeded outside at 4:32 PM. LPA Goldie observed area free of debris. Broken window caused by client behavior has been boarded by PME management and is estimated to be replaced no later than 05/15/22. LPA Goldie received copy of work order. Storage sheds were opened by PA. Shed 1 contains additional cleaning supplies and shed 2 contains BBQ. During the course of the investigation, LPA Goldie interviewed the following: 2 staff on 02/10/2022 Program Administrator(PA) and S8 and 3 staff on 04/05/2022 , S1, S2 and Board Certified Behavior Analyst BCBA, and PA on 04/19/2022. LPA Goldie conducted a record review including incident reports, MARs and needs and services plans for C1, C2, C3 and C4. LPA Goldie observed and confirmed with PA that C1, C2 and C4 are unable to be interviewed. LPA Goldie observed medication administration to clients on 02/10/22. PA confirmed that two medication errors occurred. On 01/22/2022, C2 received another consumers medication and on 03/24/22 C1 medications were not given. The MAR review confirms that both of these incidents occurred. On 01/23/2022, S3 assigned to C1 prepared medication and did not maintain line of sight with C1. LPA Goldie determined from Needs and Services Plan that C1 is unable to self protect and eloped. Two deficiencies are being cited today from Title 22 regulations. See 809D for specifics. An exit interview was conducted, report was provided and appeal rights were discussed and left at the facility.

On 5/10//22, at 9:04 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Connie Goldie, met with Lead Marissa Corral to conduct an unannounced Annual/ Random inspection of a single story, four bedroom, 2 bath home. At 9:06 AM, Lead Corral greeted LPA Goldie and shared that there are three staff and three Board Certified Behavior Analysts (BCBA's) present that and the current census is three clients. All of the clients are at school. An Entrance Checklist was provided to the Lead. LPA Goldie and Lead Corral began the inspection at 9:35 AM in the office. LPA Goldie observed posted documents including license, Emergency Disaster Plan, LIC 500 and Youth Personal Rights. We proceeded to living room at 9;45 AM where LPA observed sofa, chair and desk area providing seating appropriate to capacity, in well-lit area, In the kitchen LPA Goldie observed appliances in good condition, oven with working burners, refrigerator 45 degrees and freezer 0 degrees with no expired items, trash can with lid, and sharps and knives locked up and inaccessible. There were no dishes in the sink. Additionally, LPA observed at least two days of perishable food and one week of non-perishables in the pantry. LPA Goldie asked Lead Corral to open cabinet under sink and observed multiple cleaning supplies inaccessible to clients. The tour continued to the dining area at 9:51 AM. LPA Goldie observed a table with four chairs all in good repair and no obstructions present .We then entered the hallway where LPA Goldie observed a hallway clear of hazards. the thermostat read a comfortable 69 degrees within the compliant range of 68-85 degrees. At 10:00 AM, LPA Goldie observed hallway closet with hygiene products available and labelled for each client, the dual smoke/carbon monoxide detectors were tested by Lead Corral and found to be operational, LPA Goldie observed 4 individual bedrooms with a bed with clean linen, dresser and closet space for each client. two bathrooms with soap, towels and running water tested at 105 degrees. The laundry room contained functioning washer and dryer and locked cabinets containing cleaning supplies. At 10:15 AM, the tour went outside where LPA Goldie observed two locked sheds, a grassy area and windows all compliant. Medications are stored in a locked cabinet in office and a locked refrigerator contains medication requiring refrigeration. The fire extinguishers are current and pins are in place and first aid kit is complete. (continued on 809C)

Physical plant inspection concluded at 10:40 AM. LPA Goldie reviewed client records, facility binder and MAR records. One technical assistance and one technical violation was issued today. These are not deficiencies. One deficiency is being cited today from Title 22 regulations 84070 (b)(13) An exit interview was conducted, report was provided and appeal rights were discussed and left at the facility.

On 05/12/2022, at 9:38 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie met with Lead Marissa Corral to continue unannounced/required Annual inspection. Lead Corral stated that three staff and one Board Certified Behavior analyst (BCBA) are currently in the facility. All clients are at school. LPA Goldie conducted five staff interviews, S1, S2, S3, BCBA and Program Administrator. LPA Goldie reviewed five Staff records with Program Administrator (PA) Chanese Thomas. All records were found to be complete. There are no deficiencies being issued today, LPA Goldie conducted exit interview with PA Thomas and Regional Director Staci Stevens at 2:30 PM. A copy of this report along with appeal rights was left at the facility

On 6/24/2022, at 4:12 PM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Connie Goldie conducted an unannounced visit and met with Lead DSP2 Jronesha Brown. LPA Goldie conducted a walk through of the facility The facility is free of clutter. Resident and Staff files are in locked cabinets located in staff offices.There is two days of perishables and seven days of non-perishable food supply. Snacks are accessible to the clients. Licensing certificate and clients personal rights are posted. Smoke Alarms are in working conditions. Clients bedrooms are clean and had linen and personal effects in the rooms. In the laundry room, LPA Goldie observed an unlocked cabinet. Lead Staff stated laundry was just started and maybe the lock was just broken. Lead staff asked S2 which cabinet she opened to get the detergent and S2 stated the left one. The right cabinet was the cabinet observed to be broken. Inside the cabinet was bleach and laundry detergent. Lead staff asked S2 to remove all chemicals and place in the adjacent locked cabinet. LPA Goldie communicated that unsecured cleaning supplies are a regulation violation. Lead staff agreed. One Title 22 deficiency is being cited today. See LIC809D for details. Exit interview was conducted with Lead Jronesha Brown at 6:05 PM. A copy of the report along with appeal rights was discussed and provided.

met_with: Robyn Cheskiewicz Director of Program Assistance Kylie LeBlanc Program Administrator in Training
narrative: On 09/09/2022, at 1:05 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie made an unannounced case management inspection and met with Robyn Cheskiewicz Director of Program Assistance (DPA) and Kylie LeBlanc Program Administrator in Training (PA) for the purpose of delivering findings on case management investigation. On 08/23//2022, LPA Goldie made an unannounced visit to facility and met with Lead DSP Jronesha Brown who assisted LPA with the inspection. During the walk-through of the home, LPA Goldie and Lead staff inspected the consumer's rooms. In one minor's room, LPA observed broken dresser. Lead staff stated it was broken by minor during a behavior in the morning. Additionally, LPA observed open gate from back yard to access to front yard which leads to the street. LPA Goldie took photo and discussed safety with staff. Lead Staff stated a reminder poster to ensure gate is closed would be placed next to gate latch for staff and a work order would be completed to tighten latch on gate. One deficiency is being cited today from Title 22 Regulations , Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 7, 80087 (a) Buildings and Grounds. An exit interview was conducted with DPA Cheskiewicz and PA LeBlanc at 1:32 PM. A copy of this report along with appeal rights was discussed and provided to the facility.

met_with: Robyn Cheskiewicz Director of Program Assistance Kylie LeBlanc Program Administrator in Training
narrative: Allegation: Reporting Guidelines not met. The allegation is staff did not report child’s injury as required. Special incident report was written and provided to Community Care Licensing on 06/21/2022, five days after incident occurred which does not meet the regulation requirement of reporting within the agency’s next working day. Based on LPA’s observations and record reviews which were conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1 Article 6 80061 (b) (1) (G) Reporting Requirements is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D Allegation: Hygiene needs of minor not being met. The allegation is staff did not ensure that minor’s hygiene needs were met. Multiple photos were provided to the Department indicating hygiene needs not being met. Photos included dirty feet on multiple occasions and long fingernails. Daily logs also indicate inconsistencies in teeth brushing. Interviews corroborated that youth’s hygiene needs are not being consistently met. Based on LPA’s observations, record reviews and interviews which were conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1 Article 6 84072 (d) Personal Rights is being cited on the attached LIC9099D. Allegation: Unsanitary conditions at facility. The allegation is the staff did not keep the facility sanitary. Records review of mopping calendar for facility reflects that between April 2022 and June 2022 there were 7 days the facility was not mopped at all. LPA observed unsanitary conditions in the backyard on 08/23/2022 during inspection. Sandbox 4’by 6’ intended for use by clients had multiple animal feces inside. Based on LPA’s observations, record reviews and interviews which were conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1 Article 7 80087 (a) Buildings and Grounds is being cited on the attached LIC9099D. Exit interview completed at 2:40 PM . A copy of this report and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie arrived at the agency to conduct an unannounced complaint investigation inspection on 09/09/2022 at 1:33 PM. LPA Goldie spoke with Robyn Cheskiewicz Director of Program Assistance and Kylie LeBlanc Program Administrator in Training , to discuss the findings of the complaint investigation and allegations stated above. LPA Goldie informed facility staff this case was investigated by LPA Goldie. The initial 10-day complaint investigation inspection was conducted by LPA Connie Goldie at the facility on 06/24/2022. LPA Goldie toured the facility and an interview was conducted with facility staff J’Ronesha Brown, Lead Staff II. Copies of facility documentation provided to LPA Goldie included :Client register, one client's individual personalized plan and IBST notes, one client's PRN medication sheets for May and June, daily shift log-hygiene, restraint log, cleaning schedule log and pest control reports/receipts for 6 months, Staff Roster, staff schedule month of June and staff contact Information. Confidential interviews were conducted with eight staff, three witnesses, co-complainant, VMRC supervisor and Program Administrator between 06/24/2022 and 09/07/2022. Records review of documents and photos obtained was completed on 07/07/2022 and 09/07/2022. Continued on LIC9099C

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Reporting Requirements (b) Upon the occurrence, ...of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day ...Events reported shall include the following:(G) Any suspected physical abuse of any minor. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interview and record review, facility failed to report incident to licensing agency within timeframe required by regulation as incident was first reported five days after incident occurred. This poses a potential risk to health, safety and/or personal rights risk to persons in care

Personal Rights (d) The licensee shall ensure that each child, ... is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9, as applicable...(1) To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where he or she is treated with respect. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observations, record review and interviews, facility did not ensure consumers hygiene needs were being met consistently.Daily logs reviewed and photos submitted indicate inconsistencies in daily care.This poses a potential risk to health, safety and /or personal rights risk to persons in care.

Buildings and Grounds (a) The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observations, interviews and record reviews, Program Administrator failed to ensure sanitary conditions.During inspection on 08/23/22, LPA observed animal feces in sandbox intended for consumer use. This poses an immediate risk to health, safety and /or personal rights risk to persons in care.

met_with: Robyn Cheskiewicz Director of Program Assistance Kylie LeBlanc Program Administrator in Training
narrative: Allegation: Personal Rights- To be free from physical, sexual, emotional or other abuse, and corporal punishment. The allegation is staff caused injury to minor in care. Although minor did present with an injury, (5 inches by 4 inches bruise on right thigh with diamond and triangle marks) Licensing Program Analyst unable to determine where injury occurred and who was responsible. Clients in facility are all non-verbal and unable to be interviewed. Facility staff interviewed all corroborate that they did not observe any behavior by clients and/or staff that would have caused the injury. School did report restraint of client on 06/16/2022 but, was transparent with photos and did not observe the injury in question. Interview with school staff corroborate that injury did not occur during restraint and school staff identified the injury the following day. Based on the investigation, records reviewed and interviews conducted, the complaint finding is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Allegation: Client not being provided with PRN medication as needed. The allegation is staff mismanaged minor’s medication. Review of daily medication chart indicates client received PRN medication on 05/19/2022. 05/21/2022, 05/25/2022 and 05/28/2022 for watery eyes and runny nose visible symptoms. Photos taken on 05/22/2022 provided to the Department show minor with a crusty nose and chapped lips and face. LPA unable to identify if PRN’s were provided as soon as symptoms began which may have prevented chapping to nose and face. Interviews with staff corroborate PRN’s are given based on visible symptoms as client does not have a way to communicate need for allergy medication. Based on the investigation, records reviewed and interviews conducted, the complaint finding is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. LPA Goldie conducted exit interview at 2:40 PM and provided and discussed a copy of this report and a copy of appeal rights to the facility.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie made an unannounced case management visit on 10/05/2022 at 10:01 AM and met with DSP Lead Tiauna Taylor to discuss three incident reports. The bedrooms all had individual beds with clean linen, dresser and closet space. Bathrooms had soap and towels available. Locks have been repaired in kitchen area and cleaning supplies are secured. 2 days of perishables and five days non-perishables were observed. Living room and dining area observed to have appropriate seating. Outdoor area free of debris and observed to be safe. Screens are bent from behaviors and work orders are being placed. LPA Goldie interviewed one staff for case management. Further investigation is required. No citations were cited. LPA Goldie concluded visit at 11:37 AM, discussed and provided a copy of the report along with appeal rights to Lead DSP Taylor.

met_with: Board Certified Behavior Analyst Blair Greenberg
narrative: Allegation # 1 Staff did not ensure supervision of youth in care. Regarding the allegation that staff did not ensure supervision of youth in care, statements made during interviews by 5 of 7 staff corroborated that emergency ratios are utilized at minimum 1-2 times a week. Emergency ratios were defined as 2:1 ratio clients going to 1:1 and 1:1 ratio client going to general supervision. One staff stated facility is never out of ratio but, did refer to emergency ratio. One staff stated the facility is never out of ratio. The Regional Center determines the level of supervision needed based upon the needs of the clients. These fluctuating ratios were not approved by the Regional Center or Community Care Licensing. All clients are unable to be interviewed because they are non-verbal. Based on LPA’s observations and interviews which were conducted, and record reviews of time sheets, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Title 22 Division 6 Chapter 5 84078 (b) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision is being cited. Allegation #2 Needs and Services plans not being adhered to for minor in care. Regarding the allegation that Needs and Services plans are not being adhered to for minor in care, statements made during interviews were corroborated. Two of three staff present corroborated that the definition of imminent danger was reached during a client behavior when client hit his eyes with closed fists and slammed his head into the wall but, a restraint was not conducted as outlined in the Individual Emergency Intervention Plan resulting in injuries to clients face- bruising and swelling to eyes and bridge of nose. One of the staff stated the restraint was not done because a staff was uncomfortable with doing a restraint. One staff does not recall how client received injuries. Based on interviews and record review of incident report and photographs submitted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Title 22 Division 6 Chapter 5 Article 8 84300(c) Emergency Intervention in Group homes is being cited. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report and appeal process was reviewed and provided to the Board Certified Behavior Analyst Blair Greenberg at 12:00 PM.
