deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Emergency Intervention in Group Homes (c) The licensee must use a continuum of interventions,... More restrictive interventions may be justified when less restrictive techniques have been attempted and were not effective and the child continues to present an imminent danger... This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interview and record review, facility failed to implement Individual Emergency intervention plan when client was in imminent danger. This poses an immediate risk to health, safety and /or personal rights risk to persons in care.

Responsibility for Providing Care & Supervision(b) The licensee shall provide those services identified in each child's needs and services plan and in the individualized health care plan for each child with special health care needs as necessary to meet the child's needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interview and record review the facility failed to implement level of supervision as indicated by Regional Center on a consistent basis as required. This poses a potential risk to health, safety and/or personal rights risk to persons in care

narrative:
On December 15,2022, an Office Conference was held at the Sacramento Children's Residential Regional Office via Teams Meeting at 1:00 PM, The following individuals were present at the Office Conference: Licensing Program Manager, Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Analyst, Connie Goldie, Valley Mountain Regional staff :Chris Pillsbury, Community Services Liaison, Danielle Wells, Program Manager, Katina Richison Division Manager, Austin McCormick Service Coordinator and Olivia Held, Program Manager; Merakey Tenaya Staff, Chanese Thomas, Program Administrator, Alex Compton, Board Certified Behavior Analyst, Annita Ydrago, Senior Leader Alisa Dean, Executive Director and Jolyn McMillan, Senior Leader. The purpose of this Office Conference was to discuss compliance concerns related to: Ratios- Emergency ratios not approved by licensing and outside of Individualized Behavior Plan specified ratio for individual clients. Personal Rights- Over-worked staff , personal rights violations. Training: Unskilled staff Leadership: Staff are unclear as to who their point of contact is. Continued on LIC809C

As a result of this office conference licensee agreed to the following: 1. Licensee has developed work groups to investigate quality control. 2. CCL has advised facility that census needs to remain at 3 for 6 months. 3. Licensee will develop a plan to address the need for Emergency Ratios and submit to licensing. The request will be required to have written approval from the Regional Center attached. 4. Board Certified Behavior Analyst will continue to conduct crisis drills with staff monthly. 5. . Licensee will develop and submit a plan to address communication concerns with DSP staff on point of contact at all times.

On 02/01/2023, at 2:20 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie made an unannounced case management visit to deliver the findings from visit conducted on 10/05/2022 and 10/26/2022 regarding two incidents that occurred on 9/26/22 and 09/27/2022. LPA Goldie met with Tiauna Taylor, Lead DSP2 and conducted a walk through of the facility both inside and out. The purpose of the visit is to deliver findings of deficiencies observed during an interview in the course of a case management investigation. LPA Goldie conducted case management on incidents received on 09/26/2022 and 09/27/2022. The incident report received on 09/27/2022 was investigated and LPA didn’t find facility was in violation. The incident report received on 09/26/2022 was investigated. During the investigation, LPA Goldie identified during an interview with S4, that although S4 was trauma informed trained, she yelled at C1. S4 stated, “I did yell. I was very upset and there may have been curse words.” This resulted in C1’s personal rights being violated. On this date the facility is being cited for the following violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5 found during case management interview on 11/04/2022, Personal Rights 84072 (d) (10). On 04/28/2023, at 10:15 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Connie Goldie and Monica Roberts made an unannounced visit to conduct an Annual/required inspection. LPAs Goldie and Roberts were greeted at the door by Jronesha Brown, Program Administrator (PA). LPA's provided Entrance Checklist to PA Brown who assisted LPAs with the inspection. PA stated two staff were at laundry mat and the 3 clients were at school. LPAs toured facility with Program Administrator (PA) 4 bedroom, 2 bath single story home with a spacious living room and adequate seating for clients/staff. The temperature was observed to be a comfortable 71 degrees. Bedroom #1 has a headboard that has observable damage which PA stated a work order has been placed for and the replacement has been ordered. LPAs observed kitchen to have a pantry with 5 days of non-perishables and refrigerator/freezer with 2 days of perishables. Refrigerator temperature reads 34 degrees and is compliant with regulation. Dining area has two seating areas for clients, bar seating as well as table dining. Family room has additional area for activities. LPAs observed soap and towels in both bathrooms. The water temperature was observed to be 112 degrees which is compliant. LPAs observed hygiene projects to be available to clients.. LPAs requested to see client phone. PA stated phone was broken two weeks ago by a client and a work order was completed. LPA Goldie stated that this is a client personal rights violation. LPAs observed two sheds in the backyard, both secured. Equipment was observed to be available for clients to participate in water play. Backyard was clear of debris. LPAs observed lawn service was needed. PA stated two weeks ago lawn service discontinued due to lack of payment by corporate PA stated a new lawn service is being obtained. LPA Roberts conducted 3 staff interviews. LPAs reviewed 5 staff files. CARE Tool components completed during todays inspection include: Physical Plant, Operations, DIsaster Preparedness and Emergency Intervention Plan. Continued on LIC809C

One Type B deficiency, 1 technical violation and 1 technical advisory were issued during inspection. A second inspection will be needed to complete Annual inspection. LPA's conducted an exit interview with Ms Brown and provided a copy of this report along with appeal rights.

Regarding the allegation that youth in care was touched inappropriately, statements made during interviews by 6 of 6 staff corroborated that C1 is capable of toileting independently but, does require prompting. 4 staff of 6 staff stated they were unaware of a client being touched inappropriately. Two staff stated that C1 was struggling with diarrhea on 09/16/2022 when S6 assisted C1 in the bathroom. S6 stated “I put on gloves and gently guided his penis into the toilet to avoid a mess.” S1 confirmed that S6 communicated this was done “as urine was shooting out.” Although S6 did touch youth, it was done to assist youth and therefore, not with negative intent. Record review of Individual Program Plan, indicates C1 is toilet trained, however does have occasional inappropriate urinations. Based on lack of observation and information provided by interviewees, the LPA found that while this allegation may have occurred or is valid, there was not a preponderance of evidence to prove that it did or did not occur, therefore LPA has found it to be unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report and appeal process was reviewed and provided to the Administrator.

On 09/05/2023, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA), Connie Goldie, conducted an unannounced subsequent inspection for the purpose of a Case Management. Based on interviews and record review, it was determined that C1 was injured when he fell and hit his head on a metal chair prior to being restrained for imminent danger of safety. However, during review of medical documentation discharge paperwork received on 07/14/2023 from the hospital, it was observed that hospital advised that C1 be scheduled for a follow up visit within 1-3 days with his primary care physician for diagnosed concussion. According to Program Administrator, as of 08/09/2023, an appointment had not been scheduled for C1. The facility was cited for Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6 regulation Health Related Services 80075(a) as the client’s medical needs were not provided for which posed a potential health/ safety risk to client in care. Please see LIC 809-D for the deficiency. An exit interview was conducted with the above administrator and a plan of correction was completed. A copy of this report and Appeal Rights were given during the inspection.

narrative: On 02/01/2024, at 01:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the facility. The purpose of the inspection was to inquire about incidents that occurred on 11/21/2023, 11/23/2023,11/25/2023, 12/04/2023 and 12/30/2023 and were reported to the Department. Lead DSP 2, Jessica Kutsoginis assisted with the inspection. 3 staff and zero clients were present. LPA observed and requested copies of the following documents pertaining to incidents: restraint logs for past 6 months, most recent emergency intervention plan for C1, C1's data logs for October-December 2023, C1's medical documentation November 2023- January 2024, staff schedule for past three months, and staff roster with contact phone numbers. LPA conducted a walk through of facility with staff, Tiauna Taylor (S1) inside and outside. In living room, LPA observed new furniture and bean bag chairs for seating, in kitchen adequate perishables and non-perishable food was available, all bedrooms were observed to have necessary furnishings in good repair, Smoke /carbon monoxide detectors were tested and compliant, bathrooms had soap and available paper towels, hygiene products were accessible. The backyard was observed to be freshly cut and free of debris. Sheds were secured as required. LPA observed staff leave backyard gate open and unsecured when he left facility. LPA conducted 4 staff interviews during inspection. A technical violation was issued. This is not a deficiency. Further investigation is required. An exit interview was conducted with Ms. Kutsoginis at 04:10 PM. A copy of reports along with appeal rights were discussed and provided to facility.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jodean Hall, conducted an informal office meeting located at 9835 Goethe Road, Suite 100, Sacramento, CA 95827 to discuss safety concerns for C1 and staff because of severe level of self-injurious behaviors and aggression towards staff. Present from Merakey Tenaya was: Jronesha Brown - Administrator, Alisa Dean- Director and Clinical Director Alex Compton. Present virtually from Valley Mountain Regional Center was: Cindy Jiminez- Program Manager, Val Harris- QBMP Chris Pillsbury, Facility Laison, Austin McCormick ,Service coordinator and Greg Lee Behavior Specialist 2. Subsequent to receiving Incident Report dated 12/30/2023 and photographs of injuries C1 incurred due to self-injurious behaviors, CCL requested the following additional information. LPA received facility staff roster with contact information, Quarterly Reports, Behavior Consultant data, Staff Data Reports, Data Tracking Sheets, Medical discharge documentation, Refusal of Emergency Medical Services forms dated 12/30/2024 and 01/04/2024, Restraint Logs, Emergency Intervention Plan updated 10/10/2023, IBSP updated 01/18/2024 with a Head Injury Plan and C1’s current Individual Program Plan. The Department acknowledges that facility has recognized the need to implement new plans and has made efforts to keep C1 safe by updating C1’s Individual Emergency Intervention Plan (IEIP), updating his Individual Behavior Service Plan (IBSP) on 01/18/2024 to include a Head Injury Plan and provided staff with additional trainings – Crisis drills and In-services by Kim Simpkins, Regional Director of Program Supports. Additionally, the Department recognizes that more restraints will be implemented based on change to C1’s IEIP. Based on the records reviewed, LPA learned that during incidents when C1 is demonstrating SIB and imminent danger is determined, and a restraint is deemed necessary, staff are unable to effectively hold C1. Staff are having to release and reset holds frequently for safety. Additionally, staff are being bitten, kicked, and scratched. Continued on LIC809C

During confidential interviews with staff, it has been stated that some staff are not as confident with conducting restraints and as a result holds are unsuccessful. The Department is recommending that the supervision ratio for C1 be increased from 2:1 to 3:1 for 90 days to provide staff support and confidence to perform effective holds when they are deemed necessary. No deficiencies will be cited . Exit interview conducted with facility staff at 11:10 AM. A copy of the report along with appeal rights were discussed and provided.

On 05/09/2024 at approximately 2:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Connie Goldie arrived unannounced at Merakey/Tenaya for the purpose of conducting a case management- incident Inspection. LPA met with Jessica Kutsoginis, Lead DSP 2 who assisted with the incident inspection. All clients are at school. During the inspection, LPA discussed concern about an Incident Report received by the Department on 05/04/2024 that indicated C1 was providing a psychotropic medication on 05/02/2024 after the medication was discontinued the previous month- (4/26/2024.) LPA interviewed Ms. Kutsoginis to determine how this medication error occurred. LPA reviewed Medication Administration Records (paper MAR, EMAR and PMAR for May 2024) for 05/02/2024 and conducted two interviews. Based on record review and interview, it was determined that C1 received a medication that was provided not as prescribed. A technical violation was issued for one missed initial on 05/02/2024, AM pass for a psychotropic medication which was received by client. This is not a deficiency. A Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Type A citation was issued Health Related Services 80075(b)(5)(B). See LIC809D. An exit interview was conducted at 03:40 PM and a copy of this report was provided.

narrative: The Department investigated the allegation, “Staff utilized inappropriate discipline to keep client in bedroom.” One staff stated that a water gun was used to keep a resident in their bedroom. Six of seven staff interviewed denied using a water gun to squirt a client and stated they did not observe any other staff do so. Two of seven staff stated water guns were used for an art activity with the behaviorist. All staff stated C1 does not sleep well at night and is frequently awake but, he is allowed to come out of the bedroom to get water, snacks and utilize the bathroom and is redirected to bedroom afterwards to rest. Therefore, it is not possible to determine whether the allegation occurred or not. Based on the investigation, records reviewed, and interviews conducted, the complaint finding is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personal Rights 84072 (d)The licensee shall ensure that each child...is accorded the personal rights...(1)To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect. narrative: The Department investigated the allegation, “Staff did not seek timely medical care for minor.” Two staff corroborate that C1 had blood in his urine on 09/12/2024 and that C1’s primary physician recommended C1 go to the emergency room. Record review of incident reports received by the Department on 09/13/2024 and 09/17/2024 indicate that C1 was taken to the emergency room but, not until after the second occurrence of blood in C1’s urine on 09/17/2024. Furthermore, C1’s prescribed medication upon discharge wasn’t obtained timely and was not received prior to the 6–8-hour timeframe for C1 to return if no urine output had occurred. C1 returned to the emergency room and was transported to Lucile Packard Children’s Hospital-Stanford Intensive Care Unit to be treated for a bowel impaction. Therefore, the allegation is determined to be substantiated. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, 80075(a) Health Related Services, are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D.” An immediate civil penalty is being issued in the amount of $500.00 and $100.00 per day until POC is received due to the seriousness of the medical outcome. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

The Department investigated the allegation, “Staff physically abused a resident in care.” Nine of nine staff denied any physical abuse towards youth in care. A reliable witness stated they “saw a female staff kick a youth and scream at him in the middle of the street” which was corroborated by another witness. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation(s) is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6 84072(d) (19) are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D.” An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the facility.

Regarding the allegation, “staff are inappropriately restraining youth in care” eight of nine staff members stated that C3 is restrained due to self-injurious behaviors which are considered to place him in imminent danger after twenty seconds. Record review of C3’s Individual Behavior Plan is consistent with this implementation. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated.” The Department investigated the allegation, “Administrative staff not reporting incidents as required.” Eight of nine staff interviewed stated all reportable incidents are being reported to either Lead, Program Administrator or Regional Director. A staff disclosed they reported an incident to the Regional Director and an incident report wasn’t written but, details indicated it was not a reportable incident. However, based on the interviews, it is a possibility that not all incidents are being reported. Therefore, it is not possible to determine whether the allegation occurred or not. Based on the investigation, records reviewed, and interviews conducted, the complaint finding is unsubstantiated at this time meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Regarding the allegation, “Administrative staff are requesting staff to falsify records,” two of nine staff members interviewed stated they have been asked to complete forms or provide signatures later by administrative staff. Record review of documents that have been asked to be updated indicate that staff have been asked to make records consistent which would not be falsifying records. However, it is unknown if all documents that have been requested to be changed by administration were disclosed. Based on the investigation, records reviewed, and interviews conducted, the complaint finding is unsubstantiated at this time meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the facility.

narrative:
The Department investigated the allegation, “Staff did not assist client in care with dental hygiene.” Confidential interviews disclosed “staff were not held accountable to brushing C1’s teeth”, “staff are doing the best they can to encourage teeth brushing but C1 has the personal right to deny” and “dental concerns when discussed were dismissed.” Record review of dental pre-op visit on 10/25/2024 indicated that severe dental decay is present, and it was noted hygiene needs improvement. On 11/25/2024, C1 under anesthesia received eight fillings, 1 crown, 7 extractions, and 4 sealants. C1 has been in facility’s care since June 2020 and until October 2025, C1 has not had a successful dental appointment. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation(s) is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1 Article 6 80075 (a) are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D.” An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the facility

Regarding the allegation, “Staff did not allow client to complete shower prior to completing dental hygiene,” two of four staff corroborate that C1 did brush his teeth while showering in the non-ambulatory bathroom. During a confidential interview, it was stated, “It is a possibility that the water was turned off.” No corroboration was available as other staff could not remember if water was turned off or left on. Additionally, C1 was unable to be interviewed as he is non-verbal. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated.” An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the facility.

On 05/01/2025, at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie met with J'ronesha Brown, Administrator to continue unannounced/required Annual inspection. Ms. Brown stated that five staff are present and all clients are at school. LPA reviewed outstanding civil penalty fee which was due on 03/07/2024 with Program Administrator. LPA informed Administrator that Annual fees are due 05/28/2025. LPA verified that all staff are background cleared. Care Tool domains Staff Records and Client Records were completed during today's inspection. LPA Goldie conducted 3 client interviews C1, C2 and C4 and 2 staff interviews S4 and S5. LPA reviewed 4 client files, medication administration records and 5 staff files. The following Title 22 citations are being cited today- Two Type B violations. Annual inspection is complete. The Department investigated the allegation, “Licensee is not adequately addressing mold in the facility.” On 04/03/2024, the facility did identify a mold issue in the facility. Youth were relocated to a hotel and treatment was completed. A previous complaint received on 05/13/2024 was investigated by the Department pertaining to the initial mold and it was determined the facility responded correctly. On 04/23/2024, the facility did test positive for mold present and was treated. On 05/06/2024, the facility was retested for mold and received a clearance report along with a Certificate of Treatment stating, “your home will be mold-free for 12 months from May 1, 2024”. Based on an email received from a staff member on 03/10/2025, stating two youth in home suffered seizures due to mold present in the home and additional assessments were completed. Two of four clients did experience a one-time seizure (C1- 11/14/2024 and C2- 02/14/2025). LPA interviewed C1’s medical assistant who stated C1 was diagnosed with a non-specified seizure and no mention of mold was identified in medical record. C2’s discharge paperwork indicates he was kept overnight for observation on 02/14/2025 due to seizure activity observed at the facility and was discharged with medication but, mold was not listed as a possible contributor. The Administrator stated that a Heating, Ventilation and Air conditioning technician, a contractor and a mold mediation company completed assessments of the home on 03/11/2025 and 03/13/2025 and no evidence of mold was observed. Record review of documentation provided by facility from Air Environmental and Pacific Pure Air corroborates this. Although two youth did experience a medical incident, there isn’t evidence to support that mold was the cause. Therefore, it is not possible to determine whether the allegation occurred or not. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the facility.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield made an unannounced Post Licensing inspection to the above facility on 11/4/2020 at 8:55 AM. LPA Belfield met with Administrator George Grant who assisted with the visit. Currently, there are two clients in placement. During this visit LPA Belfield reviewed client files and staff files. a review in the Information System, showed that all staff had current clearance. LPA Belfield and administrator Grant toured the facility inside and out. During today's inspections, five staff and two clients were present. Observed during a tour of the facility; two fire extinguishers, license, personal rights, disaster plan and food menus were posted in the facility. Also observed by this LPA, was sufficient food supply, facility was clean and in good repair. Clients bedrooms were kept at a good temperature and clients had appropriate bedding. At the time of the inspection, records of clients allowance and P&I monies were not available for review. Administrator Grant states that they would obtain the records for this LPA's review by the end of the day. While touring the facility LPA Belfield observed that C1 ( see LIC 811 dated 11/4/2020) did not have a proper dresser for clothing storage. Advisory issued, technical assistance of section 84088(c)(4) Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment and Supplies. LPA Belfield observed at the time of this inspection the clients to be calm and display positive interactions with staff. LPA discussed the disaster plan with administrator Grant and stated that updates should be made to those in charge during an emergency. Advisory issued. There were no Violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be sent to administrator George Grant.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield conducted an announced case management inspection (tele-inspection due to COVID 19 via Microsoft Teams). The purpose of this inspection is to discuss concerns regarding C1 ( see LIC 811 dated 4/23/2021). LPA Belfield, Administrator George Grant and Licensee Yasmin Faraj, discussed C1 turning 18 years old in November 2021. Based on his dangerous behaviors and staffs’ inability to manage them safely, which potentially causes a health and safety concern to any other children residing in the facility, LPA Belfield recommends the facility begin working closely with the placement agency to locate an appropriate Adult Residential Facility for C1 to move to upon his 18th birthday. Based on his behaviors, this may be difficult to find, which is why the search for an adult placement is being recommended this far in advance. Unless there is a significant change to his behaviors, C1 would likely not be compatible to remain in care with children or remain in a Group Home beyond his 18th birthday.” Licensee Faraj stated to LPA Belfield that conversations regarding C1's future placement have already begun. There were no violations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be sent to Licensee Yasmin Faraj.

On 6/17/2021 at 1:26 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield conducted and unannounced Annual / Required inspection at the above facility. During this inspection there were five staff and one client. LPA Belfield met with administrator George Grant who assisted with the inspection. Currently, there are two clients in placement. During this visit LPA Belfield reviewed client files. A review of medication and medication records for both clients in care were in compliance. A review in the Licensing Information System, showed that all staff had current clearance. LPA Belfield and administrator Grant toured the facility inside and out. Observed during a tour of the facility; license, personal rights, disaster plan and all other required forms were posted, including food menus and dietary suggestions and instructions. Also observed by this LPA, was a sufficient food supply, located in three locations in the facility, along with an emergency food supply. The facility was observed to be clean and in good repair. Clients bedrooms were kept at a good temperature and clients had appropriate bedding. C1 ( see LIC 811 dated 6/17/2021) bathroom is missing the top cover to the toilet, facility issued advisory for section 80088 (e)(3) Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies. LPA discussed with administrator Grant the C1 removed the lid to the back of the toilet and was attempting to use it as a weapon, there is an incident report on file with the department. Administrator Grant states there is a plan in place to replace the toilet with a non-removable cover. Administrator also states that the toilet is fully functioning. LPA observed and tested the toilet during the inspection

LPA tested the water temperature which measured at 112 degrees. This temperature is between 105 and 120 degrees which is within the requirement. At this time, a staff file review must be conducted in order to complete the annual inspection. Advisory issued. California Code of Regulation, Title 22, Division Six, section 80088 (e)(3) Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies. An exit interview was conducted with administrator Grant and a copy of this report will be sent to administrator Grant and Licensee Yasamin Faraj.

On 6/23/2022 at 9:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the above licensed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the required annual inspection. There were six staff members and two clients present at the time of the inspection. LPA met with George Grant, Administrator, and conducted the physical plant inspection. LPA observed the up-to-date posted license and neighborhood policy. LPA observed the facility to be clean, sanitary, and in good repair. LPA observed an adequate food supply and all cleaning supplies were kept in locked cabinets. There are four rooms in the facility, two of which are occupied by clients. The facility had working carbon monoxide detectors. LPA observed that the locked medication binder has the client's medication properly labeled and organized. LPA did not observe any deficiencies during the physical plant inspection. LPA and Administrator reviewed the files in the backyard of the home. Most of the files are kept on an online server, the client portion is accessible to direct care staff via agency cell phones. LPA observed the facility's disaster plan, staff roster, face sheets, and centrally stored medications binder. LPA did not observe any deficiencies regarding the file review. LPA conducted interviews with two staff members. LPA did not interview clients because they were both sleeping. There are no Title 22 deficiencies to be delivered at this time. LPA conducted an exit interview with Licensee, Yassamin Faraj, at 11:30AM, whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted a case management visit to the above facility on 9/12/2022 at 2:00PM. On 9/9/2022, a staff member found a piece of marijuana on the floor while cleaning underneath the staff lockers. The staff member immediately showed this to George Grant, Administrator, who disposed of the marijuana outside of the facility. LPA met with Administrator, George Grant at 2:20PM. Administrator explained the steps that were taken to understand how the marijuana would have gotten into the facility. On 12/12/2022 at 2:25PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the licensed facility. On 12/12/2022, Licensee Yassmin Faraj informed LPA Hood that a client alleged that during a restraint on 12/7/2022 a staff member had hit them. Licensee had conducted an internal review and did not believe that the staff member had hit them. LPA conducted three confidential interviews (see LIC 812). LPA requested the restraint training for the staff member involved. Of the three interviews, three interviewees stated that the staff member did not punch the client. Based on confidential interviews, the staff members involved followed facility protocol on de-escalation and manual restraints. LPA conducted an exit interview with George Grant, Administrator, at 3:15PM, whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

investigation_findings: 13On 3/15/2023 at 4:05PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the licensed facility. The purpose of this visit was to deliver the findings on the above allegations. LPA met with George Grant, Administrator. During the course of the investigation, LPA Hood conducted twelve interviews between 2/22/2023 and 3/10/2023. The two youth involved declined to interview. LPA reviewed the administrator clock-in schedule, incident reports, and employee expectations documentation. Based on confidential interviews, eleven out of twelve of the interviewees stated that they had never heard staff curse or say inappropriate things in front of the youth. Eleven of the twelve interviewed stated that they had not heard staff talking about their personal sexual experiences in front of the youth. Eleven of the twelve interviewed said they had not suspected any staff of smoking on the premises.

narrative: Based on confidential interviews and incident reports, staff was visually observing both residents while they were watching the content. At the time of the incident, the facility was in appropriate staff-to-resident ratio. Based on program statement and case management notes, the protocol for both residents is to not intervene unless there is imminent danger. Prior to this, the non-minor dependent was showing staff appropriate videos on their phone, so the staff did not assume it was an inappropriate video. Based on confidential interviews, the residents were watching the content for less than one minute, and staff immediately intervened after one resident told them what type of content they were watching. After learning about the nature of the content on the phone, the staff separated the two residents. Although the incident did happen, the allegation that due to staff not intervening, resident was exposed to inappropriate content on a phone from another resident in the home may or may not be true. The allegation has not met the preponderance of doubt and therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. LPA conducted an exit interview with George Grant at 2:47PM whose signature confirms the receipt of the document.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct a Case Management inspection. LPA discussed this with George Grant, Administrator (ADM) at 10:45 PM on 10/4/23. This case management was opened to discuss an incident report (IR) the department received for an incident that occurred on 9/14/23. The incident report stated, in summary, that C1 unexpectedly exited the facility van during a drive in the community. This happened despite staff trying to prevent C1 from exiting the facility van. While outside the van, C1 ran into the street. To prevent C1 from getting hit from an oncoming car, staff used a non-FEIP/IEIP approved restraint to pull C1 out of the street and preventing him getting seriously injured. The facility created a plan of corrective action to avoid this type of incident in the future. The plan includes: The facility will refraining from outings unless a third person (admin) is available to assist. Submitted a licensing exception for use of a seatbelt buckle guard. Staff have been notified that the staff sitting in the middle row and providing the duty of primary staff should be a male staff (due to Dominic’s preference, not ability level of staff). Staff will repeat additional emergency intervention training refresher. LPA also discussed with the facility about the frequency of IRs related to restraints/incidents related to C1. LPA also informed facility that they needed to identify staff members in IRs. LPA requested C1's NSP (Needs and Service Plan.) Exit interview was conducted with George Grant, ADM.

On March 13, 2024, at 3:30PM, a meeting was held between Community Care Licensing (CCL) San Jose Regional Office, San Andres Regional Center, Brite Horizons School, Santa Cruz County Office of Education (SCCOE), Monterey County Dept. of Social Services (MCDSS), and Facility Representatives. The attendees were as follows: Nelson Martinez – Regional Manager, Community Care Licensing (RM) Helga Wong – Licensing Program Manager, Community Care Licensing (LPM) Paul Simien – Licensing Program Analyst, Community Care Licensing (LPA) Durriya Anwar – QBMP, BCBA, SARC Yassmin Faraj – Support Services, License/BCBA, Mosaic Manor Harold Thomas – LCSN Specialist, Mosaic Manor Greeshma Sanchula, BCBA, SARC Maria Aleman – District Manager Transition Unit, SARC Mike Keeley – Director of Consumer Services, SARC Arushie Nugapitiya – Associate Director of Consumer Services, SARC Devin Stark – Director of Special Education, SCCOE Matt Peterson – Site Director/Behavior Analyst, Brite Horizons School Jessica Little – Executive Director of North Santa Cruz SELPA Stephanie Krol Vieira – Clients' Rights Advocate Attorney for Catchment Clients OCRA/DRC, SARC Lisa Hartley – Associate Director, SARC Brandon Ayala – Support Service Admin. Program assistant, Mosaic Manor Janice Frederick – Director Clinical Services, Brite Horizons Dr. Azelin Ellis – ASD & Clinical Manager, SARC Continued on LIC 809-C...

Matthew Torres – I.D.E.A Specialist, SARC Evelyn Benitez –Socail Worker, MCDSS During the meeting the attendees discussed Brite Horizons and SCCOE's concerns regarding a client expressing feeling unsafe at the facility due to peer-to peer aggressions. Facility representatives explained the processes they have to keep clients safe, data gathered showing a decrease in peer-to-peer aggression, and support services they provide clients to serve their needs. SARC representatives explained their involvement with the facility and how they help with providing services to support clients. SARC representatives also explained what an Enhanced Behavior Home (EBH) is and the oversight/support services that are required for these types of facilities. Representatives from Brite Horizon and the facility agreed to keep an open dialog via email or Google Document regarding client feeling unsafe. They also proposed having a quarterly meeting to further discusses this. CCL will conduct a follow up meeting with the group sometime in September to ensure the health and safety of clients. The meeting was adjourned at 5:06 PM. *Documents were signed digitally by facility representative on 3/21/24*

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct a Case Management inspection. LPA discussed this with George Grant, Administrator (ADM) at 11:00 AM on 10/16/24. CCL received a phone call expressing concern with the frequency of the above listed facility's phone calls to law enforcement. LPA Simien went over the facility's policy regarding law enforcement contact. ADM stated that there was an increased in calls mostly due to clients calling emergency services. ADM stated that sometimes clients call 911 on personal phones without staff knowledge or request the facility phone and then call 911. When staff witness a client call 911 they will inquire what the issues is. If appropriate, staff will try to redirect the client by either trying to solve the issue or provide an alternative resource (I.E. mental health hotline). If the client insists on calling 911 then that's within the clients' personal rights. ADM mentioned that sometimes when a client wants to go to the hospital they will reject using facility transport and insist on using emergency services. ADM stated that when staff calls emergency services, it's mostly due to clients needing medical attention. ADM stated that they use Ukeru pads to help prevent self-harming and will use restraints as a last resort if a client is in imminent danger but sometimes clients will still need medical attention after engaging in self harm. ADM mentioned that himself and staff have been confronted by local law enforcement officers about the increased calls. ADM stated that he has attempted to explain the regulations that facility works within to local law enforcement officers when confronted but has mostly been disregarded. LPA Simien reviewed the facility's incident reports involving law enforcement from August 2024 and September 2024 and found no violations of regulations. Exit interview was conducted and and a copy of this report was provided to George Grant, ADM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward made an unannounced licensing visit to conduct the annual/required inspection. The inspection began at 3:00 PM and was conducted with the assistance of administrator Azeez Lamina. The following was observed. The facility is implementing COVID Screening as required. This is three bedroom, two bathroom home located in the City of Inglewood, CA. There are currently two clients in care. Both clients are non-verbal and considered non-ambulatory although they are both capable of walking. Children's records were complete. The parents of both clients maintain medical rights, therefore no JV 220 paperwork is required. There are no bodies of water, firearms or fireplaces on the premises. There are no security bars on windows. The yard area is free of visible hazards. LPA observed a generator in the backyard, All bedrooms are equipped with one full sized bed each, including all required linens. The windows in bedroom #2 are covered in decorative paper rather than blinds or curtains due to the resident's tendency to tear down window coverings. There is a complete supply of first aid items. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are working and properly placed. There is a fire extinguisher near the kitchen; it is recommended that this unit be recharged. All knives, household chemicals and medicines are stored under lock and key. The following were posted as required: Notice if Personal Rights, employee schedule, COVID 19 postings, and floor plan. There is a current menu; However the menu is not posted. The last disaster drill was conducted 11/23/21. There were no deficiencies cited on this date. LPA will return at a later date to review staff records.

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with administrator Tiffany Murguia to conduct an investigation of an incident report concerning a medication error. The IR Follow-up case number is 0001671-FN. Per the incident report, two staff in charge of administering medications failed to give a client her medication because they did not notice that it was lodged in the bubble pack. The missed medication was discovered and reported by a member of the nursing staff as she was reviewing the medications. Per Ms. Murguia, the two staff who caused the error have undergone a medications administration hands on review and are in the process of completing five additional classes on the subject of medication handling. LPA Jones-Steward collected a photo of the missed medication, copies of the disciplinary write-ups, a copy of the hands-on medication review, and proof of completion for the trainings that have been completed. Per Ms. Murguia, the staff are not allowed to handle medications until they have completed all trainings. The facility was cited under Title 22 84775(b)(2).

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Health Care Services Medications shall be administered as prescribed... The licensee failed to meet this requirement when staff did not give a client her prescribed medication because they overlooked the pill that was lodged in the packaging,

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lisa Gilbert conducted an Case Management tele-Inspection with the above facility on 9/18/2020 at 2:00PM and met with Fenina Pham, Administrator. The facility's provisional license was effective 12/17/2019 and is due to expire on 12/16/2020. The facility is licensed for four non-ambulatory male/female clients and they currently have one male client in care. The facility has four bedrooms, two bathrooms, kitchen, living room, “sensory” room, staff office and garage. LPA observed the kitchen to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. The facility has a total of two refrigerators. One is in the kitchen and the other in the garage. Both refrigerators contain at least two days of perishable food and seven days of non-perishable food. LPA observed the kitchen pantry stocked with dry and canned foods. Fresh bananas were observed on the kitchen counter. The administrator reported that bananas are C1’s favorite fruit and currently C1’s daily skills include learning to cut bananas with a banana slicer. LPA observed knives and sharp objects stored and inaccessible in a kitchen drawer. LPA observed a menu binder on the kitchen counter as well as a generic menu posted on the wall. The administrator stated the facility has a lot of flexibility with meals because C1 is currently the only placement. Due to the inspection conducted virtually, LPA was unable to measure the water temperature in the kitchen sink; however, the facility logs the water temperature daily. LPA observed a mini fridge available for refrigerated medications in the event C1 or a new placement is prescribed medication that must be refrigerated. All disinfectants, cleaning solutions and poisons are in the laundry room adjacent to the kitchen and stored and inaccessible to clients. The living room, “sensory” room, garage and outdoor space were observed to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. There is adequate seating for capacity and all furniture is in good repair. Smoke detectors were tested during the inspection and are in working order and delayed egress doors were in working condition. Service dates for both fire extinguishers in the facility were past due. The last services inspection was conducted in August of 2019. The facility landlord was notified, and it was verbally confirmed their housing Services (Brilliant Corners) did not service the fire extinguishers during their visit on 7/06/2020.

LPA requested documentation of this.The fire extinguishers are scheduled to be serviced on 10/1/2020. Proof of service is to be sent via email to LPA when complete. LPA observed a basketball court and patio swing located in the back of the facility. LPA observed both bathrooms to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPA observed personal hygiene products and linens stored in the hallway closest. Soap and paper towel products were accessible in both bathrooms. All bedrooms were equipped with a bed frame, mattress, bedspread, dresser, and night stand. The windows all have screens and blinds. LPA observed the facility license, CCL’s Centralized Complaint Hotline number, Personal Rights, Surety Bond and information regarding COVID-19 posted in the facility. Registration is current in both facility vehicles. LPA reviewed one client and three staff files. LPA requested the facility scan and send C1’s Individual Behavioral Supports Plan, current Individual Emergency Plan, MAR/PMAR for the month of August 2019 and the last two weeks of C1’s progress notes and data collection. LPA requested the facility scan and send S1, S2, and S3’s training and qualifications and relevant certificates. LPA also requested the facility’s most current LIC500 (Personnel Report). The facility is in good standing and the facility did not note any concerns at this time. No Title 22 Regulations cited during today’s inspection. Exit interview conducted and a report was provided to the facility.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shoua Xiong conducted an unannounced Case Management inspection to the facility on 3/23/21 beginning at 1:15PM. Due to COVID-19 Restrictions, LPA conduced this Case Management telephonically. LPA spoke with the Administrator, Fenina Pham, and explained that the purpose of today's call was to discuss an Incident Report dated for 3/12/21 which the Department Received on 3/22/21. This Incident Report involved Client (C1) who was placed in a restraint. On today's date, LPA interviewed the Administrator regarding the incident. LPA and Administrator discussed the importance of accurate documentation when reporting incidents into the Department. No deficiencies were cited on today's date. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to the Administrator, Fenina Pham, with a request for the report to be signed and returned electronically.

The agency has investigated the complaint allegations that the Youth was handled in a rough manner while in care and youth was slapped while in care. The incident was reported by staff and after the administrator viewed the video the staff was immediately terminated. The video footage that was submitted on March 22, 2021 shows the youth being handed in a rough manner and being slapped in the back of the head with an open palm by Staff 9. Based on video footage, LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted and record reviews(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation(s) is (ARE) found to be Substantiated. The facility is cited on the attached LIC 9099D under the California Code of Regulations, for Personal Rights ILS 88487.8(b)(2) A copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to the agency. No title 22 regulations were cited during today’s inspection.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mary Shelton conducted a tele visit at the agency on June 9, 2021 and LPA spoke with Fenina Pham, Administrator to deliver findings of the investigation on the complaint allegations as stated. The initial 10-day complaint inspection was conducted by LPA Mary Shelton, at the agency on 3/16/2021 and included a review of the facility and obtaining of relevant documents: Needs and Services, monthly treatment plan, supervised visit log, certificate of approval, facility sketch, staff training records and staff roaster. LPA Shelton interviewed the facility administrator on 3/16/2021. Additional interviews were conducted by LPA Mary Shelton, which included Sheriff Deputy Neri, C1’s Social Worker and Staff. between 3/16/2021 and 6/2/2021.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 88487.8(b)(2) Personal Rights "To be free from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation…physical, sexual, emotional, mental or other abuse...” This requirement has been met as evidenced by: Based on video footage and Interviews conducted during this investigation prove the youth was handled in a rough manner and slapped while in care by Staff 9. This poses potential Health, safety or Personal rights risk to residents in care.

narrative:
On 12/16/2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mary Shelton conducted an unannounced Annual inspection at 11:49AM and met with Andrew Nguyen, Administrator The home is an Enhanced Behavioral Support Group Home with the requested capacity of four non-ambulatory clients. There is currently one non-verbal client placed in the home. Andrew Nguyen - Administrator who accompanied LPA on an inspection of the facility inside and out. There were no clients present during the inspection due to school. The facility has four bedrooms, two bathrooms, staff office, kitchen, living room, dining room, sensory room, a living space designated for reading, gym, outside area and a three car garage. LPA Shelton inspected and/or reviewed the following: · Postings of facility license and Personal Rights Poster were appropriately posted · Disinfectants/Cleaning solutions were inaccessible and locked as required · Refrigerator Temperature was at or below 45 degrees F and Freezer Temperature at or below 0 degrees. · Nonperishable Foods for one week and fresh perishable foods two days minimum were present · Menu binder was present and accessible in the kitchen · LPA observed a working telephone on the premises · Carbon monoxide detectors and Smoke Detectors were present and functioning

· First Aid Kit was present and fully stocked as required · Common Room (living room) was available for clients · Dining area with enough seating for clients in care was present and in good condition · Medication was centrally stored, locked/inaccessible. Centrally stored medication and log reviewed · LPA reviewed five (5) staff files and one (1) client file · LPA conducted interviews with two staff. · Motor Vehicle appeared to be properly maintained. LPA observed lights, tires, registration/insurance and working seat belts at the time of the inspection. · LPA observed that the facility appeared to be free of vermin · LPA reviewed complaint procedures for clients. · Disaster Preparedness was updated and available for review, quarterly drills are completed and logged in a binder and there are disaster preparedness supplies available and verified by LPA · Staff training was in compliance · Criminal record clearances were verified by LPA and in compliance · Staff files reviewed had First Aid Certificates and CPR cards with a valid dates as required · Staff job titles/qualifications were verified along with the required training · Trauma informed practices are implemented as needed (including specialty mental health services and extracurricular activities and social supports) per discussion with the administrator. No citations were issued, and LPA requested the following document from the facility as part of the annual review: LIC 500 Exit interview was conducted and documents were provided to the facility.

On 2/18/22, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Connie Goldie conducted an unannounced case management inspection. LPA met with Administrator Interim (AI), Andrew Nguyen at 2:40 PM . LPA Goldie conducted a walk through of the facility inside and out and observed the following: three bedrooms with a bed, dresser and closet space, one bedroom client declined entry, two bathrooms with soap and towels, three days of perishable and five days of non-perishables, functioning smoke detectors, fire extinguisher, and medication storage. Additionally LPA observed outdoor area free of hazards. LPA Goldie conducted two staff interviews, reviewed one client file and observed medication preparation. LPA requested training documents for one staff, MAR sheets for February 5, 2022. No citations were given today. LPA conducted exit interview with (AI) and thanked him for his time.

met_with: Lead Staff Isha Dhaliwal and Administrator Program Adminstrator Interim Andrew Nguyen
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie made an unannounced case management visit and met with Lead Staff Isha Dhaliwal.Lead staff conducted the walk through.The purpose of the visit is to deliver findings of deficiencies observed during a previous inspection date on 2/18/22. Program Administrator Interim (PAI) Andrew Nguyen arrived a t 12 PM and LPA Goldie delivered findings to him. LPA Goldie conducted a walk through of the facility with Lead Staff Dhaliwal both inside and out and observed the following: A living room, reading area room, a sensory room, 4 individual client bedrooms with dresser, bed and desk (two of which are occupied), 2 bathrooms with appropriate amounts of soap and towels, 3 days of perishables and five days of non-perishables, 9 working smoke detectors / carbon dioxide monitors inside. LPA Goldie observed a gym area as well as equipment for the clients and no hazards outside. On 2/18/2022, LPA Goldie identified during an interview with S1, that S1 was not trained on medication dispersal prior to being responsible for passing medication. This resulted in a client receiving two 3 mg dosage at one time instead of one 1 mg and one 2 mg dosage during morning medication violating C1's personal rights. The PAI verified that S1 was not trained prior to administering medication during records review of S1's file. LPA Goldie also observed during inspection on 2/18/22 that two cameras were installed in C1's bedroom and active prior to approval from CCL. A waiver is pending but, has not been approved yet. The initial waiver request was sent by Program Administrator Fenina Pham and received by the Department. On this date the facility is being cited for the following violation of Title 22, Division 6 , Chapter 5 found during case management inspection on 2/18/2022 ,Personnel Requirements, Medication Training 84065 (3) (m). Additionally, the facility is receiving a technical violation for proceeding with camera installation prior to a waiver being approved. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was left at the facility.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie made an unannounced case management visit and met with Andrew Nguyen Interim Program Administrator(PA). The purpose of the visit is to discuss Incident Report dated 11/06/2022. One client is currently at home due to illness and 4 staff are present. LPA Goldie conducted a walk through of the facility with PA Nguyen both inside and out and observed the following: A living room, reading area room, a sensory room, 4 individual client bedrooms with dresser, bed and desk (three of which are occupied), 2 bathrooms with appropriate amounts of soap and towels, 3 days of perishables and five days of non-perishables, LPA Goldie observed a gym area as well as equipment for the clients and no hazards outside. LPA observed property damage from behaviors that occurred on 12/10/22 and 12/11/22. The broken window in the office is boarded. Holes in walls have been patched. Kitchen cabinetry has been removed. Work orders for damage were submitted 12/10- 12/12 and property management has been to facility and made everything safe. LPA Goldie conducted two staff interviews. Based on information obtained, the following is being cited. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5 84072 (d) (11) , is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D.” LPA Goldie conducted an exit interview at 1:00 PM. A copy of this report along with appeal rights were discussed and provided to PA Nyugen.

Regarding the allegation that staff called minor inappropriate names, statements made during interviews by 4 of 4 staff corroborated that staff and C1 joked back and forth and often client called staff names but, staff did not. Additionally, C1 denied being called names by staff. However, one out of four staff stated that one time they called C1 fat. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation(s) is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6 , Chapter 5 84072 (d) (10) , are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D.” An exit interview was conducted at 11:15 PM, a copy of this report and appeal process was reviewed and provided to the Administrator.

narrative: On 12/28/2022, at 11:03 AM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Connie Goldie made an unannounced visit to conduct an Annual/random inspection. LPA Goldie was greeted at the door by Lead DSP II, Jules Auditor. Program Administrator Interim (PA) Andrew Nguyen assisted LPA Goldie with the inspection. Six staff and 3 clients were present in the home. LPA Goldie observed the following during the inspection of this single story home: The yard is clean. A board with nails exposed and an electrical outlet attatched was loose on the ground. A work order was submitted by PA.. Screens are in good repair. The garage contained an additional refrigerator, outdoor equipment and chemicals in locked cabinetry. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sharps are inaccessible to clients as required. Locked and centrally stored medications along with a complete first aid kit were observed. The facility has 4 single occupancy bedrooms and two client bathrooms. Adequate supply of linens and bedding were observed. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. The dining room has a large table with chairs to accommodate all clients. Carbon monoxide detector and fire extinguishers with pins in place observed and tested. Facility maintains a current fire clearance. Appropriate forms posted in view included license, Client register, and Emergency Intervention Plan. Kitchen observed to have 2 days of non-perishables and 5 days of non-perishables. Temperature was a comfortable 73 degrees . Water temperature measured 113, within compliant range of 105 degrees and 120 degrees. Hygiene supplies were observed in closet along with additional linens and towels. 5 staff interviews and 8 staff record reviews were completed. 1 Type A and 5 Type B Title 22 violations were cited. 1 Technical Violation was given. This is not deficiency. Exit interview conducted at 5:45 PM and reports discussed and provided to facility.

narrative: On 12/28/2022, at 11 :00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Connie Goldie conducted an unannounced visit to complete a random annual. LPA Goldie met with Program Administrator Interim (PA) Andrew Nguyen to assist with the inspection. At 11:25 AM on 03/28/2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie made an unannounced Case Management - Incident inspection to the facility listed above. The reason for the inspection is to review an incident that took place involving a medication error. LPA met with Andrew Nguyen, Program Administrator (PA) who helped facilitate the inspection. LPA Goldie toured facility with PA and observed a single story home with four individual bedrooms with clean linen and adequate furniture , two bathrooms with soap and towels, kitchen with 2 days of perishables and 5 days of non- perishables, sharps and medication were inaccessible. Laundry appliances were observed to be in good repair, Living room . reading nook, and dining area had sufficient seating and were observed to be inviting areas for clients in care. Fire detectors and carbon monoxide were tested and compliant. Outside was toured and observed to be free of hazards/debris.r. LPA inquired about incident that occurred on 03/19/2023 involving a medication error resulting in youth being taken to emergency room. PA stated medication was prepped for all clients at the same time due to a staff member calling out sick and a staff running late. Preparing medication for more than one client at a time is not part of medication protocal /procedures.. Additionally, staff member that passed medication was the verifier and not the passer. Two staff interviews were conducted that corroborated that both of these led to medication being passed to wrong client and client needing to be taken to Kaiser Emergency Room at 1 Quality Drive Vacaville, CA 95688. Facility is being cited for Title 22, Division 6 Chapter 1 80075(b) (5) (B) Health Related Services deficiency. See LIC809D. Exit interview was conducted with Program Administrator and a copy of report along with appeal rights were discussed and provided.

On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie conducted a case management inspection at the facility. The purpose of the inspection was to inquire about two incidents that were reported to the Department on 04/02/2023 and 04/03/2023. LPA met with Andrew Nguyen, Program Administrator, (PA) who helped facilitate the inspection. LPA inquired about medication error incident that occurred on 04/02/2023, the second medication error to happen within 30 days. and the elopement that occurred due to lack of supervision on 04/01/2023.Program Administrator informed LPA of staff who were involved for both incidents. 4 staff interviews were conducted. Further investigation is required. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report was provided to facility.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie made an unannounced Case Management visit to the facility. LPA spoke to Program Administrator, (PA) Andrew Nguyen regarding a case management involving two incident reports (IR) which occurred on 04/01/2023 and 04/02/2023. IR #1 stated C1 eloped from facility due to lack of supervision. LPA interviewed 4 staff and the PA who all corroborated that C1 is a 1:1 client and there was a lapse of supervision when S4, (C1’s assigned staff at the time) used the restroom and did not ensure another staff was supervising C1. As a result, C1 eloped and left through an open garage door. C1 was not discovered to be missing by staff but, by individual at community store. C1 must be within the line of sight of a staff to be kept safe, as he has a history of elopement IR# 2 stated a medication error occurred. PA and staff involved confirmed a medication error occurred due to S1 misreading Medication Administration Record (MAR) and S3 not catching error when verifying medication preparation. Additionally, medication change form was removed from staff sign in area so S1 did not observe it. Lastly, the MAR did not have a black mark to decease previous dosage because date of change was on the last day of March. Based on LPA’s interviews and the incident reports, two Title 22 deficiencies are being cited. 80075 (b)(5) (B) and 84078 (b) One civil penalty is being assessed for repeat violation within 30 days. An exit interview was conducted with PA, Andrew Nguyen and a copy of this report was left at the facility

The Department investigated the complaint that a minor sustained unexplained bruises while in care. Although minor did present with an injury, ( 6 inches long by 2 inches in width of multiple small red circle bruises in a row and scratch marks under his left under arm-), Licensing Program Analyst was unable to determine where injury occurred and who was responsible. Clients in facility are all non-verbal and unable to be interviewed. Facility staff and school staff interviewed all corroborate that C1 demonstrates self injurious behavior. Facility staff stated they did not observe any behavior by clients and/or staff that would have caused the injury. An investigation was completed at C1’s school and staff did not observe behavior that would indicate how the injury in question occurred. Additionally, RP stated they are 95% certain the bruising did not occur at the facility based on “how fresh injuries looked” and C1 had been at school all day prior to injury being observed. Based on the investigation, records reviewed, and interviews conducted, the complaint finding is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. No Title 22 deficiencies were cited. LPA Goldie provided a copy of report along with appeal rights and discussed with Administrator.

On 10/04/2023, at 12:50 PM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Connie Goldie conducted an unannounced visit to follow-up on Case Management inspection conducted on 08/16/2023. One client and 5 staff were present at facility upon arrival. Program Administrator, (PA), Andrew Nguyen assisted with inspection. LPA toured home with PA and observed blinds in bedroom 5 as broken due to behavior of client. PA stated it will be repaired by Friday,10/06/2023. LPA observed them to not be a safety hazard at this time. Case Management inspection pertained to incident report received by the Department on 08/13/2023 which involved C1 obtaining batteries out of a toy and placing them in his mouth. On 08/16/2023 and 08/28/2023, LPA conducted interviews with two staff and learned C1 was in his bedroom enjoying privacy when incident occurred and the staff had no reasonable basis to believe C1 was unsafe. Staff took appropriate action by calling poison control and did take C1 to the hospital to ensure he was safe. Based on the fact that staff are now aware of this potential a technical advisory is being issued. This is not a deficiency. An exit interview was conducted with Mr.Nguyen and a copy of this report along with appeal rights were provided.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie made an unannounced Case Management visit to the facility at 01:50 PM. LPA spoke to Program Administrator, (PA), Andrew Nguyen, regarding a case management involving an incident report dated 09/19/2023. The incident report stated client (C1) had left facility without authorization and was unobserved by assigned staff. C1 requires 1:1 supervision and staff did not maintain supervision resulting in C1 being in an unsafe situation. The lack of supervision resulted in client leaving facility grounds and law enforcement ensuring safety. The client's location was unknown for approximately 15 minutes. LPA interviewed two staff and reviewed employee disciplinary notice for S1. Based on LPA’s interviews and the incident report, one deficiency is being cited, 80078 (a), Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. An exit interview was conducted with PA, Andrew Nguyen, and a copy of this report was left at the facility along with appeal rights..

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a)The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interview,observation and record review. the above requirement was not met when S1 did not maintain supervision of C1 resulting in client eloping from facility and being in an unsafe situation which posed a immediate risk to health, safety and or personal rights risk to persons in care.

narrative: At 03:30 PM on 11/21/2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie made an unannounced Case Management - Incident inspection to the facility listed above.The purpose of the inspection was to inquire about an incident report that was received by the Department on 11/03/2023 for an incident that occurred in the community on 11/01/2023. Program Administrator, (PA) Andrew Nguyen assisted with the inspection. Additionally, two clients, 2 direct care staff, 1 lead staff and a shadow staff were present during visit. One client is on an outing and another is on a home visit. A walk through of the facility was completed and no deficiencies were observed. Two interviews were conducted. At this time, further review is needed for this Case Management. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On 12/06/2023 at 1:10 PM, an unannounced case management inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA), Connie Goldie to follow up on a visit to the facility conducted on 11/21/2023. LPA Goldie met with Margarita Hernandez, Lead staff, who assisted with the visit. During phone call with Andrew Nguyen, Program Administrator on 11/09/2023, LPA learned that C1 was in the community with only one staff which wasn’t compliant with ratio determined necessary in C1’s Individual Program Plan as C1 requires a 2:1 staff to client ratio in the community. As a result, C1 ran away and was unsafe in the community without supervision for an hour and a half. During visit to facility on 11/21/2023, LPA conducted 2 staff interviews and both staff stated that procedures in place to ensure safety of C1 were not followed. LPA interviewed a witness who stated that incident of C1 being unsafe in the community, without supervision, could have been avoided if staff followed the rules. The agency is being cited for one Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, violation Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision 84078(b). An exit interview was conducted where the citation and plan of correction were discussed. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mentioned above.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision 84078 (b) The licensee shall provide those services identified in each child's needs and services plan ... as necessary to meet the child's needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interview and record review the facility did not implement the level of supervision as indicated by Regional Center on a consistent basis as required when C1 was taken into the community with a 1:1 ratio vs 2:1 ratio necessary. This posed an immediate risk to health, safety and/or personal rights risk to persons in care.

narrative: On 12/14/2023, at 09:35 AM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Connie Goldie made an unannounced visit to conduct an Annual/Required inspection. LPA Goldie was greeted at the door by Program Administrator, Andrew Nguyen who assisted LPA Goldie with the inspection. 5 staff and 0 clients were present in the home. LPA Goldie observed the following during the inspection of this single story home: Documentation required posted in office included License, Client roster, and Emergency Disaster plan. Grievance forms were observed to be accessible to residents in hallway adjacent to office door. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. The spacious living room included seating for residents and staff as well as guests to engage with one another. Sharps are inaccessible to clients as required in a locked drawer in kitchen. Locked and centrally stored medications along with a complete first aid kit were observed. The facility has 4 single occupancy bedrooms and two client bathrooms. Water tested in bathroom #2 and kitchen measured 122 degrees which is not in compliance range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. Program Administrator adjusted the water heater and afterwards, temperature measured at 115 degrees. Adequate supply of linens and bedding were observed. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. Bedroom four was observed to be missing a top sheet. The dining room has a large table with chairs to accommodate all clients. Carbon monoxide detector and fire extinguishers with pins in place observed and tested. Facility maintains a current fire clearance. Kitchen observed to have 2 days of perishables and 5 days of non-perishables. Temperature was a comfortable 74 degrees. Hygiene supplies were observed in closet along with additional linens and towels. 4 staff interviews and 5 staff record reviews were completed. 3 Type B Title 22 violations are being cited during today's inspection. Additionally, 3 Technical Violations are being issued. These are not deficiencies. LPA will return to complete Annual inspection on a later date. Exit interview conducted at 5:10 PM and reports discussed and provided to facility.

On 06/19/2024 at 09:40 AM, an unannounced case management inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA), Connie Goldie to follow up on Waiver rescission issued on 06/14/2024 and received by facility on 06/17/2024. LPA Goldie met with Andrew Nguyen ,Program Administrator. (PA) who assisted with the inspection. 5 staff and 4 youth are present. LPA conducted a walk through of the facility with PA Nguyen. LPA observed the cameras to no longer be in C1's bedroom as requested by the Department. No deficiencies were observed. An exit interview was completed at 10:10 AM with Mr. Nguyen and a copy of this report was provided to the facility.

The Department investigated the complaint that a minor sustained unexplained bruises while in care. Although minor did present with an injury, (a linear bruise on his thigh above the top of his knee about 2 inches long and ½ inch thick and a bruise to the kneecap about 3 inches wide, both were purple, brown in color.) C1 is non-verbal and non-ambulatory. C1 engages in self-harm behaviors. Both the school and home stated that C1 has SIB (Self Injury Behavior) The reporting party stated that C1 likes to hit his head with his leg but that this injury is different and was concerned about C1 receiving 1:1 care at home. The reporting party stated that the injury was noticed at approximately 10:00 AM on 7/24/2024 at C1’s school. Facility staff and school staff interviewed all corroborate that C1 demonstrates self injurious behavior. The increase in C1’s SIB (Self-injury-behavior) behavior could be the result of a medication change according to the Administrator. During confidential interviews with staff at the home C1 is receiving 1:1 care during the day and 1:2 care at night. This is also noted in C1’s Needs and Service Plan. At school C1 is receiving 1:1 care. LPA Shelton observed C1 at school on 7/31/24 and notice a red mark on C1’s noise and the injury to C1’s was no longer purple or brown in color. Based on the investigation, records reviewed, and interviews conducted, the complaint finding is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. No Title 22 deficiencies were cited. LPA Shelton provided a copy of the report along with appeal rights and discussed with Administrator.

Based on the investigation, records reviewed, and interviews conducted, the complaint finding is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred.
