narrative: On 01/07/2025, at 09:15 AM , Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA), Connie Goldie, made an unannounced, subsequent visit for the purpose of closing out a Case Management, regarding incidents that were reported to the Department on 10/11/2024, 10/14/2024 and 10/24/2024.LPA met with McKenzie Jeppson, Registered Behavior Technician . LPA interviewed the licensee and five staff members for an incident reported on 10/24/2024 and the licensee and ten staff members for the incidents reported on 10/11/2024 and 10/14/2024. Based on interviews and review of incident reports, it was identified that the incidents reported on 10/11/2024 were reported 2-3 months after observation by S2 and on 10/14/2024 2-3 weeks afterwards by S8 and therefore, the facility was out of compliance with reporting requirements. S2 and S8 both admitted to not reporting timely as required. Three staff members stated they did not have training on reporting requirements that they understood until a month ago. Additionally, three staff (S3, S4 and S7) stated the trampoline was used to isolate a client, C1, as the netting was zipped and clipped. It was stated that S3 and S8 did this. This is a personal rights violation. The facility is being cited for two Title 22 deficiencies, Reporting Requirements 80061(b) and Personal Rights 84072(d)(1). See LIC809D. Fenina Pham, licensee, provided the plan of correction via telephone. The case management is closed. No follow-up investigation is required. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were discussed and provided to McKenzie Jeppson, Registered Behavior Technician.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement was not met as evidence by: Based on record review and interviews, the licensee did not comply with the section cited above due to S1 taking C1 on a van ride alone on 4/16/2025, who requires 2:1 supervision during van rides. On 4/16/2025 during an inspection conducted by DDS, it was observed that the facility was out of ratio upon their arrival, with three staff present when five staff were required, which poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.

80076(a)(1) Food Services. In facilities providing meals to clients, the following shall apply: All food shall be safe and of the quality and in the quantity necessary to meet the needs of the clients. All food shall be selected, stored, prepared and served in a safe and healthful manner. This requirement was not met as evidence by: Based on observation and interviews, it was observed by LPA and LPM that there was an open package of ground turkey open and not stored properly in the freezer. Which poses a potential health, safety or personal right risk to persons in care.

80087(a) Buildings and Grounds. The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. This requirement was not met as evidence by: Based on observations and interviews which were conducted by LPA on 4/17/25 and DDS on 4/16/2025, the licensee did not comply with the section cited above due to two cabinet doors broken off the hinges in the kitchen, a broken drawer which makes it difficult to open properly and a hole in the wall by the laundry room, which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care.

narrative: The incident occurred on January 11, 2025, at 9:30AM, it was stated that S7 took C1 on a van ride alone and when leaving the facility, C1 appeared to be fine with no signs of injuries. Upon his return from the outing around 11AM, C1 was given his lunch and laid down for a nap. When S9 woke up C1 from his nap at 2pm, he observed C1 to have bruising on his head. When S2 observed C1, a big fresh bruise was noticed on the right side of C1’s head, redness on C1’s nose which appeared worse than it was when observed in the morning at 7:30AM. During the shift change, S7 told S2 that the minor had redness on his nose, a red mark on his neck and bruising around his eye. S2 stated S7 did not appear concerned about the injuries. S2 checked the body scan from the previous day, January 10, 2025, and stated that it did not mention any bruising on C1’s head. Record review by LPA of body data documentation indicates that there was not bruising on C1’s head on 01/10/2025. LPA conducted a record review of C1’s file. It is indicated on C1’s IBST (Individualized Behavior Support Team) which was conducted on 12/14/2024, that he is a 1:1 ratio. Within this report, it was stated that Polaris will “provide additional staff support during changing, bathing and riding in the van. Outings are to be planned in advance with the lead staff or other available staff to support the outing and at least one staff person should be seated in the back of the van with C1.” Additionally, it is indicated on Polaris’ “key strategies document” under the section labeled, “things we should always do to help”, it was indicated that C1 will have additional staff present during van rides. This was not being implemented. Three out of twelve staff who were interviewed stated, “some don’t react as fast” and “they are not quite sure when to intervene” but they do intervene. Twelve out of twelve staff interviewed state that they do get continuous training's to help clients who engage in self injurious behaviors. Due to the clients in the home being non-verbal, they were unable to make any statements during this investigation. Based on LPAs observations, record review and interviews which were conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore, the above allegation(s) is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights discussed. A copy of all reports along with the appeal rights were provided to the facility.

narrative: During confidential interviews, it was confirmed that S2 did lock C1 in the room for more than thirty minutes without anyone taking over his 1:1. C1 was locked in his room without having anyone near his door to ensure that he was safe. While discussing the allegation with Administrator, Benjamin Rimorin, he stated that due to the most recent behaviors from C2 towards C1, it was discussed and decided between the Licensee, Fenina Pham, Administrator Benjamin Rimorin and the Behavioral Specialist, Haley Garr, that in order to provide extra protection for C1, it would be approved to lock C1 in his room to add an extra barrier between C1 and C2. The condition of this was that staff are to still sit in the hallway to be close to C1 and if for any reason the assigned staff needed to leave their position at any time, they are to notify the lead on shift, and provide the key to C1’s door and then the lead is to take over that staff’s 1:1 until they return. Seven out of eight confidential interviews confirmed that it is allowed to lock C1 in his room. The Department has investigated the complaint alleging staff locked minor in the room for an extended period of time and staff did not provide adequate supervision to minor. Based on LPAs interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter1, are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview and appeal rights were discussed with Margarita Hernandez, Lead and a copy of this report was provided.

narrative:
LPA reviewed the video footage of the incident and observed C1 going towards C2s bedroom which is out of the cameras sight. Shortly after, you see C1 pulling C2 on the ground by his left arm and pulls him into his room. During confidential interviews, four out of six interviews stated that they were short staffed on February 22, 2025, which is why no one was sitting outside of C2s room. S1, S2 and S3 who were present at the time of the incident, all stated that they did not see or hear anything. The Department has investigated the complaint alleging Staff did not prevent minor in care from engaging in inappropriate interactions with other minor in care. Based on LPAs interviews which were conducted, review of video footage and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter5, are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview and appeal rights were discussed with Benjamin Rimorin, Administrator and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights were provided.

Polaris has worked on preventing C1 from gaining access to C2 by making sure that C2 is never left alone and if he is in his room, staff are always sitting right outside his door. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview and appeal rights were discussed with Benjamin Rimorin, Administrator. A copy of this report along with the appeal rights were given to name and title.
investigation_findings: 13On 5/23/2025 at 09:10 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michelle Silvas initiated an unannounced complaint investigation inspection at the above listed facility. LPA met with Benjamin Rimorin, Administrator, who assisted with the inspection. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver findings for the above listed allegation. Six staff and no clients are present. On May 2, 2025, the Department received a complaint regarding this incident. LPA conducted the initial 10-day complaint investigation at the facility on May 7, 2025. LPA conducted six confidential interviews between 4/22/25 – 5/19/25. It was alleged that staff did not prevent minor in care from engaging in inappropriate interactions with other minor in care. It was reported that on February 22, 2025, at approximately 8:00AM, C2, who is non-ambulatory, was in his room sleeping while his 1:1, S1 was in the kitchen preparing C2s breakfast. C1 was in the living room watching TV with his 1:1, S3. C1 left to go towards his room and his 1:1 did not follow him. Around 8:23AM, C2s 1:1, S1, went to his room and noticed that he was not in his room. S1 found C2 in the bedroom of C1 propped up in an upright position on C1s bed. S1 then assisted C2 back to his room. Continue LIC9099-C

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80078(a) Responsibility for providing Care and Supervision: The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement was not met as evidence by: Based on record review, video footage and interviews, the licensee did not comply with the section cited above when C2 was left in his room without his 1:1 nearby which gave direct access to C1 who went into C2s room and dragged him into C1s bedroom and was not observed to be missing from his room for nearly thirty minutes, which poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.

84072(d)(19) Personal Rights: (d)The licensee shall ensure that each child… (19) To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, exploitation, infliction of pain … This requirement was not met as evidence by: Based on record review, interviews and video footage, the licensee did not comply with the section cited above when C1 had direct access to C2 who was in his bedroom and dragged him out of his own room and into C1s room, which poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights rist to persons in care.

narrative: On 12/5/2024, at 10:25 AM, Licensing Program Analysts, (LPAs) Michelle Silvas and Connie Goldie made an unannounced visit to conduct an Annual/Required inspection. LPAs Silvas and Goldie were greeted at the door by Program Administrator, Benjamin Rimorin who assisted LPAs Silvas and Goldie with the inspection. 2 staff and 0 clients were present in the home. LPAs Silvas and Goldie observed the following during the inspection of this single story home: Documentation required posted in office included License, Client roster, and Emergency Disaster plan. Copies of the LIC 500 and LIC 610C and the roster of Minors were requested and received. Grievance forms were observed to be accessible to residents in hallway adjacent to office door. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. The spacious living room included seating for residents and staff as well as guests to engage with one another. Sharps are inaccessible to clients as required in a locked drawer in kitchen. Locked and centrally stored medications along with a complete first aid kit were observed. The facility has 4 single occupancy bedrooms and two client bathrooms. Water tested in bathroom #1 measured at 108 and kitchen measured 106 degrees which is in compliance range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. Adequate supply of linens and bedding were observed. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. The dining room has a large table with chairs to accommodate all clients. Dual smoke and Carbon monoxide detectors and fire extinguishers with pins in place observed and tested. Facility maintains a current fire clearance. Fire doors are currently not functioning but a work order has been submitted. Kitchen observed to have 2 days of perishables and 5 days of non-perishables. Temperature was a comfortable 68 degrees. Hygiene supplies were observed in closet along with additional linens and towels. All three vans were inspected and tires have good tread, seat belts working properly and all signal lights functioning properly. One van was missing a first aid kit and the other two need replenishment. 1 Type B Title 22 violation is being cited during today's inspection. Additionally, 1 Technical Violation is being issued. This is not a deficiency. LPAs will return to complete Annual inspection on a later date. Exit interview conducted at 3:46 PM and reports discussed and provided to facility.

On 12/06/2024, Licensing Program Analysts, (LPAs) Michelle Silvas and Connie Goldie made an unannounced subsequent visit to complete the Annual required inspection at 10:00 AM. LPAs Silvas and Goldie completed staff and client record review domains in the Care Tools including medication review of Medical Administration Records. LPAs completed 5 staff interviews. During the inspection, five Type B Title 22 regulation violations were cited. See LIC809D pages. One technical assistance was issued. This is not a deficiency. Annual Required inspection will be finalized upon the completion of the 4 client interviews. Exit interview was conducted with Program Administrator and reports along with appeal rights were discussed and provided.

met_with: Fenina Pham Owner of LLC & Benjamin Rimorin Administrator
narrative: On June 4, 2025, at 10:00 AM, Regional Manager, Margo Castaneda, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michelle Silvas conducted a Non-Compliance Review Meeting in the Sacramento Regional Office. The purpose of the office meeting is to discuss some serious concerns related to recent complaint findings and other compliance concerns identified. The following NCC primary areas of concern were reviewed: lack of oversight of the facility, staff to child ratio, medication errors and lack of leadership. The compliance for Polaris: was reviewed for the time period of March 2023- May 2025. Operation of the facility was discussed and additional documentation related to the operation of the facility and compliance plan is documented on the LIC9111. A copy of this report was sent to Fenina Pham, Owner of LLC, for signature.

LPA Silvas received an email from Administrator, Benjamin Rimorin, on 12/23/2024 indicating that the accused staff, Joha Thomas, will no longer be working at Polaris. Regarding the allegation that staff hit and kicked youth, staff yelled at youth and staff threw objects at youth, statements made during interviews by 2 of 6 staff and video footage of client pointing to alleged staff, corroborated that staff did hit and kick youth, staff yelled at youth and staff threw objects at youth. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation(s) is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report and appeal process was reviewed and provided to the Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michelle Silvas arrived at the agency to conduct an unannounced complaint investigation inspection on 1/16/2025 at 9:10 AM. LPA Silvas toured the facility and interviewed six staff. Copies of facility documentation provided to LPA Silvas included: staff schedule for the next two weeks, contact information for the noc shift staff, daily shift notes for the child, daily notebook notes and body scan notes. Four clients were not interviewed as they are non-verbal. LPA Silvas observed all four clients on 12/16/2024. Records review of documents obtained was completed on 12/16/2024. Continued on LIC9099C.

narrative:
On 7/14/22 at 9:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriouez conducted a Pre-Licensing Inspection, Component II and Component III at the above facility. LPA Lor and LPM Rodriguez met with the Regional Program Director and Cheryl Gutierrez. The facility consisted of a formal living room equipped with a set of 3 couches, a formal dining room equipped with a large table with 6 chairs. There is a resting area/second living room area equipped with a TV and board games. The kitchen was equipped with counter space with 4 stools, locked cabinets to store the sharp objects/knives and dish soaps, plates, utensils, cups, silverware, and a large trash can with lid on. 2 office rooms, one room will be used for staff and to lock the files and medication. The second office (the garage) will be utilized by the Administrator. There are 4 bedrooms equipped with a full size beds, closet (curtain will be installed) dresser, night stand, trash can with lid, 2 1/2 bathrooms, one bathroom is for ambulatory clients and the second bathroom is built especially for non-ambulatory clients. Laundry room equipped with a washer/dryer and lock cabinets to store the laundry soap. There is an open back patio, backyard with a basketball court, and a gated section in back for gardening, The front yard was clean and free of hazards. The telephone land line and internet service were in working order. The water temperature was tested and it was between 105 - 120 degrees. There was a little of perishable/non-perishable food available but more will be purchased prior the first placement. During the pre-inspection, LPA Lor and LPM Rodriguez observed the following: 1 first aid kit which was missing the thermometer, and instruction booklet, 2 fire extinguisher located by the main (see 2nd page)

entrance, and kitchen area, carbon monoxide and smoke detector were built in throughout the entire house, system was tested and in working condition. Component II was completed during today's inspection and the following areas of the Program Statement were reviewed with the Regional Program Director: Program Description, Client Service, Emergency/Disaster Plan, and Exit Criteria. No additional modifications are needed for the Program Statement. Component III was also completed during today's inspection and the following forms were reviewed with the Regional Program Director: LIC198A -Child Abuse Central Index Check for State Licensed Facilities (family child care homes; children’s residential homes and facilities; and adult residential facilities if, through an approved exception or a specialized license, they provide care to a person under age 18), LIC198B - Out-of-State Child Abuse/Neglect Report Request, · LIC 306-Reporting Requirements to Department. of Social Services, LIC 308 - Designation of Facility Responsibility, LIC 500 - Personnel Report, LIC 501 - Personnel Record, LIC 503 - Health Screening Report (including TB Clearance), LIC 508 -Criminal Record Statement, LIC 508D - Out-of-State Disclosure & Criminal Record Statement, LIC 613B - Personal Rights, LIC 624 -Unusual Incident/Injury/Death Report, LIC 627B - Consent for Medical Treatment, LIC 9058 - Applicant/Licensee Rights, LIC 9182 - Criminal Background Clearance Transfer Request, LIC 9188 Criminal Record Exemption Transfer Request, Appendix D - A Guide to Safeguarding Resident/Client Cash Resources, LIC 311B - Records to be Maintained in a Group Home, LIC 311E - Records to be Maintained in a Small Family Home, LIC 313 - Evidence of Program Consultant (Group Homes), · LIC 601 Identification and Emergency Information, LIC 602 - Physician’s Report for Community Care Facilities, LIC 603 - Preplacement Appraisal Information, LIC 622 - Centrally Stored Medication and Destruction Record, LIC 625 - Appraisal/Needs and Services Plan, LIC 9106 - Group Home Program Statement, LIC 9106A - Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Statement General Instructions, LIC 9128 - Foster Family Agency Program Statement, Neighborhood Complaint Policy (see 3rd page)

Regional Program Director was instructed to obtain the following items: Thermometer, First Aid Instruction Booklet, and a small refrigerator to utilize if medication needs to be stored in the refrigerator. LPM Rodriguez informed the Regional Program Director that the facility cannot be licensed until CCL received certification from DDS and certification for the Administrator from the Regional Center. Exit interview conducted with Regional Program Director and a copy of the report will be emailed by 07/15/2022.

On 8/10/23 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Stephanie Lor made an unannounced visit to conduct a case management regarding an incident report received by Community Care Licensing for an incident that occurred on 7/19/23 regarding missed medication. On 8/10/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor made an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Post Licensing Inspection. LPA met with the Program Administrator who provided LPA with a tour of the interior and exterior of the facility. LPA observed the following: This facility has 4 bedrooms, 2 living rooms, 2 staff office, kitchen, backyard and 3 bathrooms. LPA observed fixtures and furniture, equipment, and supplies necessary for this operation. LPA observed locked cabinets personnel files to ensure confidentiality. Facility was unable to test out smoke detectors due to the high ceiling, but showed proof of annual testing for the alarms. LPA observed chemicals and sharps to be locked. A first aid kit and fire extinguishers were on site. The water temperature was tested at a safe temperature. LPA Lor observed the agency’s license posted in the front entrance. A Technical Assistant (TA) was provided to post up personal rights poster, complaint procedure, and emergency disaster plan in a common area. The agency currently employs one Administrator, one Administrative Assistant, and 6 Direct Support Professionals. The agency currently has one client on site. LPA reviewed one client’s file with all required documents. During today’s inspection there are no deficiencies cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to the Administrator at the conclusion of the inspection.

On December 18, 2023 at approximately 08:45 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Farhaan Sarangi and Sara Luman-Gonzalez arrived unannounced at Turning Point-Avalon for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Other inspection to verify training of facility staff members. During the Case Management-Other inspection, LPAs reviewed a sample of staff records and observed that 1 out of 6 staff members does not have an active First Aid/CPR Card (See LIC 9102-Technical Violation). The remaining 5 staff members have an active First Aid/CPR Card. In addition, LPA reviewed training and observed that 6 of 6 staff members have the required 40 hours of initial training and 20 hours of annual training as outlined in Title 22 regulations. LPA toured the facility and observed the facility to be clean and at a comfortable temperature with all exits free from obstruction. However, LPA did observe a screen that was not on a clients window. Administrator stated that the client took off the screen and that staff members will reinstall it today (See LIC 9102-Technical Advisory) LPA observed sufficient perishable and non-perishable foods. LPA observed that all medications were centrally stored and locked as outlined in Title 22 regulations. Fire Extinguishers were last charged on May 2023. No deficiencies were cited during today's Case Management-Other inspection. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was signed and given to the Administrator.

8 out of 11 interviews stated that the staff at the facility were being dignified and giving the youths at the facility respect. 2 of 3 youths placed at the facility state that the staff treat them well and that they have no complaints with the staff. Secondly, based on records review, it is noted that C1 does have a history of not telling the truth, attempting to control others, or manipulating others to get their way. Also, the Service Coordinator for the youth in question has no concerns for the treatment of the youth in the facility. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did occur therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, and Appeal Rights were discussed with Shadayleon Walker, Facility Administrator Assistant. A copy of this report and Appeal Rights were left at the facility.

facility_name: TURNING POINT OF CENTRAL CALIFORNIA INC.-ATLANTIS
narrative: On the date above a pre licensing visit was conducted at Turning Point of Central California-Atlantis by Licensing Program analyst (LPA) Les Inouye. I was met by Administrator Alicia Carroll and Rosemary Maurillio. A review of the Physical Plant was conducted including the Indoor Activity Space, Fixtures Furniture Equipment and Supplies and Outdoor Activity Space. The indoor space is an open floor plan with not hazards. Kitchen non-perishable items were observed in the pantry. Lockable drawers for sharps, cleaning supplies were observed. Bedrooms were observed, 4 single occupancy and a capacity of 4. All bedroom doors are key locked. All rooms were appropriately furnished with additional linens was observed and adequate space for clients. All chemicals and cleaning supplies were locked and secured. Smoke Alarms and Carbon Monoxide detectors, fire suppression system and fire extinguishers was observed and operating. Fire door between bedrooms and living room/kitchen was observed. Hot water temperature was measured at 118 degrees. Staff office was observed with medication cabinet and supples. The outdoor area is fee of hazards. There is a utility shed in the back yard which is secured. Back yard there is no pool or hot tub, yard consisted of a lawn area, basketball court and raised bed planting boxes. The back fence is metal and has a view of city walking path "Dry Creek Trail". The garage is converted to an office space for the administrator and Asst. Administrator. Garage doors are fully functional and central air conditioning has been added. Laundry room is open with no doors. The indoor activity spaces (2) had games. The facility does not use a Delayed Egress system. The physical plant review was observed to be clean, safe, and free of hazards. The physical plant has met. Other issues to be reviewed during the Plan of Operation submission will be updating the facility floor plan, mattress and box spring combination and Emergency Generator.

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with Dr. Moore-Fulton via Zoom to conduct the pre-licensing evaluation. The following was observed. This is a four bedroom, 2 bathroom home located in a residential section to the City of Compton, CA. There are no security bars, bodies of water, firearms or fireplaces on the premises. There is a security system and sprinkler system in place, There is a surveillance system with camera that do not face into bedrooms or bathrooms. The surveillance system is video only In the kitchen area there is a fully stocked refrigerator and a working gas range. The kitchen cabinets appear to be fully stocked with canned and dried foods. There are adequate plates and utensils for four clients There is locked storage for sharp knives, medicines and household cleaners. There is separate locked space for refrigerated medicines in the office. The showers and toilets in the two bathrooms appear to be clean and functional. There are no hazardous items stored under the sinks. The home is fully furnished with living room and dining room furniture. Each of the four bedrooms has 1 bed equipped with a blanket, sheet set, pillows and a mattress cover. There is the required closet and drawer space in each room. There are no security bars on bedroom windows. There is a fully stocked first aid kit in the hallway closet. Outside yard space was free of visible hazards. There are tables and chairs at which clients may sit if they wish to sit outside. There were no physical plant deficiencies noted during the pre-licensing inspection..

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward arrived at the facility at 2:00 PM to conduct the post-licensing inspection. However LPA found to the home to be under minor construction due to findings by the City of Compton that un-permitted additions to the home had been completed prior to Dr. Moore-Fulton purchasing the house. LPA did not observe any dangers to the clients in care. Dr. Moore-Fulton estimates that the construction will be completed by the week of 01/17/22. LPA advised Dr. Moore-Fulton to submit a letter detailing the necessary construction and also the measures that are being taken to keep the clients safe. LPA will return to the home to complete the post-licensing inspection after the construction work is complete.

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with lead staff Orlando Omoruyi to follow up on the incident of 05/01/22. Dr. Moore-Fulton joined about 15 minutes into the interview. In this incident Client #1 was reported to have assaulted a staff member with a metal pole that he found in the backyard. Mr. Ompruyi states he was not on duty during the incident and does not know the details. However he states that the backyard is kept free of hazards. LPA Jones-Steward observed the backyard as well as the yard areas along side the house. Client reported that he hit staff with a pole that was used to hold up a tree. LPA observed a white pole that was stuck loosely into the ground and used to support a small tree. LPA advised Mr. Omoruyi that the pole needs to be secured into the ground or removed. Mr. Omoruyi removed the pole and locked it in the tool shed.

However the regional center has instructed the facility to keep the bed open until they can figure out what to do with her. LPA observed that the yard area was free of visible hazards. There is a current menu posted. The following are also posted: Floor plan, employee schedule, notice of employee rights and client complaint procedure. Restraint log and medication logs were reviewed. LPA interviewed the one client who was present at time of inspection. LPA will interview staff at a later date. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection

narrative: On September 17, 2024, at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem and applicant Richard Enriquez (RE) met at the Community Care Licensing San Diego office for a Component II orientation. LPA and RE went over application revisions and discussed the application process prior to licensure. RE stated that the facility should be ready for fire inspection in two months at the earliest, and LPA advised RE to remain in contact with the fire inspector. A pre-licensing inspection will be scheduled once the applicant’s revisions are approved by the Department and fire clearance and criminal background clearance are received. A signed copy of this report was provided to applicant Enriquez.

On July 8, 2025, at 10:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem met with Administrator/Applicant Richard Enriquez and Lead Direct Support Professional Salvador Anton for the purpose of conducting a pre-licensing inspection for an Enhanced Behavioral Support Home. Applicant Enriquez is applying for a license for four clients age 12-17, two non-ambulatory. The home is a one story residence located on a residential street. LPA, Applicant Enriquez, and lead DSP toured the home inside and out. LPA inspected the facility’s physical plant, including personal rights postings, health related services, buildings and grounds, food services, telephones, indoor and outdoor activity space, and furniture, fixtures, equipment and supplies. The home is clean, in good repair, and free from observable risks to clients' health, safety, and personal rights. The current home contains a four client bedrooms, two client bathrooms, kitchen, two open living room areas, staff office, garage, backyard with storage shed, and staff closet and locked file cabinet where client files and medications will be stored. The license will be posted in the front hallway upon licensure. The client bedrooms will be set up as follows: bedroom 1 sleeps one ambulatory client, bedroom 2 sleeps one ambulatory client, bedroom 3 sleeps one non-ambulatory client, and bedroom 4 sleeps one non-ambulatory client. The home has a cental smoke and carbon monoxide detection system, which is connected to the facility's approved delayed egress system, in additional to other protective measures for non-ambulatory clients, such as automatically closing fire door. The home also contains ramps for all entrances and grab bars in the client bathroom next to the bedrooms designated for non-ambulatory clients. The facility has demonstrated compliance with Title 22, Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator/Applicant Richard Enriquez.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tana Kinder conducted an unannounced Post Licensing inspection of the facility. Due to Covid19, the inspection occurred using the video conferencing platform, Facetime. LPA met with DSP, Joe Brooks and inspected the facility inside and out. The facility is licensed to serve 4 clients, between the ages of 6-18. There are currently 3 male residents. There are 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. LPA observed the facility to be clean, safe and sanitary. The walkways were free of obstruction throughout the house and backyard. There is a locked shed in the backyard that contains extra cleaning supplies and bottled water. The outside area consists of the following: A garden area with raised beds, picnic table, benches, basketball court, play equipment in an open shed structure, walking paths, and bicycles. Documentation was posted which included, personal rights emergency exit plan, disaster plan, Covid19 protocol, and grievance procedure. Employee and clients files are kept in a locked cabinet in the garage. A fully stocked first aid kit is kept in the staff office. Each client had a hygiene kit kept in a locked cabinet in the bathroom. The window screens were in good repair. Medication disbursement is logged using the program, Quick MAR and is cross reconciled with the bubble packs and bottles medications are kept in. There are two fire extinguishers that are fully charged, with current tags. The facility vehicle is a mini van with current tags that will expire in April of 2021. The tire tread was in a safe range. The kitchen knives were kept in a locked cabinet. The kitchen was stocked with enough perishable/non-perishable food for 3/12 days for 3 clients. The March menu was misplaced and will be addressed as a Technical Assistance advisory note. The kitchen was stocked with plates, utensils and drinking cups sufficient for 4 clients. The water temperature in the kitchen faucet was 114 degrees. Each client's bedroom had a firm mattress, with a bed cover, sheets, blanket and pillows. There were addition linen in the laundry room, along with additional bath towels and face cloths. Laundry supplies were stored in a locked cabinet. LPA will request records and documentation for review. No deficiencies noted at today's evaluation. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was emailed to the Administrator, Kayla Barreto at kayla@walkoflifejustamere.com

investigation_findings: 13On 7/30/2021 at 1045am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Tana Kinder conducted an unannounced inspection to deliver complaint investigation findings with the group home senior lead. Prior to the meeting, LPA Kinder reviewed the agency’s file at the licensing office, including the complaint history, criminal background check, incident reports and facility personnel report summary. LPA Kinder conducted an inspection of the facility inside and out and no citations were issued. LPA conducted 17 confidential interviews between 6/22/2021-7/27/2021. LPA obtained and reviewed the following documents: 2 IPPs, 2 behavioral assessments, log notes. Confirmed staffing schedule for 2 clients for 6/18/2021 and staff in general for that day, staffing for the month of May/June 2021, staff training records for 2020-2021, staffing roster with contact information, Elk Grove Police Department report and facility sketch. The allegation is: Staff did not provide adequate supervision to minors while in care. Based on 5 interviews there is corroboration that staff were not providing line of sight supervision for either client during the time of the incident. The staff were being provided a brief training that resulted in no direct supervision for enough time to allow clients to engage in inappropriate behaviors. Continue...

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This was not met as evidenced by: Based on the interview with staff present during incident, the facility did not ensure staff was providing proper care and supervision to the client which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.

narrative:
An annual required inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tana Kinder on 3/02/2022 with Senior Lead DSP/DSP. Criminal record clearances were reviewed, and the facility is in compliance. Community Care Licensing file, incident reports, facility roster, facility profile and complaint history were reviewed prior to visit at the agency. The licensing fees are current. The EBSH Facility has a capacity of 4 and currently 1 resident. There are 21 staff members associated to the license and 3 currently working at the EBSH Facility. LPA reviewed 5 staff files, all which were reviewed were complete and up to date. Staff files reviewed have required training hours, education, and fingerprint clearances. 1 child file was reviewed. The child’s needs and services plan/Individual Program Plan, Behavioral Plan (IBST) and quarterly reviews were complete and up to date. Immunization records were current. Medical consent forms were signed by authorized representative and current. Additionally, the child’s file had a record of personal property. Personal rights, menu, license and emergency exit plan were posted. The facility was inspected jointly with Teja Ordonez-Phillips, Senior Lead DSP/RBT of the EBSH Facility. LPA attempted to interview 1 client, but due to their diagnosis of intellectual disability and Autism, the client was not able to communicate verbally. There are 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. Each client's bedroom had a firm mattress, with a bed cover, sheets, blanket and pillows. Additionally there is a sensory room for the clients to play in. The common area has couches and chairs to sit in, a TV and an in-door basketball hoop game for the clients. The facility is in good repair. There are cabinets in the laundry room with additional linen if needed for the bedrooms and the bathrooms. Additionally, each bedroom also has extra linen available. Client and staff files are in locked cabinets, in a locked office. The passageways from the front to the back of the facility are unobstructed. LPA observed 2 locked sheds in the backyard with facility supplies and client belongings and 1 unlocked shed with toys/equipment for the clients. LPA observed enough perishable/non-perishable food for 1 client for 4 days/2 weeks. Smoke detectors are in working order. There is a carbon monoxide monitor and 2 fully charged fire extinguishers. Continued...

Disinfectants and cleaning solutions were in a locked cabinet in the laundry room. Sharps were kept locked in the office. The kitchen was stocked with plates, utensils and drinking cups sufficient for 4 clients. The water temperature from the bathroom faucet was 105.4 degrees. Medication disbursement is logged using the program, Quick MAR and is cross reconciled with the bubble packs and bottles medications are stored in. The client's hygiene kit was stocked and stored in a locked cabinet in the bathroom. A fully stocked first aid kit is kept in the staff office. Exit interview conducted, and discussed with Teja Ordonez-Phillips,Lead DSP. No citations were issued and a copy of the annual inspection report was provided to the Administrator.

Based on LPA’s observations and interviews that were conducted and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulation, Title22, 84072 (d)(11) is being cited on the attached LIC9099D. Exit interview conducted, a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights will be provided to the Agency.

The incident was reviewed with the Facility Administrator. LPA reviewed documentation and the plan that was developed to address the issue. No citations were issued. On May 20, 2021 at 1:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kourtney Williams and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore conducted an annual inspection of the facility. The facility was toured inside and out with facility administrator, Evelyn Preston. The home is a one-story residence with four bedrooms and two bathrooms. Two clients and five staff including the administrator were present at the facility during the inspection. The home was approved for two non-ambulatory clients and two ambulatory clients age 6-18. The bedrooms were arranged so that there was one client to a room, and there was one client per bed. Client #1 was in room #1 and Client # 2 was in room #3. The facility currently had two vacant rooms. Clients bedrooms had the required furniture and linens. Clients had adequate hygiene supplies stocked in the hallway closets near client rooms. There were adequate shelves and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water was measured to be 110.F degrees. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The kitchen had adequate cooking supplies and utensils. The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the kitchen. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the kitchen underneath the kitchen sink and additional cleaning supplies were located in the garage. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The First Aid Kit was located inside the staff office and contained all required items. The living room area had a closet with age appropriate games and activities. The garage had activity equipment for clients and laundry area. The facility's smoke detectors in the hallway near the front door were checked and were operable. The carbon monoxide detector located in the hallway near the front door was operable. All windows and screens were in good repair. There were no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Administrator Evelyn Preston. There were cameras in the common areas and outside the facility. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance procedures, personal rights, ombudsman poster, visitation policies, and current menu. Cont on 809 C

Clients medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in the kitchen cabinet. The medication logs were kept updated and the dispensing records had no discrepancies. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. Two clients were interviewed and indicated that they feel safe in the home and accorded their personal rights. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. In the back yard, there was a locked swimming pool inaccessible to clients. The pool was surrounded by a wrought iron fence measured over 6 feet tall with a gate that self-latches and opens outward. The facility had an operable delayed egress and sprinkler systems. Clients files were reviewed and following document were present: Independent Behavior Support Plan, Individual Program Plan, health records, LIC 621 and medical consent. Staff records including current crisis prevention intervention (CPI), First Aid and CPR were reviewed during the inspection. The facility emergency plan was also reviewed Two staff including the administrator had the Department of Justice and Child Abuse Clearance Index clearances (CACI) however, two other staff (S1 and S2) who were working during the inspection didn’t have a CACI clearance. Based on reviews and the administrator confirmation, S1 and S2 did not have any proof of fingerprints clearance. The facility is being cited for Title 22, Division Six, Regulation 80091 (e) (3)Criminal Record Clearance. The administrator confirmed that S1 and S2 has worked in the facility since January 18,2021 without a criminal record clearance. Immediate civil penalties are being accessed for $1.000. A copy of this report was reviewed and given to facility representative, Evelyn Preston along with appeal rights and a Confidential Names List (LIC 811).

On August 18, 2022 at 10:25 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Anne Visaya and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore arrived at Wonderland of Choices Premier Services Enhanced Behavioral Support Home to conduct a required annual inspection of the facility. LPA and LPM was toured inside and out with House Manager Jodi Lindsay. There were four clients and seven staff including the house manager were present at the facility during the inspection. The home was approved for two non-ambulatory clients and two ambulatory clients age 6-18. The home is a one-story residence and consists of: Bedroom #1 furnished with full bed size, a closet and storage space It sleeps a 16- year old male client Bedroom #2, furnished with a full size bed, a closet and plenty of storage space. It sleeps a 16-year-old male client Bedroom #3 furnished with twin size bed, a closet and storage space it sleeps a 10 year old male client Bedroom #4 furnished with full size bed, a closet and storage space it sleeps a 14 year old male client A dining room with a large table, a furnished living room no fireplace, a kitchen, a pantry, a 2 walk-in handicap access full bathrooms, and the game room/activity area in the garage. All bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room was commonly used for other purposes other than a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were working properly. The laundry room was located in the garage. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water was measured to be 112 F degrees. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The kitchen had adequate cooking supplies and utensils.

The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the kitchen. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the kitchen underneath the kitchen sink and additional cleaning supplies were located in the garage. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The First Aid Kit was located inside the cabinet in the kitchen and contained all required items. The living room area had a closet with age appropriate games and activities. The garage had activity equipment for clients and laundry area. All windows and screens were in good repair. There were no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by House Manager Jodi Lindsay. There were cameras in the common areas total 3 located in the office, living room and kitchen and outside the facility. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance procedures, personal rights, ombudsman poster, visitation policies, and current menu. Clients medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in the kitchen cabinet. The medication logs were kept updated and the dispensing records had no discrepancies. LPA and LPM observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. Two clients were interviewed and indicated that they feel safe in the home and accorded their personal rights. Additionally four Staff were interviewed and no issue were found. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. In the back yard, there was a locked swimming pool inaccessible to clients. The pool was surrounded by a wrought iron fence measured over 6 feet tall with a gate that self-latches and opens outward. The facility had an operable delayed egress and sprinkler systems. Clients files were reviewed and following documents were present: Independent Behavior Support Plan, Individual Program Plan, health records, LIC 621 and medical consent. Staff records including current crisis prevention intervention (CPI), First Aid and CPR were reviewed during the inspection. The facility emergency plan was also reviewed and all staff had the Department of Justice and Child Abuse Clearance Index clearance Based on today's inspection and observations, there are no deficiencies being cited at this time in accordance with Title 22, Division 6, Chapters 1, 5 and 6. A copy of this report was reviewed and given to facility representative, who the administrator Evelyn Preston authorized Jodi Lindsay House Manager. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to Facility Manager this date.

On December 8, 2023 at 12:54 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Wonderland of Choices Premier Services Enhanced Behavioral Support Home to conduct a required annual inspection of the facility. The facility was toured inside and out with House Manager Jodi Lindsay. There were two clients and seven staff in the house. The home was approved for two non-ambulatory clients and two ambulatory clients age 6-18. The home is a one-story residence and consists of: · Bedroom #1 furnished with full-sized bed, a closet and storage space It sleeps a 17-year-old male client · Bedroom #2, furnished with a full-size bed, a closet and plenty of storage space. It sleeps a 17-year-old male client. · Bedroom #3 furnished with twin size hospital bed, a closet and storage space; it sleeps a 11-year-old male client · Bedroom #4 furnished with twin size bed, a closet and storage space; it sleeps a 15-year-old male client · A dining room with two round tables, a furnished living room with no fireplace, a kitchen, a pantry, two walk-in handicapped access full bathrooms, and the game room/activity area in the garage. All bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room was commonly used for other purposes other than a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawers and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were working properly. The laundry room was in the garage. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water was measured to be 110 F degrees. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The kitchen had adequate cooking supplies and utensils.

The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the kitchen. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the garage. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The First Aid Kit was located inside the cabinet in the kitchen and contained all required items. The living room area had a closet with age-appropriate games and activities. The garage had activity equipment for clients and a laundry area. All windows and screens were in good repair. There were no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by House Manager Jodi Lindsay. There were cameras in the common areas total 3 located in the office, living room, kitchen and outside the facility. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance procedures, personal rights, ombudsman poster, visitation policies, and current menu. Clients medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in the kitchen cabinet. The medication logs were kept updated and the dispensing records had no discrepancies. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. Two clients were in the house, non-verbal and were observed to be safe in the home. Additionally, three Staff were interviewed and no issues were found. The facility outside the grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. At the back yard, there was a locked swimming pool inaccessible to clients. The pool was surrounded by a wrought iron fence measured over 6 feet tall with a gate that self-latches and opens outward. The facility had an operable delayed egress and sprinkler systems. Clients files were reviewed and the following documents were present: Independent Behavior Support Plan, Individual Program Plan, health records, LIC 621 and medical consent. Staff records including current crisis prevention intervention (CPI), First Aid and CPR were reviewed during the inspection. The facility emergency plan was also reviewed, and all staff had the Department of Justice and Child Abuse Clearance Index clearance. Based on today's inspection and observations, there are no deficiencies being cited at this time in accordance with Title 22, Division 6, Chapters 1, 5 and 6. A copy of this report was reviewed and given to facility representative, who the administrator Evelyn Preston authorized Jodi Lindsay House Manager. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to Facility Manager on this date.

During investigation, confidential interviews stated that C1 has a history of exhibiting inappropriate behaviors and states falsehoods. In addition, C1 uses inappropriate sexual language towards staff. A confidential interview indicated that staff discourage C1 from displaying inappropriate behaviors. Furthermore, confidential interviews corroborated that C1 has inappropriate behaviors and uses inappropriate languages for jokes. Based on confidential interviews and a review of pertinent documents, the allegation that staff encouraged C1 to use inappropriate behavior may have occurred, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal right were provided to Administrator Evelyn Preston.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendy Brown conducted an announced Pre-licensing inspection on 02/14/2025, arriving at the facility at 1200 Carson Woods Road in Fortuna, California at 9:30 AM. The licensure application is for an Enhanced Behavioral Supports Home (EBSH) with a capacity of four clients male and/or female ages 12 through 17 years. LPA met with Cheryl Karran, LSW - Regional Director, Melissa Koren, QBMP and Ann Martin, Administrator. During the pre-licensing visit, LPA conducted a Health and Safety inspection using the CARE tool. INTERIOR: LPA observed that the facility is a single-story residence with four client bedrooms. Sufficient storage space for client’s personal belongings was observed in each room. No food was observed as there are no clients, and no pending placement at this time. Facility will verify required food on hand at time of client placement. LPA observed the facility was clean and safe inside and out. The facility has four bedrooms, a family room and separate living room, kitchen, dining area, sensory room, laundry room, two staff offices, a med room, laundry room, an activity area, and two bathrooms. Extra effort is made to prevent damage from clients who may have escalated behaviors to include weighted chairs too heavy to throw, triple sheet-rocked walls, and doors with piano hinges. There are two bathrooms in the facility that are accessible and available for client use. The water temperature was tested and found to be 109 degrees. CONTINUE ON 809C

Appliances throughout the facility are new including those in the kitchen and the washer and dryer in the separate laundry room. YARD: LPA observed the back yard of the facility to be sloped, tiered and a fenced yard with a cement slab at ground level. There’s a fence at the rear of the property leading to a trail in the forest behind the property. The front yard has a garden area and parking with a circular driveway. The front is fenced but has unlocked walk-through gates allowing pedestrian access in and out Both yards are well maintained. SECURE AND SAFETY ITEMS: LPA observed a staff office space that is locked and inaccessible to clients, where client records will be retained. LPA observed a refrigerator and locked medication cabinet in the locked “med room”. Emergency exits and evacuation plans are clearly marked. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were throughout the home, were tested and found to be functional during the inspection. Fire extinguishers were present with an expiration date of 11/28/2027. LICENSURE: Appropriate documentation has been received by the Department. As this will be a new facility, several required items were ordered and verification of those items being in place will be provided to LPA before a license will be issued this EBSH facility. A signed copy of this report was provided to Administrator and Regional Director. END.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendy Brown conducted an unannounced post-licensing inspection on 7/25/2025 at 10:00 AM at the above location, as required for the Enhanced Behavioral Supports Homes (EBSH) licensure. LPA met with Administrator Steven Toal. The EBSH has a capacity of four clients male and/or female ages 12 through 17 years. During the post-licensing visit, LPA conducted a Health and Safety inspection using the CARE tool. LPA observed the facility was clean and safe inside and out as was previously observed during the pre-licensing inspection. The few items missing at the time of the pre-licensing inspection were accounted for and observed by LPA. The outside of the facility is fenced and includes a garden area in the front and a patio in the back. LPA observed client bedrooms, equipped with appropriate furniture, bedding, and supplies for clients. Sufficient storage space for client’s personal belongings was observed in each room. One client is currently in placement. LPA observed the medication stored and locked in a locked office in a locked filing cabinet. The kitchen area was equipped with needed supplies. LPA observed two days of perishable food and seven days of non-perishable food on site. LPA observed a staff office space that is locked and inaccessible to clients. Client and staff records are locked. The facility has an outdoor shed used for maintenance supplies and is locked and made inaccessible to clients. The laundry room does have an unlocked door for client and staff access, but all cleaning supplies and chemicals are locked up high in cabinets. Report continued on 809- C

The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are functional and there is a fire sprinkler system in the facility. Fire extinguishers were present and service was current. A fully equipped first aid kit was in the laundry room. LPA observed the following items posted: license, personal rights, emergency disaster plan/contacts, exit signs, and the facility sketch with emergency exit routes identified. There are two bathrooms in the facility that are accessible for client use. LPA conducted four staff interviews and one client interview. LPA reviewed five staff files and one client file. This facility meets Interim Licensing Standards mandates and is clean safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPA recommends the facility obtains permanent license with management approval. A signed copy of this report was provided to the Administrator via email.

On 08/21/25 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lyta Vue arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Administrator (ADMIN) Derrick Buchanan. LPA Vue conducted a Case Management to conduct a client file review and did a Health and Safety Inspection. During the post-licensing inspection by LPA Wendy Brown the client had very recently been placed at the facility and the file had not been completely established. LPA Brown was advised that the client’s representative had not been responsive in providing needed information and Medi-Cal information was pending to establish local care providers for the client. LPA Vue used the Client Records portion of the CARE Tool in conducting the file review. LPA Vue observed there to be no deficiencies at this time. An exit interview was conducted A sign copy of this LIC-809 was provided to Derrick Buchanan

facility_name: YAI EAST TABOR AVE.-ENHANCED BEHAVIORAL SUPPORTS
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Tana Kinder conducted a pre-licensing, Component II meeting with Cheryl Karran on 2/3/2022 to review revision requests to the program design. The meeting was conducted using the video conference platform, Microsoft Teams. Section 3: Every box was checked. Do you truly see this program serving every type of need identified on the list? Have you had experience and training with every population identified? Section 4: Page 2: Other descriptions, for example, behavioral and/or medical assessments? NSP & IPPs. Page 5, Line 9: remove comma after Regional Center Staff. Page 5: includes Long Beach Aquarium as a possible activity, please remove and identify specific options in your area- what is in your community? Give names and locations of dining places, parks, gyms; etc. Page 6: Note: and parent- check with them also. Line 31 the sentence starts with “Ways.” Line 32 …not limited to (should not have colon(:). Line 33 as support (insert regulations) to the person’s needs. Line 36 codes and regulations. Line 39 ensuring. Page 7: Under dating line 5 physicals written 2# 5. Page 9: Please refer to local activities. Page 10: Are these optional? Aroma and meditation. Continued...

Section 5: Lists services for San Joaquin and Solano county. Also make sure the programs listed are available to Regional Center clients-use examples of vendored services if applicable. Section 6: Page 15: top- will family or legal guardian also be informed and included? Page 15, Line 3: Individual(s) *Attach a copy of the appointment history tracking form to this section. Page 16: First Aid Kit-you list some specific items. Make sure you have everything required by regulations. Page 17, 2nd paragraph, line 5: Add PMAR with MAR. 2nd paragraph, last sentence: Be specific-where are you going to store? Have a designated area assigned. Page 20: Expired Medication Disposal- Change locations to local area. Section 7: Page 21, line 1: Define vigorous background check. 2nd sentence vigorous. *If you use volunteers add information here regarding driving policy. *Address potential use of car seats or car restraint systems for younger/smaller clients. Section 8: Individual move-in agreement: Page 23, Bullet 7: What age group? Be more specific. Page 26, Initial Screening: Will you take county referrals or only Regional Center? Later it says only Regional Centers. Clarifying would provide consistency. Page 28, Line 2: “individuals (who) are…” Under admission meeting documentation: please add Personal Rights will also be reviewed and a copy will be provided (unless I missed where you cover that). Page 29: Will you be taking CSEC clients? Continued...

Section 9: Page 32, Bullet 2: remove the period (.) after the word following and perhaps use a colon (:) after “the plan of operation:” since you are listing the following information. Page 36, Line 1: remove the period (.) after “Individual Behavior. Supports…” Page 36: Who is responsible for completing the IBST? Section 10: Provide a detailed policy/procedure for removal of youth. Have a copy of the discharge plan/policy that would be signed by the parent/guardian in the child’s record in this section. Section 11: When are visits allowed? Are the designated times/days visits happen or times they do not happen (during groups at the facility, etc.)? Section 12: Please address: Curfews, dress codes, dating policy, completing homework (?). Gambling and betting?? Why is Personal Hygiene addressed here? There is nothing that says anything about rules in the narrative. Maybe Section 9? Section 14: Page 44: Why is that first (very long) sentence in this section? What are you trying to convey? Maybe it should be rewritten and put in Section 3? Page 44, Line 8, last word: Avoid(s), remove (s). Line 14: “When an individual is safely (restrained) no restraint. Line 16: “simultaneously are restraint” should be “are simultaneously restrained.” Page 45, paragraph 5, line 3: the last word, advise(d), paragraph 6, 1st sentence does not make sense. Already involved in Criminal Justice or preventing Criminal Justice involvement or additional Criminal Justice involvement? Continued...

Section 15: Incident Report Section, Bullet 1: Individua(l)’s Section 16: Do you have a grievance form for the client’s to access? Will you document the process if a client initiates a grievance? Where will this be kept? Section 17: Please edit the Policy and Procedures for Handling Children’s Funds to reflect a minor. For example, remove the examples that do not apply to children; tax credits, renter credit, gambling winnings, etc. Include parents in this section as it applies. Page 56, Bullet 8: remove cigarettes and perhaps some of the other examples listed on page 56 and 57 as they do not pertain to minors. Please address allowance and how that will be handled. Section 18: Page 61, 2nd paragraph, line 3: sense (of) ownership. Are there paid chores? Section 19: Page 62, 2nd paragraph, line 2: Individuals is (are). Last ling page 63: fitting (fit). Page 64, Bullet 6: similar substance is (will). 2nd Bold/underlined section: “If at any point the dishwashing machines … staff is (are). Section 20: Bullet 1, line 3: Rapidly change(s). Last bullet, line 1: “to be spend, (spent). Continued...

Section 21: What is peer partner position? If you don’t have it, do you want to eliminate? Otherwise, elaborate regarding the parameters for this position, including training, background check, etc. Should this be in Section 26? Section 22: QBMP/BCBA: “Several years of writing reports,” be more specific; 2-3 years? 3-4 years? Page 72, line after paragraph 3: “The success(ful) candidate must…” Section 22, 23 and LIC 500: Be consistent with job titles: Administrator/Program Administrator, RN/RN Consultant, etc. Section 24: Where will you track and keep documentation for each employee’s training. Add this information. Section 25: Don’t see Appendix VII, specifically LIC 309. Section 26: Should Peer Partners be included here? Where will you keep track of volunteer training? Section 27: Provide a copy of the lease. Sections 28: Please identify where the Main Shutoff Valve is located. Section 29: Please provide Board of Directors information. Continued...

Appendix II: Page 1, under Policy: “Upon admissions…” Page 1, last paragraph, line 4: “and so for(th).” Or so on?? Line 5: “developed by and DDS,” Page 2, Line 6: regarding a restraint not lasting longer than 10 minutes: How was that timeframe determined? If the client is still escalated, how will you end the restraint? Page 2, line 8: “child is safely restraint (restrained).” Page 2, Multiple Emergency Interventions: How do you determine adequate number of staff? In the training handbook, is there a minimum number of staff that are required? Do you need to take the size of the client and staff into consideration? Maybe defer to the protocol of the technique you are using and document that here. Page 2, last paragraph, line1: “or a compliant (complaint).” Page 3, Debriefing, Bullet 1: “Child who was restraint (restrained). Bullet 9: “Determining where (if)…” Page 4, paragraph 2, line 1: “CCH will report to the Department…” is the Department DDS, DSS or both? CCL? Appendix III: Financial Policy Page 1, paragraph 4, line 4: individual(‘)s file Page 2: Where is the bonding documentation kept? *This appears to have been written for an adult client population. Please review and revise for minors and their parents and/or representatives like CPS. There is policy regarding loans, paycheck stubs, etc. Is any amount of $200 going to be returned to the client’s parent or representative? Page 9: The list needs to reflect minors. Same with page 11 list of disallowed expenses.

facility_name: YAI EAST TABOR AVE.-ENHANCED BEHAVIORAL SUPPORTS
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tana Kinder conducted an announced pre licensing inspection with the Administrator, Qualified Behavioral Modification Professional (QBMP) and Director of Residential Services on 7/28/2022 at 10:30 am at the facility. LPA conducted the walk through of the facility with the above named staff and observed 4 bedrooms, 1 garage, 2 common areas, 2 bathrooms, a kitchen, laundry room, sensory room and a locked medication room. All spaces were clean, sanitary, free of insects, and had unobstructed pathways. LPA observed 7 days' worth of non-perishable, food for 4 potential clients. The refrigerator was 39 degrees and the freezer was 0 degrees. The hot water from the kitchen sink was 106.8 degrees. The facility does not utilize protective separation rooms. All the bedrooms are furnished with a bed, dresser, nightstand, desk/chair, closet and is well-lit. The front yard and back yard are fenced in with an accessible gate to the front of the property. The grounds have a recreation area with a basketball hoop and plenty of space for activities. No cameras are in use in the facility. There is a backup located on the side of the property. The water source is county water. The water sprinkler system is located on the side of the house. There is a locked storage structure in the enclosed part of the backyard. The backyard is fenced off with extra yard on the other side that is not accessible to the clients at this time. On the other side of the locked backyard there are 2 unlocked sheds, and 2 horse stable structures that are not in use or accessible to the clients. The facility is using a monthly rental minivan to transport clients. There are 24 staff associated to the facility. There are currently no clients at the facility. Continued...

LPA has observed the following that need to be brought into compliance before issuance of the license. 1. Hygiene products need to be purchased and available for 4 clients. 2. Mattress pad covers for (4) beds. 3. Laundry detergent in the laundry room. 4. Facility Sketch needs to include the whole property and all dwellings. 5. The access to the side yard will be made in accessible like the rest of the outer backyard. 6. The ditch on the outside of the fenced front yard will be filled or secured so it is inaccessible. LPA reviewed the following forms with the facility staff: An exit interview was conducted and copy for the report was provided.

facility_name: YAI EAST TABOR AVE.-ENHANCED BEHAVIORAL SUPPORTS
narrative: Based upon 6 confidential interviews and a review of the records, there is documented information provided regarding timely work orders for the damage caused to the facility including the windows in question. The facility is required to use a specific company to address damage that is significant like broken windows and doors. Although communication could have been better, it is unknown as to whether that would have prompted the State appointed contractor to address the repairs sooner. Regarding the issue related to the client receiving medication in a timely manner, documentation indicates the client was complaining of cold like symptoms on 3/13/23 but was ambivalent about going to a doctor for treatment at that time. Documentation is not clear as to when the client was seen by a doctor, but there were a couple of attempts to get treatment from a provider and to offer to get treatment for the client. The client refused a couple of times and one urgent clinic refused to see the client. The client did receive over the counter medications to treat the cold symptoms starting on 3/13/23 and ending on 3/16/23 with a medical providers prescription in place. It is possible that other options may have resulted if the client received medical treatment sooner, like seeking a telehealth appointment. The allegations are determined to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to provide the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED.
investigation_findings: 13On 5/24/23 at 3pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Kinder met with BCBA to deliver complaint investigation findings. The allegations are: Staff did not pick up minor's medication in a timely manner and the facility windows are in disrepair. Continued...

facility_name: YAI EAST TABOR AVE.-ENHANCED BEHAVIORAL SUPPORTS
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Eunice conducted an unannounced case management inspection to the above facility for the purpose of ensuring compliance with Title 22 regulations regarding Health Related Services. The Department received an incident report regarding a child’s missed medication on or about 10/26/2023. A staff person administered medication, and it was not documented in the facility’s medication log. When the mistake was discovered, a full medication audit was conducted, staff training followed, Enhanced Behavioral Supports Home administrative staff conducted an internal investigation, a medical professional/registered nurse was notified. Additionally, a preventative plan was put in place which included the previously mentioned medication audit, training plan and Registered Behavior Technician (RBT) staff devised and implemented a new medication protocol. This case management inspection is closed on 11/08/2023.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Health Related Services - Clients shall be assisted as needed with self-administration of prescription and nonprescription medications. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: The Department received an incident report which reported a child's medication was not logged while in the care of YAI EBSH. This poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.

narrative: On 12/01/23 at approximately 11:00 a.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jacqueline Carmona made an unannounced visit to conduct a case management regarding a medication error. During the visit it was discovered the client only had one of the three bags of medication. It is unclear if client missed their medication. LPA conducted a walk through of the facility. LPA conducted interviews with (3) staff and (1) client. LPA obtained LIC500, MARS Log, Activity Log and Facility Staff Schedule. facility_name: YAI EAST TABOR AVE.-ENHANCED BEHAVIORAL SUPPORTS
narrative: On 1/18/24 at approximately 11:00 a.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jacqueline Carmona made an unannounced visit to conduct a case management regarding a medication error. LPA Carmona met with Steven Toal, Program Administrator. On 11/30/23 an incident report was received by the Department regarding a client missing their medication dose(s). It was reported that on 11/22/23 a client was transported to a visit and the facility staff packed 3 bags of medication for the client. During the client’s visit it was discovered the client only had one of the three bags of medication. LPA Carmona conducted 9 confidential interviews and LPA Farhaan Sarangi conducted 1 confidential interview. LPA Carmona obtained and reviewed LIC500, MARS Log, Behavior Agent Notes, Facility Staff Schedule, Internal Investigation Report, Medication Transfer Sheet, Sections 6 and 7 of Program Statement, Staff Training Certificates, and SIR dated 11/22/23. Based on confidential interviews and documents obtained it was confirmed a client had possession of their medication during an unsupervised period of time. 4 confidential interviews confirmed facility staff did not include a Medication Transfer Sheet form with the medication prepared for the visit. In addition, Program Statement section 6 states medications will not be left unattended by staff members. Due to the facility staff allowing the client to have possession of their medication while being unsupervised and the proper protocols not being met the facility has been cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Administrator. This case management investigation is closed and has been cited Plan of Operation 80022 (k).

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Plan of Operation (k) The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so. This requirement was not met as evidence by: Based on documents reviewed and interviews conducted it was confirmed client had possession of medication while being unsupervised. Which poses an Immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
