facility_name: YAI EAST TABOR AVE.-ENHANCED BEHAVIORAL SUPPORTS
narrative:
On January 26, 2024 at 11:00 AM, The Department met with Licensee for the purpose of an Informal Office Meeting to discuss areas of facility compliance. Attendees were: Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Farhaan Sarangi, Jacqueline Carmona, Sara Luman-Gonzalez, Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Rosa Rodriguez, Regional Manager (RM), Margo Castaneda, CDSS Staff Attorney, Erik Brunkal, Licensee, Cheryl Karran, HR Manager, Emily Ramos, Attorney Jake Reinhardt, Department of Developmental Services (DDS), Leah O'Meara, Catherine Knight and Angela Craven, Regional Center of the East Bay, Brooke Guerrero, Regional Manager at Regional Center of the East Bay, Jeff Nagafuji, Resource Developer with Regional Center for the East Bay, Heather Jacobs and DDS Angela Munoz. Areas of Concern: · Increase in number of complaints between both facilities (YAI East Tabor Rd and YAI Davis Rd.) primarily due to lack of staffing. Licensee acknowledges issues with staffing. The population that the facility serves requires a lot of attention. Licensee acknowledges that the clients they serve have a 2 to 1 ratio. HR Manager reports that there are four applicants going through the hiring process. Licensee reports that the house has been challenging regarding the culture in that home and the former facility staff. Licensee terminated previous employees that created a toxic work environment. Licensee has hired Prospective Administrator, Amber Palesi. Licensee reports having staff work double shifts. Licensee reports that the contingency plan put in place is sharing staff from other homes if staffing issues continue. New staff have been very good at picking up extra shifts. HR is adamant about visiting colleges, recruitment fairs and ongoing recruitment efforts. · Department of Developmental Services (DDS), Leah O'Meara advised that 80 hours of training is required for new staff and per diem staff that are new to YAI facilities. (Page 1 of 2)

· Licensee was reminded of Reporting Requirements as it relates to submitting incident reports timely. · Required records availability-Licensing needs to have access to records as per Inspection Authority. Protocol for providing documentation to Licensing agency; ensuring records are readily available and easily accessible to CCL during business hours. LPA, Carmona advised that the Internet connectivity issues being a concern. Licensee acknowledges that there have been struggles with the internet connectivity. Licensee uses two different internet providers and is currently exploring other options to remedy this issue. · Staff do not feel that they are properly trained on medication dispensing. Staff issues with dispensing medication and the changes around medication dispensing. Licensee acknowledges their multiple medication errors and has since hired a Registered Nurse to train staff on medication procedures and review the MARS for both facilities. · No authorized staff members delegated at the facility to sign licensing reports. Licensee plan is to ensure an Administrator or lead staff is always in the home should Licensing arrive to the home. · General upkeep of physical plant: General Window discussion on replacing windows in a timely manner Window Screens need to be in place and inspected regularly. Heating and AC in facilities. Licensee reports that there have been multiple windows being broken. Licensee acknowledges the property destruction and physical plant concerns. Licensee reports of putting in a brand new screens. Licensee reports that the heating has been fixed in the facility. Licensee reports that they have hired two maintenance staff for both facilities. Licensee will put in procedure for submitting work orders when maintenance issues arise upon the departments request. · Accessibility to all parts of the facility. Licensee reports that it is a lactation room. Licensee reports that the leads have all the codes. Licensee will submit a new facility sketch to address the lactation room and will ensure that lead staff have access when CCL comes for unannounced inspections. Licensee has requested the Program Director to be contacted if a room is not accessible. Support & Resources: Licensee requested a Technical Support Program Referral (TSP). Referral to CDSS Technical Support Program pending. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to the Licensee for signature.

narrative: Based on interviews conducted during the investigation process the above allegations cannot be substantiated because there were inconsistent statements obtained from current and former staff. Records reviewed, and an Individualized Behavior Support Plan for the minor in care dated November 16, 2023, reported that C1 was receiving services to include behavior health, trauma informed care, verbal de-escalation, and an emergency intervention plan. C1 had access and received food service, leisure, and community outings. It was also reported that the facility does not have enough staff to provide care and supervision to minor(s) in care. During records review, it was documented that C1 required 1:1 supervision while at the hospital and 2:1 supervision at the facility. C1 was admitted to the hospital in November 2023, hospital staff called the facility when C1 was due to be discharged but were unable to pick C1 up due to no staff being available. It was reported that the facility was leaving C1 at the hospital because they might not have staff to care for C1 during the weekends. LPA Stiger was not able to confirm if staff was not available to pick up C1, but interview statements obtained indicated that the facility has had Administrator changes but was fully staffed and current staff will pick up shifts as needed. Lastly, LPA Stiger was not able to obtain supportive information from C1 or C2 because they were distracted with their electronics and not engaging with LPA during the interview process. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview conducted with Lead RBT, Kristen Fox. A copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided to the facility.

met_with: Imanya Anderson, Lead Registered Behavior Technician
narrative: Four out of the four interviews conducted confirmed that staff handled minor in a rough manner causing injury and staff are not providing a comfortable environment for minor did not occur. During the interviews LPA Turner was informed by the client in care that they initiated the altercation and expressed a desire for the staff member to retaliate physically. The staff member made clear efforts to avoid engaging in any physical confrontation and attempted to de-escalate the incident. The staff member tried to run away and distance themselves from the client. It was confirmed by another staff member present that the staff involved sustained minor injuries further demonstrating that they did not try and fight back. The client in care stated that they are struggling with their behaviors and the change in environment was hard at first. The client stated they are feeling better in the home and are working on strategies to better themselves. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.

facility_name: YAI EAST TABOR AVE.-ENHANCED BEHAVIORAL SUPPORTS
narrative:
On 2/07/2025 at 10:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan made an unannounced visit with the purpose of conducting an Annual inspection to the above facility using the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tool. LPA met with Lanasha Devers, Assistant Administrator, and a walk through of the interior and exterior was completed.The facility serves up to 2 ambulatory and 2 non ambulatory female and male clients between the ages of 12-17 and 18-22 years old with an exception. Physical Plant Room 1 is a staff office with client files, a printer, and an exit to the garage. Room 2 is a client bedroom that has a dresser, a full size bed, and a Television. Room 3 is a bathroom which has a toilet, storage drawers, and a trash can with a tight fitting lid. Room 4 is a medication closet that has medical binders, a mini refrigerator, a safe, and a fire extinguisher. Room 5 is a common area with a large sectional, a facility phone, and a coffee table. Room 6 is entertainment room with 2 couches, an area rug, and a television. Room 7 is a sensory room connected to room 6 and has a foosball table, an office chair, and pads to sit on. Room 9 is a kitchen with a working stove, trash with a tight fitting lid, and a combination refrigerator and freezer. Room 10 is a dining room with 2 tables, 6 chairs, and a emergency disaster plan posted. Room 11 is a closet connected to the dining room and only stores the facility routers and other technology. Room 12 is a client bedroom with a twin size mattress, 2 storage units, and a rug. Room 13 is a bathroom with a working toilet, a storage unit, and trash can with a tight fitting lid. Room 13 is a client bedroom with a full bed, 2 storage units, and a PlayStation 5. Room 14 is a client bedroom with a twin bed, table, and chairs. The 2 client bathrooms have water temperatures at 112.9 degrees Fahrenheit. The backyard is gated, has a shed, and is clear of debris. (continued on LIC 809C)(Page 1)

The following required documents were posted, License and Personal Rights. Disinfectants/cleaning solutions were inaccessible to clients in care and stored in the locked garage. Refrigerator Temperature at or below 45 degrees Fahrenheit. Nonperishable foods one week and fresh perishable foods two days minimum. Menu present and posted in the kitchen area on the fridge. Working telephone are available at the facility. Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are in working order. First Aid Kit fully stocked. Medication centrally stored, locked/inaccessible to children. Hot Water between 105–120 degrees Fahrenheit. Fire Extinguisher up to date and in working order. Toilets wash basin, bath, and shower fixtures in good repair/no leaks/hot water temperature. Soap and Paper towels are available to clients. Bedrooms required linen and furnishings are fully stocked. Facility is free of vermin. The following domains were also reviewed during today’s inspection, Operations, Disaster Preparedness, Staffing, Emergency Intervention, and Client Records. A total of 5 staff files and 2 client files were reviewed. LPA also conducted 2 staff interviews. LPA was unable to conduct client interview but will follow up at a later date. A review of the Licensing Information System indicates the facility is not up to date on their facility. The facility fees which are due in the amount of 681.00 were due on 09/26/24. All the staff were fingerprint cleared and associated to the facility. Based on confidential interviews conducted no concerns for follow up were noted at this time. An exit interview was conducted with Lanasha Devers, Assistant Administrator, and a copy of this report, and the Appeal Rights were provided to the facility.

facility_name: YAI EAST TABOR AVE.-ENHANCED BEHAVIORAL SUPPORTS
narrative: On August 6, 2025 at 10:13am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Tatyana Shulz made an unannounced visit to conduct a case management regarding DDS Semi-Annual Review that took place at the facility on June 26, 2025. LPA met with Lanasha Devers, Assistant Administrator who granted LPA access to the facility. Prior to the meeting DDS Behavior Specialist II, Justin Pineda Carlos conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where the Specialist observed the following deficiencies: · A buildup of residue, cobwebs, dust bunnies, smudges/grime, and residual adhesives throughout the facility. · The side gate leading to the gated and repaved parking lot could not be open as it is obstructed by gravel or other material. · All the kitchen cabinets do not have doors and drawers installed and are all covered by curtains affixed by Velcro. LPA Shulz conducted a walk through of the facility and observed that the obstruction and the residue throughout the facility that was noted on the June 26, 2025, inspection have been corrected. The facility is currently waiting for the custom cabinet and drawers to be delivered to the facility. LPA was shown that the work order was placed on July 1, 2025. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided to Lanasha Devers, Assistant Administrator. The facility has been cited for Buildings and Grounds on LIC809D. This case management will remain open until a follow up inspection has been conducted.

facility_name: YAI EAST TABOR AVE.-ENHANCED BEHAVIORAL SUPPORTS
narrative: On August 20, 2025 at approximately 10:18am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tatyana Shulz made an unannounced inspection to close a case management at the above facility. LPA was greeted by Lanasha Devers, Assistant Administrator who granted LPA access. Prior to the meeting LPA Shulz conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where LPA observed the following deficiency. All the kitchen cabinets do not have doors and drawers installed and are all covered by curtains affixed by Velcro. LPA conducted a walk through of the facility and observed that the deficiency noted on the August 06, 2025 inspection has not been fixed, the facility is currently looking for a cabinet supplier and states that due to the cabinets being custom the process will take an additional 5-6 weeks after the order is placed. LPA will conduct a follow up visit around that time. This case management will remain open until a follow up inspection has been conducted. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility with Assistant Administrator, Lanasha Devers.

On January 17, 2023 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez arrived at Yai Morro Rd. Enhanced Behavioral Support Home (EBSH). LPA met with applicants Regional Deputy Director Elizabeth Steffens, Assistant Director Dana Simon, VP Program Development Sandra Speiser, Qualified Behavioral Modification Professional and Registered Behavior Technician who led a tour of the home. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct the pre-licensing inspection. The home was toured inside and out with the applicants. Applicants are applying for a maximum capacity of four clients. The home is requesting to be approved for 2 ambulatory clients and 2 non-ambulatory clients clients age 1-17 and is pending fire clearance approval. The home is a one-story residence with four bedrooms and two bathrooms. The home will serve four clients between the age of 12-17 years old. Bedroom #1 The room consists of a twin-size bed, dresser, night stand, desk and closet space. It sleeps one client- vacant. Bedroom #2 The room consists of a twin-size bed, dresser, night stand, desk, and closet space. It sleeps one client- vacant Bedroom #3 The room consists of a twin-size bed, dresser, night stand, desk, and closet space. It sleeps one client- vacant Bedroom# 4 The room consists of a twin-size bed, dresser, night stand, desk, and closet space. It sleeps one client- vacant. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than one child shares a room. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. There is sufficient linens, blankets, towels and pillows. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were working properly. There are two fire extinguisher's in the home, one is located by entrance and one in the staff office, and both have a current inspection tag. Office will remain locked and staff/client files will be kept on site. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medication will be locked in medication room.

Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in a locked cabinets. In laundry room is equipped with washer, dryer and locked cabinets for chemicals. Outdoor storage will have emergency supply back pack, extra PPE and extra daily supplies. There is a small refrigerator in locked medication room for refrigerated medications. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in the locked kitchen drawer. First Aid kit was accessible and had all required items including the thermometer. There are no weapons allowed at the facility as stated by the regional deputy director. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be at 105 degrees. Applicants understands that the water temperature must be maintained within the regulation range of 105-120 degrees. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. Personal Rights, The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan and visitation policy were posted. The backyard was observed to be clean and free of hazards. The facility has two doors with 30 seconds delayed egress. LPA verified and confirmed the delayed egress doors were functional during the inspection. The facility had the emergency intervention plan and emergency evacuation procedures in place. LPM completed the component III Orientation and discussed Incident reporting, including incidents related to Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. Based on this inspection, the fire clearance and program administrator are pending. Once completed, the request of License will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval and pending the Department of Developmental Services Certificate of Program Approval. An Enhanced Behavioral Supports Home shall not be licensed by the Department until the Certificate of Program Approval, granted by the Department of Developmental Services, has been received in accordance with Health and Safety Code section 1567.62. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to applicant.

On January 26, 2024, at 11:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui arrived unannounced to YAI Morro and met with Portia Tresvant, Administrator. The purpose of this visit was to address a deficiency that was noted. On December 8, 2023, the Department became aware of unusual incidents of interactions between Foster Children (C1, C2). Based on interviews and record review, the Licensee did not ensure to notify Community Care Licensing (CCL) with a date, time , duration, location of the incident and the licensee did not provide CCL with a detailed narrative describing the incident. This posed an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care, the facility is being cited for a Type A violation of 84061 Reporting Requirements Reporting Requirements. (h) Incident Reports must include the following:(1) Date, time, duration and location of the incident. (2) A detailed narrative, describing the incident and the events leading up to incident. An exit interview was conducted, plan of operations was developed with Portia Tresvant, Administrator. A copy of this report along with appeal rights was provided to Portia Tresvant, Administrator.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Reporting Requirements Reporting Requirements. (h) Incident Reports must include the following:(1) Date, time, duration and location of the incident. (2) A detailed narrative, describing the incident and the events leading up to incident. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and record review, the facility did not report the incidents of C2 putting their hands down C1’s pants, which poses an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.

narrative: Confidential interviews did not believe the interactions was due to lack of supervision, however, other confidential interviews did not provide consistent statement of the alleged events. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that due to lack of supervision, inappropriate sexual interactions between C1 and C2 occurred, may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegation. Therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this signed report was provided to Portia Tresvant, Administrator.

There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The living room is furnished with couches and a television. The kitchen was observed to be free from observable hazards. Confidential interviews did not produce information to corroborate the allegation, and the investigation did not reveal any there were no other witnesses to the alleged event. investigation_findings: 13On July 24, 2024, at 1:03 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui arrived at the facility unannounced and met with Portia Tresvant, Administrator to discuss the investigative finding for the allegation noted above. LPA Jauregui conducted an inspection of the facility on January 26, 2024 and no deficiencies were noted. During the investigation, LPA Jauregui interviewed nine staff (S1-S11), one client (C2), and LPA attempted to interview Client 1 (C1), however, C1 is non-verbal. LPA obtained C1's Individual Behavior Support Plan, and staff schedule. On January 24, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that staff (S2 and S3) handled minor in a rough manner. It was reported that C1 became physically aggressive towards S1, and S2 and S3 stepped in to assist, and S2 and S3 grabbed C1 by their wrists and ankles.Confidential interviews yielded that staff have not observed S2 or S3 be aggressive towards C1. CONTINUED....

narrative: Confidential interviews and record reviewed also indicated that the facility is out of ratio when there are three staff present for two clients, as 1:1 supervision is not safe due to the behaviors of clients in care. Confidential interviews indicated the facility struggles with meeting staffing ratio, and staff are called in for coverage when needed. Record reviewed reflected that during the week of January 15 through January 19, 2024, the facility was out of ratio during the hours of 2:00 PM to 10:30 PM. Additionally, the facility was out of ration on January 15, 2024 and January 19, 2024 during the hours of 10:00 PM to 6:30 PM. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation that facility was out of ratio is SUBSTANTIATED because the preponderance of evidence has been met. This posed a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care. The facility will be cited for violating Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06. Continuing Requirements, Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision 80078(a), [See LIC 9099D]. An exit interview was conducted, and a plan of correction was developed with Portia Tresvant, Administrator. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Portia Tresvant, Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On July 24, 2024, at 12:40 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui arrived at the facility unannounced and met with Portia Tresvant, Administrator to discuss the investigative findings for the allegation noted above. LPA Jauregui conducted an inspection of the facility on January 26, 2024 and no deficiencies were noted. During the investigation, LPA Jauregui interviewed seven staff (S1-S6, S10), one client (C1), and LPA attempted to interview C2, however, C2 is non-verbal. LPA obtained C1's Individual Behavior Support Plan, level of supervision chart, staff schedule and Client Activity notes dated January 2024. On January 22, 2024, the Department received an allegation that the facility was out of ratio. It was reported that the facility was out of ratio during the week of January 15 through January 19, 2024. Confidential interviews and record reviewed indicated the required ratio was is 2:1 for each client (C1 and C2). CONTINUED....

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, the licensee did not ensure that there were sufficient staff to meet the needs of two of two clients in care, which posed potential health and safety risks to persons in care.

narrative: On August 8, 2024 at 11:42 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui conducted an unannounced Case Management visit at the facility. deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. narrative: Confidential interviews indicated C1 and C2 were running around attempting to go out through the facility’s gates. Confidential interviews indicated C1 was approved to go on a walk; however, due to C2’s dangerous behavior, C2 was not allowed to go out at that time. Confidential interviews yielded C1 began hitting and spitting at S2 and, according to a staff interview, staff observed S2 closing the door on C1 leaving black marks on C1’s arms. Other confidential interviews yielded there were no injuries on C1, and the black marks were caused by dirt that was on the fence and it was easily wiped off. It was stated in one confidential interview that C1 was shoved with a ukeru pad. However, there was no corroborating evidence. The allegations were denied, LPA received conflicting statements, and there were no other witnesses to corroborate the event. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that staff inappropriately handled a youth in a rough manner while in care and staff hit a youth while in care may have occurred, however, the allegations are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this signed report and appeal rights were was provided to Portia Tresvant, Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On August 8, 2024, at 11:48 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui arrived at the facility unannounced and met with Portia Tresvant, Administrator to discuss the investigative findings for the allegations noted above. LPA Jauregui conducted an inspection of the facility on March 6, 2024, and no deficiencies were noted. During the investigation, LPA Jauregui interviewed five staff (S1-S5) and one client (C1). LPA attempted to interview C2; however, C2 is nonverbal. On March 1, 2024, it was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that staff inappropriately handled a youth in a rough manner while in care and staff hit a youth while in care. It was reported that S2 was allowing C1 to take a walk if they wanted to, C1 became aggressive towards S2, and S2 closed the door on C1. Confidential information received also indicated that C1 was hit by S2, and C1 was observed to have a scrape and black marks on C1’s arms. CONTINUED....

narrative: C1 was transported from the facility to a local hospital, at which time C1 was admitted into the hospital on a 5150 hold. It was reported that on 2/22/24, C1 met with the hospital psychiatrist, and the 5150 hold was discontinued, as it was determined that C1 did not need to go to a psychiatric hospital. It was reported that on 2/22/24, S2 was informed that C1 was ready for discharge, and S2 refused to pick up C1 from the hospital. Confidential interviews indicated the facility was not comfortable to pick C1 up from the hospital due to C1’s dangerous behavior. Confidential interviews indicated that facility staff were waiting for a referral for C1 to be transferred to the hospital or for C1 to be reassessed. However, C1 was unable to be transported to the hospital due to the termination of C1’s 5150 hold. Record review indicates C1’s 5150 hold was discontinued by medical personnel on 2/22/24. Although confidential interviews revealed that facility staff were present with C1 at the hospital, confidential interviews and record review indicate that C1 was not picked up from the hospital by facility staff and returned to the facility until 2/24/24. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation that staff refused to pick up minor from the hospital is SUBSTANTIATED because the preponderance of evidence has been met. This posed a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care. The facility will be cited for violating Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 03. Application Procedures, Plan of Operation 80022 (b) The plan and related materials shall contain the following: (10) Transportation arrangements for clients who do not have independent arrangements. An exit interview was conducted, and a plan of correction was developed with Portia Tresvant, Administrator. A copy of this report, LIC9099D, and appeal rights were provided to Portia Tresvant, Administrator.

LPA obtained C1’s hospital discharge paperwork and Special Incident Reports. On February 28, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that staff refused to pick up minor from the hospital. Law enforcement was called to the facility in response to C1’s dangerous behaviors. CONTINUED.....

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 03. Application Procedures, Plan of Operation 80022 (b) The plan and related materials shall contain the following: (10) Transportation arrangements for clients who do not have independent arrangements. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and record review, the licensee did not arrange for transportation pick up 1 of 2 clients (C1) from the hospital after being discharged, which posed a potential health, safety, and personal risk to persons in care.

narrative: It was reported that the client, aggressively attacked two women who’d come from the direction of the facility and a scuffle ensued, during which the client and women fell to the ground. Confidential interviews indicated C1 eloped to the neighbor’s property and began to bang their head on a parked vehicle on the property. Confidential interviews indicated facility staff used ukeru pads to intervene, and C1 would push the pads out of the way. Confidential interviews indicated C1 was hanging on the side view mirrors of the vehicle. Confidential interviews indicated C1 attempted to open the house door of the property. Confidential interviews indicated staff attempted to place C1 on two holds, however, staff were unsuccessful due to C1 dropping their body to the floor. Confidential interviews indicated staff used ukeru safe turn approaches to redirect C1. Confidential interviews indicated C2 remained at the facility and wanted to follow C1. Confidential interviews indicated C2 walked to the property with staff and C2 wanted to get close to C1. Confidential interviews indicated C1 spit and hit C2, and C2 responded by grabbing C1 by the hair, which resulted in C1 and C2 falling to the ground. Confidential interviews indicated there was a physical altercation; however, interviews yielded that the altercation was between C1 and C2. The investigation did not yield no evidence to corroborate the allegation that staff engaged in a physical altercation with a client. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that staff engaged in a physical altercation with a minor in care may have occurred, however, the allegation is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this signed report and appeal rights were provided to Portia Tresvant, Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On August 15, 2024, at 10:35 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui arrived at the facility unannounced and met with Portia Tresvant, Administrator to discuss the investigative finding for the allegation noted above. LPA Jauregui conducted an inspection of the facility on April 26, 2024, and no deficiencies were noted. During the investigation, LPA Jauregui interviewed five staff (S1-S5). LPA was unable to interview C1 due to C1 being non-verbal. On April 18, 2024, it was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that staff engaged in a physical altercation with a minor in care. It was reported that a client was sitting on the steps of a nearby residential property and a couple of women were with the client. It was reported that the women were trying to place ukeru pads between the client and a car that was parked on the property. It was reported that more people came over, from the direction of the facility, with ukeru pads and tried to intervene by placing the ukeru pads between the client and a the parked car. CONTINUED....

narrative: It was reported that on 5/20/24, C1 was taken to the hospital for abdominal pain and minor surgery was performed. It was reported that on 5/24/24, C1 was discharged from a psychiatric hold, and on 5/28/24, C1 ingested a silica packet. Confidential interviews indicated that on 5/14/24, C1 swallowed a paperclip at school that was found in the bathroom after a school aid did not conduct a sweep prior to C1 going in. Record review indicated on 5/19/24 C1 exhibited highly escalated behaviors breaking the phone box open and ripping a piece of phone chord off that C1 swallowed. Confidential interviews indicated on 5/20/24 C1 was taken to the hospital to address stomach pain. Confidential interviews indicated C1 engaged in a behavior where C1 was attempting to take masks to swallow the metal nose piece found in the face mask. Record review indicated C1 was admitted to the hospital and was discharged on 5/24/24. Confidential interviews indicated on 5/28/24 C1 was at an outing with three staff at the movie theater. Confidential interviews indicated C1 was eating beef jerky and C1 ingested gel silica packet from the beef jerky pack. Confidential interviews indicated staff contacted Poison Control and were advised it was harmless and to have C1 rinse off their mouth. Confidential interviews indicated staff were advised by facility administration (regional deputy director) to still take C1 to the Emergency Room. Confidential interviews indicated during the van ride, C1 was not feeling well, unbuckled their seat belt, and went to the trunk of the vehicle. Confidential interviews indicated C1 grabbed the pin from the fire extinguisher in the trunk and swallowed it. Confidential interviews indicated the vehicle was in motion and staff could not engage in a hold. Although there were plans in place to address C1’s behavior of ingesting items, confidential interview indicated there was an increase in C1’s ingestion due to the anniversary of C1’s relative passing in May and C1’s deceased relative’s birthday in April. Based on confidential interviews the allegations that staff are not addressing the needs of minor and staff are not providing adequate supervision for minor may have occurred, however, the allegations is are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report along with appeal rights was provided to Portia Tresvant, Adminsitrator
investigation_findings: 13On September 19, 2024, at 9:25 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui arrived at the facility unannounced and met with Portia Tresvant, Adminsitrator to discuss the investigative findings for the allegation noted above. LPA Jauregui conducted an inspection of the facility on June 4, 2024, and no deficiencies were noted. During the investigation, LPA Jauregui interviewed three staff (S1,S2,S6) and obtained C1’s Individual Behavior Supports Plan, Hospital Discharge Paperwork and Special Incident Reports (SIR’s). LPA attempted to interview one staff (S3), however after various attempts LPA was unsuccessful. On May 30, 2024, it was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that staff are not addressing the needs of minor and staff are not providing adequate supervision for minor. It was reported that on 5/14/24 C1 was taken to the hospital for throat discomfort due to swallowing a paperclip. It was reported that on 5/19/24 C1 was taken to the hospital for abdominal pain, an x-ray was conducted, and a foreign object was found. CONTINUED...

narrative: Confidential interviews indicated C1 is aggressive towards staff and engages in self-injurious behavior. Confidential interviews indicated C1 elopes frequently, and for C1’s safety, C1 is placed in CPI (crisis prevention intervention) holds. Confidential interviews indicated when C1 is placed in CPI holds, at times, C1 drops down to the floor with their knees and thighs together and legs outward. Confidential interviews indicated on March 6, 2024, when C1 was being dropped off at school, C1 was running to and from the van repeatedly. Confidential interview indicated, after several minutes of the back and forth, C1 ran past the staff and outside the gate going into oncoming traffic. Confidential interviews indicated S1 and S2 attempted to place C1 in a hold, however, C1 dropped to the floor, so staff let go of C1. Confidential interview indicated staff did not observe C1 drop down on their knee. Confidential interviews indicated school aids walked over to provide support and escorted C1 into the school. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that staff inappropriately restrained a minor resulting in a fracture may have occurred, however, the allegation is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this signed report and appeal rights were provided to Kelsea Wochaski, QBMP.
investigation_findings: 13On October 3, 2024, at 9:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui arrived at the facility unannounced and met with Kelsea Wochaski, QBMP to discuss the investigative finding for the allegation noted above. On March 20, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui conducted an initial complaint investigation visit. The investigation was conducted by Special Investigator (SI) Ge Sun. SI Sun interviewed one client (C1), four staff (S1-S4), one witness and one San Diego County Social Worker. Pertinent records were obtained and reviewed. On March 15, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that staff inappropriately restrained a minor resulting in a fracture. It was reported that on March 7, 2024, C1 informed facility staff about their knee hurting in the morning while getting ready for school. It was reported that C1 was taken to the doctor and staff were informed that C1 had a fracture in their knee. Additionally, it was reported that an unauthorized hold was done on C1 on the same day on which C1 complained of knee pain. CONTINUED....

narrative:
Confidential interviews indicated S1 and C1’s interactions were good. Confidential interviews indicated if S1 and C1 hugged it would be a side hug. Confidential interviews denied seeing S1 hold C1 like a baby. Although there was no corroborating evidence of inappropriate physical contact, confidential interviews indicated S1 called C1 “turd.” Confidential interviews corroborated S1 addressed C1 with “turd” and C1 would call S1 “turd” also. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that staff engaged in inappropriate behavior with minor in care is SUBSTANTIATED because the preponderance of evidence has been met. This posed a potential Personal Rights risk to children in care. The facility will be cited for violating Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 06. Continuing Requirements, Personal Rights 84072(d)(18), [See LIC 9099D]. An exit interview was conducted and Plan of Corrections was developed with Portia Tresvant, Adminsitrator. A copy of this signed report, LIC 9099D and appeal rights were provided to Portia Tresvant, Adminsitrator.

Confidential interviews indicated S7 and S8 were assigned to C1’s supervision and S1 remained in the staff office in meetings. Confidential interviews indicated S7 would step away from C1 due to C1 being inappropriate. Confidential interviews indicated that C1 was triggered C1 and began throwing items at their relative. According to confidential interviews, S8 intervened with a ukeru pad and the items did not make contact with the relative. Confidential interviews indicated music was playing on the television in the living room, staff mistakenly left the remote on the couch arm rest, and C1 snatched it and raised the television volume as loud as it could go. Confidential interviews indicated C1 has music restrictions where they do not listen to music with explicit language and songs with lyrics only on the screen, and interviews did not corroborate that C1 was allowed to listen to inappropriate music. Based on confidential interviews the allegations that staff did not prevent minor from engaging in sexual behavior and staff allow minors to listen to inappropriate music may have occurred, however, the allegations are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this signed report and appeal rights were provided to Portia Tresvant, Adminsitrator.
investigation_findings: 13On October 3,2024 09:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui arrived at the facility unannounced and met with Kelsea Wochaski, QBMP to discuss the investigative finding for the allegation noted above. LPA Jauregui conducted an inspection of the facility on June 19, 2024, and no deficiencies were noted. During the investigation, LPA Jauregui interviewed seven staff (S2-S8), one witness (W1), and reviewed staff schedule, C1’s needs and services plan and YAI’s internal investigation. LPA attempted to interview one staff (S1), however after various attempts LPA was unsuccessful. On June 13, 2024, it was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that staff engaged in inappropriate behavior with minor in care. It was reported that a staff member, S1, was observed to be inappropriate with C1. It was reported that S1 was observed cradling C1 like a baby with C1’s arms around S1’s neck, and it was reported that S1 had several nicknames for S1 that are inappropriate. It was reported that S1 was observed to be cuddling with C1 under the blankets on the couch. CONTINUED....

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personal Rights 84072(d)(18) The licensee shall ensure that each child. . .is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9, and below, as applicable: To be accorded dignity in their personal relationships with staff and other persons. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews, licensee did not ensure that 1 of 2 clients (C1) in care was accorded dignity in their personal relationships with staff, which posed a potential personal rights violation to persons in care.

narrative: On 11/05/2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that a staff left a minor unsupervised. It was specifically reported that S1 was asleep while on duty and left C1 unsupervised. During the investigation, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that S1 fell asleep while S1 was supposed to be watching C1 during an overnight shift. In addition, a confidential interview disclosed that S1 was not asleep at any point during S1’s shift. In addition, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that there were three staff on shift the night S1 allegedly fell asleep and that two of the three staff witnessed S1 asleep while in C1’s bedroom. Based on interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the Department has determined that staff left a minor unsupervised. Therefore, the allegation is substantiated. The facility is being cited for the violation of the Title 22, Division 6 Chapter 1 Article 06. Continuing Requirements 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (See LIC 9099D) An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Devante Fields, Assistant Program Administrator.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client’s needs. This requirement was not met evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews staff was caught sleeping at the facility. This poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.

narrative: On 01/16/2025, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that staff did not ensure the minor attended their scheduled medical appointments. It was specifically reported that staff have not taken C1 for medical care in the past and as of today (01/16/2025). During the investigation, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that the staff ensures clients are taken to medical appointments and when the clients do not attend medical appointments, CSWs are notified, and missed appointments are documented and rescheduled. In addition, a confidential interview disclosed that on 10/09/2024 C1 missed an appointment and it was rescheduled for 10/15/2024 and C1 attended their (C1) appointment. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that staff did not provide records to minor's health care provider. It was specially reported that there have been several occasions when the facility’s staff did not bring C1’s medical documentation binder to an appointment with the caregiver. During the investigation, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that staff do not withhold clients’ medical documentation from caregivers. In addition, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that staff do a great job communicating with CSWs regarding client’s medical needs. In addition, a confidential interview disclosed that not to their knowledge at any point were C1’s medical records requested from the clinic C1 attended. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that staff did not ensure the minor attended their scheduled medical appointments and staff did not provide records to minor's health care provider are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or be valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Devante Fields, Assistant Program Administrator.

Enhanced Behavioral Supports Home (EBSH) and met with Devante Fields, Assistant Program Administrator to deliver the investigative findings for the allegations listed above involving the EBSH staff and client 1(C1). On 01/21/2025, LPA L. Jauregui conducted a health and safety inspection at the EBSH, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. In addition, on 05/14/2025, LPA M. Chavez conducted an additional visit at the EBSH. LPAs conducted interviews with staff (S1 & S2) and County Social Workers (CSWs). LPAs were unable to interview clients #1 and #2 (C1 & C2) due to C1 being placed on a 72-hour hold at the hospital and C2 being non-verbal.

narrative:
On 01/16/2025, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that staff touched a client in an inappropriate manner. It was specifically reported that there were concerns about sexual abuse and that S1 showered C1. During the investigation, a confidential interview disclosed that on one occasion, there wasn’t the same gender staff available, S1 assisted C1 with showering only using verbal prompts with the bathroom door cracked open outside the bathroom. A confidential interview stated that S1 was not in the bathroom while C1 was showering and did not touch C1 at all. In addition, a confidential interview disclosed that S1 have not seen C1 naked and C1 can shower without assistance from staff and get dressed by themselves. A confidential interview disclosed that the facility staff always reports when they are short-staffed and has even adjusted the schedule so that there is always the same gender staff working with C1. Another confidential interview disclosed staff are present when C1 showers but C1 needs minimal prompting and if only the opposite gender staff are available, they will wait outside the door and assist with having C1's required equipment and clothes ready. Multiple confidential interviews disclosed that there are no concerns for staff at the facility. LPA was unable to gather additional information. In regard to the allegation that staff showed the client inappropriate violent video content, it was specifically reported that S1 has shown C2 violent and aggressive videos called "Two-year-old gets beaten down to death by babysitter and boyfriend." During the investigation, a confidential interview disclosed that while staff were at the hospital with C2, staff let C2 watch a documentary on the facility’s work phone and that two staff took turns holding the phone. In addition, a confidential interview disclosed that S1 held the phone for C2 after C2 had already watched the first half of the documentary. Furthermore, a confidential interview disclosed that the documentary was called “’ Monster’ Babysitter and Boyfriend Savagely Beat 2-Year-Old Girl to Death” and was educational but uneasy. In addition, a confidential interview disclosed that C2 watches a lot of movies such as scary movies, cop shows, and people being arrested and C2 also tries to watch cartel videos, animals being dissected, and other inappropriate videos. LPA was unable to receive additional information.

Regarding the allegation that staff applied improper forms of restraint on a client, it was specifically reported that S1 had put C2 in improper restraints. During the investigation, a confidential interview disclosed that C1 has had to be put in a restraint, but exact date and reason could not be recalled. Multiple confidential interviews disclosed that some restraints have been unsuccessful but there haven’t been any improper restraints reported. Lastly, a confidential interview disclosed that the facility typically does hold restraints that are not appropriate, and restraints are not used very often. In addition, the confidential interview disclosed that the facility has done a lot of work to come up with solutions on how to work with C1 and adjust to C1’s needs for example, getting padded shields to de-escalate C1 from running away and avoid having the restrain. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that staff touched client in an inappropriate C1, staff showed C2 inappropriate violent video content, and staff applied improper forms of restraint on C2 may have happened or be valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Devante Fields, Assistant Program Administrator.

narrative: On the date above a pre licensing visit was conducted at Guardian Home by Licensing Program analyst (LPA) Les Inouye. I was met by Licensee Paul Llamoso, Cherry Ann Agravante, Tara Marie Lacanilao, Julianne Datuin, Nemia Atendido. A review of the Physical Plant was conducted including the Indoor Activity Space, Fixtures Furniture Equipment and Supplies and Outdoor Activity Space. The indoor space is an open floor plan with not hazards. The outdoor area is fee of hazards. There is a utility shed in the back yard which was secured during the visit. Kitchen was clean and non-perishable items were observed in the kitchen and additional non-perishable items were observed in the pantry. Bedrooms were observed, 5 single occupancy and a capacity of five. All rooms were appropriately furnished with additional linens was observed and adequate space for medical equipment. All chemicals and cleaning supplies were locked and secured. Smoke Alarms and Carbon Monoxide detectors, fire suppression system was observed and operating. Hot water temperature was measured at 110 degrees. Back yard -there is no pool or hot tub, yard consisted of a lawn area. The physical plant review was observed to be clean, safe, and free of hazards. The physical plant has met standards. At this time the applicant is in the process to be set up with Guardian and access with a Guardian login. Applicant will notify LPA when approved. A new revision of the Review by CCL will be completed and submitted to LPA and will be reviewed.

On the date above a Case Management visit was conducted at Guardian Home by Licensing Program analyst (LPA) Les Inouye. I was met by Licensee Paul Llamoso, Cherry Ann Agravante, Tara Marie Lacanilao, Julianne Datuin, Nemia Atendido. The visit was to discuss corrections that were requested on the last review. Detailed discussions took place on several regulations, the format of the review and the required corrections. Guardian Home and LPA have a better understanding of required corrections and a revision will be submitted to the LPA once completed.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Les Inouye contacted Paul Llamoso by phone to discuss the application status. Paul advised LPA that he is out of the country and referred LPA to discuss the application with Tara Lacanilao. Paul texted Tara's phone number. LPA phoned Tara and left a voice mail message to call LPA, Number left to call back. I was able to talk to Tara and we discussed that the submission should be in by tomorrow. 3/28/25. We also discussed the Emergency Intervention Plan and review by a certified behavior analyst. She indicated that the facility is already working with someone who provides services for their other facilities. I provided Tara with a name of a behavior analyst, I came across who is an employee with Regional Center. Just a reminder that the information in the EIP section should be included in the training, Section 24. As always if there are any questions, please do not hesitate to contact me.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Les Inouye Scheduled a Teleconference with Paul Llamoso of Guardian Home to go over the latest review of the Program Statement which was returned for updates and corrections on 05/23/25. Tara Lacanilo was designated to attend the meeting. During the meeting all issues identified on the review were covered. Tips to address each issue was discussed such as a Table of classes which is easier to provide required information. Also discussed was that each class must included identified required information. Tara stated that the EIP Section was currently under review by their Behavior Analyst. LPA advised to get a expected approved return date from the BCBA and inform LPA of when the EIP section can be returned for review. Tara explained that she has a scheduled call with the BCBA and will inform LPA of the status. At the end of the meeting Tara had no further questions and the meeting ended at that time.

On 9/03/2024 at approximately 9:01 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tatyana Shulz, Sarina Buchannan, Zaria Turner, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez made an announced visit with the purpose of conducting a pre-licensing inspection to the above facility. LPAs and LPM met with Administrator, Paul Fernandez, and a walk through of the interior and exterior was completed. Physical Plant LPAs and LPM entered from the front door into the Great Room that has 1 couch, 2 chairs, coffee table and a TV, with a closet housing their emergency food supply and water. There is a dining room with a table and 4 chairs next to the kitchen area. There are 5 bedrooms all of them equipped with 1 twin bed, 2 dressers, closet, TV, lamp, patient lift, trash cans with lids and a door with access to the backyard with an attached alarm system. Room 1 is an office area with a desk, closet, filing cabinets and the medication storage lockup. Room 2 is the multipurpose room with Big Jenga, connect 4 and have sufficient activities for clients, including books, age-appropriate toys, arts/craft materials and all furniture is in good repair. There are two full bathrooms and 1 half bathroom, with working toilets, and running warm water with a temperature of 105 degrees. The two full bathrooms are also equipped with a patient lift and there is 1 shower bed available. The backyard is gated, with ADA accessible ramps leading from each exit and room. There is a gazebo area with a table and 6 chairs. There is a generator located next to the table and the shed. The shed is stocked with chairs, tools, extra refrigerator, water, nonperishable food, storage bins, and extra cleaning supplies. On the back side of the shed the property has 14 trash bins. The facility has ordered a van to transport the clients and the information will be provided to the LPA once available. Report continues on 809-C.

The following required documents were posted, Emergency Disaster Plan, Personal Rights and complaint contact numbers. Disinfectants/cleaning solutions are inaccessible to children in care and locked under the kitchen sink. Refrigerator temperature at or below 45 degrees F. Nonperishable foods one week and fresh perishable foods three days minimum. Water and fridge temperature posted on the front of the refrigerator. Sharp objects are locked in the drawer and there are containers to place leftover food. A working telephone is available at the facility. Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are in working order. First Aid Kit fully stocked. Hot Water between 105–120-degree F. Fire Extinguishers are up to date and in working order. Toilets, wash basins and shower fixtures in good repair, there are no leaks and hot water is accessible. Soap and paper towels are available to clients. Bedroom required linen and furnishings are fully stocked. The facility is free of vermin. The generator and water valves located in the backyard area are easily accessible to clients in care. There is approximately a 5 foot L shaped fence surrounding the generator and the water valves can be easily reached from the walking path. If the population served changes those two areas will need to become inaccessible to clients. However, due to the population that the facility serves currently, the licensee will not need to be concerned with these changes, as of now. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator, Paul Fernandez and a copy of this report will be provided to the facility, the home is in full compliance.

On August 23, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Demetris Teal and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Tira Logan-Shanks conducted a Component II- in person meeting at the Monterey Park Regional Office. The following was present; Terrobin Phillips President of 2 Loving Hearts facility. LPA and LPM discussed their application and program statement advising of the following corrections. The following information must be completed and submitted to Licensing: Section A Board of Resolution Authorizing Individual(s) to applying on behalf of the Board of Directors: who is Deesha Inc? Who are the members of Deesha Inc.? Who was present for the vote on March 1, 2023, where it was decided that Terrobin Phillips is authorized to represent and act on behalf of 2 Loving Hearts? Why doesn’t it say 2 Loving Hearts LLC as the “members”? LIC 308 lists “TBH” as the person designated in the absence of the facility administrator. A name needs to be specified. LIC 309 list a president as N/A, yet the board of resolution names a president. Statement of Information on the Secretary of State website shows Keisha Law as a Manager or Member, but she is not listed on the LIC 309. LIC 400 needs a signature. Articles of Organization is not submitted. LIC 402 Surety Bond needs to list LLC as the applicant. Continued...

.....Continued LIC 500 Personnel Report needs to be completed. 610 D signed by Terrobin Phillips is not for Community Care Licensing (CCL). 610 C is needed. 9282 signed by Terrobin Phillips is not for Community Care Licensing (CCL). LIC 503 Health Screening Report needs to have the updated T.B tests. Program Statement needs to be followed per CCL template. Administrator currently has full time employment outside of the Group Home setting. Application shows proof of Adult Care Certification only. Discussed with president what is required for the Program Statement in detail. Program Statement details regarding tabs and information, where to look for Title 22 regulations, Interim Licensing Standards and make sure the Program Statement coincides with all regulations. President agreed to submit all information discussed and required by September 1, 2023 Exit interview conducted. A signed copy of this report was provided to the applicant along with Notice of Incomplete Application.

On October 3, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Johanna Lofton conducted an announced visit at 2 Loving Hearts Group Home with the purpose of conducting a pre-licensing inspection. This facility will accommodate Regional Center Clients between the ages of 11-17. LPA Lofton met Facility Administrator Terrobin Phillips and Facility Manager Kiesha Law and together conducted a walk through of the facility. The facility is a one level house located in a residential area. The facility consist of three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, living room, kitchen, dining room, garage and backyard. The master bedroom will be used as an office which is equipped with a desk, computer and office supplies. The other two bedrooms are for the clients. These bedrooms are equipped with two (2) full beds each, dressers and closet space. At the time of the inspection, all utilities (gas, water, electricity) were on. The fire alarm was tested and it was in working conditions. LPA Lofton observed nonperishable food in the fridge, freezer and pantry. There is a fire extinguisher located in the kitchen by the door leading to the backyard. Additional linen and an extra refrigerator/freezer were observed in the garage along with washer and dryer. There is a cabinet in the garage which will contain: sharps, cleaning supplies and anything toxic that will pose a risk to the clients. This cabinet will be kept locked at all times. LPA observed the outdoor of the home to be clean and free of debris and/or obstructions. There is a fully stocked first aid kit located in the office area. There were no corrections observed to be made prior to the facility being licensed. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to the above mentioned administrator.

...Continued Adequate supply of beddings and linens were observed. Overall, facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Operations There are no clients or staff at the facility. On March 19, 2025 at 1:00 P,M., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Demetris Teal conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at the above named facility. LPA met withTerrobin Phillips-Administrator. The facility currently has a provisional Group Home (GH) license. The GH is licensed to serve up to four (4) clients ages 12 to 17. The facility serves ambulatory developmentally disabled clients, level 4I Regional Center Clients and provide one on one care. There is currently one (1) client in placement. The LPA requested the following: Personnel Report LIC500, Client Roster, Board of Meeting Minutes, Clients and Staff Files. The facility is a single-story home with 3 bedrooms, living room, kitchen, backyard and two (2) full bathrooms with two toilets. There are no firearms or ammunition in the facility. There are no bodies of water in the facility premises. At 1:30 P.M.,LPA conducted a walk-through of the entire facility. Physical Plant The license, facility sketch, personal rights, emergency disaster form, complaints poster, emergency phone numbers and food menu are posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept inaccessible and locked staff office. Sharps/knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked staff office cabinet. Facility has non-perishable food for at least one week and perishable food for at least two days. Medications are centrally stored in a locked staff office cabinet . Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and in proper working order. Fire extinguisher was fully charged. First Aid Kits were checked and found to be complete. Room temperatures are maintained at 76 degrees F. The hot water temperature was tested and measured at 115 degrees F. All sinks, showers and toilets are in working order. No more than one (1) children share a bedroom. All beds are in good repair; equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows. Adequate supply of beddings and linens were observed. Facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. Overall, facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. continued.....

.....continued Operations Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. The board of directors regularly conduct meeting to review and discuss the GH’s operation. The facility administrator is the responsible and capable staff for communicating with emergency personnel in the facility. Disaster Preparedness Plan Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster and fire drills are conducted monthly for each shift. The drills are documented, and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Individual Treatment Plan for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. Emergency Intervention Plan Facility does not use manual restraints. However, all staff (2) members are trained on emergency intervention procedures. Client Records LPA reviewed one (1) client record. All client records are available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client records contain required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, individual treatment plans, medical assessment, safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables, education records; personal rights forms; and medication administration records. Current client has been in the home for less than a month. Medical records have been requested and will be updated by Regional Center Staff LPA interviewed one (1) client in care. Continued.....

....continuation Staff Records LPA reviewed two (2) staff records. All staff have been subjected to criminal records review and have been fingerprinted and cleared with DOJ, FBI and CACI. The administrator meets the required qualifications and/or experience. Documentation of the required education and experience will be sent to LPA. It was not observed at the time of the review. LPA verified at least 20 hours of annual training for Facility Manager. Clients with Special Health Care Needs There are currently no clients in care with special health care needs. LPA interviewed one (2) staff member. There were 2 citations assessed during this inspection one (1) technical advisory and three (3) technical violations. Exit interview conducted.
