facility_name: A RAY OF SUNSHINE CHILDREN'S HOME
narrative: On Thursday February 3, 2022 Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Alyssa Ng made an unannounced inspection to conduct an annual required inspection. LPA met with Administrator Mesalina Lee-Gonzales. The facility has a census of five clients. Administrator Mesalina informed me that they are licensed for an Adult Residential Facility (ARF). They were licensed on 07/22/2021. Administrator made a copy of the license was given to LPA Ng. LPA Ng also received their Children's Residential license. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator Mesalina .

On 4/20/22 at 11:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng made an unannounced annual/required inspection to this location. LPA Ng came in at 11:45 and met with Administrator Nelly Robillo. Administrator informed LPA Ng that they closed the entrance gate due to the incidents of a client AWOLing (See LIC 809-C for more details).The facility is licensed for six residents, and currently in placement is 3 clients. LPA observed one client in care who is non-verbal, however appeared to be in good spirits. Client had a visitor which was her dad. Safety precautions were taken, including screening call, hand hygiene, and mask-wearing. LPA Ng toured the facility inside and out, and the facility consist of four bedrooms. Three bedrooms for clients and one for staff and all bedrooms are double occupancy and four bathrooms. Two bathrooms are located in master bedrooms which are located on both sides of the home, and two single bathrooms. The water temperature measured 105.4 degrees F. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary. The facility had sufficient perishable and nonperishable food supplies. The smoke detectors and fire extinguishers are in working order. No bodies of water on the premises. All walkways were free from debris or hazards. All window screens are in good condition. All client records complete with all of the required documentation. Each client has their own separate binder of all required documents. Each psychotropic medication was observed to have its own Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR), as well as individual Centrally Stored Medication Destruction Records (CSMDR). All medications were consistent with these records. Staff has a centralized binder that contained their training, qualifications, and other personal information. LPA looked through all binders and were complete with all the required documentation. ------CONT. ON LIC 809C-----

Resident and staff records were observed to be complete and the facility in compliance, with only the following exceptions: Complaint procedures were not posted in the facility and was not accessible for staff and clients and their authorized representatives. LPA advises per CCR regulation, 84072.2(a)(3), complaint procedures must be posted in the facility within clear view of clients and their authorized representatives. LPA also gave a technical assistance regarding the entrance way. Upon arrival, LPA Ng called the facility five times due to no doorbell and locked entry way. There was no entry point or door bell to inform the facility that the LPA was here. LPA saw Administrator leaving and was able to flag Administrator Nelly down. Administrator let LPA come in to conduct the annual inspection. During Inspection, LPA Ng called the house phone and it rang. Administrator stated that they did not hear the phone. LPA let Administrator know that annual visits and all other CCL visits are unannouced and LPA's can show up at any time. Administrator informed LPA that they will install a doorbell at the gate to notify if a visitor/CCL is here. At this time, 1 deficiency and technical assistance were given. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Licensee/Administrator Nelly Robillo, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: 13On 7/25/22 at 10:25 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to the facility and met with Nelly Robillo, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. Based on the report, the allegation pertains to client C1 (See LIC 811, dated 6/30/22), who sustained unexplained injuries while in care. While investigating, LPA Ng interviewed staff, case manager, and reviewed incident reports and Needs and Service Plans. LPA Valenzuela visited the facility on 6/30/22 and took pictures of (C1)'s arms. Upon review, there was two scrapes on (C1) left arm. The scrapes were ½ a centimeter in size and light brown and white in the middle. LPA Ng received an incident report dated 6/22/22, explains how C1 got the scrape, where it came from, and what immediate action was taken. Staff hugged C1 to shield them from C3, immediately separated them, treated the wound with an ice pack and antibiotics. LPA Ng found no additional cuts or bruises on client’s arm. During confidential interviews from staff, (C1) got the scrapes from C3 which matches what was written in the incident report. After a review of C3’s needs and service plan and talking to their case manager, C3 has a history of pinching behavior. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that minor sustained unexplained injuries while in care, therefore the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy was sent to Nelly Robillo, Administrator.

13On 11/3/22 at 12:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection at Achiever’s Group Home and spoke with Nelly Robillo, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to open the complaint and deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During investigation, interviews were conducted and documents were reviewed, and it was determined that the Facility incorrectly charged resident, Facility is mismanaging resident's P & I monies, and Facility is mismanaging resident's records. Based on LPA’s interview with staff, clients, and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations, Facility incorrectly charged resident, Facility is mismanaging resident's P & I monies, and Facility is mismanaging resident's records is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6 & Chapter 1: 80026(h) Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property and Valuables. At this time, one deficiency was given. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was given to Nelly Robillo, Administrator.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property and Valuables. Each licensee shall maintain accurate records of accounts of client cash resources, personal property valuables entrusted to his/her care… This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, the licensee failed to maintain accurate records of client’s P&I funds, which poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.

narrative:
On 3/30/22 at 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng made an unannounced annual/required inspection to this location. The facility is licensed for six residents, and currently in placement is 3 clients. There were three staff present at the time of the inspection. All clients were at school at the time of the inspection. Safety precautions were taken, including screening call, hand hygiene, and mask-wearing. At 10:15 AM, LPA Ng toured the facility inside and out, and the facility consist of four bedrooms. Three bedrooms for clients and one for staff and all bedrooms are double occupancy and four bathrooms. Two bathrooms are located in master bedrooms which are located on both sides of the home, and two single bathrooms. All client bedrooms are currently single occupancy. The water temperature measured 107.5 degrees F. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary. The facility had sufficient perishable and nonperishable food supplies. Knives and chemicals are locked in a secure area. The smoke detectors and fire extinguishers are in working order. No bodies of water on the premises. All walkways were free from debris or hazards. All window screens are in good condition. At 11:00 PM, LPA Ng observed the backyard with a wooden fence. There were two storage sheds on the side of the house. Both contained extra linens and decorations. There were no open bodies of water and no hazards. Their centralized AC unit was on the other side of the house and inaccessible to clients in care. All client records complete with all of the required documentation. Each client has their own separate binder of all required documents. All medications were consistent with these records. One client is on psychotropic medication. Staff has a centralized binder that contained their training, qualifications, and other personal information. LPA looked through all binders and were complete with all the required documentation. Resident and staff records were observed to be complete and the facility in compliance, with only the following exceptions: ----cont on 809C----

During a review of the clients medication records, LPA Ng found that one client was taking psychotropic medication. Facility did not use a separate form for the psychotropic medication. Facility cited per CCR regulation, 84070(b)(13), under Children's Records. Please see 809D for more information. At this time, 1 deficiency was given. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was printed and given to Licensee/Administrator Nelly Robillo, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 05/31/2024 at 1:25 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jasmine Cardeno and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Carolyn Flynn made an unannounced visit to Achiever’s Group Home to conduct a required annual inspection. LPA Cardeno and LPM Flynn met with Facility Administrator, Nelly Robillo, who helped assist with the inspection. The Facility Achiever’s Group Home has a current census of 3 clients and all clients are nonverbal. At the start of the inspection, the clients were at school and there were 4 staff present at the time of the inspection. Later, 2 clients came back home from school and greeted LPA and LPM and appeared happy, smiling at LPA and LPM. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to conduct the inspection. At the start of the inspection, LPA Cardeno and LPM Flynn conducted a walk-through of the facility, both inside the home and outside of the home. The facility is currently under construction for 1 client's bathroom. The client's bathroom is under construction to replace the flooring. LPA and LPM observed that there were construction materials and tools present on the facility grounds. When the clients were present on the facility grounds, the construction materials were removed and not made available for the clients. There are 3 bedrooms for clients and 4 bathrooms. There are 3 bathrooms for clients and each client has their own personal bathroom. All client bedrooms are single occupancy, and beds have clean linens. LPA Cardeno observed centrally stored medications maintained and locked secure in the closet located in the living room. The facility had sufficient perishable and nonperishable food supplies. The Facility Achiever’s Group Home is maintained at 76 degrees Fahrenheit and the hot water temperature measures at 109.2 degrees Fahrenheit, which the temperatures are both within range. Sharps were locked in a secure cabinet under the sink of the kitchen. At 1:50 PM, LPA Cardeno observed that there was a sharp knife that was in a kitchen drawer and not locked away in a secure location.

At this time, due to time constraints, LPA Cardeno was not able to conduct staff interviews and do further file review including the client files and staff files during this visit. LPA Cardeno discussed the following with Facility Administrator, Nelly Robillo, and issued 2 Technical Violations: LPA observed the chemical cleaning supplies that were stored were not locked away as the garage door was open. Usually, the garage door is closed and the door to the garage storage area is locked and the cleaning supplies are locked in the location. LPA observed that there was a sharp in a drawer that was unlocked. The Facility Administrator locked away the sharp right away in the secure cabinet and explained that the knife was used during the construction. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to Facility Administrator, Nelly Robillo, whose signature on this form confirms the receipt. LPA Cardeno will continue this Annual Inspection at a future date.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) T. Davis went to Adolescent Growth, Inc. on March 17, 2022 at 10:20am for the purposes of conducting a Required 2 Year inspection. LPA met with Dr. Joilyn Lewis, President/CEO and John Lewis, COO, and discussed the purpose of today's visit. The license issued by Community Care Licensing (CCL) allows the licensee to serve six ambulatory clients ages 12-17 years old. The facility is located in a residential neighborhood and has three bedrooms, three bathrooms, kitchen, living room, and dining area. LPA and the licensee toured the facility and discussed the inspection in detail. Currently, there are no clients in placement at the facility. The facility has no direct care staff as of this date but is in the process of hiring new staff. LPA observed three bathrooms to be in good repair and working order. The three bedrooms contained two twin beds in each bedroom as well as ample closet space. LPA observed adequate seating in the dining area and the living room. The smoke alarms were operable throughout the facility. There is also a classroom area inside the facility for the clients to use. LPA observed several desks and chairs in the classroom area that were arranged in a classroom style setting. There were books, board games, and arts and crafts supplies inside the classroom. . The facility does not have any clients in placement at this time nor direct care staff; therefore, no client or direct care staff files were available to review. The President/CEO stated that there were no guns or weapons on the premises. Licensee will scan LPA an updated LIC500 (Personnel Report) and a copy of their most recent Board of Director's meeting minutes. LPA found no Title 22 deficiencies on this date. Exit interview done

On October 4, 2022 at 10:00 AM, LPA Rarela conducted an unannounced case management inspection to the facility in order to cite deficiencies from a previous inspection as detailed below. On September 29, 2022 at 10:45 AM, LPA Rarela conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility and was informed by staff that there was no facility manager present and did not allow the LPA enter the facility to conduct the unannounced inspection. Per Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5 84065.2 Personnel Duties, a licensed facility shall have one or more facility managers on the premises with the authority and responsibility necessary to manage and control the day-to-day operation of a community care facility and supervise the clients. In addition, Per Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5 84044(b) Inspection Authority of the Department of Licensing Agency, the licensing agency shall have the inspection authority specified in Health and Safety Code section 1538.9. The aforementioned regulations were cited. A copy of this report, LIC 809-D for deficiencies and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative.

Confidential statements obtained could not corroborate the allegation. The facility client who made the initial disclosure later changed their account during the investigation denying the allegation. Other confidential statements obtained from facility clients did not provide any corroborating evidence to support the allegation. Facility staff also denied the allegation. Based on the information gathered, the allegation is unsubstantiated as the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met although the allegation may have happened or is valid. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative via electronic mail.

met_with: Dr. Joilyn Lewis, President/CEO and John Lewis, COO
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) T. Davis was advised by Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Yan Yeung to conduct a case management visit to cite Adolescent Growth, Inc. based on observations made by LPA Olena Maico on Friday, August 08, 2025. LPA went to Adolescent Growth, Inc. on August 12, 2025 at 12:35pm for the purposes noted above. LPA met with Dr. Joilyn Lewis, President/CEO (P/CEO) and John Lewis, COO, and informed both individuals of the citation. LPA advised the P/CEO and the COO that LPA Maico drafted the report and citation and he will present the report and citation verbatim as drafted by LPA Maico. LPA Maico's report is as follows: On 08/08/2025 at 11:15 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olena Maico visited the facility during the unannounced complaint investigation and did not observe Facility Manager or Administrator on premises. During LPA's visit the staff who was at the door stated she was a Medical Assistant (MA. LPA asked if there was another staff on premises and MA stated there was also a Therapist. The MA called the Facility Manager (FM) and the FM stated she took a day off today. LPA asked if the FM or Administrator were on premises and FM said no. FM stated she will be on her way to the facility. At around 12:15 LPA asked MA if the FM was coming and MA stated the the FM should be here in 10 minutes. At around 12:40 PM the Administrator arrived at the facility and spoke with the LPA. LPA asked if the Facility Manager is scheduled to be on the premises when the children are present. Administrator stated that the Facility Manager was on premises till 10 AM and the other supervisor also has been present. LPA was shown the video of the person sitting at the desk. LPA inquired why the contradicting information was provided to the LPA and LPA was informed that the Facility Manager was not on premises.

LPA requested LIC 500 from the Administrator. LIC 500 was provided to the LPA. LPA did not observe the Facility Manager position on the LIC 500. LPA informed the Administrator that the position is required by the Title 22 and needs to be revised. Title 22 Chapter 5 Article 6 84065 (d) states The licensee shall designate at least one facility manager to be present at the facility at all times when children are present. LPA did not observe Facility Manager or the Administrator present at the facility at the time LPA arrived and there were 3 children at the facility at the time of LPA's visit. The Administrator did not arrive to the facility until 12:40. The facility is being cited for the violation of the section 84065 (d) Administrator. The copy of this report and LIC 809d as well as LIC 811 was provided to the Administrator. Exit interview done. Appeal Rights given

On Wednesday 6/16/21 at 9:33AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to conduct a required annual inspection. A screening email and phone call were sent/attempted prior to the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including face masks, hand sanitizer, disinfectants, and social distancing. Additionally, LPA is vaccinated, tested negative for COVID-19 on Monday 6/14/21, and does not have any symptoms of COVID-19. LPA met with Dr. Linda LaBrie, Clinical Supervisor, and informed of the purpose of the visit. At 9:45AM, LPA conducted a tour of the facility and grounds. The facility is clean and free of debris. The grounds are free of obstructions and are well-maintained. The kitchen is stocked with food to meet the needs of the residents in care and meets the mandated 7-day non-perishable and 2-day perishable standard. Food items are in date and are labeled by date of purchase. Cleaners and sharps are kept in locked storage areas downstairs, and the laundry room (upstairs) is locked. There is a sign-in and screening table set up by the front entrance that includes a sign-in sheet, a thermometer, and hand sanitizer. At 10:05AM, LPA observed some kitchen cleaner in a high cabinet in the kitchen. Staff immediately moved these to the locked cleaning cabinet. At 10:22AM, LPA observed that the water temperature in the upstairs resident bathroom measured 125.6 F. LPA advises that, per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80088, hot water at vanity sinks should measure between 105 and 120 F, and measurements above 125 F require a hot water warning sign. Staff agreed to post a sign here until the hot water temperature can be lowered. At 10:35AM, LPA observed that there are cameras located in the following locations: facility entrance, front office, front living/dining area, back living room, classroom, and upstairs lounge. On 5/29/20, the facility was informed that a camera waiver is required before cameras can be used or fixed onto walls. LPA advises that the facility immediately deactivate the cameras and submit a waiver request for approval to use cameras.

At 10:50AM, LPA reviewed the facility files that were accessible to present staff. Emergency documentation was stored for each resident in an emergency information binder in the staff office. Staff and resident records, such as admission agreement, consent forms, etc. are only accessible to director, who agreed to send LPA the requested documents. LPA requested the following: most current LIC 500 Personnel Summary, LIC 610 Emergency Plan, all staff qualifications (LIC 501), all staff training record for 2020-current, each resident's face sheet, needs and services, admission agreement, and treatment/medical consent forms. There are no citations and two advisories. A follow-up to review the facility files will be conducted. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Dr. Linda LaBrie, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

met_with: Administrator Joy Lewis; CFO John Lewis
narrative:
On Tuesday 11/09/21 at 12:50PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah met with Administrator Joy Lewis and CFO John Lewis and informed of the purpose of the visit, which was to issue citations for deficiencies found during the course of an investigation at the facility. During investigation, it was discovered that multiple incidents occurred at the facility, including incidents in which the police were called. Local police confirmed that police responded to incidents on 06/08/21 for a 5150 evaluation, 06/13/21 for an unauthorized absence, 06/16/21 for a suicide threat and 5150, 06/23/21 for a traffic complaint by a neighbor for which police contacted the facility, and 06/29/21 for suicide threat and 5150. None of these incidents or police contacts were reported to the Licensing agency. Only one report was submitted for an incident on 07/25/21. Additionally, the report for an incident in which two residents engaged in sexual activity at the facility was not properly reported to the Licensing agency. Review of resident R1’s (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) Medication Administration Record (MAR) indicated that medication administration is not properly documented. The MAR used is an excel sheet rather than the LIC 622A and LIC 622B, or variation that includes all required information. The MAR was missing the dosage information for the medications and the chart of staff names administering medications. Only staff initials were included. There is disparity in administration time of medications that may be PRN and administered as advocated for by the youth. For instance, the same night medication was administered as early as 8:06PM and as late 11:51PM, and the morning medication was administered as early as 8:14AM and as late as 10:52PM. The latter may be a typo in the AM versus PM. However, the log does not document which medications are PRN or if medications not administered were missed or not administered for another reason. Lastly, the log includes all medications, including Sertraline (brand name is Zoloft), a psychotropic medication. Psychotropic medications must be logged separately on the LIC 622B or variation that includes all the same required information.

On 10/11/21, LPA learned in staff interviews that the facility was temporarily closed. LPA confirmed this with the administrator. No formal notice of closure was sent to the Licensing agency. LPA is issuing two citations and one advisory, per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Sections 80061(b) Reporting Requirements, 84070(b)(13) Children’s Records, and 80061(e) Reporting Requirements. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Administrator Joy Lewis.

met_with: Administrator Joy Lewis; CFO John Lewis
narrative: Staff and local police also confirmed that incidents occurred at the facility but were not properly reported and incidents were not documented on written incident reports sent to the Licensing agency. As such, specific incidents can not be evaluated for supervision requirements being met. However, incidents reported by the police to LPA do not confirm that a lack of supervision was the cause of any incident or that there was a violation related to any incident. Despite staff statements that the facility was understaffed, statements also indicate that staff did work overtime and/or step in to ensure supervision. Additionally, the facility has temporarily closed the facility, and there are no residents in care at this time. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews with residents and staff, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. LPA is issuing one advisory, per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Chapter 5, Section 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report left with Administrator Joy Lewis.
investigation_findings: 13On Tuesday 11/09/21 at 11:50AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins delivered investigation findings for the above allegations. LPA met with Administrator Joy Lewis and CFO John Lewis and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on report, the above allegations pertain to residents being improperly supervised. During investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews with staff and witnesses. LPA also referred to previous resident interviews conducted less than a month prior to the report. Based on interviews, staff and residents confirmed that the facility is very understaffed, and lead staff were at times unable to tell which staff were on the next shift. Additionally, due to lack of staff, staff were forced to work overtime and were unsure if they were properly compensated. It was reported that lack of staffing resulted in clinical staff stepping in for supervision, potentially limiting time for individual therapy sessions, although this was not confirmed. Staff indicated that all staff were well-trained, but there was inconsistency in staffing at times.

narrative:
... Residents were left in the milieu to get ready for bed while staff went down the hall to prepare night medications. Staff returned to the milieu between 3 and 5 minutes later, but the exact time could not be confirmed. However, it was long enough for R1 and R2 to engage in sex in R1’s room. Due to the known risk, there should have been enhanced supervision. The youth were separated and checked in with separately. Later, clinical staff responded and came to the facility that night. R1 was informed that this event was grounds for discharge. In response, R1 packed a bag and left the facility that night on an unauthorized absence. Based on staff interviews, R1 was not properly informed of this, triggering the leave. The police located the youth and were informed by clinical staff, as confirmed by clinical staff, that the youth could not return to the facility. R1 waited with police and then waited on the porch the next day until R1’s parent could pick up R1. Staff kept an eye on the youth on the porch and provided food. However, the youth should have been encouraged to remain in the facility with enhanced supervision to keep youth separate from each other and the discharge procedures followed properly. R1 was prescribed the psychotropic medication Zoloft, AM dose, and an informed consent was signed by the parent, consenting to the administration of the medication while R1 was in the facility’s care. However, it was confirmed that the medication was not administered because R1 was assessed by the facility's hired nurse practitioner, who continued the Zoloft and added additional medications, for which a new medication consent form needed to be signed by the parent(s). However, there should be no lapse in administration of medications, especially psychotropic medications. Documents and witness and staff interviews indicate that R1 was admitted on 7/14/21 and left the facility on 7/15/21. Per Administrator and CFO, R1 was assessed on 7/15/21 afternoon. The AM Zoloft dose should have been administered on 7/15/21 morning. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegations are found to be Substantiated. LPA is issuing three citations, per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Sections 84065.5 Staff/Child Ratios, 84068.4 Removal and/or Discharge Procedures, and 85075 Health Related Services. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Administrator Joy Lewis.

LPA is issuing an advisory per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 84072 Personal Rights and advises that the facility document when medications are transferred out of the facility at discharge similar to the documentation of medication at admission. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Joy Lewis.
investigation_findings: 13On Tuesday 11/16/21 at 9:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins delivered investigation findings for the above allegations. During investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews with staff, witnesses, local police, and authorized representative and reviewed resident records. Based on interviews, staff openly confirmed the events. R1 and R2 engaged in a sexual incident during a short lapse of supervision at night. However, per treatment plans, both residents were known to have sexualized behaviors. R1 had a known history of significant drug abuse, unauthorized absence, suicidality, and hypersexuality. Staff confirmed the day of the incident that clinical staff observed R1 and R2 “cliquing” as soon as R1 was admitted to the program. Due to their concern about this, it was communicated with staff that extra supervision was required for youth. Staff confirmed that night shift staff was in the upstairs milieu watching a movie with the 4 residents in care...

narrative: On November 10, 2021 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White arrived at the above location for the purpose of reviewing client and staff records in order to complete the STRTP Annual Required Inspection which began on 11/09/2021. LPA met with the Facility Manager, Azadeh Ebrahimi who granted access to location and provided the electronic files. The Program has a four (4) clients and six (6) staff. LPA reviewed all client and staff files. This inspection included an overview of required Core Services and Supports and an inspection of facility records of the staff and clients. LPA discussed the following with the Facility Manager: Incident reporting, including incidents related to Law Enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving Emergency Intervention. Discussed procedures for CFT (Child and Family Team) meetings. Licensee is meeting all requirements. There were no deficiencies noted on this date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was signed and left with the Facility Manager.

On November 9, 2021 at 11:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White arrived at ( ) for the purpose of conducting an Annual Random Inspection. LPA met with the Facility Manager, who granted access to the location and together a tour of the entire facility was conducted both inside and out. The facility is licensed to provide care and supervision services for six (6) children, ages 12-17 years old, ambulatory only. The census today is four (4). The program only accepts Private Placement Clients. The facility is set up as follows: This is a two-story home with 3 bedrooms, 2 full bathrooms and 2 half bathrooms, staffing offices, a therapy room, living room, dining room, kitchen, classroom, laundry area, conference room, a nursing office, and a backyard. Living room/community area: has ample seating, and a non working fire place. Dining room: is equipped with a table and seating for 6 people. Kitchen: is equipped with two (2) freezers/refrigerators, an oven, stove top with four (4) functional burners, dishwasher, and ample cabinet/storage space. Sharp objects and chemicals are kept in locked cabinets. Classroom: is located next to the kitchen. It is equipped with a multiple tables and seating, and lockers for children in care. The room contains two doors, one leading outside to the right of the home and the other leading to the garage both doors remain locked. Laundry Area: is located in a closet inside the classroom and has a stackable washer/dryer combination. Staffing offices: Three (3) staffing offices are located on the first floor. Therapy room: is located to the right of the entry way along a hallway at the front of the home. It is equipped with two desk and three chairs. Nursing Office: is located to the right of the entry way along a hallway next to the therapy room. It is equipped with a double locked cabinet that contains medications and the First Aid Kit. Conference room: is located on the second floor and is used for meetings. The room is equipped with a TV, a table, and seating for more than 8 people. Report continued on LIC 809C.

Bedrooms: All bedrooms are located on the first floor to the left of the entry way. Each bedroom is equipped with two twin beds, ample closet and drawer space. Bedrooms #1 and #2 both have sliding glass doors leading to the left side of the house. Bedroom #3 contains a bathroom and an exit door leading to the backyard. Bathrooms: Bathroom #1 and a ½ bathroom are located on the first floor along the hallway to the left of the entry way. Bedroom #3 contains Bathroom #2 and there is a ½ bathroom located on the second floor next to the conference room. All bathrooms were observed to be in good repair and working order. The hot water temperature was tested and found to be between 105-120 degrees (F). LPA observed four (4) fire extinguishers throughout the home and all were found to be in good condition. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. Medications are stored in a locked cabinet located in the nursing room and made inaccessible to children in care. All doors and exits are attached to an alarm system that alerts staff when doors are opened. There is a working telephone readily accessible. LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. There was no swimming pool, hot tub, spas, nor similar bodies of water located at the facility. LPA reminded Licensee to ensure the following: Children are accorded personal rights and the corresponding form is in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Licensee acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. During the visit, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements for Group Home Licensure and Emergency Plan were met. The Program has a total of six Staff. LPA interviewed all six Staff members and all Children in care. LPA will return on a later date to review client and staff files. There were no deficiencies noted on this date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was signed and left with the Facility Manager.

met_with: Administrator - Joilyn Lewis and COO - John Lewis
narrative:
On October 11, 2022 at 10:00 AM, a Non-Compliance Meeting was conducted at the El Segundo Regional Office to discuss compliance issues with Adolescent Growth, Inc. Present at the Non-Compliance Meeting were the following individuals: 1. Joilyn Lewis, CEO/Administrator 2. John Lewis, COO 3. Kellee Coleman, Regional Manager 4. LaKescia Smith, Licensing Program Manager I 5. Stephen Kim, Staff Service Manager I 6. Charmetha White, Licensing Program Analyst 7. Connie Jones-Steward, Licensing Program Analyst 8. Zena Phillips, Licensing Program Analyst The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the following: 1. Substantiated IB complaint dated 12/08/2021 2. Reporting requirements 3. LE Contact 4. Lack of Supervision 5. Staffing issues Regional Manager, Kellee Coleman discussed with licensee the concerns related to the Substantiated IB Compliant. Report continued on LIC 809C.

Licensee informed Regional Manager the incident was not reported to the department because an internal investigation conducted by the Administrator revealed that the allegations were not true as the client retracted the allegation. It was advised during the meeting that the Licensee will attend the Quarterly Provider meetings, train staff on reporting requirements, submit timely incident reports, and conduct three (3) month check ins with their assigned analyst for the next twelve (12) months to ensure the department is receiving incident reports. Copies of the following regulations discussed and provided to the licensee during the meeting: H&S 1533; H&S 1538.7; 80044; 80061; 84065.2; 84078; 80078; 84061; 85078 Additionally, the following Provider Notices were discussed and provided to the licensee during the meeting: PIN 17-04-CRP; 17-11-CRP. An exit interview was conducted with licensee, a copy of this report was given to the licensee at the end of the Office Meeting.

On December 16, 2021, Investigator Hector met with licensees, requested additional information and issued a 10-Day Complaint Notification. The investigation continued consisting of, confidential interviews and contacts with, five former residents, five staff members, Facility Administrator, Facility Director, and other associated parties. The investigation further included review of related client and staff files, facility file history, facility records, and review of related Los Angeles Police (LAPD) report and LAPD associated records. On October 28, 2020, LAPD responded to Adolescent Growth, Inc. concerning an alleged sexual assault between Y1 and Youth #2 (Y2) reportedly occurring on October 27, 2020, for which Y2 was subsequently arrested. Records reviewed found that the facility failed to report the incident occurring between Y1 and Y2 to CCL and further failed to report the incident concerning Y2’s related arrest. The investigation revealed a pattern of inappropriate behavior of youths in the facility occurring prior to the incident on October 27, 2020, yet measures were not taken to stop that behavior. Information obtained revealed staff failed to conduct room checks every 15 minutes in the evening and staff was usually working solely in the evenings. Staff on duty during the incident involving Y1 and Y2, had reported needing more support, including more staff and/or training resources, in order to effectively perform their job duties. Request for more help during the night shifts was not supported as Administration did not provide staff’s request. A review of records found multiple incidents including, but not limited to, youth’s absence without permission occurring in October 2020, in which local law enforcement was called and responded to the facility, that were never reported to Community Care Licensing. Statements obtained indicate incidents were submitted to facility administration; however, Investigator’s request for these incident reports were not produced. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

Based on information from record review and confidential interviews, the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. The Department has determined substantiated findings for neglect/lack of supervision contributing to inappropriate sexual activity between Y2 and Y1; Failure to Report incidents and failure to allow CCL staff entrance into the facility during initial complaint notification. The above-mentioned concerns pose an immediate and potential health, safety and personal rights risk of harm to youth placed in care. The following citations are issued in accordance with California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5; 84065.2 Personnel Duties; 80061 Reporting Requirements and 80044 Inspection Authority. [See page LIC9099-D for cited deficiencies]. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were discussed. A copy of this report, Confidential Names List and appeal rights were provided to Facility Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On October 11, 2022 at 11:00, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin met with licensees to issue investigative findings concerning the above-mentioned allegations. On December 8, 2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging neglect/lack of supervision as Youth #1 (Y1) was reportedly sexually assaulted by another youth resident while in care (see LIC811, dated October 11, 2022). The allegation was investigated by Licensing Special Investigator Edward Hector of CCL Investigations Bureau. On December 14, 2021, Investigator Hector attempted to conduct an unannounced visit at the facility (Adolescent Growth, Inc.) to initiate the investigation into reported claims; however, after Investigator Hector arrived at the facility, identified himself with a State business card, an official State badge and photo identification positively confirming Investigator’s employment with the State of California, Investigator Hector was refused access into the facility by facility staff member and further denied entry by facility supervisor to no avail. When Investigator Hector asked the facility supervisor for their name, they replied that their name was “Program Manager” and refused to further identify themselves. (Continued on page 9099-C)

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personnel Duties - Child care staff shall perform the following duties in part: Supervision, protection and care of children individually and in groups at all times. This requirement was not met as evidence by: Confidential statements and record review revealed on 10/27/2020, licensee failed to properly supervise youths in care resulting in an inappropriate sexual encounter between Youth #1 and Youth #2 thus pose an immediate health, safety and personal rights risk of harm to youth placed in care.

Inspection Authority of the Licensing Agency- The licensing agency shall have the inspection authority specified in Health and Safety Code Sections 1526.5, 1533, 1534, 1538, and 1538.7. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: On 12/14/2021, Investigator Edward Hector was rudely denied entry into facility (Adolescent Growth, Inc.) by facility staffs despite positively identifying himself as an authorized State Employee, thus posing immediate health, safety and personal rights risk of harm to youth placed in care.

Reporting Requirements-Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in part, Any unusual incident...a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours. This requirement was not met as evidence by: Confidential statements and record review revealed licensee failed to report unusual incident occurring on 10/27/2020, involving youth’s (Y1 and Y2) reported inappropriate sexual encounter, while in care.

Reporting Requirements-The licensee shall submit reports to the Department, using form LIC 624-LE or a report containing all the information required in LIC 624-LE, regarding any incident that involves law enforcement contact with a child residing in the facility. This requirement was not met as evidence by: Record review revealed licensee failed to report law enforcement contact concerning the arrest of Y2 occurring 10/28/2020. Information also revealed licensee did not report youths unauthorized absences from facility on at least two additional occasions in October 2020, thus posing potential health, safety and personal rights risk of harm to youth in care.

investigation_findings: 13On November 9, 2022, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) C. White conducted an unannounced visit to the facility for the purpose of delivering findings on the above allegations. LPA met with Facility Manager, April Barnes and discussed the complaint findings. During the course of this investigation LPA conducted confidential interviews and reviewed records. Staff denied speaking inappropriately towards minors. Staff stated they would never provoke minors to act inappropriately towards each other. Staff stated retalition against minors is not allowed. Staff stated minors are not denied the use of restrooms. Staff denied failing to provide client records to authorized representatives. Client interviewed stated staff would get upset when clients would speak up for each other. Client interview did not reveal that staff provoked inappropriate behaviors between minors nor prevented minors from using the restroom. The information obtained did not produce corroborating evidence to support the allegations. Thus, the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated, meaning although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. No deficiencies cited. Exit interview completed and a copy of this report was left with facility staff.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward visited the facility and met with the primary therapist in response to an Incident Report dated 07/03/23. The report indicated that C1 attempted suicide on 06/30/23. The facility response was to discharge the client because she attempted suicide. However the facility plan of operation indicates that the facility's program is designed to treat clients who attempt suicide. Therefore the discharge of C1 was in violation of Adolescent Growth, Inc's plan of operation and thus a violation of Title 22. The facility was cited under Section 80022(k) of Title 22

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Plan of Operation The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so. The facility failed to meet this requirement by discharging a client in response to the client's suicide attempt eventhough the plan of operation says that the program is designed to treat such cases. This presents a potential health or safety hazard to clients in care.

narrative: On November 16, 2023 Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward and Licensing Program Manager Lakescia Smith arrived at the facility to conduct the annual required evaluation. The following was observed: This is is a two-story home with 3 bedrooms, 1 full bathrooms and 3 half bathrooms, staffing offices, a therapy room, living room, dining room, kitchen, classroom, laundry area, conference room, a nursing office, and a backyard. The census today is 2. The facility only accepts private placements clients. There is one non-operable fireplace. There are no security bars on windows. There are working smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors in the home. LPA observed that the smoke detector in bedroom #2 had hanging wires and no battery, However, there were working smoke detectors in the hallways between the bedrooms. Two out of three fire extinguishers were fully charged. There is a first aid kit that is missing a first aid manual LPA observed uncovered trash cans in the bathrooms. All knives and medications were safely stored. Refrigerator and kitchen stove were in working condition. The supply of non-perishable foods does not meet Title 22 requirements, All bedrooms have two beds in good condition with the required linens and the required drawer and closet space. LPA observed torn window and door screens in all three bedrooms. Hot water temperature in client bathroom was tested at 135 degrees which is outside the safe temperature range See LIC 809-D for deficiencies. Exit interview completed

An inconclusive finding means that although an allegation my be true or valid, there inadequate information to find conclusively that it did happen

On October 14, 2020 at 3:20 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kim Robinson conducted a case management tele-inspection with the group home (GH) administrator, Evonnda Hull, in order to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP) regarding the child care worker #1 (S1). See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated October 14, 2020. On April 24, 2020, the Department concluded a complaint investigation on S1 under this GH. The complaint alleged that C1 was involved in sexual acts with S1. S1 acknowledged performing lewd and lascivious sexual acts with two clients #1 (C1) and client #2 (C2), on two separate incidents, inside and outside the GH. The allegations were substantiated and the GH was cited for 84072(d)(10) Personal Rights. S1 willfully, on separate incidents, participated in multiple lewd acts with minors, by use of S1's employment with the GH. C1 and C2 sustained physical abuse as a result of the sexual encounters with S1. Based on the analysis of the interviews, the Department has determined that an enhanced civil penalty is warranted for the physical abuse. The penal code section 288a(b)(1) and 288a(b)(2) defines sexual conduct with a minor as physical abuse. This section describes a number of more or less direct and (always) willful acts that constitute sexual assault. Pursuant to the Enhanced Civil Penalty law, Health and Safety (H&S) code section 1548 (f)(1)(c), the Department will be issuing an immediate civil penalty of $2500.00. An exit interview was completed and appeal rights discussed. Due to the COVID 19 guidance, an electronic copy of this report, the Confidential Names List, Appeal Rights and a Civil Penalty Assessment - Serious Bodily Injury/Physical Abuse (Form 421-D) were sent to the administrator for review and signature. The signed copy will be retained in the facility file.

Witnesses expressed they chose not to engage in the physical activities offered as the activities were not interesting. Confidential witness confirmed they are allowed family visitation and confirmed they are allowed to refuse the visits or phone calls. All staff reported, C1 was encouraged to engage in physical activities. Staff reported C1 received mental health services, and the County visitation plan was followed. CSW’s expressed concern that the facility was not providing the clients with enough opportunities during COVID 19. LPA reviewed C1’s needs and service plan dated 11/2/2020. The needs and service plan indicated C1 was receiving specialty mental health services and was encouraged to engage in physical activity. C1’s needs and service plan did not indicate any restrictions to the visitation plan. On November 13, 2020, the Department received a second allegation. The allegation alleged that on November 8, 2020 and on at least four other unknown dates, C1 was on the roof of the facility. Confidential witnesses confirmed C1 was on the roof of the facility. Other confidential witnesses denied C1 or other clients were on the roof of the facility. All staff members denied C1 was on the roof of the facility during their shift. Staff members reported they “heard about” C1 being on the roof however, all staff denied observing the C1 on the roof. Administrator confirmed that information was received alleging C1 was on the roof of the facility. Administrator stated she contacted the facility manager after the information was received and the staff indicated that C1 was in C1’s bedroom and had not been on the roof. CSW’s did not report concerns regarding the supervision provided by the staff members. C1’s needs and service plan indicated C1 had the ability to follow rules and had not had any major behavioral issues since C1’s arrival. On November 13, 2020, the Department received a third allegation alleging that C1 was not being provided with meals in accordance with the American Diabetes Association. Confidential witnesses confirmed C1 was provided with sugar free products and was provided the same meals as the other clients. Confidential witnesses reported the facility was not providing meals which met the requirements of a diabetic diet. Staff reported that C1 was provided with a variety of sugar free and whole wheat products during meal and snack times. Staff reported, C1’s diabetic needs were being met. CSW’s did not report concerns with the food provided in the home. LPA reviewed C1’s medical records, which indicated, C1 was on a regular diet with “carb counting”. On November 23, 2020 at 12:18pm LPA observed the food at the facility. LPA observed, sugar free wafers, sugar free oatmeal cookies, sugar free Jell-O/gelatin, unsweetened apple sauce, sugar free cake mix, Diet Coke Zero, gram crackers, Werther Original sugar free candies, and canned vegetables. The refrigerator had sandwich meat, cheese, fresh vegetables, and fresh fruit. Report continued on page three

Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that staff not meeting clients (C1) needs, staff fails to provide adequate supervision to clients (C1) in care, and client (C1) not being provided appropriate dietary meals may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to Program Director Amy Osborn. A copy of the signed report will be placed in the facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On February 19, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kendal Zirbes met with Facility Manager Liz Burner via FaceTime to deliver the investigative finding for the above stated allegations. Furthermore, LPA completed a review of the facility records, and conducted a facility tele-inspection on November 23, 2020 at 12:13pm. On November 13, 2020, the Department received an allegation that on an unknown date, the staff were not meeting C1’s needs. According to the information received, C1 was not receiving mental health service, and was not engaging in cardio activity three times a week as required by the American Diabetes Association. Furthermore, the Department received information that C1 was not allowed family visitation. Confidential witnesses confirmed mental health services were received at the facility. Confidential witnesses further reported that they refused to receive the mental health services that were offered. Confidential witnesses expressed the staff encouraged cardio activity and offered activities such as taking a walk or playing basketball. Report continued on page two

narrative:
On March 2, 2021 at 2:11pm, an unannounced virtual Post-Licensing Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Kendal Zirbes and Linda Haynes. A virtual inspection was conducted as a result of the Covid-19 related restrictions. During the inspection, LPA's met with Program Director Amy Osborn via FaceTime. LPA's and Program Director inspected the facility inside and out. The facility was licensed as a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) on October 2, 2020. The facility is a one-story house with three bedrooms, three bathrooms, a game room, staff office, kitchen, dining area, and living room. This location also houses the facilities Children's Residential Intensive Services (CHRIS) program. The CHRIS program has a separate entrance from the facility. The office space for the CHRIS program consists of a reception area, one office space and a storage room. The facility currently has Mental Health Certification through San Bernardino County. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/video games/books/board games were observed for youth’s recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order. The facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. The facility had all required documents posted throughout the facility. Medications are locked and centrally stored in a locked filing cabinet within the locked staff office. Six individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water was measured by Precious Spence, Facility Manager. At the time of this inspection the hot water temperature was 105. The facility has a fully equipped first aid kit and first aid manual. The facility does not have cameras. At the time of this inspection, there were no bodies of water on the facility ground. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility and smoking is prohibited. The facility vehicle was observed to be in safe operating condition and the registration was up to date Youth files are maintained in a locked filing cabinet within the staff office. Personnel Files are retained at the corporate office located at 17198 Yuma St. Suite B, Victorville CA 92395. Report continued on page two

Staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection and they were in accordance with the regulations. Youth and Personal files will be reviewed on a future date at the at corporate office. An exit interview was conducted with Program Director Amy Osborn. A copy of this report was emailed to the facility.

On March 5, 2021 at 12:20pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kendal Zirbes met with Administrator Evonnda Hull at the Alpha Connection Corporate office located in Victorville CA. The purpose of the inspection was to complete the continuation inspection for the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Post licensing inspection that was initiated on March 2, 2021. A sample of six personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Five of the six files that were reviewed were for employees who converted from group home personnel to STRTP personnel. LPA observed the converted staff members were not trained according to the STRTP training requirements. Technical Assistance Advisory Note (TA) will be issued. LPA reviewed six client files. LPA observed all six Needs and Service Plans did not contain information regarding the clients ability to manage his/her own money. In addition, LPA observed the Admission agreements were not updated to reflect a STRTP placement. Technical Assistance Advisory Notes (TA) will be issued. LPA requested the recent board meeting be provided to CCL by March 8, 2021 at 11:00am, A copy of this report and the advisory notices were provided to Administrator Evonnda Hull.

On March 8, 2021 at 2:13pm, an unannounced Case Management tele-inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kendal Zirbes. A virtual inspection was conducted as a result of the Covid-19 related restrictions. During the inspection, LPA met with Amy Osborn, Program Director. On March 5, 2021, LPA reviewed the facilities personnel files. During the evaluation, LPA reviewed staff 1 (S1) Criminal Record Statement and Out of State Disclosure (LIC 508) dated December 8, 2020. On the LIC 508, S1 indicated S1 had lived in a state other than California in the last five years. On March 8, 2021, LPA discussed the LIC 508 with Program Director Amy Osborn. Program Director indicated the facility had not submitted the required forms (LIC 508OOS and LIC 198B) to the Caregiver Background Check Bureau (CBCB) as required. Therefore, a check of the child abuse/neglect registry was not initiated for the other state S1 had lived in. A Technical Violation Advisory Note (TA) will be issued. Furthermore, the facility manger was advised that S1 may not be present in the facility until S1 obtains an out of state child abuse and neglect clearance. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Program Director Amy Osborn. A signed copy of the report will be placed in the facility file.

Confidential interviews confirmed an altercation did occur in the facility and the whereabouts of staff during the altercation was unknown. Record review revealed a second video was observed by SI and noted an additional altercation between C3 and C4 occurred on the basketball court at the facility where again no staff supervision was observed. Confidential interviews confirmed the second altercation occurred and the whereabouts of staff during the altercation was unknown. Based on confidential interviews and observation of video footage the allegation lack of supervision resulting in minors (C1, C2, and C3) getting into an altercation with another minor in the home is substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations regulation 80078(a) Responsibility for providing care and supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client’s needs. An Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP) determination is pending. If an ECP is assessed a Community Care Licensing (CCL) representative will return to the facility to deliver the penalty assessment. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to Alpha Connection – Anoka Ranch, Administrator Evonnda Hull.
investigation_findings: 13On July 29, 2021 at 11:20am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, met with Alpha Connection – Anoka Ranch, Administrator Evonnda Hull to deliver the findings for the above stated allegation. The investigation was conducted Community Care Licensing (CCL) Investigation Branch Special Investigator (SI) Marlon Williams and LPA Kendal Zirbes. The investigation included interviews with Program Director (PDir), Administrator (ADM), County Social Worker (CSW), three of six residents (Child #1 [C1], Child #2 [C2], Child #3 [C3]), two staff members (Staff #1 [S1], Staff #2 [S2]). In addition, county records and facility records were reviewed. On March 5, 2021, CCL received an allegation alleging lack of supervision resulting in minors (C1, C2, and C3) getting into an altercation with another minor in the home. Specifically, it was reported a video sent by an anonymous party showed five minors stomping on the head of another minor. Record review of SI’s observation of the video noted an altercation did occur in the facility and no staff members were observed. CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Responsibility for providing care and supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client’s needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and observation of video footage at least two altercations involving residents of the facility occurred at which time staff whereabouts was unknown which posed an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to children in care.

narrative:
On September 9, 2021, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Christina Barnes, and Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jose Gonzalez and Jazmond Harris arrived at Alpha Connection-Anoka Ranch Short Term Residential Therapeutic Residential Program (STRTP). LPM and LPA's, were met and granted access by and Facility Manager Tyler Frankland. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. At 9:04 AM, Program Director Amy Osborn and Administrator Evonnda Hull, led the physical inspection of the facility with LPM Barnes and LPA’s Gonzalez and Harris. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility’s, activity center, gaming room, kitchen area, refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, client bedrooms, bathroom/showers. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Sports equipment/toys/books/games/computers were observed for children’s recreation time. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee does not maintain an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and the menus were not posted. All other required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored inside staff's office. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client’s bathrooms was measured to be between 102 and 120 degrees. Per the Administrator, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. The facility has a dining area, kitchen area, living room, open common area/formal living room, a clinician's office for therapeutic services, an entertainment room, and a room where the washer and dryer are located. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. ******CONTINUED on 809 C*****

Chemicals and/or poisons, sharp objects/knives are locked in a file cabinet in the staff office. First Aid Kits are stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office. LPM and LPA's reviewed the facility's disaster and mass casualty plan. The facility currently has two children sharing each bedroom. The facility must ensure that each client is aware of the bedroom sharing policy and document the advisement in the clients’ files. Based on record review, the facility did not provide the bedroom sharing document to clients which poses a personal rights risk. The facility will be cited. The facility is also required to ensure medications are not transferred between containers. LPM and LPA’s observed medication in cups on the desk in the staff office. This is a violation of licensing standards, which will also be cited. The facility is required to provide the clients access to food. LPM and LPA's observed their requirements for food were not available for the six clients in care. The facility did not have monthly restraint log for review. LPA advised Administrator that a monthly log regarding manual restraints is required. LPA requests that Administrator provides LPA Gonzalez with the document by the requested date. LPA also informed Administrator that all staff members needs to complete the required 40 hour training as noted in ILS standards by October 2021. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 9099-D, LIC 9102, and appeal rights were provided to Administrator.
