Licensing Program Analyst, Margaret Lentner conducted a case management inspection on November 9, 2021, at 10:05am, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. 3 out of 11 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files as identified on the LIC 811 confidential names dated 11/9/2021, were reviewed. 3 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 5 youth were interviewed. The Plan of Operation including policies and procedure were reviewed. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Evonnda Hull, Administrator.

On November18, 2021 at 1:30pm an Informal Office Conference was held with the Alpha Connection Youth and Family Services Inc. (ACYFS) Corporation via Microsoft Teams. The following people were in attendance: Regional Manager (RM) LaCresha Cook, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Christina Barnes, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jose Gonzalez, Law Enforcement Contact Review Unit, (LPM) Angela King, (LPA) Margaret Lentner, Department of Health Care Services (DHCS) David Gutierrez, Alexandria Andrews, San Bernardino Behavioral Health Representatives Melissa Graham, San Bernardino Behavioral Health, Diane Wolkenhauer, System of Care (SOC) Stacie Kinney, Dianna Wagner, , San Bernardino County Children and Family Services Amy Guisa, Heather Copeland and Griselda Marron, Rose Collins, and Michele Meza. ACYFS Administrative staff, Barron Wilson, Amy Osborn, Evonnda Hull, Dr. Maurizio Assandri, Board Member, Mary Jane Jones, This conference was held to discuss the following concerns: Lack of oversight by Management and lack of supervision: Drug paraphrenia was found in client’s room. Clients are being bullied and assaulted by other clients and staff are not aware of it. An increase of rounds in the facility need to be conducted by executive management to ensure that the staff are following the program statement and supervising the clients to ensure safety of the clients in care. The need for Administrative staff and facility staff to use trauma informed therapeutic approach in encouraging clients to attend school. ****CONTINUED on 809 C****

Clinicians to coach the facility staff in trauma informed care approach in working with the clients. Clinicians to inform the clients of trauma informed care approach. A specific trauma informed care approach plan in addressing the bullying of clients occurring at the facility. Staff to be trained in trauma informed care approach focus in reviewing the client’s needs and services plan. Staff to be trained in trauma informed care approach focus of the interventions described in the client’s needs and services plan. Staff to be trained on the secondary trauma informed care approach resources for direct care staff and how it is being documented and updated in the client’s needs and services plans. Core Services - Lack of Trauma Informed Milieu: Activities need to be provided for clients which include trauma informed therapeutic approach. An activity log needs to be sent to Community Care Licensing (CCL) with the activities that were provided for the last 90 days. A description of how trauma informed activities are provided to the clients and a list of trauma informed activities for the rest of the year shall be provided to CCL. Continues Quality Improvement (CQI): Review bi-annually or as needed to identify specific problems that need to be addressed for compliance. How are facility incident reports being reviewed by facility management? How are Needs and Service plans being reviewed by facility management? Staffing according to client need, not client ratios: Administrative staff to assess daily need of additional staff outside of required ratios to ensure safety of clients and staff. Emergency Intervention Plan: Staff to be trained on the secondary trauma informed care approach resources for direct care staff and how it is being documented and updated in the client’s needs and services plans. *******CONTINUED on 809C********

Lack of information/or incomplete Special Incident Reports/Law Enforcement: Reports are not being submitted to required agencies, not including interventions that are being conducted, shadowing, de-escalation techniques being used. Staff to be trained on descriptive incident report writing. Additional items discussed included: Clarification of specialty mental health services. How are medication services provided for the clients? Psychiatrist services are provided for the client’s thorough community resources. Needs to be more trauma informed, de-escalation and behavioral interventions. System of Care explained Harm Reduction process and accessible services were discussed. Regional Manager L. Cook provided the Licensee with Harm Reduction contact information kelley.hartman@dss.ca.gov The Technical Support Program (TSP) was recommended to the licensee and accepted. A TSP referral will be submitted by LPM Barnes. It was recommended that the licensee assign additional support staff for Program Director, Amy Osborn to assist with her duties, as she also is the Administrator of one of the STRTPs. Licensee, Barron Wilson, agreed to complete the recommendations in order to bring the facility into compliance by December 9, 2021. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report was emailed to Barron Wilson. A copy of the signed report will be placed in the facility file.

On November 16, 2021 at 6:50pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, met with Alpha Connection – Anoka Ranch, Administrator Evonnda Hull to deliver a case management deficiencies report. According to information obtained by Community Care Licensing (CCL) the facility submitted a Serious Incident Report (SIR) to CCL regarding an incident occurring at the facility on June 13, 2021. CCL has received information the SIR submitted does not accurately reflect the incident. The SIR notes C1 was escalated with both S1 and Staff #3 (S3). Confidential interviews reported this SIR was not accurate as Child #1 (C1) became escalated only with Staff #1 (S1) while inside the facility and then followed S1 outside to the dumpster. The report noted S3, S2, and S1 counseled C1, however confidential interviews confirmed S2 and S3 were attempting to de-escalte C1 but S1 was yelling and arguing back with C1 which continued to escalate C1. The report also notes that S3 was acting as lead during the restraint. Confidential interviews noted that in S3’s attempts to de-escalte C1, C1 was informed if C1 did not de-escalte a restraint would be needed however this was done as part of the de-escalation process not as S3 taking lead on a possible imminent restraint. The SIR notes that due to C1’s continued assault on staff, S3 and S1 placed C1 in an authorized ProAct laying down restraint. Confidential interviews reported this did not accurately reflect the situation. Confidential interviews reported as S2 and S3 were attempting to de-escalate C1, S1 came from the back/side knocking C1 and S2 to the ground, at which time S1 jumped on top of C1. Confidential interviews reported that once S1 was on top of C1 with his torso on C1’s back S3 provided assistance by holding C1’s legs to assist S1. Confidential interview reported S1 did not communicate that he was taking C1 to the ground and the way in which S1 took C1 to the ground are not are not consistent with how an approved Pro-Act restraint is initiated. The report notes that S4 was monitoring C1’s breathing during the restraint. Confidential interviews reported that S4 was in the area and witnessed the incident, however, was not providing any assistance. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

The SIR submitted to CCL notes that an approved Pro-Act restraint was used on C1. However, record review could not provide current Pro-Act training for S1. S1 initiating and/or participating in any restraint while S1’s Pro-Act training is not up-to-date is a violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87095.65(e). Also noted on the SIR was prior to the incident between C1 and S1, C1 had injured C1’s hand by punching a metal door, to which S2 was going to take C1 to the hospital to be evaluated. S1’s approach to handling the situation coming from behind/side of C1 knocking C1 to the ground is a violation of ILS 87095.00(c)(5). Additionally, Program Director (PDir) who reviewed the SIR and submitted it to CCL along with Pro-Act training certifications failed to notice the date of S1’s Pro-Act training. This failure to notice S1’s Pro-Act training had not been maintained resulted in the facility being in violation of ILS 87095.65(f), as a corrective action plan was not initiated. Confidential interviews and photographs obtained noted the way in which C1 was knocked to the ground by S1 caused C1 to sustain a bloody nose, scratches to the arms, and a busted lip. These injuries were not noted on the SIR submitted to CCL as required by Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87061(j)(6)(E). The SIR provided past types of behavior issues C1 had since arriving at the facility, however the history provided does not include all of the required information that is to be reported to CCL, including dates of previous incidents. This is a violation of ILS 87061(j)(3)(B)(1). Also noted missing from the SIR was information regarding actions taken by facility personnel in response to previous incidents as required by ILS 87061(j)(3)(B)(3). The facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87095.65(e). EMERGENCY INTERVENTION STAFF TRAINING (e) Staff must receive on-going training to maintain certification. The facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87095.00(c)(5). GENERAL PROVISIONS: (c)Short-term residential therapeutic program staff may be justified in using ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

restraints as an emergency intervention if all of the following conditions are met: (5) The child receiving the restraint has no known medical or physical condition due to which there is reason to believe that the use of restraint would endanger the child’s health and safety or exacerbate the medical condition; The facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87095.65(f) EMERGENCY INTERVENTION STAFF TRAINING (f) When an inappropriate manual restraint technique is used during an emergency intervention, the licensee must develop a corrective action plan, and as part of the plan may require staff to repeat the appropriate emergency intervention training. The facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87061(j)(6)(E). REPORTING REQUIREMENTS: Incident Reports (6) Incident Reports documenting the use of manual restraints must include the following: (E) Description of any injuries sustained by the child or facility personnel. What type of medical treatment was sought and where was child taken. Provide an explanation if medical treatment was not sought for injuries. The facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87061(j)(3)(B)(1) REPORTING REQUIREMENTS (j) Incident Reports must include the following: (3) Analysis of the incident: (B) Description of other previous incidents. (1) Dates of previous incidents. The facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87061(j)(3)(B)(3). REPORTING REQUIREMENTS: (j) Incident Reports must include the following: (3) Analysis of the incident: (B) Description of other previous incidents. (3) Action taken by facility personnel in response to previous incidents. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to Alpha Connection – Anoka Ranch, Administrator Evonnda Hull.

narrative: On November 17, 2021 at 11:45 AM, Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Kim Robinson met with the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Program Director, Amy Osborn, to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP). On July 29, 2021, the Department concluded a complaint investigation alleging that Child Care Staff neglected to provide care and supervision to minors, resulting with a twelve-year-old child #1 (C1) sustaining serious physical abuse. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated November 17, 2021). The allegations were substantiated and the STRTP was cited under the Title 22 Regulations, Section 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The investigative evidence gathered shows multiple clients engaging in physical altercations, both inside and outside the STRTP, without staff making any attempts to intervene and meet the needs of the children in care. Based on the analysis of the interviews and video footage, the Department has determined that an enhanced civil penalty is warranted for STRTP staff neglecting to provide the care and supervision for children in care as required in the General Licensing Requirements. Section 11165.2 of the Penal Code defines severe neglect as negligent treatment or maltreatment of a child when a person responsible for the child’s welfare permits any child to suffer unjustifiable physical pain. This section describes a number of more or less direct and (always) willful acts that constitute physical abuse. Pursuant to the Enhanced Civil Penalty law, Health and Safety (H&S) code section 1548 (f)(1)(A), the Department will be issuing an immediate civil penalty of $2,500.00. An exit interview was completed, and appeal rights discussed. A copy of this report, the Confidential Names List, Appeal Rights, and a Civil Penalty Assessment - Serious Bodily Injury/Physical Abuse (Form 421-D) were provided to the program director.

and a busted lip. Record review revealed on June 13, 2021 C1 became escalated and aggressive towards S1, alleging S1 had called C1 an idiot. Confidential interviews reported instead of S1 deescalating C1, S1 was arguing with C1, which escalated the situation. Confidential interviews reported Staff #2 (S2) and Staff #3 (S3) were attempting to de-escalate both C1 and S1, as S1 and C1 continued to argue. Confidential interviews reported during the entire time S2 was attempting to de-escalate the situation, S1’s actions of arguing and pushing C1 away in an aggressive manner, continued to escalate the situation resulting in S1 coming from the side/behind of C1, and knocking C1 to the ground. S1’s action of knocking C1 to the ground caused C1’s face and stomach to land on the gravel driveway where the incident occurred. Additionally, the manner in which S1 took C1 to the ground resulted in S2 to also falling to the ground as S2’s arm was trapped between S1 and C1. Confidential interviews reported once C1 was on the ground S1 then jumped on top of C1’s back landing with S1’s torso on top of C1 and began banging C1’s head on the rocks/gravel beneath him. Confidential interviews reported after the incident S1 contacted Program Director (PDir) informing PDir that S1 “took C1 down.” Confidential interviews and photographs revealed as a result of this incident and the manner in which S1 “took C1 down,” C1 sustained injuries to C1’s nose, arms, and lip. Based on record review and confidential interviews the allegation staff member (Staff #1 [S1]) physically assaulted resident (Child #1 [C1]) is substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard Personal Rights 87072(d) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9 as applicable. In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights. An Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP) determination is pending. If an ECP is assessed a Community Care Licensing (CCL) representative will return to the facility to deliver the penalty assessment. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to Alpha Connection – Anoka Ranch, Administrator Evonnda Hull.
investigation_findings: 13On November 16, 2021 at 6:09pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, met with Apha Connection – Anoka Ranch, Administrator Evonnda Hull to deliver the findings for the above stated allegation. The investigation was conducted Community Care Licensing (CCL) Investigation Branch Special Investigator (SI) Marlon William. The investigation included interviews with Program Director (PDir), Administrator (ADM), County Social Worker (CSW), two of six residents (Child #1 [C1] and Child #2 [C2]), four staff members (Staff #1 [S1], Staff #2 [S2], Staff #3 [S3], and Staff #4 [S4]) and San Diego County Social Worker from the Open Case Investigations Unit (OHI). In addition, county records, medical records and facility records were reviewed. On June 30, 2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation alleging staff member (Staff #1 [S1]) physically assaulted resident (Child #1 [C1]). Specifically, it was reported S1 and C1 got into an argument resulting in S1 jumping on top of C1 causing C1 to sustain a bloody nose, scratches to C1’s arms, ***CONTINUED ON PAGE 2***

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personal Rights. The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9 as applicable. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews the facility did not ensure C1 was accorded personal rights when S1 assaulted C1 by knocking C1 to the ground and banging C1’s head into the gravel/rocks, causing C1 to sustain a bloody nose, scratches to the arms, and a busted lip which posed an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to children in care.

narrative: On November 30, 2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jose Gonzalez met with Administrator (AD), Evonnda Hull. The purpose of this case management is to issue a citation from a previous LPA visit. On November 22, 2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jose Gonzalez arrived at Alpha Anoka STRTP home to initiate a compliant investigation and met with Facility Manager (FM), Tyler Frankland. LPA conducted a safety inspection of the facility and observed that there was only one staff supervising five clients. FM informed LPA that additional staff had left the facility with one client and was returning shortly. LPA informed FM that he was out of ratio and needed to contact cooperate for additional staff. LPA observed that facility staff had returned 35 minutes later with the client. The STRTP facility is being cited for not meeting the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Version 4 87065.5 (a)(1) Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios. This requirement was not met as evidence by: Based on LPA’s observations, the facility did not ensure the staff to child ratio of one staff for every three children was met, on 11/22/2021, there was one staff to five children. This poses an immediate Health, Safety and Personal Rights risk to the children in care. An exit interview was conducted where the citation and plan of corrections was discussed with Administrator (AD), Evonnda Hull. A copy of this report, appeal rights were provided to Evonnda Hull.

Confidential witnesses denied the allegations. Additional confidential witness statements indicate that C1 was possibly injured during a physical altercation between C1 and C4. Confidential witness statements also revealed that C1 and C2 were involved in a physical altercation because C1 had destroyed C2’s personal TV. Additional confidential witness statements indicate that C1 was the aggressor towards the other clients at the facility. Confidential witness statements revealed that C1 was bulling the other clients at the facility. Additional confidential witness statements indicate that no clients were making sexual advances towards C1 and that the clients are all teenagers and they make inappropriate comments. Confidential witness statements revealed that C1’s cell phone was destroyed by C2 because C1 had destroyed C2’s personal TV and the house TV. Additional confidential witness statements indicate that C1 did sustain injuries while at the STRTP home. Confidential witness statements revealed that C1 was being physically abused by the clients at the home. Additional confidential witness statements indicate that C4 was making sexual advances towards C1. Confidential witness statements revealed that C1’s cell phone was destroyed by C2 and that the other clients had destroyed C1’s personal property. FM stated that C1 had destroyed C2’s TV and the facility living room TV. FM also stated that he attempted to deescalate C1 prior to C1 destroying C2’s and the house TV’s. FM stated that C1 and C2 were involved in a physical altercation (wrestling) and that FM had intervened and separated C1 and C2. FM stated that he had observed redness around C1 and C2’s neck and arms. FM states that the clients jokingly make inappropriate sexual comments to one another and that the comments are not made in a serious manner in making sexual advances. FM stated that he verbally redirects the clients to stop making inappropriate comments. AD stated that C1 was not being physically abused by the clients and that it was C1 bullying and intimidating the other clients at the home. AD stated that the clients did not make sexual advances towards C1. CSW states that it was C1 bullying the other clients CSW went on to add that C1 was also destroying the facility property. CSW was unaware of the client’s making sexual advances towards C1, and that the clients were destroying C1’s property. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that alleged client #1 (C1) sustained injuries while in care, C1 is being physically abused by other clients in the home, clients are making sexual advances towards C1, and that the clients are destroying C1’s property., may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Facility Manager (FM), Tyler Frankland.
investigation_findings: 13On December 17, 2021 at 8:57AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jose Gonzalez met with Alpha Connection Anoka Ranch Facility Manager (FM), Tyler Frankland, to deliver the findings for the above stated allegations. LPA conducted a safety inspection at the facility at 9:57am on August 13, 2021 and no safety hazards were observed. LPA also reviewed seven of seven client’s records. During the investigation, interviews were conducted with four of the seven clients, Facility Manager (FM), Facility Administrator (A), and County Social Worker (CSW). An interview with client’s #3, #4, and #5 (C3, C4, C5) was attempted but the clients refused to be interviewed. The Department received a complaint on August 10, 2021, that alleged client #1 (C1) sustained injuries while in care, C1 is being physically abused by other clients in the home, clients are making sexual advances towards C1, and that the clients are destroying C1’s property. *****CONTINUED on 9099C*****

narrative: Confidential witness statements also revealed that the clients have the option to turn in their money to be secured in a lock box inside of a locked file cabinet located in the staff office. Confidential witness statements indicate that no money was found in C1’s bedroom and that C1 never turned in C1’s money for safeguarding. Additionally, witness statements indicate that the facility administrative staff does not condone such behavior and that the administrative staff did not pay C1 to physically assault other clients in care. Witness statements also revealed that it was not observed that staff paid C1 to assault the other clients. Witness statements indicate that the facility staff do supervise the clients throughout the milieu and that the facility monitors the client’s interactions. Additional confidential witness statements indicate that the facility staff had removed C1’s money from a black lock box located in C1’s bedroom. Witness statements also revealed that C1 was paid by facility administrative staff to assault other minors in care. Additionally, witness statements indicate that the facility administrative staff would pay C1 $200.00 a week to assault the other clients that were not following the STRTP house rules. Witnesses further stated, that the facility staff did not supervise the clients and that the facility staff were not monitoring the client’s interactions. Confidential witness statements also revealed that the facility administrative staff condone such behavior. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that alleged the facility staff did not safeguard client #1 (C1) money, facility staff paid C1 to physically assault other clients in care, and that the facility did not supervise clients, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Facility Administrator (FA), Evonda Hull.

During the investigation, interviews were conducted with five of seven clients, as two clients refused to be interviewed, Executive Director (ED), Assistant Executive Director (AED), Staff #1 (S1) Staff #2 (S2), Staff #3 (S3), and County Social Worker (CSW). The Department received a complaint on July 7, 2021, that alleged the facility staff did not safeguard client #1 (C1) money, facility staff paid C1 to physically assault other clients in care, and that the facility did not supervise clients. narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jose Gonzalez, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Christina Barnes, and Facility Manager (FM) Tyler Frankland conducted a safety inspection. During the safety inspection with FM, LPA, and LPM observed a smoked cigarette butt by the back-door entrance in the bushes. The Deficiencies will be cited.

On April 12, 2022, at 1:00pm an Informal Office Conference was held with the Alpha Connection Youth and Family Services Inc. (ACYFS) Corporation via Microsoft Teams. The following people were in attendance: Community Care Licensing (CCL) Regional Manager (RM) LaCresha Cook, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Christina Barnes, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jose Gonzalez, Joon Choi, Law Enforcement Contact Review Unit, (LPM) Angela King, Department of Health Care Services (DHCS) David Gutierrez, San Bernardino Behavioral Health Representatives Melissa Graham and Diane Wolkenhauer, System of Care (SOC) Marjana Jackson, Social Services Practitioner (SSP) San Bernardino County Children Family Services (CFS) Deborah Baeza and Heather Martinell, Supervisor CFS San Bernardino County Hannah Gutierrez, San Bernardino County Consultant Jamie Richter, Case Management Supervisor at Far Northern Regional Center (FNRC) Katherine Bogue, FNRC Lisette Leyva, FNRC Service Coordinator Mary Cardin, Inland Regional Center Consumer Service Coordinator Sierra Meza, Alta Regional Center Service Coordinator Lindi Houser, California Alliance for Child and Family Services Ric Weisgal, Laveenya Young. ACYFS Administrative staff, Chief Executive Officer Barron Wilson, Program Director/ Facility Administrator Amy Osborn, Facility Administrator Evonnda Hull, Clinician Muarizo Assandri, Clinician, Mark Daniels, Clinician Herberth Valle, and Dan Thorne. The following information was discussed: · Administrative oversight · Trauma Informed Care, Services and Approach · Law enforcement service calls · Absence Without Leave (AWOLS) · Poor school attendance procedures · Ongoing client substance abuse (alcohol and drugs) *****CONTINUED on LIC 809 C*****

· Provision of varied, enrichment and individual activities · Staff Supervision · Shared room agreements · Supervision of clients · Administrative Rounds · Lack of detail in Special Incident Reports (SIRs), under-reporting (minimizing), and failure to report · Lack of reporting to CCL, authorized representatives, Inland Regional Services, and San Bernardino Behavioral Health contract consultant The meeting included a discussion regarding the above concerns. During the discussion RM Cook, LPM Gonzalez and LPM Barnes discussed CCL’s concerns regarding the above-mentioned issues and requested input from the various oversight agencies participating in the meeting discussion. The Department recommended the licensee take full advantage of the System of Care support service recommendations, Law Enforcement Contact Review Unit advice for submitting law enforcement incident reports, San Bernardino Behavioral Health contract consultants’ recommendations for the Head of Service to increase the amount of Specialty Mental Health services provided to clients and ensuring incident reports for presumptive transfers are sent to San Bernardino Behavioral Health, and Department of Health Care Services request to ensure that the facilities therapy sessions notes and policies include accurate documentation of all therapeutic services provided to clients. RM Cook emphasized the importance of following the actual policies and procedures written in the program statement, corrective action and facility oversight. The facility was given until 04/29/2022 to submit a plan of correction to Community Care Licensing for approval. The licensee agrees to the following: 1. The licensee will submit proof of daily administrative rounds completed by Administrator or administrative staff. Overnight rounds shall be included between the hours of 9pm and 6am to check on the well-being of clients and staff. The visits shall be at various hours, a minimum of 15 minutes, and shall be documented in the daily logbook and the administrative rounds sheet. The visiting Administrator or administrative staff and the facility staff member on shift shall sign the administrative rounds sheet, logbook, state the time and date of arrival, time and date of departure, and any unusual observations.****CONTINUED LIC809C****

2. The licensee will submit a plan on how incident reports are reviewed by administration, including the facility’s plan of action/correction and how the facility will ensure the appropriate agencies are receiving the incident reports. 3. Within 24 hours of an incident, Administrator will submit an incident report to placement agencies, authorized representatives, Inland Regional Services, and San Bernardino Behavioral Health contract consultant. This shall include SIRs with client-involved aggression/assaults, regardless of the location of the incident, when a client refuses to go to school, drug use, drug paraphernalia, and contraband found in placement. Provide full details describing the incident and the disposition including the facility’s plan of action/correction. 4. The licensee shall submit the activity calendar of 2022 of the enrichment planned activities from January through April 31, 2022. The calendar needs to be specific for the facility to include the dates, times, and location of each activity, the names of clients who participated in each activity, and to include the names of clients who did not participate and the reasons why. This will continue through December 2022. 5. The licensee will provide documentation of individualize enrichment activities for each client for the month and continue to submit this documentation through December 2022. 6. The licensee shall increase individual specialty mental health services as recommended by San Bernardino Behavioral Health consultant. 7. The licensee shall submit a plan on how bedroom sharing agreements are being assessed, reviewed and updated by the administration/ administrator. This plan will include, the facility’s plan of action/correction and how the facility will ensure the that clients are compatible. This form will be updated when a new client is placed into an existing client’s bedroom. 8. The licensee shall submit a plan to reduce AWOLs. 9. The licensee shall submit a plan to address smoking and drug use at the facility. LPA Jose Gonzalez reviewed and discussed the report with CEO, Barron Wilson. A copy of this report was emailed to Barron Wilson for signature. A copy of the signed report will be placed in the facility file.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Daniel Mena met with Facility Director, Tyler Frankland to discuss the investigative findings for the above stated allegation. Special Investigator, Brittany Hudec (SI) conducted an inspection to the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) on December 07, 2021. Special Investigator (SI), Brittany Hudec interviewed three staff (S1, S2, S3), six of six foster children (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5 & C6), two County Social Workers (CSW1, CSW), as well as reviewed police, client and facility records. Community Care Licensing received information on December 06, 2021 alleging that staff member # 1 (S1) gave Child # 1 (C1) marijuana in lieu of medication, as well as smoked marijuana with C1 while in care. Information obtained in confidential interviews did not corroborate the allegations with a preponderance of evidence. On July 28, 2022 at 2:00 PM, Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Kim Robinson met with the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) administrator, Evonnda Hull, to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP). On April 11, 2022, the Department concluded a complaint investigation with allegations of STRTP staff neglecting to provide care and supervision to minors, resulting with one minor sustaining serious bodily injury from the assault of another minor. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated July 28, 2022). The allegations were determined substantiated. The STRTP was cited for the violation of Personal Rights from the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Section 87072(c)(11). Based on the police report and the confidential interviews, the Department has determined that an enhanced civil penalty is warranted for STRTP staff neglecting to provide the care and supervision for children in care, resulting with serious bodily injuries. Penal Code Section 11165.2 defines severe neglect as negligent treatment or maltreatment of a child when a person responsible for the child’s welfare permits any child to suffer unjustifiable physical pain. This section describes a number of more or less direct and (always) willful acts that constitute physical abuse. Pursuant to the Enhanced Civil Penalty Law, Health and Safety (H&S) code section 1548 (f)(1)(A), the Department will be issuing an immediate civil penalty of $2,500.00. An exit interview was completed, and appeal rights discussed. A copy of this report, the Confidential Names List, Appeal Rights, and a Civil Penalty Assessment - Serious Bodily Injury/Physical Abuse (Form 421-D) were provided to the administrator.

On August 31, 2022, at 10:00 am a virtual meeting was held with the Alpha Connection Youth and Family Services Inc. (ACYFS) Corporation via Microsoft Teams. The following people were in attendance: Community Care Licensing (CCL) Regional Manager (RM) LaCresha Cook, Licensing Program Managers (LPMs) Christina Barnes, Cheraki Davis, Natasha Dunlop, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jose Gonzalez, Darlene Oseguera, Nicole Strictland, Joon Choi, California Department of Social Services Rates Oversight Manager Michael Ford, Foster Care Rate's Analyst Tera Tapp, CDSS Department of Health Care Services (DHCS) David Gutierrez, San Bernardino Behavioral Health Representative Diane Wolkenhauer, Social Services Practitioner (SSP) San Bernardino County Children Family Services (CFS) Amy Guisa, Andria Innerbichler, Supervising Social Services Practitioner (SSP) San Bernardino County Children Family Services (CFS) Nakila Hill, PSW San Diego County Residential Placement Ruth Cisneros, Fresno County Department of Behavior Health Lesby Flores, Sr DPO Riverside County Probation Juan Bretado, Imperial County Probation Raul Manriquez, Imperial County Children & Family Services Donald Fulton, Yuba County Child and Adult Protective Services Social Worker Jean Hobbs, Mendocino County Social Worker Supervisor Lindsey Coke, California Alliance for Child and Family Services Rich Weisgal, ACYFS Administrative staff, Chief Executive Officer Barron Wilson, Program Director/ Facility Administrator Amy Osborn, Facility Administrators Evonnda Hull, Guy Williams, Anthony Riley, Clinician Muarizo Assandri, Clinician, Mark Daniels, Cameron Wilson Special Assistant to the Executive Director. The following information was discussed: · Substantiated complaints for all four Short Term Residential Therapeutic Programs (STRTPs) · Current client census for all four STRTPs · Application Denial Letter for STRTPs · Appeal Rights for the denial of the applications · Request for a Closure Plan · STRTPs reverting back to Group Homes

During the discussion RM Cook expressed concerns regarding eight substantiated complaints against the STRTPs since the previous informal office conference held on April 12, 2022. RM Cook discussed that the department had met and communicated with the licensee to resolve concerns about the operation of the STRTP programs, to ensure that the programs could meet the high-level requirements for STRTPs. However, despite the outcome of those interactions, Alpha Connection has demonstrated an inability to comply with the operative statutes and regulations. RM Cook explained the denial of the applications are based upon the licensee’s failure to provide satisfactory evidence that they can meet or conform to the licensing requirements in the Health and Safety Code, Title 22 California Code of Regulations, and CDSS Short-Term Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards (“ILS”). RM Cook also explained that the decision is based on the evidence set forth in the reports, statements, and other documentary evidence contained in the official files compiled by the department. RM Cook informed Alpha Connections Youth and Family Services (ACYFS) Chief Executive Office Barron Wilson and all participants on the virtual meeting that the department will be issuing ACYFS an application denial letter for all four of the Alpha Connections Youth and Family Services STRTP facilities that includes an allowance of adequate time to submit a closure plan to Community Care Licensing and the County placing agencies, and for appropriate placements for the youth to be assessed. Chief Executive Officer (CEO) Barron Wilson expressed his disdain for RM Cook, his disappointments, frustrations, and concerns with the denial decision. RM Cook asked CEO Wilson if he wanted to convert back to Group Home operations once the applications are denied and CEO Wilson stated yes. RM Cook then explained the department would also begin the revocation process for the Group Home facilities once the STRTPs converted back to group homes. There was additional discussion from the STRTP representatives regarding their disdain for RM Cook and their opinions and frustrations regarding the complaint investigations, the effects on the clients in placement, and concerns with the denial decision. ACYFS and California Alliance consultant, Yuba County and Imperial County representatives voiced their positive reflections of working with ACYFS. RM Cook concluded the meeting by requesting the licensee to submit a closure plan in writing for all four ACYFS STRTP programs as soon as possible to Community Care Licensing. *******CONTINUED on LIC 809C*******

The facility was given 09/30/2022 as the date to close their STRTP program. Mr. Wilson is advised that a closure plan is needed which will include the following: 1. The licensee will notify all placing agencies of ACYFS closure. 2. The licensee will work with all placing agencies in a safe transition of all clients to other programs. 3. This plan will include the facility’s plan of action and how the facility will work with the placing agencies to ensure that all clients are transitioned in a respectful and safe manner. 4. The licensee will notify their employees of ACYFS closure. 5. The closure date will be September 30, 2022. LPA Jose Gonzalez and LPM Cheraki Davis reviewed and discussed the report with CEO, Barron Wilson. A copy of this report was emailed to Barron Wilson for signature. A copy of the signed report will be placed in the facility file. Mr. Wilson refused to sign the LIC 809 document. Mr. Wilson was informed that the document will be recorded and placed in the facility file.

narrative: The Department received an allegation on April 8, 2022, that facility staff did not prevent minor, client #1 (C1) AWOLING. Confidential interviews disclosed that facility staff encouraged C1 not to AWOL. Additional confidential interviews indicated that C1 would not follow facility staff’s verbal redirection. Confidential interviews disclosed that facility staff encouraged C1 to use their coping skills. Other confidential interviews revealed that facility staff did not engage C1. Additional confidential interviews indicated that STRTP Home did not provide C1 activities to keep C1 engaged. Confidential interviews disclosed that Alpha Connections Youth and Family Services (ACYFS) did not use trauma informed care to meet C1s behavioral needs. The Department also received an allegation that facility staff did not report C1s AWOL. Confidential interviews disclosed that facility staff contacted law enforcement (LE) when C1 went absent without leave (AWOL). Additional confidential interviews indicated that facility staff notified C1s county social worker of C1 AWOL behaviors. Other confidential interviews revealed that C1 was allowed several hours to return to the STRTP home prior to the facility staff contacting LE and filing a missing person’s report. Additional confidential interviews indicated that there is a possibility that facility staff did not notify LE of C1 leaving the STRTP Home unsupervised in a timely manner. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that that facility staff did not prevent minor, C1 from AWOLING, and that facility staff did not report C1s AWOL, may have occurred, however, are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Sydney Penate ,FM .
investigation_findings: 13On September 08, 2022, at 03:20 pm, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s) Joon Choi and Jessica Peete met with Facility Manager (FM), Sydney Penate, to deliver the findings for the above-stated allegations. LPA conducted a health and safety inspection on April 14, 2022, at 1:07 pm, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. LPAs also reviewed six clients’ records. During the investigation, interviews were conducted with six out of six clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6), Staff #1 (S1), Facility Manager (S2), Facility Administrator (S3), and County Social Worker (CSW).

narrative: The Department received an allegation on July 11, 2022, that Facility Staff (FS) are smoking marijuana in the presence of minors, FS are smoking marijuana with minors in care, and that (FS) are allowing minors to smoke substances while in care. Confidential interviews disclosed that FS do not smoke marijuana in the presence of minors in care. Additional confidential interviews indicated that FS do not smoke marijuana with the minors in care. Confidential interviews disclosed that the STRTP home is a nonsmoking and smoke free environment. Additional confidential interviews indicated that C1 makes up fabricated stories. Other confidential interviews revealed that there is a possibility that FS do smoke marijuana in the presence of minors in care. Additional confidential interviews indicated there is a possibility that FS does smoke marijuana with the minors. Confidential interviews revealed that there is a possibility that FS allows the minors to smoke substances while in care. Additional confidential interviews disclosed that C1 is asthmatic and C1s asthma flares when people are smoking. The Department also received an allegation that the clients are not being provided a safe and healthful environment while in care. Confidential witness denied the allegations. Additional confidential interviews indicated that clients are provided a healthful and safe environment. Confidential interviews disclosed that facility staff (FS) intervene and separate clients during an argument or fight. Additional confidential interviews indicated that FS are proactive with the clients and keep the clients engaged. Confidential interviews disclosed that clients do not feel safe because a person can climb through the window and hurt them. CSW also stated that their client needs a lot of supervision due to their assaultive and unsafe behaviors. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that Facility Staff (FS) are smoking marijuana in the presence of minors, FS are smoking marijuana with minors in care, FS are allowing minors to smoke substances while in care, and that minor is not being provided a safe and healthful environment while in care, may have occurred, however, are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Sydney Penate FM.
investigation_findings: 13On September 08, 2022, at 03:20 pm, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s) Joon Choi and Jessica Peete met with Facility Manager (FM), Sidney Penate, to deliver the findings for the above-stated allegations. LPA conducted a health and safety inspection on July 15, 2022, at 12:18 pm, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. LPAs also reviewed five clients’ records. During the investigation, interviews were conducted with four out of five clients (C1, C2, C3, and C4), Facility Manager (FM), Staff #1 (S1), and County Social Worker (CSW), client C5 refused to be interviewed.

narrative: The Department received an allegation on March 18, 2022, that facility staff are not providing supervision to the minors in care. Confidential interviews disclosed that the minors do feel safe at the home. Additional confidential interviews indicated that the facility staff interact with the minors. Confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff intervened immediately when the residents argued or fought. Confidential interviews reported that the facility staff are checking on the minors and providing supervision for the minors in care. Other confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff does not keep the minors engaged. Additional confidential interviews indicated that minors would leave staff supervision because the minors were not engaged. The Department also received an allegation that facility staff #1 (S1) is sleeping during work shifts. Confidential interviews reported that the minors are asleep and were not aware of S1 sleeping during the night shift. Confidential interviews indicated that the facility staff is not sleeping during work shifts. Confidential interviews reported that S1 and the other facility staff conduct headcounts every 10 minutes. Confidential interviews disclosed that S1 works the night shift at this home and another home. Other confidential interviews reported that S1 is sleeping during his designated time of working at the home. Confidential interviews disclosed that S1 has been observed sleeping during his designated time of working at the home. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that facility staff are not providing supervision to the minors in care and that facility staff #1 (S1) are sleeping during work shifts may have occurred, however, are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Sydney Penate, FM.
investigation_findings: 13On September 08, 2022, at 03: 20 pm, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s) Joon Choi and Jessica Peete met with Facility Manager Sydney Penate (FM), to deliver the findings for the above-stated allegations. LPA conducted a safety inspection at the facility at 1:13 pm on March 18, 2022, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. LPA also reviewed six out of six client’s records. During the investigation, interviews were conducted with six clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6), the Facility Manager (FM), and Staff #1 (S1). LPA attempted to interview C6 but was unsuccessful due to C6 refusing to be interviewed.

narrative: no health or safety violations were observed at the time on inspection. It was alleged that on or around 07/07/22, staff confiscated C1’s belongings and staff spit on C1. It was reported staff spit on C1 and staff took C1’s belongings. Several witness statements corroborate that staff do not confiscate facility client’s belongings, however, several witnesses also corroborate staff will confiscate drug or alcohol paraphernalia when client’s AWOL and then return to the facility and are observed with these things. Other witnesses corroborate that staff might sometimes take away things like cell phones as consequences, however, all witnesses corroborate the items are returned in a timely manner and not simply “taken away”. Several other witnesses corroborate they have never had their personal property confiscated by staff and not returned to them. Additionally, while one witness maintains a staff did spit on a client, no details were provided as to which staff or which client were involved in this incident, or when it occurred. Several witnesses deny any staff ever spitting on any clients. All staff interviewed deny these allegations. While another witness maintains the allegations are true, several witnesses deny ever observing these allegations occur. Based on interviews conducted, the allegations that staff confiscated C1’s belongings and staff spit on C1 may have occurred, however, they are not supported or proven by evidence. The allegations are, therefore, UNSUBSTANTIATED. There are no deficiencies to be cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights, were provided to FM, Nancy McCarthy, for original signature. Signed report will be placed in facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On September 21, 2022, at 3:10 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Carmen Escobar and Erika Lopez arrived at the short term residential therapeutic program (STRTP) facility and met with Facility Manager (FM), Nancy McCarthy. LPA Escobar conducted a facility risk assessment with FM and LPA Lopez proceeded to continue with the facility inspection to issue the investigative findings for the above allegations. During the investigation, LPA Jose Gonzalez requested documents from client 1 (C1’s) file including placement agreement, copy of C1’s most recent needs and service plan, special incident reports involving C1, one on one contract between C1 and facility, children and family team meeting notes, 14 day notice, and memo regarding C1 from facility. LPA Gonzalez also obtained a copy of the STRTP client roster and staff roster. LPA Escobar conducted interviews with three staff members, C1, C2, C3, C4, C1’s county social workers (CSW1 and CSW2), C1’s probation officer, and another involved party. LPA Gonzalez conducted an in-person inspection of the STRTP on 07/08/22 at 10:01 AM,

narrative: An additional allegation alleging minor’s medication is not properly stored was also received by CCL. Specific information was not provided as to whose medication was improperly stored or when the incident occurred. Confidential interviews provided consistent statement on how medication is to be stored at the facility however additional confidential interviews reported a retraining on proper medication storage was provided after a unknown staff member had been disciplined for leaving medication out on staff’s desk in the staff office. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute that this was a one time incident. LPA observed the medications to be locked during the time of the health and safety inspection. CCL received an additional allegation alleging Staff allowing minors to bully other minors. Confidential interviews confirmed that all residents in the home tease and bully each other. Confidential interviews provided conflicting accounts on how staff address the bullying of residents. Confidential interviews reported as soon as staff hear any resident teasing or bullying another resident the staff redirects the aggressor and puts a stop to it. Additional confidential interviews reported some staff just tell residents to stop and do not take any additional action to limit the teasing/bullying, while other staff do not address the teasing/bullying at all. An allegation that staff are not treating minors with respect was also received by CCL. Specific information as to which staff or which minor was not provided to CCL. Confidential interviews provided conflicting statements of respect towards minors in the facility was reported. Confidential interviews reported that staff (unnamed) will yell and use profanity at the minors when they are not following house rules or doing what staff want. Additional confidential interviews deny any yelling or cussing at the minors occurs. CCL received an additional allegation alleging lack of supervision resulting in minors AWOLing. Specifically, it was reported that overnight staff would fall asleep during their shift resulting in minors leaving the facility for long periods of time. LPA received inconsistent statements regarding whether or not minors were AWOLing during the overnight shifts. Based on record review and confidential interviews the allegations of minors have access to drugs and alcohol while in care, minors medication is not properly stored, staff allowing minors to bully other minors, staff are not treating minors with respect, and lack of supervision resulting in minors AWOLing, may or may not have occurred, however they are not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was provided along with appeal rights to Alpha Connections – Anoka Ranch Administrator (ADM), Amy Osbornl.
investigation_findings: 13On September 22 2022 at 12:00 pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA's), Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Joon Choi, met with Alpha Connections – Anoka Ranch Administrator (ADM), Amy Osborn to deliver the findings for the above stated allegations. A health and safety inspection of the facility occurred on March 25, 2022 and no immediate safety concerns were observed. The investigation included interviews with, ADM, Administrator #2 (ADM2), eight residents (Child #1 [C1], Child #3 [C3], Child #4 [C4], Child #6 [C6], Child #7 [C7], Child #8 [C8], Child #9 [C9], and Child #10 [C10]), five staff members (Staff #1 [S1] Staff #2 [S2] Staff #3 [S3], Staff #4 [S4], and Staff #5 [S5]). In addition, county records and facility records were reviewed. On March 15, 2022 Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation alleging minors have access to drugs and alcohol while in care. Confidential interviews provided conflicting statements regarding the drug and alcohol use of the minors residing in the facility. Confidential interviews reported most of the minors participate in drug and/or alcohol use, while other confidential interviews denied the use of drugs and/or alcohol by the minors. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute where, when, or how the minors get access to the drugs and alcohol. Other confidential interviews disclosed that the drug and/or alcohol use occurs away from the facility while minors are absent without leave (AWOL). Continued on page

narrative: Other confidential witnesses stated that C1 and C2 were involved in a physical altercation at the facility in which C1 was very upset and threatening to assault C2 after C2 slammed C1. LPA received inconsistent information regarding the allegation. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation that client #1 was punched in the eye by client #2 may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. investigation_findings: 13On September 22, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA's) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Joon Choi met with Amy Osborn to issue the finding for the above stated allegation. The complaint investigation was jointly conducted by LPA Almaraz, LPA Leslie Covarrubias, and LPA Jose Gonzalez. Additionally, LPAs conducted interviews with two county social workers, four staff, and five of six clients. One of six clients is absent without leave (AWOL) and could not be located for LPA interview. On July 11, 2022, the Department received a complaint alleging minor hit another minor while in care. More specifically, it was alleged that on July 8, 2022, client #1 (C1) (see confidential names list LIC 811) was punched in the eye by client #2 (C2). County social workers stated that they were not informed by their clients that they were struck by other clients in care. narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst, Daniel Mena and Licensing Program Manager, Natasha Dunlap conducted a teleconference meeting with Alpha Connection, Program Director, Amy Osborn, Clinician, Lindsay Baston and Consultant, Dan Thorne to discuss and review the probationary conditions that go into effect once Alpha Connections STRTP reverts back to a Group Home on January 01, 2023. On December 31, 2022, the STRTP applications for Alpha Connection Group Home For Children, License No. 366412000, 21398 Pine Ridge, Apple Valley, CA 92307; ACYFSAnoka Ranch, License No. 366401649, 22675 Anoka Road, Apple Valley, CA 92308; ACYFS-Shoshonee Place, License No. 366402331, 20048 Shoshonee Road, Apple Valley, CA 92307; and ACYFS Nisqually Nest, License No. 366403207, 12915 Chief Joseph Road, Apple Valley, CA 92308 (collectively the "facilities") are terminated and Alpha will transition/convert back to its group home licenses subject to a three (3) year probationary term with the following conditions: 1. Alpha shall operate each facility in substantial compliance with the regulations and statutes governing the operation of a group home. 2. During the period of Probation, the Department in its sole discretion may conduct unannounced site visits for the purpose of determining whether there is substantial compliance with the regulations and statutes governing the operation of the group home. 3. Alpha will submit an updated group home plan of operation and program statement for each group home to the Department within 30 days of the effective date of this Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release including but not limited to:

a. A description of trauma-informed and evidence-based intervention and de-escalation techniques that will be used to promote the safety of all individuals in the facility, including but not limited to children or nonminor dependents who have a propensity for behaviors that result in harm to self or others. b. A runaway plan that includes a continuum of non-physical interventions and strategies to de-escalate a situation where a child has indicated his /her intent to run away, that will be utilized by staff to prevent and Alpha to runaway behaviors. 4. Alpha shall ensure that all children are supervised 24 hours per day, 7 days per week, in accordance with its Program Statement and Plan of Operation and licensing regulations. 5. There shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows: a. During the hours of 7 am to 10 pm, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every three children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum b. During the hours of 10pm to 7am, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every six children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum. c. In addition to staff required in paragraph 1 or 2, when one or more children are present at the facility, at least one direct care staff shall be on call and capable of arriving at the facility within 30 minutes. d. If a child requires special care and supervision because of age, behavior or other factors, the number of awake and on-duty care staff shall be increased. 6. Any administrator employed by Alpha to operate the facility shall have, at minimum, the education and experience specified in California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation 84064 and shall be certified as a group home

administrator pursuant to California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation 84064. 2. No exceptions shall be made to these requirements during probation. 7. Alpha shall ensure that a qualified and certified administrator is present and available on premises of each facility, a minimum of 20 hours a week. In the administrator's absence, a designated substitute as defined in the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation 84064(d) shall be present and available on the premises of the facility. Alpha shall timely notify the Department of any change in administrator and the name, address, date of hire, background, qualifications, and certification of the new administrator. 8. Alpha shall develop a comprehensive training curriculum for all new and current staff who provide direct care services to children in care. The content of the training shall include, but not be limited to, the following: supervision of youth, reporting requirements to the Department and reporting requirements as a mandated child abuse reporter, personal rights, crisis prevention, and emergency intervention, including Alpha's runaway plan, and all applicable licensing laws and regulations. Training shall be mandatory for all employees. A detailed description of the in-service training and a record of all staff who attended the trainings shall be maintained and made available to the department upon request. a. Training to include (ii) Trauma Informed Interventions and Treatment Practices. Two (2) hours of instruction in the physical and psychosocial needs of the children, including behavior management, de-escalation techniques, and trauma-informed crisis management planning, including the use of emergency interventions. The training plan shall be designed to ensure the provision of trauma-informed services and be appropriate for the population and shall consider the training needs and skill level of staff b. All outstanding training, including but not limited to the training listed above, shall be completed by staff within 45 days of the group home transition.

c. Additional staff hired after the transition to the group home must complete the trauma informed training within 45 days of hire and any additional training must be completed within the time frames outlined in the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation 84065. In the Matter of Alpha Connections Youth & Family Services, Inc. v. CDSS Case No. CVR12203769 Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release 9. Alpha shall adhere to the reporting requirements as defined in California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulations 80061, 84061, in the regulations and statutes governing the operation of a group home. Alpha shall report to the Licensing office the following: any unusual incident, including, but not limited to, client death or injury which requires medical treatment, any suspected physical plant changes, and all unexplained absences. These incidents must be reported by the next working day, and a written report of the incident must be submitted within seven days following the occurrence of the incident. All unusual incident reports shall be complete, including addendums and follow-up information. 10. Alpha shall ensure compliance with California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulations 84068.1, 84068.2, 84068.3 and 84068.4 regarding Intake Procedure, Needs and Services Plans and Modifications, and Removal and/or Discharge Procedures. Prior to and during placement Alpha shall determine whether it can provide the services necessary to meet the child's needs and to effect discharge if it is determined that Alpha cannot provide the services necessary to meet the child's needs. Further, Alpha shall ensure that an appropriate assessment of a child's compatibility with other children in care is conducted during the intake process and is re-evaluated on a continuance basis when individual needs dictate. Alpha agrees that it shall not accept or retain, and will promptly discharge with written notice to the authorized representative, any child for whom it cannot adequately and safely provide care, any child who requires a higher level of care, and any child who would cause the Alpha to violate laws and regulations, or the conditions of Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release.

11. Alpha shall ensure the personal rights of all children in its care including the right to be provided safe, healthful, and comfortable accommodations to meet their needs, and shall be free from corporal or unusual punishment, pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other action of a punitive nature. 12. Alpha shall ensure that each child in care receives first aid and medical services, including arrangements and transportation. Further Alpha shall ensure that medications and any other toxic products are properly stored and kept in a safe and locked place that is not accessible to children in care or other persons other than employees responsible for the supervision of the centrally stored medication pursuant to California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation sections 80075 and 84075. Employees of Alpha shall immediately document on the medication log any refusals of medication by a child in care and shall follow-up with proper notification to the child's physician. 13. Alpha's Board of Directors shall be active in ensuring accountability and ensuring that Alpha complies with all applicable regulations, by reviewing, on a quarterly basis Alpha's operation and documents as specified in Health and Safety code section 1520. 1(f), including a review of special incident reports and all licensing reports issued by the Department. 14. For the duration of the probationary period, Alpha shall provide all current and prospective parents or responsible parties of children in the facility with a copy of the settlement terms, as outlined in the Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release. Proof of Acknowledgement shall be kept in the respective child’s record and available for inspection by the Department. 15. Alpha will work collaboratively with the Department to comply and fully implement all Plan of Corrections and agreements. This Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release supersedes any Compliance Plan or Corrective Action Plan that has previously been submitted by the Alpha to the Department. A copy of this report was provided and emailed for signatures.

Based on confidential interviews and record review the allegation Staff did not create a safety plan for minor (Child #4 [C4]) is substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. This is a violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87072(c) PERSONAL RIGHTS (c) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Sections 16001.9 as applicable. Resolved due to expiration of the STRTP license, as outlined in the September 2022 settlement agreement. A copy of the report and appeal rights were given to a facility representative. Original signature placed on file.

In addition, county records and facility records were reviewed. On March 21, 2022 Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation alleging Staff did not create a safety plan for minor (Child #4 [C4]). Specifically, it was reported C4 had been harassed, bullied, threatened and assaulted. Confidential interviews and record review revealed consistent concerns of C4’s safety prior to and after the assault were presented to the facility. Record review and confidential interviews were unable to provide evidence the facility created a safety plan for C4 addressing the concerns. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

On February 22, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daniel Mena arrived at Alpha Connection- Group Home (GH). LPA Mena was granted access by Administrator, Evonda Hull. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. Administrator led the physical inspection of the facility with LPA Mena. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility’s visitor's room, living room, kitchen area, dinning area, office, therapist office area, refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, 3 client bedrooms, front and backyard areas, and 3 bathroom/showers. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Sports equipment/toys/books/games/computers were observed for children’s recreation time. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintain an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and the menus were posted. All other required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. Medications are to be locked and centrally stored inside staff's office. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. Hot water temperature was measured. Per the Administrator, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. The facility has a visitor's room, living room, kitchen area, dinning area, office, therapist office area, laundry room, food storage areas, 3 client bedrooms, and 3 bathroom/showers. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. CONTINUES on LIC 809C

Chemicals and/or poisons, sharp objects/knives are locked in a file cabinet in the staff office. First Aid Kits are stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office. LPA reviewed the facility's disaster plan. The facility currently has two children, each in their own bedroom. The facility must ensure that each client is aware of the bedroom sharing policy and document the advisement in the clients’ files. Based on record review, the facility did provide a signed bedroom sharing document in their files. There are currently no children taking prescribed medications. There were no deficiencies/corrections observed on this date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report were provided to Administrator.

LPA advised the facility to adhere immediately to the exclusion order. Copies of the exclusion order were provided to Administrator for Alpha Connection Youth and Family Services Facilities: Alpha Connection-Shoshonee Place #366402331, Alpha Connection-Nisqually Nest #366403207, Alpha Connection-Anoka ranch #366401649, and Alpha Connection Group Home for Children #366412000 due to S1 being associated to all four facilities. A copy of the exclusion order was also provided to S1. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, LIC 811 and the appeal rights with the exclusion order was provided to Administrator Evonda Hull. Due to LPA's printer malfunctioning, all the above stated forms were emailed to administrator.

LPA Mena conducted an unannounced Case Management visit on this date. LPA Mena met with Program Administrator, Evonnda Hull.
