In addition, LPA Mena conducted interviews with staff (S1 & S2) and two Clients (C1 & C2) who were present on facility grounds during visit. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provide.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi on 11/20/2023 at 10:49 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the visit, LPA Choi met with Adminstrator Evonnda Hull and conducted a health and safety inspection of the facility. No immediate health or safety risks were observed. LPA reviewed 2 of child’s records and 3 of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed 2 of child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed 2 of staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed 2 of children currently prescribed psychotropic medication. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Administrator Evonnda Hull and provided a copy of this licensing report.

An unannounced case management inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kendal Zirbes on September 24, 2020 at 2:21pm. Due to Covid 19, a tele-inspection was conducted. During the inspection LPA met with Facility Director, Precious Spence via FaceTime. A facility safety inspection was conducted at 2:21pm on September 24, 2020. There were no deficiencies to be cited at this time. The purpose of the inspection was to issue an advisory notice regarding an incident that occurred at the facility on August 23, 2020. Over the course of the case management, LPA interviewed the Chief Executive Officer (CEO), facility Administrator, Facility Director, one County Social Worker (CSW) and a confidential witness. On September 3, 2020, LPA received and reviewed the facility logs for August 22, 2020 and August 23, 2020. Furthermore, LPA reviewed the 2020 incident reports submitted by the facility to Community Care Licensing (CCL). On August 25, 2020 CCL received information regarding an incident that occurred at the facility on August 23, 2020. The information received from the facility reported that on August 23, 2020, at approximately 2:17am facility staff observed an unknown male peer attempting to hide in resident 1 (R1’s) bedroom. Refer to confidential names list (LIC 811) dated September 24, 2020. Per the information received, R1 then absconded from the facility without all of R1’s on. Confidential interviews confirmed an unknown male peer has come to the female facility on more than one occasion. Confidential interviews confirmed the male peer, came to the facility around 12:00am on August 23, 2020, and knocked on all bedroom windows until someone let him in. Confidential interviews stated the male peer was on the facility grounds for one to two hours and visited the residents in two of the three bedrooms. Confidential interviews reported the staff conduct nightly room checks every hour during the NOC shift. Staff interviews confirmed an unknown male peer was present on the facility grounds on August 23, 2020. Staff interviews expressed a male was in the backyard at approximately 11:00pm on August 22, 2020. This same male was observed again on August 23, 2020 around 2:00am in R1’s bedroom. Staff expressed they do not believe the unknown male was on grounds for one to two hours and reported checks were conducted at least every ten minutes. Staff interviews confirmed, that unknown male peers have been on the facility grounds on more than one occasion. Report continued on page two

Report continued from page one Administrator reported, prior to the incident on August 23, 2020, the facility hired Liberty Protection Services to monitor the facilities and deter unwanted visitors. In addition, the facility had flood lights installed in the front and back yard to assist the staff with perimeter checks. Furthermore, a security system was installed at the facility on September 11, 2020. LPA’s review of the facility logs, documented R1 was off grounds, in the backyard or AWOL during the following times on August 22, 2020 and August 23, 2020: 10:50pm, 11:00pm, 12:40am, 1:10am, 2:20 - 05:00am. The logs reflected staff updates every ten minutes. Per CCL records, on August 23, 2020, July 22, 2020, and May 16, 2020, an unidentified male was on the facility grounds. The facility is being issued an Advisory Note – Technical Violation for California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. A copy of this report was reviewed with the Facility Director and emailed to Program Director, Amy Osborn.

LPA Rubio obtained copies of the client and staff rosters, the needs and services plan for C1 and San Bernardino County Child Protective Services Investigative report. On January 25, 2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging minor was inappropriately restrained while in care and staff mishandled a minor while in care; specifically, that on multiple occasions FD applied pressure with her arm to C1’s neck while being restrained and FD pulled C1’s hair, both due to C1’s aggression and to prevent C1 from being physical with peers. Confidential interviews revealed staff do not restrain clients and FD has not been observed to place her arm on C1’s neck or pull C1’s hair. Further confidential interviews revealed if a client is being physical with another client staff will separate the clients by pulling them apart however staff does not restrain clients. Confidential interviews with both staff and clients revealed staff intervene by placing themselves in between clients so that clients cannot harm each other. Confidential interviews with staff also revealed staff separate clients, use verbal de-escalation and incentives to get clients to calm down. Other confidential interviews revealed FD and other staff have had to restrain C1 on one occasion when C1 was attempting to commit suicide and grab anything C1 could to hurt C1’s self. Additionally, interviews revealed staff has had to get a butter knife out of C1’s hand when C1 has said C1 was going to hurt C1’s self but did not restrain C1. Additionally, CSW1 and CSW2 had no concerns of staff restraining or mishandling clients. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations C1 was inappropriately restrained while in care and FD mishandled C1 while in care may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were explained and emailed to Administrator for signature. Signed reports will be placed in facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On February 26, 2021, at 1:20 pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jessica Rubio made contact with Alpha Connection, Nisqually Nest (STRTP), Administrator Amy Osborn via Google Duo video due to COVID-19, to discuss the investigative findings of the allegations listed above. On February 1, 2021 at 12:20 pm, LPA Rubio conducted a safety tele-inspection of the facility. No safety hazards were observed and no deficiencies were cited. During the investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews with Administrator (AD), Facility Director (FD), staff (S1, S2, S3, S4, S6, S7, S8). An interview with staff # 5 (S5) was attempted however not completed due to S5 being on leave. LPA also conducted interviews with county social worker of C1 (CSW1) and county social worker of C2 (CSW2). An interview with client #1 (C1) was conducted however not completed due to C1’s unwillingness to continue to participate. Interviews were conducted with clients #2 and #5 (C2, C5). Interviews with other clients (C3, C4) present in the facility were not completed as all clients refused to speak with LPA. Client #6 (C6) was not interviewed due to being on a home pass and then being moved to a new placement during the investigation. (Continued on LIC 9099-C)

narrative:
On January 22, 2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging staff did not prevent youth from engaging in Commercial Sexual Exploitation of Children (CSEC) activity; specifically, that C1 and C2 engaged in sexual acts with an adult male when C1 and C2 went AWOL from the facility. Confidential interviews and record review revealed on 1/18/2021 and 1/19/2021, C1 and C2 went AWOL from the STRTP. Confidential witness interviews revealed C1 and C2 met and communicated with an adult male via a dating app on their cell phones. Confidential witness interviews revealed C1 and C2 went AWOL on 1/18/2021 and 1/19/2021 and were picked up down the street from the facility by the adult male. Confidential interviews and record review revealed it was later disclosed that C1 and C2 engaged in sexual acts with the adult male in exchange for marijuana. Confidential witness interviews indicated on 1/18/2021, when C1 and C2 left the facility, S1 followed them on foot and verbally redirected them however clients did not comply and entered an awaiting vehicle and drove off. S7 also conducted a community search by driving around the area however did not locate C1 and C2. Confidential witness interviews revealed on 1/19/2021, when C1 and C2 left the facility S2 ran after C1 and C2 and verbally redirected clients however clients did not comply and got into an awaiting vehicle. S2 approached the vehicle and yelled to the adult male in the car informing him the clients were minors and he could not leave with C1 and C2, however the male drove off. Both S2 and S3 followed the vehicle in the facility vehicle until it was unsafe and staff obtained the vehicle’s license plate. Confidential interviews and record review revealed police reports were filed both on 1/18/2021 and 1/19/2021 after C1 and C2 went AWOL. Confidential interviews and record review revealed C1 has excessive AWOL behaviors and participates in CSEC activity. Confidential interviews also revealed staff has observed C1 communicating with a presumed adult male via social media in the past and has discussed it with C1 and C1’s Therapeutic Behavioral Services (TBS) coach. Confidential interviews and record review revealed C2 has a history of AWOL behaviors however had not had a history of CSEC activities prior to these incidents. Confidential interviews revealed C1 has previously been in a cell phone contract and had C1’s phone taken away however, C1 has earned it back and then fails to comply or will access and use other client’s phones. Confidential interviews conducted with staff revealed staff do not monitor client’s cell phone usage due to clients cell phones being the client’s personal property while other interviews revealed staff do monitor client’s cell phone usage by asking to see client’s screens to verify the websites and apps they are using are appropriate. Further interviews with AD revealed that the facility has taken numerous steps to ensure the safety of the clients. AD disclosed C1 has been assigned a one to one staff, an alarm system has been installed at the facility as well as security contracted to be outside of the facility. (Continued on LIC 9099-C)

AD also revealed since the incident, the facility and CSW1 are in the process of petitioning the court to not allow C1 to have a cell phone. Further interviews revealed C1 has an array of services offered including therapy, a TBS coach, a CSEC advocate, monthly Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings and weekly check ins. Further interviews revealed C2 also receives therapy, has a Court Appointed Special Advocate and regular CFT meetings. Additionally, county social workers for C1 and C2 had no concerns of C1 or C2’s care in the facility. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation staff did not prevent C1 and C2 from engaging in CSEC activity may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were explained and emailed to Administrator Amy Osborn for signature. Signed reports will be placed in facility file.

narrative: On March 2, 2021 at 11:00am, an unannounced virtual Post-Licensing Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kendal Zirbes. A virtual inspection was conducted as a result of the Covid-19 related restrictions. During the inspection, LPA met with Administrator Amy Osborn via Google Duo. LPA and Administrator inspected the facility inside and out. The facility was licensed as a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) on October 2, 2020. The facility in the process of receiving a Mental Health Certification with San Bernardino County. The facility is a one-story house with three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a bonus room, staff office, kitchen, dining area, and living room. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/books/games were observed for youth’s recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order. The facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. The facility had all required documents posted throughout the facility. Medications are locked and centrally stored in a locked filing cabinet within the locked staff office. Six individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. At 12:25pm, the hot water was measured by Precious Spence, Facility Manager. At the time of this inspection the hot water temperature was 105. The facility has a fully equipped first aid kit and first aid manual. The facility is not equipped with cameras, but is equipped with a security system. At the time of this inspection, there were no bodies of water on the facility ground. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility and smoking is prohibited. The facility vehicle was observed to be in safe operating condition and the registration was up to date. Youth files were maintained in a locked filing cabinet within the staff office. Personnel files are retained at the corporate office located at 17198 Yuma St. Suite B, Victorville CA 92395. Staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection and they were in accordance with the regulations. Youth and Personal files will be reviewed on a future date at the at corporate office. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator Amy Osborn. A copy of this report was emailed to the facility.

On March 5, 2021 at 09:50am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kendal Zirbes met with Administrator Evonnda Hull at the Alpha Connection Corporate office located in Victorville CA. The purpose of the inspection was to complete the continuation inspection for the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Post licensing inspection that was initiated on March 2, 2021. A sample of six personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Six of the six files that were reviewed were for employees who converted from group home personnel to STRTP personnel. LPA observed the converted staff members were not trained according to the STRTP training requirements. Technical Assistance Advisory Note (TA) will be issued. LPA reviewed six client files. LPA observed all six Needs and Service Plans did not contain information regarding the clients ability to manage his/her own money. In addition, LPA observed the Admission agreements were not updated to reflect an STRTP placement. Technical Assistance Advisory Notes (TA) will be issued. LPA requested the recent board meeting be provided to CCL by March 8, 2021 at 11:00am, A copy of this report and the advisory notices were provided to Administrator Evonnda Hull.

On February 2, 2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging lack of supervision resulting in inappropriate interactions between minors, specifically inappropriate interactions between C1 and C2. Confidential witness interviews and record review revealed that in December 2020, during a PM shift, C1 penetrated C2 with a make-up brush in the bathroom of the STRTP. Other confidential interviews revealed it was disclosed the incident happened in the bedroom of the STRTP. Additional confidential interviews revealed the act was at first consensual and then was not while other records of interviews revealed the act was consensual. Further confidential interviews revealed this incident occurred while C1 and C2 were on a video call with C2’s boyfriend. Record review also revealed in another incident, C1 held the phone for C2 during a video call so that C2 could touch herself. Confidential witness interviews revealed that C1 and C2 shared a bedroom and on one occasion around November 2020, C1 and C2 were observed in C2’s bed together under the blanket and with the door closed. Further confidential witness interviews revealed on another occasion around November 2020, C2 had discussed in front of clients and staff that C2’s breasts were sore due to C1 playing with them. Confidential interviews also revealed that C1 attempted to get in the shower with C2 when C2 was first placed in the facility in early 2020. Confidential interviews and record review revealed that C1 has been assigned a one to one staff supervision since 2019. The facility plan of operation indicates a 1:3 ratio of staff to clients. Confidential interviews and record review revealed that there are usually two staff for the AM shift, three staff for the PM shift and two staff for NOC. Other confidential interviews revealed there are three staff for the AM shift. On 2/8/2021, LPA observed only two staff in the facility during AM shift, one staff was the one to one for C1 and the other was the facility director. At that time, five clients including C1 were present in the facility. Confidential interviews revealed C1’s one to one staff person is usually stable during AM shift however varies on the PM shift. Further confidential witness interviews revealed there is no one to one staff for C1 during NOC shift. Further confidential interviews revealed staff are to check on and log client’s whereabouts every 10 minutes or more often if needed. Based on the multiple inappropriate, sexual related incidents that occurred between C1 and C2 in the facility, staff was not providing adequate supervision or the one to one intensive supervision that is to be provided to C1 as stated in C1’s needs and services plan. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The department has determined the allegation of lack of supervision resulting in inappropriate interactions between C1 and C2 is substantiated. (Continued on next page)

The facility is being cited for violation of the STRTP Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 7.5, Version 3.1, Regulation Section 87078(b): Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. Per confidential interviews and record review, the facility failed to provide care and supervision resulting in C1 and C2 engaging in inappropriate, sexual related incidents which is an immediate health, safety and personal rights risk to children in care. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights was provided to Administrator Amy Osborn.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (b) The licensee shall provide those services identified in each child's... needs and services plan... as necessary to meet the child's... needs. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and record review, the facility failed to provide care and supervision resulting in C1 and C2 engaging in inappropriate, sexual related incidents which is an immediate health, safety and personal rights risk to children in care.

narrative: As a result of these altercations, M1 received a black eye and multiple injuries to neck and back. Confidential witness confirmed the physical altercations occurred. Confidential witness reported, multiple staff members were present and attempted to de-escalate and separate the minors. Staff members reported, that during the incident on October 3, 2020, staff 1 (S1), staff 2 (S2), and Staff 3 (S3) were providing supervision to six minors. According to the staff interviews, the incident involving M1 and M2 occurred on September 29, 2020. The staff reported, that staff 3 (S3) and staff 4 (S4) were providing supervision to six minors. LPA’s review of minor 3 (M3) needs and service plan dated July 20, 2020 reported the following: “M3 continues to need a 1:1 staff for intensive supervision…”. During the altercation on September 29, 2020, the facility failed to follow the required supervision plan for M3. The staff to client ratio is stated in the plan of operation as one staff to three minors (1:3). M3 was to have a 1:1 staff assignment, the five other minors required two additional staff to meet the 1:3 ratio. Based on the record review, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove there was a lack of supervision resulting in minor (M2) causing injuries to another minor (M1) in care. The Facility is cited under the Interim Licensing Standards, Version 3.1, regulation 87078 (b) Responsibility for providing care and supervision. The facility failed to provide care and supervision and staffing levels to meet the needs of minors in care. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to Administrator Amy Osborn. A copy of the signed report will be placed in the facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On March 2, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kendal Zirbes met with Administrator Amy Osborn via Google Duo to deliver the investigative finding for the above stated allegation. Due to COVID 19 a tele inspection was conducted. During the investigation, LPA interviewed one of six minors (M4), three direct care staff members, one facility manager, and the administrator. Five of the six minors made the decision to not be interviewed. LPA interviewed one County Social Worker (CSW) and made unsuccessful attempts to gather information from other five CSW’s. Furthermore, LPA completed a review of the facility records, and conducted a facility tele-inspection on October 13, 2020 at 1:00pm and no safety hazards were noted at that time. On October 5, 2020, the Department received an allegation that due to a lack of supervision, minor 1 (M1) was injured by another minor in care. According to the information received, M1 was involved in two physical altercations. One of the incidents occurred on October 3, 2020 and involved all six of the minors (M1, M2, M3, M4, M5, M6) residing in the facility. The other incident occurred a few days prior, and involved M1 and minor 2 (M2). Report continued on page two

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: (b) Responsibility for providing care and supervision: The licensee shall provide those services identified in each child's or nonminor dependent’s needs and services plan, or Transitional Independent Living Plan, as necessary to meet the child's or nonminor dependent’s needs. The requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and interviews conducted, on September 29, 2020, the facility failed to provide care and supervision and staffing levels to meet the needs of minors in care. This poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the children in care.

narrative:
On February 23, 2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging the facility did not follow reporting requirements, specifically that the facility did not report that C1 was observed to have blisters or burn marks on C1’s back, neck and arm after coming out of the STRTP bathroom with C2. Confidential interviews revealed that in February 2021, staff observed what appeared to be burn marks from a lighter on C1’s back, neck and arms. Further interviews revealed, it was suspected that the burn marks were caused by C2 burning C1. Interviews revealed staff informed FD of the incident and staff also wrote up an incident report regarding the observed injury. Further review of the facility Special Incident Reports (SIR) file revealed CCL had not received any SIR’s related to burn marks observed on C1 nor that it was suspected that C2 caused the burn marks. The facility was unable to provide any documentation of an SIR or write up regarding the incident. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The department has determined the allegation the facility did not follow reporting requirements is substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80061 Reporting Requirements. Per confidential interviews and record review, the facility did not ensure reporting requirements were followed when an injury was observed on C1 and was suspected to be caused by C2, which is a potential health, safety and personal rights risk to clients in care. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights was emailed to Administrator Amy Osborn for signature. Signed reports will be placed in facility file.

On February 23, 2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging minor was burned by another minor while in care and minor had access to dangerous object; specifically, that C2 burned C1 in the bathroom of the STRTP with a lighter. Confidential interviews with staff revealed there is an ongoing issue with clients going into the bathroom together and locking the door. Interviews further revealed C1 and C2 often go into the bathroom together and lock the door. Interviews with staff revealed in February 2021, blister or burn marks were observed on C1’s back, neck and arm after C1 came out of the STRTP bathroom with C2. Interviews conducted with staff revealed the marks were not seen earlier in the day and C1 had been wearing the same clothes all day. Confidential interviews revealed staff were suspicious of where the marks came from and they appeared to be from a lighter being heated up and touched to C1’s skin. Interviews indicated it was believed that C2 burned C1 with a lighter while other interviews revealed C1 has been observed to burn C1’s self with a melted crayon or lighter in the past. Record review revealed C1 has self-harmed in the past however other interviews revealed C1 had not been self-harming recently. Regarding the allegation minor had access to a dangerous object, specifically that C1 or C2 had access to a lighter, confidential interviews revealed clients sometimes bring contraband such as marijuana and lighters into the facility. An interview with staff revealed C2 has had an issue with bringing lighters and other contraband into the facility in the past however not recently. Additional interviews with staff revealed that lighters have been found in and around the facility within the last couple of months however have been found in common areas of the facility and have not been confiscated from a particular client. Interviews revealed that staff ask that the clients empty their pockets and shoes when returning from an absence without leave (AWOL). Further interviews revealed clients do hide contraband in their bras or underwear to bring into the facility. Additional interviews revealed staff do conduct room checks at random and if there is suspicion of contraband. Based on confidential interviews and conflicting statements, the allegations minor was burned by another minor while in care and minor had access to dangerous object may have occurred, however are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were explained and emailed to Administrator Amy Osborn for signature. Signed reports will be placed in facility file.

narrative:
On September 23, 2021, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Christina Barnes, and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jose Gonzalez arrived at Alpha Connection- Nisqually Nest Short Term Residential Therapeutic Residential Program (STRTP). LPM and LPA, were met and granted access by and Facility Manager Elizabeth Lecona. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. At 9:02 AM, Program Director Amy Osborn, led the physical inspection of the facility with LPM Barnes and LPA Gonzalez. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility’s, activity center, gaming room, kitchen area, refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, client bedrooms, bathroom/showers and garage. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Sports equipment/toys/books/games/computers were observed for children’s recreation time. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintain an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and the menus were posted. All other required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored inside staff's office. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client’s bathrooms was measured to be between 107 and 125 degrees. Per the Administrator, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. The facility has a dining area, kitchen area, living room, open common area/formal living room, a clinician's office for therapeutic services, an entertainment room, and a room where the washer and dryer are located. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. Chemicals and/or poisons, sharp objects/knives are locked in a file cabinet in the staff office.**CONT809C**

First Aid Kits are stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office. LPM and LPA reviewed the facility's disaster and mass casualty plan. The facility currently has two children sharing each bedroom. The facility must ensure that each client is aware of the bedroom sharing policy and document the advisement in the clients’ files. Based on record review, the facility did provide a signed bedroom sharing document in their files. The facility is also required to ensure all client medications refusal are documented and signed by staff in the MARs medication log. LPA informed Administrator that all staff members need to complete the required 40 hour training as noted in ILS standards by October 2021. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 809, and appeal rights were provided to Administrator.

An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cheraki Davis on 11/02/2021 at 2:20 PM. During the inspection, LPA met with Amy Osborn, Administrator and Lesly Rodas, Facility Director and inspected the facility. LPA reviewed two out of two child’s psychotropic records on site at the facility at 2:38 PM. During the review of children’s records, LPA observed one out of two children (C1) did not have a current JV 220 and JV 223. LPA reviewed two staff personnel files on site at the facility at 3:40 PM. LPA began two staff interviews at 3:17 PM. LPA interviewed one out of two children currently taking psychotropic medication beginning at 3:32 PM. One child refuse to interview. LPA conducted exit interview with Amy Osborn at 4:25 PM. LPA provided the Summary Report, LIC 9102, Appeal Rights to Amy Osborn, Administrator upon completion. One Advisory Notes- Technical Violation was issued (refer to LIC 9102) during the inspection.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jose Gonzalez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Christina Barnes conducted a safety inspection. During the safety inspection with facility manager (FM) Misty Hutchings, LPA, and LPM observed a cogitate butt by the back-door entrance and bedroom #3 had a cigarette smoke odor.

On April 11, 2022 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jose Gonzalez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Christina Barnes met with Chief Executive Officer (CEO), Barron Wilson to deliver the finding of a case management. On February 18, 2022 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jose Gonzalez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Christina Barnes conducted a safety inspection at ALPHA CONNECTION-NISQUALLY NEST, THE 366403207. During the safety inspection LPA, and LPM obtained a copy of a video dated 11/29/2021 in which the Program Director (PD), Amy Osborn, and two clients are having a verbal interaction. LPA and LPM observed that PD was confronting client #1 (C1) in a non-trauma informed approach, for smoking a cigarette in C1’s bedroom. PD also threatened to cancel C1’s family visit due to C1 smoking a cigarette in the bedroom. LPA and LPM also observed that PD sprayed C1 with air freshener from a can that she was holding. During the video review, LPA and LPM observed that PD’s further interaction with C1 was also in a non-trauma informed approach. The facility will be cited for the deficiencies under ILS 87072 (11) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, was provided to Chief Executive Officer Barron Wilson.

On May 3, 2022 at 4:32pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, met with Alpha Connection - Nisqually Nest to deliver a case management deficiencies report. LPA Strickland was at the facility speaking with Administrator Amy Osborne in the staff office. At 3:26pm LPA and Administrator opened the door to the staff office to exit when LPA and Administrator observed the smell of Marijuana. Administrator and LPA walked toward the living room where Staff #1 (S1)was siting with Child #1. Administrator and LPA asked S1 what the smell was to which S1 stated she didn't know. LPA then observed the back door of the facility to be open and Staff #2 (S2) came into the living room from the hallway. Administrator asked S2 about the smell. S2 responded that Child #2 and Child #3 were in the room and had been smoking marijuana. Administrator headed back to room #2 where the door to the room was observed to be closed. Administrator knocked on the door and asked permission to come in. Administrator entered the room and after approximately 30 seconds exited the room with a white cap approximately 1 and 1/2 inches in diameter with marijuana residue and half smoked blunt (marijuana rolled in the form of a cigar). Administrator proceeded to dispose of the contraband and reentered the room and confiscated a container that also had marijuana residue in it. The facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87065.2 (b)(1) Personnel Duties (b) Direct care staff shall perform the following duties: (1) supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to Alpha Connection - Nisqually Nest Administrator (ADM), Amy Osborne.

A copy of this report was given to Facility Manager, Pasami Savea. This report was emailed to Pasami Savea, Facility Manager for signature. Original signed reports will be placed in facility file.

On June 10, 2022 at 11:31am, Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA's), Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Jose Gonzalez, conducted a collateral visit to the facility for the purpose of interviewing client #1 and client #2, client #3 (see Confidential Names form (LIC 811), dated June 17, 2022), regarding a prior placement. The interview is not related to this facility. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the facility.

corroborate these allegations with a preponderance of evidence. Confidential interviews denied a lack of supervision resulting in C1 being injured while in care. According to confidential information, C1 and C4 got into an altercation in which staff immediately intervened. According to confidential interviews, C1 was asked if they were fine and offered medical attention to which C1 declined. It was not until the following day that C1 began to complain of pain in their arm and was taken by staff to receive medical care and was diagnosed with a “sprained shoulder.” Confidential interviews also denied that C1 ever tested positive for COVID 19. According to confidential information, although other clients in the home were COVID positive during the time that C1 resided in the home, C1 was tested for COVID on at least two occasions to which C1 tested negative. Confidential interviews also denied allegation that C1 had missed school due to short staffing. According to confidential interviews, if there is insufficient staff for transportation, they will obtain additional help from one of their other facilities. Regarding allegation that C1 was not receiving the required products for their hair care, confidential interviews denied that this was true and stated that whenever the facility does not have a product for a specific type of hair, clients can request it from the staff and they will purchase it. While other confidential information received by Licensing Office stated that these allegations had occurred. Based on confidential information obtained during the course of this investigation, the allegations that Child # 1 (C1) was injured while in care due to lack of supervision, that staff did not report that C1 was COVID positive, that C1 did not attend school on one occasion due to a staffing shortage, and that staff is not assisting C1 with hygiene, more specifically that staff was not providing the required products for C1’s hair care, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Daniel Mena met with Facility Manager, Psami Savea to discuss the investigative findings for the above stated allegations. Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Jose Gonzalez and Daniel Mena conducted an inspection to the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) on February 11, 2022 at 9:01am and on May 27, 2022 at 11:00am. No immediate hazards observed. LPAs Gonzalez and Mena interviewed five staff (S1, S2, S3, S4 & S5), four foster children (C1, C2, C3 & C4), as well as reviewed client and facility records. LPA Mena was unable to interview Child # 5 (C5), due to their current whereabouts being currently unknown. Community Care Licensing received information on February 4, 2022 alleging that Child # 1 (C1) was injured while in care due to lack of supervision, that staff did not report that C1 was COVID positive, and that C1 did not attend school on one occasion due to a staffing shortage. Allegation also claimed that staff is not assisting C1 with hygiene needs, more specifically that staff was not providing the required products for C1’s hair care. LPAs obtained conflicting information in confidential interviews and did not

narrative: evidence. Confidential interviews denied that any “grown men” deliver or drop off drugs and alcohol to any of the clients, and that facility is not only gated, but that there are also motion lights and alarms on the doors and windows of the facility which would have alerted staff if this had occurred. Confidential interviews stated that if drugs and alcohol is obtained by clients, it is usually done so while on AWOL (absence without official leave) status or on approved leave passes. According to confidential interviews, searches are conducted upon return to the facility, but that clients often hide contraband near their private areas which they know will not be searched by staff. LPAs also obtained conflicting information regarding allegation that C4 had access to a knife and had made threats against C1 and other clients. According to confidential information, C1 had never actually had possession of a knife, and that only verbal threats were made. Other confidential information received regarding knife, stated that C4 “might” have made the comment while cooking and holding knife under the supervision of staff but could not recall, while other confidential interviews stated that C4 possibly found a knife inside one of the vehicle’s belonging to one of the boy’s home. Confidential interviews also denied having any knowledge of C1 having any personal items stolen, while other confidential interviews stated that C1 never filled out a reimbursement request when told to report stolen items and even later told some staff that they had found the items that they thought were previously stolen. Based on confidential information obtained during the course of this investigation, the allegations that Child # 1’s (C1) possessions are not being safe guarded, that minors have access to drugs and alcohol due to “grown men” dropping these items off at facility, as well as a lack of supervision by staff that led to Child # 4 (C4) gaining access to a knife and making threats to other minors in care; including C1, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nicole Strickland arrived unannounced to Alpha Connection-Nisqually Nest and met with Administrator (ADM), Evonda Hull to deliver an amended report originally delivered March 14, 2022. A copy of this report along with the Amended report was provided to Administrator (ADM), Evonda Hull.

On July 13, 2022, at 5:00 pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, met with Alpha Connection – Nisqually Nest, Administrator (ADM), Evonda Hull to deliver a case management deficiencies report. According to information obtained by Community Care Licensing (CCL) there were at least two separate incidents where Child #4 (C4) was jumped/beat up by other residents in the facility. Confidential interviews revealed during one occasion Staff # 1 (S1) observed Child #7 (C7) choking C4 and hitting C4 in the head with a skateboard causing C4 to sustain a knot on C4’s head and bruises on C4’s neck, arm and thigh. Confidential interviews reported during an interview with C4, on March 2, 2022, Investigations Branch, Special Investigator (SI) observed C4 to have bruising on the side of C4’s face. Confidential interviews reported C4 was sitting on C4’s bed when Child #2 (C2), Child #6 (C6) and Child #5 (C5) entered the bedroom and “jumped C4, stealing C4’s necklace.” Confidential Interviews reported during the struggle C4 was hit in the face with the necklace. Confidential interviews reported staff attempted to pull C2, C6, and C5 off of C4 and then provided C4 with ointment. Record review was unable to provide evidence that either of these qualifying events were reported to Community Care Licensing and/or the residents authorized representatives. The facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR) regulation 80061(b)(1)(E) REPORTING REQUIREMENTS: (b)(1)(E) Any unusual incident or client absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. Confidential interviews and record review revealed an Serious Incident Report (SIR) for incident dated 3/22/22 written for Child #7 (C7) which notes C7 continued to verbally threaten the other resident (not named) stating C7 was going to “kill (Child #6 [C6]).” The report notes C7 was so enraged that C7 ran to C7’s room, retrieved a pointed comb and threatened to stab the other resident. The report further notes ACYFS staff quickly intervened and created a barrier to prevent C7 from using the comb to cause physical harm, C7 became

frustrated that C7 could not get to the other resident, so C7 started to push ACYFS staff threatening to fight them if they did not let C7 go. Confidential interviews revealed when C7 attempted to stab Child # 6 (C6), Staff #4 (S4) “bear hugged” C7 in order to prevent anyone from being injured. Record review revealed the incident was reported to Community Care Licensing and noted that Law Enforcement was contacted, however the SIR does not include information regarding C7 being placed in a manual restraint. The facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR) regulation 80061(b)(3) REPORTING REQUIREMENTS 80061(b)(3) Each time the child has been placed in a manual restraint, to be reported as required in section 87095.61. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to Alpha Connection – Nisqually Nest, Administrator (ADM), Evonda Hull.

On July 16, 2022, at 8:58 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jose Gonzalez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Christina Barnes made an unannounced case management visit to Alpha Connections Nisqyually Nest (STRTP) regarding the STRTP staff/ client ratio. LPA and LPM conducted a health and safety inspection. During the health and safety inspection, LPA and LPM reviewed the facility log to determine compliance. LPA and LPM observed the facility log to be in compliance during the visit. LPA observed plastic utensils are being used by clients during mealtimes and staff stated clients are provided metal utensils upon request. There were no deficiencies observed during the visit. A copy of the report was discussed and provided to Alpha Connection Facility Manager (FM), Jasmin Morales.

reported C1 was rushed to the Emergency Department after consuming a whole bottle of alcohol. Confidential interviews reported the incident occurred in the late evening of February 10, 2022. Confidential interviews reported C1 and Child #2 (C2) entered the facility bathroom at approximately 11:30 pm were C1 consumed an entire bottle of alcohol, the amount of time C1 and C2 spent in the bathroom is uncertain as confidential interviews report it was a long time with statements noting anywhere from an hour to an hour and a half as time given. Confidential interviews reported staff did try to enter the bathroom and reported was blocked. However, facility communication log was unable to provide evidence of the timeline for the evening as the communication log for February 10, 2022 had no entries. A review of the Serious Incident Report (SIR) provided for the incident written by the facility, incident occurred on 2/11/2022 at 12:38 am and reported time in bathroom was fifteen minutes. Confidential interviews reported when C1 exited the bathroom staff observed C1 to stumble out of the bathroom stumbling words and shortly after C1 began vomiting. Confidential interviews reported feeling concerned as it was unknown if other substances were consumed or if C1’s prescribed psychotropic medications may cause dangerous side effects. Confidential interviews reported that staff contacted Administrator (ADM) who was overheard to say let C1 sleep it off, not to call 9-1-1, and continue to assess. Confidential interviews reported when staff arrived for the overnight shift, the staff was made aware of the concerns for C1 and observed C1 to have labored breathing and reported C1’s color to be changing prompting staff to call 9-1-1. Confidential interviews and record review revealed C1 was transported to the hospital on 2/11/2022 at 0233 hours and diagnosed with Acute Alcohol Intoxication and dehydration. Based on confidential interviews and record review the allegations Lack of supervision resulted in minor (Child #1 [C1]) consuming excessive amount of alcohol while in care, requiring hospitalization, Medical treatment for minor (C1) in care was not sought with reasonable promptness that met the needs of the child and Minor (C1) was not properly supervised while in care are substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87065.2 (b)(1) PERSONNEL DUTIES (b) Direct care staff shall perform the following duties: (1) supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups, 87072(c) PERSONAL RIGHTS (c) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified n Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9 as applicable, and 87065.2 (a)(2) PERSONNEL DUTIES (a)The Facility manager shall meet the requirements of Health and Safety code section 1522.4 and be responsible for: (2) Supervising the direct care staff, ensuring appropriate care and ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

supervision is provided to the children in accordance with applicable law, licensing regulations, and the facilities polices. An immediate civil penalty is being assessed to the facility for violation of 87065.2 (a)(2) PERSONNEL DUTIES (a)The Facility manager shall meet the requirements of Health and Safety code section 1522.4 and be responsible for: (2) Supervising the direct care staff, ensuring appropriate care and supervision is provided to the children in accordance with applicable law, licensing regulations, and the facilities polices. A civil penalty for repeat violation of 87065.2 (b)(1) PERSONNEL DUTIES (b) Direct care staff shall perform the following duties: (1) supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups is also being assessed to the facility. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along civil penalty assessments (LIC 421FC, and LIC 421IM) with appeal rights to Alpha Connections Nisqually Nest, Administrator (ADM), Evonda Hull

narrative: Additional confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff did not document on Medication Administration Record Sheet (MARS) logbook that the medications were administered to minors. Confidential interviews disclosed that facility staff had to contact the facility staff from the previous shift of 07/04/2022 to ensure the medications were administered per doctor orders. The Department also received an allegation that the facility was operating out of ratio. Confidential interviews revealed that on 07/05/2022, Staff #1 (S1) had transported Staff #2 (S2) home, which left the Facility Manager (FM) with six minors. Additional confidential interviews revealed that the FM was aware that the facility would be out of ratio and had instructed S1 to take three minors on the transport to S2’s home. Confidential interviews disclosed that it was observed by a County Social Worker (CSW) that FM was out of ratio with six clients. FM admitted that the facility was out of ratio with six minors present with only one staff member on 07/05/22. Based on LPA confidential interviews and County Social Worker observations, the facility staff did not maintain accurate medical records for minor(s) in care, and the facility was operating out of ratio are substantiated as the preponderance of evidence standard has been met for the allegations. The facility will be cited for a violation of the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87070(b)(13)(H) Children’s Records and 87065.5 (a)(1) Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Program Director (PD), Amy Osborn..

narrative: On August 18, 2022 at 3:45 PM, Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Kim Robinson met with the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Administrator, Amy Osborn, to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP). On July 13, 2022, the Department concluded a complaint investigation of allegations that a seventeen-year-old client (C1) suffered acute ethanol intoxication, resulting with emergency hospitalization. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated August 18, 2022). The allegations were substantiated and the STRTP was cited under the Interim Licensing Standards, Section 87072(c) Personal Rights and 87065.2 (b)(1) Personnel Duties with a $500.00 immediate civil penalty assessment. The investigative evidence gathered shows Alpha Connection – Nisqually Nest (AC-NN) staff neglected to supervise and provide timely medical care of C1, allowing a situation that endangered the health of C1. Based on the analysis of the medical reports and interviews, the Department has determined that an enhanced civil penalty is warranted for STRTP staff neglecting to supervise and provide timely medical care to ensure the well-being of all minors in care as required in the Interim Licensing Standards. Section 11165.2 of the Penal Code defines neglect as negligent treatment or the maltreatment of a child by a person responsible for the child’s welfare under circumstances indicating harm or threatened harm to the child’s health or welfare. This section describes a number of more or less direct and (always) willful acts that constitute physical abuse. Pursuant to the Enhanced Civil Penalty law, Health and Safety (H&S) code section 1548 (f)(1)(A), the Department will be issuing an immediate civil penalty of $2,000.00. An exit interview was completed, and appeal rights discussed. A copy of this report, the Confidential Names List, Appeal Rights, and a Civil Penalty Assessment - Serious Bodily Injury/Physical Abuse (Form 421-D) were provided to the administrator.

All observations were corrected day of visit. LPA and CFS reviewed the medication log to determine compliance. LPA and CFS observed medication board change for client #1 (C1) dates August 9, 10, and 11, 2022. PD will provide additional information by end of business day regarding medication board change for C1. A copy of the report was discussed and provided to Alpha Connection Program Director (PD) Amy Osborn.

Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Amy Osborn.
investigation_findings: 13On August 23, 2022, at 12:51 pm, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s) Jose Gonzalez and Joon Choi met with Program Director (PD), Amy Osborn to deliver the findings for the above-stated allegations. LPA conducted a safety inspection at the facility at 2:48 pm on March 18, 2022, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. LPA also reviewed six of six clients’ records. During the investigation, interviews were conducted with six of six clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6), Facility Manager (FM), and Staff #1 (S1). The Department received a complaint on March 18, 2022, that alleged facility staff are not providing supervision to the minors in care. Confidential interviews indicate that facility staff are providing supervision for the minors in care. Additional confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff intervened immediately when the residents argued or fought. Confidential interviews indicate that the facility staff are checking on the minors every 15 to 30 minutes. Additional confidential interviews revealed that minors are picking on other minors when the facility staff are not supervising the minors. **CONTINUED on LIC 9099**

narrative:
On March 23, 2022, at 1:00pm an Informal Office Conference was held with the Alpha Connection Youth and Family Services Inc. (ACYFS) Corporation via Microsoft Teams. The following people were in attendance: Regional Manager (RM) LaCresha Cook, Licensing Program Managers (LPMs) Christina Barnes, Cheraki Davis, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jose Gonzalez, Law Enforcement Contact Review Unit, (LPM) Angela King, Department of Health Care Services (DHCS) Jennifer Margedant, San Bernardino Behavioral Health Representatives Melissa Graham, Olivia Oliveros, and Diane Wolkenhauer, System of Care (SOC) Marjana Jackson and Dianna Wagner, San Bernardino County STRTP Coordinator Evelyn Martinez, San Bernardino County Children and Family Services (CFS) Amy Guisa, San Bernardino County investigation social workers Raquel Holguin and Norma Jimenez, Tulare County investigating social worker Emergency Response Lucia Rodriguez, Tulare County CWS Social Worker Brenda Bustos, Tehama County Angela Ackley, CFS manager, placement resource division Tracy Raymond, California Alliance for Child and Family Services Ric Weisgal, SSSP Fallon Greene. ACYFS Administrative staff, Chief Executive Officer Barron Wilson, Program Director/ Facility Administrator Amy Osborn, Facility Administrator Evonnda Hull, Clinician Lindsay Ruston, Clinician, Mark Daniels, and Dan Thorne. Nisqually Nest 366403207 The following information was discussed: · Administrative oversight · Trauma Informed Care, Services and Approach · Head of Service Capacity · Law enforcement service calls *******CONTINUED on LIC 809 C******

Absence Without Leave (AWOLS) · Clients have poor school attendance · Ongoing client substance abuse (alcohol and drugs) · Clients’ lack of motivation towards the program · Lack of varied activities · Staff Supervision · Staff unable to manage defiant clients · Lack of detail in Special Incident Reports (SIRs), under-reporting (minimizing), and failure to report · Failure to follow program statement · Attempting to handle serious problems without involving law enforcement · Supervision of clients · Administrative Rounds · Lack of reporting to CCL, authorized representatives and San Bernardino Behavioral Health contract consultant · CSEC The Department recommended the licensee take full advantage of the System of Care support service recommendations, Law Enforcement Contact Review Unit advice for submitting law enforcement incident reports, San Bernardino Behavioral Health contract consultants’ recommendations for the Head of Service and Department of Health Care Services request to update the facilities therapy sessions policy. RM Cook emphasized the importance of following the actual policies and procedures written in the program statement, corrective action and facility oversight. The facility was given until 04/8/2022 to submit the plan of corrections to Community Care Licensing (CCL) for approval. The licensee agrees to the following: 1. CCL is recommending an increase in staffing to ratios to increase the staff to client ratios. The licensee will submit a staff supervision plan. ******CONTINUED on LIC 809 C ******

1. The licensee will submit proof of daily administrative rounds completed by Administrator or administrative staff. Overnight rounds shall be included between the hours of 9pm and 6am to check on the well-being of clients and staff. The visits shall be at various hours, a minimum of 15 minutes, and shall be documented in the daily logbook. The visiting Administrator or administrative staff shall sign the logbook, state the time and date of arrival, time and date of departure, and any unusual observations. 2. Submit a plan on how the licensee will address the lack of staff involvement in preventing/dissuading clients engaging in CSEC behaviors. Plan will include how facility will encourage client involvement in preventing CSEC behaviors. 3. The licensee shall train staff to immediately contact law enforcement if staff believe that a crime has occurred or is in progress. Proof of training will be submitted. 4. The licensee will submit a plan on how incident reports are reviewed by administration, including the facility’s plan of action/correction and how the facility will ensure the appropriate agencies are receiving the incident reports. 5. Within 24 hours of an incident, Administrator will submit an incident report to CCL, placement agencies, authorized representatives, and San Bernardino Behavioral Health contract consultant regarding SIRs with client-involved aggression/assaults, regardless of the location of the incident, when a client refuses to go to school, drug use, drug paraphernalia, and contraband found in placement. Provide full details describing the incident and the disposition including the facility’s plan of action/correction. 6. The licensee shall submit a report of 2022 planned activities from January through March 31, 2022. The report needs to include the dates, times, and location of each activity, the names of clients who participated in each activity, and include the names of clients who did not participate and the reasons why. 7. The licensee will submit a plan to reduce AWOLs. 8. The licensee shall submit a plan to address smoking and drug use at the facility. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report was emailed to Barron Wilson. A copy of the signed report will be placed in the facility file.

Administrator denied that the facility had bed bugs, however, Administrator added that due to the location of the facility some insects would enter the facility, so pest control began to service the facility twice a month. County social workers stated that when they visited the facility, it was always clean, and they did not see any cockroaches or other insects. Furthermore, county social workers added that they had not seen any bite marks on the clients to suggest the facility had a beg bug problem. County social worker #2 (CSW2) added that he had not been told by his client that the facility had beg bugs or an insect problem. During inspection, LPA didn’t observe insects. LPA was provided with receipts of new mattresses purchased, and invoices from pest control services. Other confidential witnesses stated that they had seen bugs on client’s beds and had not seen the facility receive pest control services or do anything to prevent or stop the insect problem. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation that the facility had bed bugs may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report was explained and provided to Pasami Savea.
investigation_findings: 13On September 8, 2022, at 10:18 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michael Almaraz arrived at the facility and met with facility manager, Pasami Savea, to issue the finding for the above stated allegation. The complaint investigation was conducted by LPA Almaraz. On July 7, 2022, at 8:21 AM LPA Almaraz arrived at the facility to initiate the investigation, conducted a safety inspection, and interviewed five staff and three clients. During the inspection, LPA reviewed facility records and six client records. Additionally, LPA Almaraz conducted an interview with two county social workers and one staff. Three of six clients refused to participate in LPA’s interview. On June 27, 2022, the Department received a complaint alleging the facility had insects. More specifically, it was alleged that the facility had bed bugs and when informed of the bed bugs, the Administrator stated that they were cockroaches. Confidential witnesses stated that they had not seen or been told that the facility had insects while others stated that they were told of insects but never seen insects. (continued on next page...)

Five of five children (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5), three staff and facility administrator were interviewed. It was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that C1 was engaging in inappropriate behaviors due to lack of supervision. Confidential staff interviews reported that C1 was leaving the facility absent without leave (awol) and engaging in inappropriate behaviors. Confidential interviews reported that when staff became aware of what C1 was doing while being awol, staff put in a 14-day notice on C1 and staff was attempting to ensure that none of the other clients in the home where engaging with C1. The interviews that were provided to the LPA were not consistent and did not provide any specific details regarding lack of supervision by staff. Confidential interviews disclosed that staff would verbally redirect C1 and encourage C1 not to AWOL while other information obtained from confidential interviews stated that staff did not intervene when C1 AWOL’d resulting in inappropriate behaviors. narrative: Confidential interviews reported conflicting statements on how staff handle residents AWOLing from the facility. Confidential interviews reported some staff will try to verbally intervene and discourage the resident(s) from leaving and will occasionally follow the residents down the street when they do leave. Additional confidential interviews reported staff do not make any attempts to stop the residents from leaving. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute the facility failed to follow the program statement resulting in CSEC behavior. Confidential interviews and record review revealed the facility had been working with the residents County Social Worker and conducted Child Family Team meetings to address the resident’s behaviors. Additional confidential interviews could not confirm CSEC behavior was or was not discussed or addressed in the CFT meetings. Based on record review and confidential interviews the allegations of facility did not follow their emergency intervention plan and the facility failed to follow the program statement resulting in CSEC (Commercially Sexually Exploited Children) behavior, may or may not have occurred, however they are not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was provided along with appeal rights to Alpha Connections – Nisqually Nest Administrator (ADM), Amy Osborn.
investigation_findings: 13On September 22, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA's) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Joon Choi, met with Alpha Connections – Nisqually Nest Administrator (ADM), Amy Osborn, to deliver the findings for the above stated allegations. LPA conducted an inspection of the facility on May 3, 2022 at approximately 12:30pm and no immediate deficiencies were observed. The investigation was conducted by LPA Strickland and included interviews with four foster youth (Child #1 [C1], Child #3 [C3], Child #5 [C5], and Child #7 [C7]), three staff (Staff #1 [S1], Staff #2 [S2] and Staff #3 [S3]), Open Case Investigator (OCI), and ADM. In addition, county records and facility records were reviewed. On April 28, 2022, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received two allegations alleging the facility did not follow their emergency intervention plan and the facility failed to follow the program statement resulting in CSEC (Commercially Sexually Exploited Children) behavior. Record review revealed on April 25, 2022 at approximately 6:45pm two residents AWOLed from the facility for two days. Record review and confidential interviews reported while the two residents were AWOL from the facility they participated in CSEC behaviors. Record review was unable to provide documentation of what if anything was done by the facility to discourage the residents from AWOLing prior to this incident. Continued on page

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst, Daniel Mena and Licensing Program Manager, Natasha Dunlap conducted a teleconference meeting with Alpha Connection, Program Director, Amy Osborn, Clinician, Lindsay Baston and Consultant, Dan Thorne to discuss and review the probationary conditions that go into effect once Alpha Connections STRTP reverts back to a Group Home on January 01, 2023. On December 31, 2022, the STRTP applications for Alpha Connection Group Home For Children, License No. 366412000, 21398 Pine Ridge, Apple Valley, CA 92307; ACYFSAnoka Ranch, License No. 366401649, 22675 Anoka Road, Apple Valley, CA 92308; ACYFS-Shoshonee Place, License No. 366402331, 20048 Shoshonee Road, Apple Valley, CA 92307; and ACYFS Nisqually Nest, License No. 366403207, 12915 Chief Joseph Road, Apple Valley, CA 92308 (collectively the "facilities") are terminated and Alpha will transition/convert back to its group home licenses subject to a three (3) year probationary term with the following conditions: 1. Alpha shall operate each facility in substantial compliance with the regulations and statutes governing the operation of a group home. 2. During the period of Probation, the Department in its sole discretion may conduct unannounced site visits for the purpose of determining whether there is substantial compliance with the regulations and statutes governing the operation of the group home. 3. Alpha will submit an updated group home plan of operation and program statement for each group home to the Department within 30 days of the effective date of this Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release including but not limited to:

a. A description of trauma-informed and evidence-based intervention and de-escalation techniques that will be used to promote the safety of all individuals in the facility, including but not limited to children or nonminor dependents who have a propensity for behaviors that result in harm to self or others. b. A runaway plan that includes a continuum of non-physical interventions and strategies to de-escalate a situation where a child has indicated his /her intent to run away, that will be utilized by staff to prevent and Alpha to runaway behaviors. 4. Alpha shall ensure that all children are supervised 24 hours per day, 7 days per week, in accordance with its Program Statement and Plan of Operation and licensing regulations. 5. There shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows: a. During the hours of 7 am to 10 pm, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every three children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum b. During the hours of 10pm to 7am, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every six children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum. c. In addition to staff required in paragraph 1 or 2, when one or more children are present at the facility, at least one direct care staff shall be on call and capable of arriving at the facility within 30 minutes. d. If a child requires special care and supervision because of age, behavior or other factors, the number of awake and on-duty care staff shall be increased. 6. Any administrator employed by Alpha to operate the facility shall have, at minimum, the education and experience specified in California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation 84064 and shall be certified as a group home

administrator pursuant to California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation 84064. 2. No exceptions shall be made to these requirements during probation. 7. Alpha shall ensure that a qualified and certified administrator is present and available on premises of each facility, a minimum of 20 hours a week. In the administrator's absence, a designated substitute as defined in the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation 84064(d) shall be present and available on the premises of the facility. Alpha shall timely notify the Department of any change in administrator and the name, address, date of hire, background, qualifications, and certification of the new administrator. 8. Alpha shall develop a comprehensive training curriculum for all new and current staff who provide direct care services to children in care. The content of the training shall include, but not be limited to, the following: supervision of youth, reporting requirements to the Department and reporting requirements as a mandated child abuse reporter, personal rights, crisis prevention, and emergency intervention, including Alpha's runaway plan, and all applicable licensing laws and regulations. Training shall be mandatory for all employees. A detailed description of the in-service training and a record of all staff who attended the trainings shall be maintained and made available to the department upon request. a. Training to include (ii) Trauma Informed Interventions and Treatment Practices. Two (2) hours of instruction in the physical and psychosocial needs of the children, including behavior management, de-escalation techniques, and trauma-informed crisis management planning, including the use of emergency interventions. The training plan shall be designed to ensure the provision of trauma-informed services and be appropriate for the population and shall consider the training needs and skill level of staff b. All outstanding training, including but not limited to the training listed above, shall be completed by staff within 45 days of the group home transition.

c. Additional staff hired after the transition to the group home must complete the trauma informed training within 45 days of hire and any additional training must be completed within the time frames outlined in the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation 84065. In the Matter of Alpha Connections Youth & Family Services, Inc. v. CDSS Case No. CVR12203769 Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release 9. Alpha shall adhere to the reporting requirements as defined in California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulations 80061, 84061, in the regulations and statutes governing the operation of a group home. Alpha shall report to the Licensing office the following: any unusual incident, including, but not limited to, client death or injury which requires medical treatment, any suspected physical plant changes, and all unexplained absences. These incidents must be reported by the next working day, and a written report of the incident must be submitted within seven days following the occurrence of the incident. All unusual incident reports shall be complete, including addendums and follow-up information. 10. Alpha shall ensure compliance with California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulations 84068.1, 84068.2, 84068.3 and 84068.4 regarding Intake Procedure, Needs and Services Plans and Modifications, and Removal and/or Discharge Procedures. Prior to and during placement Alpha shall determine whether it can provide the services necessary to meet the child's needs and to effect discharge if it is determined that Alpha cannot provide the services necessary to meet the child's needs. Further, Alpha shall ensure that an appropriate assessment of a child's compatibility with other children in care is conducted during the intake process and is re-evaluated on a continuance basis when individual needs dictate. Alpha agrees that it shall not accept or retain, and will promptly discharge with written notice to the authorized representative, any child for whom it cannot adequately and safely provide care, any child who requires a higher level of care, and any child who would cause the Alpha to violate laws and regulations, or the conditions of Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release.

11. Alpha shall ensure the personal rights of all children in its care including the right to be provided safe, healthful, and comfortable accommodations to meet their needs, and shall be free from corporal or unusual punishment, pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other action of a punitive nature. 12. Alpha shall ensure that each child in care receives first aid and medical services, including arrangements and transportation. Further Alpha shall ensure that medications and any other toxic products are properly stored and kept in a safe and locked place that is not accessible to children in care or other persons other than employees responsible for the supervision of the centrally stored medication pursuant to California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation sections 80075 and 84075. Employees of Alpha shall immediately document on the medication log any refusals of medication by a child in care and shall follow-up with proper notification to the child's physician. 13. Alpha's Board of Directors shall be active in ensuring accountability and ensuring that Alpha complies with all applicable regulations, by reviewing, on a quarterly basis Alpha's operation and documents as specified in Health and Safety code section 1520. 1(f), including a review of special incident reports and all licensing reports issued by the Department. 14. For the duration of the probationary period, Alpha shall provide all current and prospective parents or responsible parties of children in the facility with a copy of the settlement terms, as outlined in the Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release. Proof of Acknowledgement shall be kept in the respective child’s record and available for inspection by the Department. 15. Alpha will work collaboratively with the Department to comply and fully implement all Plan of Corrections and agreements. This Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release supersedes any Compliance Plan or Corrective Action Plan that has previously been submitted by the Alpha to the Department. A copy of this report was provided and emailed for signatures.

narrative: ***This is an amended report of a report that was originally issued on 9/8/2022*** On May 6, 2022, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation alleging Minors are smoking marijuana while in care. Specifically, it was reported during three out of four unannounced visits County Social Worker #1 (CSW1) observed residents inside their rooms smoking marijuana. Record review of the facilities communication log/running log revealed during the period for April 13, 2022 through May 1, 2022 staff noted 14 separate incidents were residents (Child #1 [C1], Child #2 [C2], Child #3 [C3], Child #4 [C4] and/or Child #5 [C5]) were observed to be smoking alone or with other residents. Confidential interviews confirmed that residents smoke in the bedrooms/bathrooms or in the backyard of the facility. Based on confidential interviews and record review the allegation minors are smoking marijuana while in care is substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87087 (c) Buildings and Grounds. The licensee shall prohibit smoking in the facility and on the grounds of the facility. . A copy of the report was discussed and provided along appeal rights to Alpha Connections – Nisqually Program Director (PD) Elysia Moore.
