narrative: On November 7, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi and LPA Nicole Strickland, conducted an unannounced visit to the facility, to deliver an amended document initially delivered on September 8, 2022.

Record review of the facilities communication log/running log revealed during the period for April 13, 2022 through May 1, 2022 staff noted 14 separate incidents were residents (Child #1 [C1], Child #3 [C3], Child #5 [C5], Child #8 [C8], and/or Child #9 [C9]) were observed to be smoking alone or with other residents. Information obtained from confidential interviews disclosed that staff would not always address clients who were smoking. Confidential interviews stated that when staff chose to address clients smoking on facility grounds, staff would direct clients to smoke outside or to open the window at the facility. The facility addressed the issue of clients smoking on grounds by providing additional staff trainings. An additional allegation alleging staff did not report an incident involving a minor was received by CCL. Record review was unable to provide evidence of the facility reporting Child #3 (C3) and Child #8 (C8) going AWOL on April 25, 2022. Record review revealed the facility submitted an incident report noting C3 and C8 were returned to the facility on April 27, 2022 after being AWOL for two days. A review of the facilities communication log/running log revealed on April 25, 2022 C3 and C8 left the facility at @ 6:45pm and were considered AWOL. Additional record review was unable to provide evidence that the 14 separate instances regarding the allegation of staff allowing minors to do drugs in the facility where (Child #1 [C1], Child #3 [C3], Child #5 [C5], Child #8 [C8], and/or Child #9 [C9]) were observed smoking in the facility were reported as required. Two additional allegations alleging staff called minors inappropriate names and staff (Administrator [ADM]), made inappropriate comments towards minors was also received by CCL. Specifically it was reported Child #5 (C5) was having an issue with school and when C5 addressed the issue with staff and ADM, ADM told C5 “tell someone who cares.” Additional confidential interviews provided consistent statements of ADM referring to and calling at least three minors (Child #1 [C1]), Child #3 [C3] and C5) as sluts, hoes, and b*****s. Confidential interviews further reported when ADM would attempt to confiscate the minors contraband ADM was heard saying “give me the s**t, you nasty slut.” An additional allegation was received by CCL alleging staff withheld minor’s (Child #5 [C5]) allowance. Specific information as to which staff withheld the minor’s allowance was not disclosed. Confidential interviews reported in March of 2022, C5 had C5’s allowance withheld for talking with CPS, CWS, or licensing. Record review could not confirm C5 receiving C5’s allowance for the week of March 9, 2022, April 6, 2022 and April 20, 2022. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

Based on confidential interviews and record review the allegations of Staff allowing minors to do drugs in the facility, Staff did not report an incident involving a minor, Staff called minors inappropriate names, Staff made inappropriate comments towards minors, and Staff withheld minor’s allowance are substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. This is a violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87087 BUILDINGS AND GROUNDS 87087(c) The Licensee shall prohibit smoking in the facility and on the grounds of the facility; ILS standard 87061 REPORTING REQUIREMENTS 87061(b)(4) Any unusual absence or failure of a child to return or inform the facility that they are not returning for a specified period of time; two violations of ILS standard 87072 PERSONAL RIGHTS 87072(c)(10) To be accorded dignity in their personal relationships with staff and other persons and 87072 PERSONAL RIGHTS 87072(c)(18) To receive an allowance. Resolved due to expiration of the STRTP license, as outlined in the September 2022 settlement agreement. A copy of the report and appeal rights were given to a facility representative. Original signature placed on file.

illegal drugs but refused to disclose which staff. Additional confidential interviews confirmed the residents use of marijuana and/or methamphetamine however, denied knowledge of staff providing the illegal drugs to minors stating they are not sure how and where the residents obtained the illegal drugs. Two additional allegations alleging staff (Staff #4 [S4]) hit minor (Child #5 [C5]) and staff (S4) restrained minor (C5) were received by CCL. Specifically it was reported S4 hit C5 in the face and put her in a choke hold; unknown date of incident. Record review and confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute these allegations. Confidential interviews reported that the facility does not go hands on when there are issues at the facility. Conflicting confidential interviews reported the facility only restrains as a last resort. Confidential interviews reported C5 “went off” on S4 hitting and kicking and even spitting on S4 . Confidential interviews reported S4 was attempting to restrain C5 in order to protect S4 and hit C5 during the restraint. Record review revealed an incident between S4 and C5 occurred on 4/8/2022 where C5 hit S4, however there is no documentation that S4 attempted to restrain C5 during the incident. An additional allegation was received by CCL alleging minors are forced out of the facility. Specific information as to which staff force minors out of facility was not disclosed, however it was disclosed that minors are forced out in order for Child Protective Services (CPS), County Social Workers (CSW), or licensing not to have the opportunity to speak with minors. Confidential interviews provided conflicting statements regarding staff forcing minors out of the facility. Confidential interviews reported that once the facility is aware that CPS, CWS, or licensing is in the area staff contact administration and then are directed by administration to take residents on impromptu outings. Confidential interviews reported impromptu outings include going to get ice cream, going to IHop or to the store. Additional confidential interviews deny the allegation and report residents are only taken on approved outings. An additional allegation alleging Staff (Administrator [ADM]) harassed minor (C5). Specifically it was reported that ADM would purposely attempt to get a reaction from C5 by touching and moving C5’s belongings. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute ADM harassing C5. Confidential interviews reported many of the residents would claim to feel harassed when staff are attempting to redirect them or providing residents with reminders to stick to the program. Conflicting confidential interviews reported that staff’s, specifically ADM’s redirection and/or reminders were more than just redirection or

simple reminders as staff including ADM would include inappropriate comments and inappropriate names when talking with minors. Based on record review and confidential interviews the allegations staff provided illegal drugs to minors, staff (Staff #4 [S4]) hit minor (Child #5 [C5]), staff (S4) restrained minor (C5), minors are forced out of the facility, and staff (Administrator [ADM]) harassed minor (C5), may or may not have occurred, however they are not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of the report and appeal rights were given to a facility representative. Original signature placed on file.

always address clients who were smoking. provided minors with vape pens. An additional allegation alleging staff are allowing the minors to engage in physical altercations was received by CCL. Confidential interviews reported that some staff intervene when there is a physical altercation at the facility, while other staff are scared to intervene. CCL also received an allegation alleging staff do not properly maintain the facility. Specifically it was reported that the facility is often dirty. Additional interviews reported when an issue is observed maintence is contacted and issue is addressed. Confidential interviews and record review could not confirm or dispute the allegation. An additional allegation alleging staff do not keep the facility free from pests. Specifically it was reported that the facility had bed bugs. Confidential interviews and record review could not confirm or dispute that the bites C5 had were received by bugs while at the facility. CCL received an additional allegation alleging Minor has access to drugs while in care. Confidential interviews provided consistent statements of residents use of drugs. Confidential interviews and record review could not confirm or dispute how and where the residents are accessing the drugs. An additional allegation alleging staff do not ensure facility has adequate amount of food was received by CCL. Confidential interviews provided conflicting statements of the residents only having noodles to eat by the end of the week as the facility runs out of food prior to the weekly shopping. Additional confidential interviews reported staff cook for the residents and residents choose not to eat what is prepared and therefore eat noodles or junk food. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

Other confidential interviews disclosed that the deliveries were thought to be food deliveries. An additional allegation alleging Staff did not prevent minors from engaging in inappropriate interactions with each other was received by CCL. Confidential interviews and record review confirm residents did engage in physical altercations. Confidential interviews reported varying accounts of how staff handled the physical altercations. Confidential interviews reported some staff would attempt to de-escalate the involved residents by using crisis communication, stepping in between the residents, and/or separating the residents involved. Additional confidential interviews reported some staff were hesitant and/or too fearful to get involved so they did not intervene. Confidential interviews and record review could not confirm or dispute the allegation. CCL received an additional allegation of minors do not have adequate meals. Record review revealed menus are created and food shopping is completed weekly. Confidential interviews reported conflicting reports of the facility not adhering to the posted menu due to residents not wanting what is on the menu. Confidential interviews reported residents are often required to make their own microwavable meals or provided with noodles to eat. Confidential interviews could not confirm, or dispute minors do not have adequate meals. An allegation alleging staff (unknown) refused to transport minor (Child #5 [C5]) to court ordered visitation. Confidential interviews and record review provided conflicting reports of how the facility handled transportation to court ordered visitations. Confidential interviews reported the facility is often short staffed and unable to take residents for visitations and the facility will often take residents on a different day stating they got mixed up with dates in order to make it appear as though attempts were made to adhere to court orders. Additional confidential interviews reported that all court ordered visitations are adhered to. Confidential interviews and record review were unable to confirm, or dispute staff refused to transport minor to court ordered visitation. CCL received an additional allegation staff (unknown) sleep while on shift. Confidential interviews provided conflicting reports of staff sleeping while on shift. Confidential interviews reported due to staff shortages staff was often asked to work long hours and were observed sleeping while on shift. Additional confidential interviews denied witnessing or knowledge of staff sleeping while on shift. Confidential interviews and record review could not confirm or dispute staff (unknown) sleep while on shift. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

An additional allegation alleging staff (unknown) interfered with minors (Child #5 [C5]) right to file a complaint with licensing was received by CCL. Specifically, it was reported licensing gave C5 a business card for C5 to contact licensing which was confiscated so C5 could not contact licensing. Confidential interviews reported facility staff, specifically the Administrator, conduct room checks in the mornings and if business cards are found they are confiscated. Confidential interviews confirmed room checks for contraband are conducted in the mornings by administration. Confidential interviews provided conflicting statements of what items are confiscated when room checks are completed. Confidential interviews reported the only items confiscated are contraband while other interviews disclosed business cards for both licensing and county workers have been confiscated if they were visible during the room check. An allegation alleging facility has pests was received by CCL. Specifically, it was reported Child #5 (C5) was observed to have six bug bites on her body. Record review revealed earlier in the year the facility did undergo treatment for bed bugs and other insects. Record review revealed the facility replaced soft surfaces including mattresses, couches, and curtains. Confidential interviews revealed although the facility had been treated earlier in the year bugs and insects were still a routine problem in the facility. Confidential interviews and record review could not confirm or dispute where and when C5 was bitten. An allegation alleging the facility is malodorous was also received by CCL. Specifically, it was reported the facility smelled of mold and was causing congestion problems for residents. Confidential interviews reported the facility often had a heavy smell of bleach or other cleaning products. Confidential interviews reported the heavy cleaning solution smell was due to cleaning and to cover other smells in the facility and not mold. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute the allegation. CCL also received an allegation alleging staff (unknown) left minor (Child #1 [C1]) at the park unsupervised. Specifically it was reported C1 was taken to the park for a two-hour supervised outing with unknown staff, after an hour of being at the park unknown staff was called by the facility and was told to return, leaving C1 at the park. Confidential interviews provided conflicting reports of C1 being left at the park. Confidential interviews reported all of C1’s outings are required to be supervised and at no time was C1 left at the park unsupervised. Conflicting confidential interviews reported staff would often drop residents off for supervised visits but would not stay with the residents. Record review was unable to provide evidence of C1’s outing and/or C1 being left at the park. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute the allegation. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of the report and appeal rights were given to a facility representative. Original signature placed on file.

On February 14, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daniel Mena arrived at Alpha Connection- Group Home (GH). LPA Mena was granted access by Administrator, Evonda Hull. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. Administrator led the physical inspection of the facility with LPA Mena. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility’s visitor's room, living room, bonus room, kitchen area, dinning area, refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, 3 client bedrooms, and 2 bathroom/showers. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Sports equipment/toys/books/games/computers were observed for children’s recreation time. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintain an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and the menus were posted. All other required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored inside staff's office. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. Hot water temperature was measured. Administrator stated that water was adjusted at time of visit. Per the Administrator, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. The facility has a dining area, kitchen area, living room, open common area/formal living room, an office, and a room where the washer and dryer are located. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. CONTINUES on LIC 809C

Chemicals and/or poisons, sharp objects/knives are locked in a file cabinet in the staff office. First Aid Kits are stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office. LPA reviewed the facility's disaster plan. The facility currently has two children sharing each bedroom. The facility must ensure that each client is aware of the bedroom sharing policy and document the advisement in the clients’ files. Based on record review, the facility did provide a signed bedroom sharing document in their files. LPA Reviewed client's medication and medication logs. See attached LIC 809D for cited deficiency. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report were provided to Administrator.

On March 12, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daniel Mena arrived at Alpha Connection- Group Home (GH). LPA Mena was granted access by Facility Director, Morgan Tyler. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. Program Administrator, Evonnda Hull led the physical inspection of the facility with LPA Mena. A physical plant inspection was completed and included living room, bonus room, kitchen/dinning area, refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, 3 client bedrooms, and 2 bathroom/showers. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Sports equipment/toys/books/games/computers were observed for children’s recreation time. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintain an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and the menus were posted. All other required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. met_with: CEO Barron Wilson and Program Director Amy Osborn
narrative:
On October 8, 2020 at 10:00am, a virtual office conference was held with Alpha Connection Youth and Family Services (ACYFS). Due to COVID-19 this office conference was conducted virtually utilizing Google Duo. The following individuals were in attendance: Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Christina Barnes, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kendal Zirbes, ACYFS Chief Executive Officer Barron Wilson, and ACYFS Program Director Amy Osborn. The following concerns were discussed during the meeting: · Substantiated complaint investigations regarding sexual misconduct by facility staff with the youth in care. These serious substantiated allegations occurred at Alpha Connection Shoshonee Place (366402331) and Alpha Connection Anoka Ranch (366401649). · Serious Incident Reports regarding physical altercations at the Alpha Connection Shoshonee Place (366402331) and Alpha Connection Nisqually Nest (366403207). During the meeting, LPM Barnes discussed the sexual misconduct allegations. ACYFS representatives were given the opportunity to discuss actions that have been taken since the incidents occurred. Per ACYFS, the administrative and hiring staff attended a three-hour training on “Confronting Unacceptable Behavior with Professionalism”. This training was conducted by an outside trainer. Furthermore, ACYFS is working with the employment broker, People Inc. a “PEO”. ACYFS stated since these serious incidents, the hiring process has changed. The current hiring process includes, three steps: 1) the interview 2) risk assessment screening 3) personal evaluation. ACYFS stated direct care staff receive ongoing training regarding maintaining appropriate boundaries with the youth in care and personal rights training. ACYFS expressed the minimum age for an employee is 21 years of age and with this new hiring process ACYFS believes qualified staff will be employed. Report continued on page two

Report continued from page one LPA Zirbes discussed the incidents regarding physical altercations. LPA Zirbes expressed the facility needs to evaluate each scenario and evaluate how the physical altercations could have been avoided. LPA Zirbes also requested the incident reports tell a story of the incident, to include triggering events leading up to the incident, details of the incident and specific outcomes. All parties discussed the need to be proactive instead of reactive to incidents. ACYFS shared a debriefing always occurs with the youth after each incident. All parties discussed the need for continued training, debriefing/evaluating incidents, crisis intervention/assessment, and maintaining the principles of Pro-Act. Furthermore, all parties discussed the added benefit of role playing and re-enacting scenarios so the facility staff can practice de-escalating techniques. ACYFS stated at least one Pro-Act trained staff member is at the facility during all shifts. Per ACYFS, new hires are signed up for a Pro-Act class within in the first 30 days of hire. ACYFS expressed a copy of the Emergency Intervention Plan is at all four facilities and the staff are required to read the youths files. ACYFS shared the program has been utilizing classes offered through Barstow Community College for staff training during the COVID-19 pandemic. In closing, CCL expressed the importance of being collaborative and emphasized that CCL can be a resource while ACYFS is on an Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Provisional license. LPM Barnes expressed if similar incidents continue to occur at the facilities, this could have an impact on the STRTP License. A copy of this report was emailed and provided to CEO Barron Wilson and Program Director Amy Osborn.

It was reported that staff provided incentives to older clients for disciplining younger clients with physical violence, causing clients to be fearful and distressed. It was further reported that Staff #1 (S1) punched Client #1 (C1) in the face and slammed the client on the sofa. Confidential interviews and reports received for the investigation resulted in consistent information provided to Investigator Hudec. Investigator Hudec’s interview with S1 disclosed that he was not trained in Pro-Act, which is Professional Assault Crisis Training. Director Barron Wilson specified that all staff are Pro-Act trained, even though multiple staff specified they had not been Pro-Act trained as of hire. S1 confirmed there was a physical altercation between he and C1. Due to another staff removing C1’s bedcovers, C1 became agitated. S1 stated he attempted to verbally deescalate the situation; however, C1 threatened and cursed at staff. A “scuffle” ensued. S1 stated he pushed C1 and made contact with C1’s cheek, causing the client to fall. S1 also stated he held C1 down as C1 attempted to hit him in the head and another client attempted to pull S1 off C1. Additional staff interviewed for the investigation witnessed S1 “choke” and punch C1 in the face. Also, staff specified S1 was upset that the clients were “mean to him” and made the comment that “next time they get in my face and push me, I will start swinging.” Witnesses attested to seeing C1 lying on the floor with S1 on top of the client with both their arms “flailing” during the physical altercation. It was also indicated that S1 became agitated very quickly and always “balled his fists” at clients. Current and former staff revealed to Investigator Hudec that there are “Alpha” clients at each facility. These “Alphas” are required to keep other clients “in line.” Staff has observed an older client hitting the younger clients and indicated that clients have received extra money on their birthdays and may receive incentives from corporate. Witnesses confirmed there is at least one client labeled “Alpha” who had received extra money in their allowance as a result of maintaining compliance among the younger clients. On at least one occasion, an Alpha client made the other clients line up in the living room and punched them once in the chest as a form of discipline. Witnesses reported the Alpha had scared and yelled at the clients and taken their phones or other electronic devices when they have stepped “out of line.” Witnesses also reported that staff has “bribed” two clients with an iPhone, Jordan sneakers, and a gaming system to keep the other clients compliant. It was additionally indicated that staff asked the clients to steal and break other clients’ phone or “beat them up” if they were “acting up” or “mess up” the facility. Moreover, Investigator Hudec’s interview with social workers disclosed being concerned with the operation of the facility. (next page)

Based on confidential witnesses and record review, the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met and the allegation that staff are manipulating group home children as well as causing group home children to be physically and emotionally harmed, and staff member had a physical altercation with group home child(ren) has been substantiated, which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care. Facility is cited for Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Section 84072(d)(10) Personal Rights and 84072(d)(11) Personal Rights. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and Appeals Rights were provided to Mr. Encinas, Facility Manager.

It was reported that clients were not checked on for several hours, and a client was able to bring a gun into the facility because staff cannot supervise properly. It was additionally reported that the clients may have been physically and sexually abused as Staff #1 (S1) removed the bedcovers off clients and touched them at night. Confidential interviews and reports received for the investigation resulted in inconsistent information provided to Investigator Hudec. Several former and current staff interviewed for the investigation indicated that two staff are present during each shift, and the ratio is 1:3. Staff are required to check on clients every ten minutes and document the checks. Other staff indicated there is only one staff present during the overnight shifts. In an interview with Investigator Hudec, S1 denied touching the clients and specified that he shook the clients’ bed and called their names to awaken them. However, multiple staff disclosed they have woken up clients by touching them, either on their shoulders or legs. Others disclosed they have awakened clients by removing their bedcovers. Witnesses confirmed all methods staff disclosed for awakening the clients. Furthermore, staff interviewed by Investigator Hudec disclosed hearing rumors of a gun being found in the facility but denied a gun was ever located. However, a witness disclosed a revolver was observed in an air vent and handed over to staff. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that facility is understaffed and neglecting adequate supervision of the group home children, group home child had access to a gun, and staff member inappropriately touched group home children, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and Appeals Rights were provided to Mr. Encinas.

This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on confidential interviews and reports reviewed, staff manipulated clients and caused them physical and emotional harm due to providing incentives to “Alpha” client to keep other clients in line, which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights.

84072(d)(11) Personal Rights To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning. This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on confidential interviews and reports reviewed, S1 punched and choked C1 during a physical altercation, which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights.

narrative:
On June 28, 2021 at 9:45am, an unannounced Post-Licensing Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Kendal Zirbes and Jose Gonzalez. During the inspection, LPA's met with facility manager, Alex Martinez who provided access to the facility. LPA's and Program Director, inspected the facility inside and out. The facility was licensed as a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) on October 2, 2020. The facility in the process of receiving a Mental Health Certification with San Bernardino County. The facility is a one-story house with three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a living room, visitation room, kitchen , dining room, and staff office. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/books/games were observed for youth’s recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order. The facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. The facility had all required documents posted throughout the facility. Medications are locked and centrally stored in a locked filing cabinet within the locked staff office. Six individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. At 12:45pm, the hot water was measured by Program Director Amy Osborn. At the time of this inspection the hot water temperature was 119. The facility has a fully equipped first aid kit and first aid manual. The facility is not equipped with cameras. At the time of this inspection, there were no bodies of water on the facility ground. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility and smoking is prohibited. The facility vehicle was observed to be in safe operating condition and the registration was up to date. Youth files were maintained in a locked filing cabinet within the staff office. Staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection and they were in accordance with the regulations. Five youth files were reviewed on this date as well as a sample of six personnel files. Files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Report continued on page 2

Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through CARF. The Accreditation is valid through August 31, 2021. Licensing fee payments have been paid. A copy of this report was reviewed with the Program Manager. A copy of this report was emailed to the facility.

Licensing Program Manager, Angela King, Licensing Program Analyst, Margaret Lentner, and Licensing Program Analyst, Sethany Yem conducted a case management inspection on July 27, 2021, at 8:54am, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. 6 out of 12 Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 6 youth files as identified on the LIC 811 confidential names dated July 27, 2021, were reviewed. 2 out of 12 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 6 youth were interviewed. The Plan of Operation including policies and procedure were reviewed. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Amy Osborn, Program Director STRTP.

A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility’s, activity center, gaming room, kitchen area, refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, client bedrooms, bathroom/showers and garage. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Sports equipment/toys/books/games/computers were observed for children’s recreation time. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintain an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and the menus were posted. All other required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored inside staff's office. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client’s bathrooms was measured to be between 102 and 125 degrees. Facility Manager stated that water was adjusted at time of visit Per the Administrator, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. Chemicals and/or poisons, sharp objects/knives are locked in a file cabinet in the staff office. First Aid Kits are stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office. LPM and LPAs reviewed the facility's disaster and mass casualty plan. The facility currently has two children sharing each bedroom. The facility must ensure that each client is aware of the bedroom sharing policy and document the advisement in the clients’ files. Based on record review, the facility did provide a signed bedroom sharing document in their files. The facility is also required to ensure all client medications refusal are documented and signed by staff in the MARs medication log. The facility needs to maintain an accurate count of all medications. LPM and LPAs observed medication refusals were not documented, and medications were missing from Client #2 bubble pack. This is a violation of licensing standards, which will also be cited. The facility did not have monthly restraint log for review. LPA advised Administrator that a monthly log regarding manual restraints is required. LPA requests that Administrator provides LPA Gonzalez with the document by the requested date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 9099-D, LIC 9102, and appeal rights were provided to Administrator.

witnessing any staff smoking with clients. Confidential interviews reported that S1 denied the allegation. In addition, confidential interviews reported that staff denied witnessing S1 smoking marijuana or providing marijuana to the clients. Confidential interviews reported that staff denied they provided drugs or alcohol to any of the clients at the facility. There were no videos or photographs of the incidents. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that staff sexually abused the minors (C1-C11) while in care. Confidential interviews reported that clients had sex with S2 but laughed afterwards. Confidential interviews reported that clients bragged they had sex with S2. Confidential interviews denied having a sexual relationship with any of the clients at the facility. Other confidential interviews reported that no one witnessed any inappropriate behavior between clients (C1-C11) and staff. Additionally, a confidential interview denied sexual intercourse with any staff. There were no videos or photographs of the incidents. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that firearms are present in the facility. Confidential interviews reported that C1 posed with a firearm on social media. Law Enforcement determined the firearm was not real and was an air soft gun. Confidential interviews reported that no firearms were confiscated or on the premises. Confidential interviews reported that clients (C1-C6) haven’t had not seen any firearms in the facility. Other confidential interviews reported that clients haven’t heard any conversations about firearms between staff and clients (C1-C6). Other information received stated that firearms are present at the facility. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that staff encouraged the minors (C1-C7) to fight one another while in care. Confidential interviews reported that S3 paid the clients to fight each other as a form of discipline. Other confidential interviews reported that all the clients get along with each other and did not witness staff encouraging clients to fight. Confidential interviews reported that staff doesn’t force clients to fight other clients. Confidential interviews reported that some of the clients attempt to have other clients fight each other while other confidential information stated that the allegation was true. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that staff did not safeguard the minor’s personal belongings. Confidential interviews reported that a client (unknown) used C9’s scooter. When staff located the scooter, it was returned to C9 damaged/broken. Other confidential interviews reported that staff denied damaging the scooter. Confidential interviews reported that C5 have had some personal items taken by other clients (unknown) and the clients doesn’t tell the truth about taking the items. Confidential interviews reported that clients (C1-C4 & C6) haven’t had any of their personal belongings taken from staff or from other

clients in this facility. Community Care licensing also received an allegation that minors are unable to sleep while in care. Confidential interviews reported that sometimes at night it’s loud. Confidential interviews reported that there are no music playing or loud talking going on at night that prevents clients (C1-C6) from sleeping. Confidential interviews reported that sometimes at night can be noisy but it hasn’t been noisy in about two months. Other confidential interviews reported that clients are able to sleep during the night. Based on confidential interviews and information obtained, the allegations that conduct inimical-staff provided drugs and alcohol to minors (C1-C11) while in care, sexual abuse-staff sexually abused the minors (C1-C11) while in care, firearms are present in the facility, staff encouraged the minors (C1-C11) to fight one another while in care, staff did not safeguard the minor’s (C5 & C9) personal belongings, minors (C1-C11) are unable to sleep while in care may have occurred, however; is not supported by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Emanuel Wiley, STRTP Facility Director.

narrative:
Additional confidential witness statements indicate that C1 was without clothing for approximately two months. Confidential witness statements revealed that C1 had written a list of C1’s missing clothing and submitted it to the FM and S1 to fax to the cooperate office. Additional confidential witness statements indicate that C1’s missing clothing list was submitted to the corporate office on two different dates. Confidential witness statements revealed that the facility staff were waiting for CEO’s approval to release the funds to purchase C1’s clothing. During LPA inspection of C1’s bedroom C1 had the following items two pair of basketball shorts, a pair of sweats, four pairs of underwear, red pajama pants, and three to four pairs of socks. Additional confidential witness statements indicate that FM and S1 had contacted Program Director, Amy Osborn regarding the funds to purchase C1’s clothing. CSW stated that the STRTP facility had informed her that the facility was going to replace C1’s clothing. Based on confidential interviews and LPA’s observations, and physical inspection at the facility, the facility did not ensure that client #1 (C1) had adequate clothing is Substantiated because the preponderance of evidence standard has been met for the allegation. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care. The facility is being cited under Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Chapter 7.5 Version 3.5 87072(d) Personal Rights (d) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code (WIC) section 16001.9, ...16001.9 (a)(3) To receive…adequate clothing. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Program Director (PD), Amy Osborn.

Additional confidential witness statements indicate that several clients allowance are locked up in the staff office and that the facility staff transport the clients to the store and purchase the items for the clients at the store. CSW also stated that the facility had informed her that they were not going to give C1 his allowance money to hold on his person but instead were going to purchase items that C1 had requested from the store. CSW went on to add that C1 would go AWOL with his money and would return to the home with alcohol, marijuana, and other substances. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that alleged client #1 (C1) that alleged the clients are not given allowance and that the clients are not provided educational rights., may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Program Director (PD), Amy Osborn.

narrative: On June 10, 2022, at 10:37 am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jose Gonzalez and Darlene Oseguera met with Alpha Connection – Shoshonee Program Director (PD) Amy Osborn to deliver a case management deficiencies report. LPA J. Gonzalez was at the facility on 11/22/2021, conducting a safety inspection. At 11:15 AM, LPA and Facility Director (FD) Manny Wiley conducted a walk-through safety inspection of the facility. During the safety inspection, LPA and FD observed the following drug paraphernalia items in the backyard area: a green apple used as a marijuana pipe with marijuana residue, two red lighters, and two tip flitters white tips from cigars. LPA and FD conducted a safety inspection inside the home. LPA and FD observed the following drug paraphernalia items in bedroom #2: a green apple used as a pipe for marijuana, a pipe with marijuana residue, and a bag of tobacco inside client #3 (C3) dresser drawer. C3 admitted that the green apple used as a marijuana pipe with marijuana residue and a bag of tobacco was C3s contraband. FD proceeded to dispose of the contraband, reentered the room, and confiscated a bag of tobacco. A Short-term residential therapeutic program is a residential facility operated by a public agency or private organization and licensed by the department pursuant to Section 1562.01 that provides an integrated program of specialized and intensive care and supervision, services and supports, treatment, and short-term 24-hour care and supervision to children and/or nonminor dependents. The licensee shall employ direct care staff to meet the needs of children as specified in 87065.2 and provide adequate care and supervision to children. Facility staff were unaware of the drug paraphernalia items until the FD conducted a walk-through safety inspection of the facility with LPA. The facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87065.2 (b)(1) Personnel Duties (b) Direct care staff shall perform the following duties: (1) supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups.

narrative: Confidential interviews indicate the facility staff never heard or observed the clients encourage C1 to commit suicide or to harm themself. Additional confidential interviews revealed that C2 had kept C1 from running into the street. Confidential interviews indicate that C1 was encouraged by other clients to commit suicide or harm themselves in a jokingly manner. Additional interviews revealed that C1 was being bullied by C2 and C3. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 never informed the facility staff that C2 and C3 were bullying C1. Confidential interviews indicate that facility staff were aware that C1 was being bullied by C2 and C3. Additional interviews revealed that C1 did not feel safe at the STRTP home. Other confidential interviews reported that C1 was transferred to another STRTP home. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that alleged facility staff are not protecting client #1 (C1) from other clients in the facility may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Amy Osborn.
investigation_findings: 13On May 27, 2022, at 10:55 am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s) Jose Gonzalez and Darlene Oseguera met with Program Director (PD), Amy Osborn to deliver the findings for the above-stated allegations. LPA conducted a safety inspection at the facility at 10:01 am on November 12, 2021, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. LPA also reviewed eight of eight clients’ records. During the investigation, interviews were conducted with seven of seven clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, C6, and C7), Facility Director (FD), Program Director (PD), Staff #1 (S1), and Staff #2 (S2). The Department received a complaint on November 3, 2021, that alleged facility staff are not protecting client #1 (C1) from other clients in the facility. Confidential interviews indicate that facility staff protects all clients. Additional confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff intervened immediately when the clients argued or fought. Confidential interviews indicate that facility staff separates the clients into different areas of the home. Additional confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff was trained in trauma informed care and de-escalation techniques.****CONTINUED on LIC 9099C****

narrative: On June 10, 2022 at 11:31am, Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA's), Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Jose Gonzalez, conducted a collateral visit to the facility for the purpose of interviewing client #1 and client #2, (see Confidential Names form (LIC 811), dated June 10, 2022), regarding a prior placement. The interview is not related to this facility. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the facility.

The Department received a complaint on November 16, 2021, that alleged that the facility staff did not report client #1 (C1), client #7 (C7), and client #8 (C8) absences to the school; the facility staff is not ensuring that clients get to school on time, and the facility staff does not ensure clients are picked up from school on time. More specifically, students have excessive absences, unexcused absences, and consistent tardy arrivals to school and the tardiness is largely due to the facilities inability to get students to school on time. It was also reported that it is almost a daily occurrence that the students are picked up late, resulting in the need for teaching staff to call to remind the facility of student release times. Confidential interviews revealed that C1, C7, and C8 tardiness and absences were not reported to the school. Interview information revealed that C1, C7, and C8 miss educational instruction time when transported to school late by staff. Confidential interviews indicate that the facility staff was not instructed to report the client’s tardiness or absence to the school. Additional confidential interviews revealed that facility staff is often transferred from one facility to another facility to assist with ratio, supervision, and school transportation. Confidential interviews reported that the facility staff call off and this creates an issue with transporting the clients to school on time. Additional confidential interviews revealed that facility staff is instructed to assist additional facilities with school transports, which also results in the clients arriving late to school. Confidential interviews indicate that the facility staff is often one to two hours late in picking up clients from school. Additional confidential interviews confirmed that facility staff is late picking up the clients from school. Confidential interviews indicate that the facility staff does not pick up the clients on time because they are instructed to assist another facility with school pick up for their clients. LPA received additional information that the facility staff could not drive the company vehicles because the facility auto insurance did not cover the staff members. Confidential interviews reported that the facility does not provide enough staff to transport the clients to and from school and that some clients refuse to attend school and are not given consequences. Based on confidential interviews and evidence gathered that the facility staff does not report client #1 (C1), client #7 (C7), and client #8 (C8) absences to the school, the facility staff are not ensuring that clients get to school on time, and the facility staff do not ensure clients are picked up from school on time are substantiated as the preponderance of evidence standard has been met for the allegations. This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care. The facility is being cited under Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Chapter 7.5 Version 4, 87078 (c) Responsibility for Providing Care. *******CONTINUED 9099C******

An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Program Director (PD), Amy Osborn.

On November 16, 2021, the Department received a complaint that alleged that the facility staff is not providing supervision resulting in inappropriate interactions between clients in care. Confidential interviews indicate that the other clients were bullying C1, C7, and C8. Additional confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff did not observe C1, C7, and C8 being bullied by the other clients in care. Confidential interviews indicate that the facility staff was not informed that the clients were bullying the C1, C7, and C8 at home. Additional confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff did observe C1, C7, and C8 being bullied by the other clients in care. Confidential interviews indicate that the facility staff was aware and informed that the other clients were bullying the C1, C7, and C8 at home. Additional confidential interviews denied the allegations. The Department also received allegations that the clients are not accorded privacy while in care and the clients drink alcohol while in care. Confidential interviews indicate that the clients are accorded privacy at home. Additional confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff was not discussing a client’s confidential and personal information in front of the other clients. Confidential interviews denied the allegation. Additional confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff addressed a client’s confidential and personal information in front of the other clients. Confidential interviews indicate that staff heard and observed discussing a client’s confidential and personal information in front of the other clients. Additional confidential interviews denied the allegations. Confidential interviews indicate that the clients are allowed to drink alcohol at the home. Additional confidential interviews revealed that empty liquor bottles have been observed, confiscated, and thrown away during room searches. Confidential interviews indicate that the clients are absent without approved leave and steal alcohol from a store and return to the home under the influence. Additional confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff had not observed the client drinking alcohol at home. Confidential interviews indicate that the clients do not drink alcohol at the house. Additional confidential interviews denied the allegations. Confidential interviews indicate that the clients empty their pockets when they return from absent without approved leave. Other confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff conducted bedroom and perimeter searches, and no alcohol bottles were observed. ***********CONTINUED on LIC 9099 C************

The Department also received an allegation that the staff did not safeguard the client’s personal items. Confidential interviews indicate that the facility staff does not safeguard clients’ personal items. Additional confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff does not safeguard the client’s personal items when a client’s absent without approved leave. Confidential interviews indicate that the other clients remove the absent without approved leave client’s personal items. Additional confidential interviews revealed that C7 personal items were missing. Confidential interviews indicate that the facility staff did not safeguard C7’s personal belongings. Other confidential interviews revealed that the C1 was bullied for a brand-new pair of Nike shoes. CSW2 stated that when she retrieved C7’s personal items, they were transferred to another home and placed in the bedroom. CSW2 stated that the facility staff informed CSW2 that some clients had gotten into C7s personal belongings. Confidential interviews denied the allegation. Based on confidential interviews that alleged that the facility staff is not providing supervision resulting in inappropriate interactions between clients in care, clients are not accorded privacy while in care, clients drink alcohol, and staff did not safeguard the client’s personal items while in care may have occurred however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Program Director (PD), Amy Osborn.
investigation_findings: 13On June 3, 2022, at 10:56 am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jose Gonzalez and Darlene Oseguera met with Alpha Connection Shoshonee Program Director (PD), Amy Osborn, to deliver the findings for the above-stated allegations. deficiencies.plan_of_correction: (c) Responsibility for Providing Care The facility staff does not report minors (C1, C7, and C8) absences to the school, staff are not ensuring that minors get to school on time, and staff does not ensure minors are picked up from school on time. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and attendance records reviewed, staff do not report minors (C1, C7, and C8) absences to the school, the facility staff are not ensuring that minors get to school on time, and the facility staff do not ensure minors are picked up from school on time are substantiated

narrative: allegations with a preponderance of evidence. Confidential interviews denied allegations that staff allowed client to AWOL. According to confidential interviews, staff always try and persuade children from AWOLing and will counsel them and give them options in order for them to change their minds. Confidential interviews also stated that once a client is in the process of going AWOL, staff will follow that client as far as possible and will file a missing persons report, as well as notify that child’s County Social Worker or Probation Officer. Confidential interviews also denied that staff allow or encourage foster children to fight, or that they take them off grounds in order to fight. According to confidential interviews, staff will always intervene whenever there is a physical altercation, as well as try and de-escalate and separate children in order to prevent fights from occurring. While other confidential information received by Licensing Office stated that these allegations had occurred. Based on confidential information obtained during the course of this investigation, the allegations of a lack of supervision resulting in Child # (C1) AWOLing (Absence without official leave) from facility, as well as staff not preventing inappropriate behavior between minors, more specifically that staff allow children to fight each other, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided.

Based on confidential interviews and record review the allegations of minors smoke marijuana at the facility and the facility smells of marijuana, may or may not have occurred, however it is not supported or proven by the evidence. narrative: On July 16, 2022, at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Leslie Covarrubias and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore made an unannounced case management visit to Alpha Connection Shoshonee Place (STRTP) regarding the STRTP staff/client ratio. LPA and LPM met with Facility Manager (S2) Vanessa Ramirez who granted access into the home. LPA and LPM conducted a health and safety inspection with S2. During the health and safety inspection. LPA observed one staff and two clients (C1 and C2) present during the visit. Per Facility Manager (S2), one staff (Program Director, S1) transported four clients (C3, C4, C5 and C6) to their basketball games located in Long Beach. LPM and LPA observed that facility log indicated that staff, Program Director took three clients approximately at 7:55am. The facility is out compliance for staff to client ratios as Staff 1 took four clients to a basketball game. The facility is being cited for Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87065.5 Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios. S2 called Program Director Amy Osborn to formulate the plan of correction and also to receive verbal authorization to sign Licensing Reports. A copy of the report was discussed and provided to Alpha Connection- Shoshonee, Facility Manager, Vanessa Ramirez.

Confidential interviews indicate that the minors do not feel safe at the home because other minors are threatening them when the facility staff are not monitoring their interactions. The Department also received allegations that facility staff #1 (S1) is sleeping during work shifts. Confidential interviews indicate the facility staff is not sleeping during work shifts. Additional confidential interviews revealed that S1 is sleeping during the nocturnal shift. Confidential interviews indicate that S1 and the facility staff conduct headcounts every 10 minutes. Confidential interviews revealed that they have not observed S1 sleeping at the STRTP home nor have they observed S1 working a nocturnal shift at the home. Confidential interviews disclosed that it was observed that S1 was sleeping during their shift. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that facility staff are not providing supervision to the minors in care and that facility staff #1 (S1) is sleeping during work shifts may have occurred, however is not supported, or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Program Director (PD), Amy Osborn.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst, Daniel Mena and Licensing Program Manager, Natasha Dunlap conducted a teleconference meeting with Alpha Connection, Program Director, Amy Osborn, Clinician, Lindsay Baston and Consultant, Dan Thorne to discuss and review the probationary conditions that go into effect once Alpha Connections STRTP reverts back to a Group Home on January 01, 2023. On December 31, 2022, the STRTP applications for Alpha Connection Group Home For Children, License No. 366412000, 21398 Pine Ridge, Apple Valley, CA 92307; ACYFSAnoka Ranch, License No. 366401649, 22675 Anoka Road, Apple Valley, CA 92308; ACYFS-Shoshonee Place, License No. 366402331, 20048 Shoshonee Road, Apple Valley, CA 92307; and ACYFS Nisqually Nest, License No. 366403207, 12915 Chief Joseph Road, Apple Valley, CA 92308 (collectively the "facilities") are terminated and Alpha will transition/convert back to its group home licenses subject to a three (3) year probationary term with the following conditions: 1. Alpha shall operate each facility in substantial compliance with the regulations and statutes governing the operation of a group home. 2. During the period of Probation, the Department in its sole discretion may conduct unannounced site visits for the purpose of determining whether there is substantial compliance with the regulations and statutes governing the operation of the group home. 3. Alpha will submit an updated group home plan of operation and program statement for each group home to the Department within 30 days of the effective date of this Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release including but not limited to:

a. A description of trauma-informed and evidence-based intervention and de-escalation techniques that will be used to promote the safety of all individuals in the facility, including but not limited to children or nonminor dependents who have a propensity for behaviors that result in harm to self or others. b. A runaway plan that includes a continuum of non-physical interventions and strategies to de-escalate a situation where a child has indicated his /her intent to run away, that will be utilized by staff to prevent and Alpha to runaway behaviors. 4. Alpha shall ensure that all children are supervised 24 hours per day, 7 days per week, in accordance with its Program Statement and Plan of Operation and licensing regulations. 5. There shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows: a. During the hours of 7 am to 10 pm, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every three children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum b. During the hours of 10pm to 7am, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every six children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum. c. In addition to staff required in paragraph 1 or 2, when one or more children are present at the facility, at least one direct care staff shall be on call and capable of arriving at the facility within 30 minutes. d. If a child requires special care and supervision because of age, behavior or other factors, the number of awake and on-duty care staff shall be increased. 6. Any administrator employed by Alpha to operate the facility shall have, at minimum, the education and experience specified in California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation 84064 and shall be certified as a group home

administrator pursuant to California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation 84064. 2. No exceptions shall be made to these requirements during probation. 7. Alpha shall ensure that a qualified and certified administrator is present and available on premises of each facility, a minimum of 20 hours a week. In the administrator's absence, a designated substitute as defined in the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation 84064(d) shall be present and available on the premises of the facility. Alpha shall timely notify the Department of any change in administrator and the name, address, date of hire, background, qualifications, and certification of the new administrator. 8. Alpha shall develop a comprehensive training curriculum for all new and current staff who provide direct care services to children in care. The content of the training shall include, but not be limited to, the following: supervision of youth, reporting requirements to the Department and reporting requirements as a mandated child abuse reporter, personal rights, crisis prevention, and emergency intervention, including Alpha's runaway plan, and all applicable licensing laws and regulations. Training shall be mandatory for all employees. A detailed description of the in-service training and a record of all staff who attended the trainings shall be maintained and made available to the department upon request. a. Training to include (ii) Trauma Informed Interventions and Treatment Practices. Two (2) hours of instruction in the physical and psychosocial needs of the children, including behavior management, de-escalation techniques, and trauma-informed crisis management planning, including the use of emergency interventions. The training plan shall be designed to ensure the provision of trauma-informed services and be appropriate for the population and shall consider the training needs and skill level of staff b. All outstanding training, including but not limited to the training listed above, shall be completed by staff within 45 days of the group home transition.

c. Additional staff hired after the transition to the group home must complete the trauma informed training within 45 days of hire and any additional training must be completed within the time frames outlined in the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation 84065. In the Matter of Alpha Connections Youth & Family Services, Inc. v. CDSS Case No. CVR12203769 Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release 9. Alpha shall adhere to the reporting requirements as defined in California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulations 80061, 84061, in the regulations and statutes governing the operation of a group home. Alpha shall report to the Licensing office the following: any unusual incident, including, but not limited to, client death or injury which requires medical treatment, any suspected physical plant changes, and all unexplained absences. These incidents must be reported by the next working day, and a written report of the incident must be submitted within seven days following the occurrence of the incident. All unusual incident reports shall be complete, including addendums and follow-up information. 10. Alpha shall ensure compliance with California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulations 84068.1, 84068.2, 84068.3 and 84068.4 regarding Intake Procedure, Needs and Services Plans and Modifications, and Removal and/or Discharge Procedures. Prior to and during placement Alpha shall determine whether it can provide the services necessary to meet the child's needs and to effect discharge if it is determined that Alpha cannot provide the services necessary to meet the child's needs. Further, Alpha shall ensure that an appropriate assessment of a child's compatibility with other children in care is conducted during the intake process and is re-evaluated on a continuance basis when individual needs dictate. Alpha agrees that it shall not accept or retain, and will promptly discharge with written notice to the authorized representative, any child for whom it cannot adequately and safely provide care, any child who requires a higher level of care, and any child who would cause the Alpha to violate laws and regulations, or the conditions of Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release.

11. Alpha shall ensure the personal rights of all children in its care including the right to be provided safe, healthful, and comfortable accommodations to meet their needs, and shall be free from corporal or unusual punishment, pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other action of a punitive nature. 12. Alpha shall ensure that each child in care receives first aid and medical services, including arrangements and transportation. Further Alpha shall ensure that medications and any other toxic products are properly stored and kept in a safe and locked place that is not accessible to children in care or other persons other than employees responsible for the supervision of the centrally stored medication pursuant to California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation sections 80075 and 84075. Employees of Alpha shall immediately document on the medication log any refusals of medication by a child in care and shall follow-up with proper notification to the child's physician. 13. Alpha's Board of Directors shall be active in ensuring accountability and ensuring that Alpha complies with all applicable regulations, by reviewing, on a quarterly basis Alpha's operation and documents as specified in Health and Safety code section 1520. 1(f), including a review of special incident reports and all licensing reports issued by the Department. 14. For the duration of the probationary period, Alpha shall provide all current and prospective parents or responsible parties of children in the facility with a copy of the settlement terms, as outlined in the Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release. Proof of Acknowledgement shall be kept in the respective child’s record and available for inspection by the Department. 15. Alpha will work collaboratively with the Department to comply and fully implement all Plan of Corrections and agreements. This Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release supersedes any Compliance Plan or Corrective Action Plan that has previously been submitted by the Alpha to the Department. A copy of this report was provided and emailed for signatures.

Confidential interviews denied allegations that staff failed prevent altercation between Child # 1 (C1) and Child # 2(C2) due to a lack of care and supervision. According to confidential interviews, Staff # 1 (S1) and Staff # 2 (S2) were present during the altercation and immediately intervened once they became aware to separate and de-escalate the clients involved. Confidential interviews also denied that C1 is being bullied by other clients in care and stated that bullying is not allowed, and that staff will immediately intervene if a client is bullied or teased by other clients. According to confidential interviews, C1 also has an adequate amount of clean clothing at the GH. Confidential interviews stated that C1 does not always shower nor change clothing on a daily basis, despite encouragement and insistence by staff and other clients. Confidential interviews also stated that C1 often mingles their clean clothing along with their dirty laundry. While other confidential Information received by Licensing Office stated that these allegations had occurred, that staff did not immediately intervene during altercation, and that C1 often goes to school with stained clothing and is verbally bullied by C2 and Child # 3 (C3). Based on interviews and confidential information obtained during the course of this investigation, the allegations that Staff did not prevent altercation between youths, does not ensure that Foster Child # 1 (C1) is accorded clean clothing, and is not accorded safe, healthful accommodations while in care, more specifically that C1 is being bullied by other clients in care, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Daniel Mena met with Group Home (GH) Program Director, Amy Osborn to discuss the investigative findings for the above stated allegation. LPA Mena interviewed two of two foster children (C1 & C2), two staff members (S1 & S2), as well as reviewed facility and client information. Community Care Licensing received information on June 23, 2023, alleging that Child # 1 (C1) was injured by Child # (C2) due to a lack of supervision from Staff # 1 (S1). Information obtained in confidential interviews did not corroborate the allegation with a preponderance of evidence. Confidential interviews denied allegations of a lack of supervision by S1. According to confidential interviews, S1 had taken C1 and C2 on an outing to a local park, and that as soon as they arrived, C1 appeared agitated and ran out of the car and away from S1. According to confidential interviews, C2 who is C1’s roommate ran after C1, in an attempt to bring C1 back to the vehicle. According to interviews, when C2 caught up with C1, C1 punched C2 and C2 retaliated by hitting C1 in return on numerous occasions. Altercation was said to have lasted a couple of minutes and resulted in both C1 and C2 receiving scrapes, bruising and other injuries. Both C1 and C2 were said to have been seen by paramedics and were taken to be treated for their injuries to a clinic. According to confidential information, S1 tried to intervene by

narrative: out of the facility vehicle and punched S1 on several occasions. According to confidential interviews, S1 did not retaliate by punching C1 in return and only deflected C1’s punches and temporarily restrained C1 until other staff were able to intervene. Confidential information stated that neither C1 nor S1 received any bruising, as a result of this incident. While other confidential information received by Licensing Office stated that these allegations had occurred and that S1 and C1 did engage in a physical altercation resulting in both C1 and S1 receiving bruising to their face. There were no other known witnesses to this allegation. Based on interviews and confidential information obtained during the course of this investigation, the allegation that Staff # 1 (S1) had engaged in a physical altercation with Client # 1 (C1), may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided.

Community Care Licensing received information on November 14, 2023, alleging that staff did not ensure minor’s medical needs are being met, more specifically that staff failed to take Child # 1 (C1) to get blood work done as instructed by C1’s medical doctor. Confidential interviews corroborated allegation with a preponderance of evidence. Confidential information obtained confirmed allegation that staff was first instructed to take C1 to get blood work done in June of 2023. According to confidential information it was not until November of 2023 that C1 was finally taken to get blood work done by staff. Based on interviews and information gathered during the investigation, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined the allegation that Staff did not ensure minor’s medical needs are being met, more specifically that staff failed to take Child # 1 (C1) to get blood work done as instructed by C1’s medical doctor is substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of

facility_name: ALPHA CONNECTION GROUP HOME FOR CHILDREN
narrative:
On June 28, 2021 at 1:50pm, an unannounced Post-Licensing Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Kendal Zirbes and Jose Gonzalez. During the inspection, LPA's met with facility manager, Manny Wiley who provided access to the facility. LPA and Facility Manager, inspected the facility inside and out. The facility was licensed as a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) on October 2, 2020. The facility in the process of receiving a Mental Health Certification with San Bernardino County. The facility is a one-story house with three bedrooms, three bathrooms, a living room, visitation room, kitchen, dining room, garage, therapy office and staff office. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/books/games were observed for youth’s recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order. The facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. The facility had all required documents posted throughout the facility. Medications are locked and centrally stored in a locked filing cabinet within the locked staff office. Six individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. At 3:00pm, the hot water was measured by Facility Manager, Manny Wiley. At the time of this inspection the hot water temperature was 105 degrees. The facility has a fully equipped first aid kit and first aid manual. The facility is not equipped with cameras. At the time of this inspection, there were no bodies of water on the facility ground. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility and smoking is prohibited. The facility vehicle was observed to be in safe operating condition and the registration was up to date. Youth files were maintained in a locked filing cabinet within the staff office. Staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection and they were in accordance with the regulations. Five youth files were reviewed on this date as well as a sample of six personnel files. Files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Report continued on page 2

Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through CARF. The Accreditation is valid through August 31, 2021. Licensing fee payments have been paid. A copy of this report was reviewed with the Program Manager. A copy of this report was emailed to the facility

narrative:
Confidential interviews disclosed that facility staff has observed the residents smoking in the backyard behind the shed. Additional confidential interviews revealed that the residents are instructed to smoke outside the home. Confidential interviews stated that residents use their community passes to smoke cigarettes or marijuana. During the safety inspection, the LPA observed in bedroom #3 bathroom the following drug paraphernalia items: a green apple used as a pipe with residue, a pen used as a pipe with aluminum foil and residue, and a plastic bottle used as a pipe with aluminum foil and residue and the bedroom had a marijuana smoke odor. Based on LPA confidential interviews and observations that alleged the residents are smoking marijuana at the facility is substantiated as the preponderance of evidence standard has been met for the allegation. The facility is being cited under Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Version 4. Section 87087(c) Buildings and Grounds. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Evonnda Hull.
