narrative: On June 3, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA's) Jose Gonzalez and Darlene Oseguera made an unannounced case management inspection. LPA's met with Alpha Connection Anoka Facility Administrator (FA), Evonnda Hull to discuss information received by Community Care Licensing. On March 16, 2022, the Department received information regarding a staff member sleeping on the overnight shift and a picture of the staff (S1), slumped to the side asleep on a couch located in the Alpha Connection Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). Confidential interviews also revealed that staff and clients have observed S1 asleep on the overnight shift at various Alpha Connection facilities during S1's assigned work hours. Based on confidential interviews, LPA's observation, and evidence gathered S1 was observed and photographed slumped to the side asleep on a couch located in the Alpha Connection STRTP. The facility is being cited for violation of Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards, Version 4, Section 87065.2(b)(1) Personnel Duties. The licensee did not ensure clients were supervised and protected at all times. This poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to the children placed in care. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Facility Administrator (FA),

narrative: On July 16, 2022, at 09:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Cheraki Davis made an unannounced case management visit to Alpha Connections Group Home for Children (STRTP) regarding the STRTP staff/client ratio. LPA Choi and LPM Davis were met by Direct Care Staff Maria Macias, Facilty Manager (FM) Karen Reyes and Facility Director (FD) Morgan Tyler who arrived later. LPA Choi and LPM Davis conducted a health and safety inspection of the facility. During the health and safety inspection, LPA Choi did not observe any immediate deficiencies. LPA Choi observed two staff and six clients present during the visit. LPA Choi and LPM Davis reviewed the facility log to determine compliance. LPA Choi and LPM Davis observed the following during the review of the facility log. At 9:30, LPA Choi and LPM Davis observed the facility's LIC 500 staff roster, was not current, as it did not list S1 and S2’s (S2 was an overnight shift staff, reported to have worked last night) work schedules. During confidential interviews with the facility's clients, it was reported that the clients were able to use regular silverware utensils. However, during confidential interviews, it was reported that a new client recently harmed another client with a silverware fork and that after this incident, it was reported that the facility staff implemented the use of plastic utensils. LPA Choi reviewed one client file. The facility is being cited for violating Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87066(b)(3). Based on record review, LPA observed S1 and S2's time schedule was not noted on the facility’s LIC 500, Personnel Report that was posted in the staff’s office. A copy of the report was discussed and provided with appeal rights, to Alpha Connection Facility Director Morgan Tyler.

narrative: Confidential interviews denied allegations of a lack of supervision resulting in C1 trespassing onto neighbor’s private property. According to confidential interviews, Staff # 1 (S1) and Staff # 2 (S2) were present the day of the incident and immediately verbally intervened as soon as they observed C1 leaving facility. According to confidential information, S1 and S2 were involved and engaging with C1 during the entire duration of the incident and were speaking and counseling C1, in an attempt to get C1 to come back to facility. According to confidential interviews, C1 was refusing to listen to staff and appeared to be “delusional” and was subsequently placed on a 5150 hold once police was called and arrived on scene. While other confidential information received by Licensing Office stated that the allegation had occurred, and that staff did not appear to do enough in order to prevent C1 from going into neighbor’s garage and physically engaging with neighbor. According to confidential information, neighbor had to hold C1 at gunpoint until police arrival after C1 had gotten a hold of a hammer inside the garage. Additional confidential interviews disclosed that they did not witness the incident because they were not on facility grounds during the time of the incident. Based on interviews and confidential information obtained during the course of this investigation, the allegation that Staff did not provide adequate supervision to minor in care, more specifically that staff was unable to prevent Child #1 from leaving facility and trespassing into neighbor’s private property, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided.

facility_name: ALPHA CONNECTION GROUP HOME FOR CHILDREN
narrative: Other confidential interviews suggest the allegation was not true. Confidential interviews were also conducted with facility staff. All confidential interviews with staff suggest that the allegation did not occur. LPA received inconsistent information regarding the allegation. The Department also received an allegation that staff (S5) instructed other minors to physically assault minors while in care. Confidential interviews were conducted with FC1, FC2, FC3, FC4, FC5 and FC6, and OC1, OC2, OC3, OC4 and OC5. Confidential interviews disclosed that after S1 took a minor’s video game system, one or more minor’s in care, locked the staff member in a client’s room. Confidential interviews disclosed that S1 called S5 for assistance. Confidential interviews disclosed that S5 brought clients from another facility to exercise physical discipline on the minors of the primary facility. Other confidential interviews disclosed that this incident didn’t happen. Confidential interviews disclosed that S5 was near the facility at the time of the incident performing regular duties such as distributing allowances and supplies. Confidential interviews were also conducted with facility staff. These interviews suggest that no such incident, as described in this allegation occurred. LPA received inconsistent statements regarding the allegation. The Department also received an allegation that staff (S1, S2), did not ensure that minor attended school. Confidential interviews were conducted with FC1, FC1, FC3, FC4, FC5 and FC6. Confidential interviews disclosed that some clients refused to attend school sometimes, and that other times, staff were late in taking them to school. Confidential interviews were also conducted with facility staff. These interviews disclosed that staff always prompt the clients for school, and that the only times clients miss school, is when they refuse. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that facility staff inappropriately handled a minor in care, instructed other minors to physically assault minors while in care, and did not ensure that minor attended school, may have occurred, however, are not supported or proven by evidence. There the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Facility Director Morgan Tyler.

facility_name: ALPHA CONNECTION GROUP HOME FOR CHILDREN
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst, Daniel Mena and Licensing Program Manager, Natasha Dunlap conducted a teleconference meeting with Alpha Connection, Program Director, Amy Osborn, Clinician, Lindsay Baston and Consultant, Dan Thorne to discuss and review the probationary conditions that go into effect once Alpha Connections STRTP reverts back to a Group Home on January 01, 2023. On December 31, 2022, the STRTP applications for Alpha Connection Group Home For Children, License No. 366412000, 21398 Pine Ridge, Apple Valley, CA 92307; ACYFSAnoka Ranch, License No. 366401649, 22675 Anoka Road, Apple Valley, CA 92308; ACYFS-Shoshonee Place, License No. 366402331, 20048 Shoshonee Road, Apple Valley, CA 92307; and ACYFS Nisqually Nest, License No. 366403207, 12915 Chief Joseph Road, Apple Valley, CA 92308 (collectively the "facilities") are terminated and Alpha will transition/convert back to its group home licenses subject to a three (3) year probationary term with the following conditions: 1. Alpha shall operate each facility in substantial compliance with the regulations and statutes governing the operation of a group home. 2. During the period of Probation, the Department in its sole discretion may conduct unannounced site visits for the purpose of determining whether there is substantial compliance with the regulations and statutes governing the operation of the group home. 3. Alpha will submit an updated group home plan of operation and program statement for each group home to the Department within 30 days of the effective date of this Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release including but not limited to:

a. A description of trauma-informed and evidence-based intervention and de-escalation techniques that will be used to promote the safety of all individuals in the facility, including but not limited to children or nonminor dependents who have a propensity for behaviors that result in harm to self or others. b. A runaway plan that includes a continuum of non-physical interventions and strategies to de-escalate a situation where a child has indicated his /her intent to run away, that will be utilized by staff to prevent and Alpha to runaway behaviors. 4. Alpha shall ensure that all children are supervised 24 hours per day, 7 days per week, in accordance with its Program Statement and Plan of Operation and licensing regulations. 5. There shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows: a. During the hours of 7 am to 10 pm, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every three children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum b. During the hours of 10pm to 7am, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every six children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum. c. In addition to staff required in paragraph 1 or 2, when one or more children are present at the facility, at least one direct care staff shall be on call and capable of arriving at the facility within 30 minutes. d. If a child requires special care and supervision because of age, behavior or other factors, the number of awake and on-duty care staff shall be increased. 6. Any administrator employed by Alpha to operate the facility shall have, at minimum, the education and experience specified in California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation 84064 and shall be certified as a group home

administrator pursuant to California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation 84064. 2. No exceptions shall be made to these requirements during probation. 7. Alpha shall ensure that a qualified and certified administrator is present and available on premises of each facility, a minimum of 20 hours a week. In the administrator's absence, a designated substitute as defined in the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation 84064(d) shall be present and available on the premises of the facility. Alpha shall timely notify the Department of any change in administrator and the name, address, date of hire, background, qualifications, and certification of the new administrator. 8. Alpha shall develop a comprehensive training curriculum for all new and current staff who provide direct care services to children in care. The content of the training shall include, but not be limited to, the following: supervision of youth, reporting requirements to the Department and reporting requirements as a mandated child abuse reporter, personal rights, crisis prevention, and emergency intervention, including Alpha's runaway plan, and all applicable licensing laws and regulations. Training shall be mandatory for all employees. A detailed description of the in-service training and a record of all staff who attended the trainings shall be maintained and made available to the department upon request. a. Training to include (ii) Trauma Informed Interventions and Treatment Practices. Two (2) hours of instruction in the physical and psychosocial needs of the children, including behavior management, de-escalation techniques, and trauma-informed crisis management planning, including the use of emergency interventions. The training plan shall be designed to ensure the provision of trauma-informed services and be appropriate for the population and shall consider the training needs and skill level of staff b. All outstanding training, including but not limited to the training listed above, shall be completed by staff within 45 days of the group home transition.

c. Additional staff hired after the transition to the group home must complete the trauma informed training within 45 days of hire and any additional training must be completed within the time frames outlined in the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation 84065. In the Matter of Alpha Connections Youth & Family Services, Inc. v. CDSS Case No. CVR12203769 Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release 9. Alpha shall adhere to the reporting requirements as defined in California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulations 80061, 84061, in the regulations and statutes governing the operation of a group home. Alpha shall report to the Licensing office the following: any unusual incident, including, but not limited to, client death or injury which requires medical treatment, any suspected physical plant changes, and all unexplained absences. These incidents must be reported by the next working day, and a written report of the incident must be submitted within seven days following the occurrence of the incident. All unusual incident reports shall be complete, including addendums and follow-up information. 10. Alpha shall ensure compliance with California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulations 84068.1, 84068.2, 84068.3 and 84068.4 regarding Intake Procedure, Needs and Services Plans and Modifications, and Removal and/or Discharge Procedures. Prior to and during placement Alpha shall determine whether it can provide the services necessary to meet the child's needs and to effect discharge if it is determined that Alpha cannot provide the services necessary to meet the child's needs. Further, Alpha shall ensure that an appropriate assessment of a child's compatibility with other children in care is conducted during the intake process and is re-evaluated on a continuance basis when individual needs dictate. Alpha agrees that it shall not accept or retain, and will promptly discharge with written notice to the authorized representative, any child for whom it cannot adequately and safely provide care, any child who requires a higher level of care, and any child who would cause the Alpha to violate laws and regulations, or the conditions of Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release.

11. Alpha shall ensure the personal rights of all children in its care including the right to be provided safe, healthful, and comfortable accommodations to meet their needs, and shall be free from corporal or unusual punishment, pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other action of a punitive nature. 12. Alpha shall ensure that each child in care receives first aid and medical services, including arrangements and transportation. Further Alpha shall ensure that medications and any other toxic products are properly stored and kept in a safe and locked place that is not accessible to children in care or other persons other than employees responsible for the supervision of the centrally stored medication pursuant to California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Regulation sections 80075 and 84075. Employees of Alpha shall immediately document on the medication log any refusals of medication by a child in care and shall follow-up with proper notification to the child's physician. 13. Alpha's Board of Directors shall be active in ensuring accountability and ensuring that Alpha complies with all applicable regulations, by reviewing, on a quarterly basis Alpha's operation and documents as specified in Health and Safety code section 1520. 1(f), including a review of special incident reports and all licensing reports issued by the Department. 14. For the duration of the probationary period, Alpha shall provide all current and prospective parents or responsible parties of children in the facility with a copy of the settlement terms, as outlined in the Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release. Proof of Acknowledgement shall be kept in the respective child’s record and available for inspection by the Department. 15. Alpha will work collaboratively with the Department to comply and fully implement all Plan of Corrections and agreements. This Settlement Agreement and Mutual General Release supersedes any Compliance Plan or Corrective Action Plan that has previously been submitted by the Alpha to the Department. A copy of this report was provided and emailed for signatures.

facility_name: ALPHA CONNECTION GROUP HOME FOR CHILDREN
narrative:
On February 22, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daniel Mena arrived at Alpha Connection- Group Home (GH). LPA Mena was granted access by Administrator, Evonda Hull and Administrator, Guy Williams. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. Administrator led the physical inspection of the facility with LPA Mena. There are currently no children in placement. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility’s visitor's room, living room, kitchen area, dinning area, office, refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, 3 client bedrooms, front and backyard areas, and 4 bathroom/showers. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Sports equipment/toys/books/games/computers were observed for children’s recreation time. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee is to maintain an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and the menus are to be posted. All other required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. Medications are to be locked and centrally stored inside staff's office. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. Hot water temperature was measured. Per the Administrator, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. The facility has a visitor's room, living room, kitchen area, dinning area, office, laundry room, food storage areas, 3 client bedrooms, and 4 bathroom/showers. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. CONTINUES on LIC 809C

Chemicals and/or poisons, sharp objects/knives are locked in a file cabinet in the staff office. First Aid Kits are stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office. LPA reviewed the facility's disaster plan. The facility currently has no children. The facility must ensure that each client is aware of the bedroom sharing policy and document the advisement in the clients’ files. Based on record review, the facility did provide a signed bedroom sharing document in their files. There were no deficiencies/corrections observed on this date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report were provided to Administrator.

facility_name: ALPHA CONNECTION GROUP HOME FOR CHILDREN
narrative: status, and not under the care and supervision of facility staff. Confidential interviews also denied allegation staff does not ensure that C1 goes to school on time or that they are picked up in a timely manner. According to confidential information, C1 is sometimes late to school in the mornings because they refuse to get out of bed, or because C1 and other clients often take convincing and encouragement by staff in order to get them to go. Confidential interviews also denied that C1 is picked up late and stated that C1 often wanders after school or AWOLs from school before facility staff arrives. While other confidential information received by Licensing Office stated that these allegations had occurred. LPA Mena spoke to C1’s County Social Worker who stated that they currently had no concerns regarding C1’s level of care at the facility. Based on interviews and confidential information obtained during the course of this investigation, the allegations that Foster Child # 1’s (C1) hygiene needs are not being met, that C1 sustained unexplained burn injuries while in care, and that facility did not ensure that C1 is taken to and from school in a timely manner, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Daniel Mena met with Group Home (GH) Facility Manager, Ajee-aonna Glover to discuss the investigative findings for the above stated allegations. LPA Mena conducted an inspection to the GH on May 17, 2023 at 9:21 AM. No immediate hazards observed. LPA Mena interviewed four foster children (C1, C2, C3 & C4), three staff members (S1, S2 & S3), Program Director (PD), County Social Worker (CSW), as well as reviewed facility and client information. Community Care Licensing received information on May 12, 2023, alleging that Foster Child # 1’s (C1) hygiene needs are not being met, that C1 sustained unexplained burn injuries while in care, and that facility did not ensure that C1 is taken to and from school in a timely manner. Information obtained in confidential interviews did not corroborate the allegations with a preponderance of evidence. LPA Mena obtained conflicting information during interviews. Confidential interviews denied allegations that C1’s hygiene needs are not being met. According to confidential interviews, C1 refuses to bathe and change clothing on a daily basis. Confidential interviews stated that C1 is strongly encouraged to bathe, but that staff cannot physically force C1 to bathe or change their clothing. LPA Mena observed an adequate amount of clothing and personal hygiene products available for C1. According to confidential interviews, cigarette burn marks observed on C1 were all self-inflicted while on AWOL (absence without official lave)

met_with: Directors Kaycee Makalintal, Nemia Apeneieo, Cherry Agravante, Jasmin Nelson, and Clair Ascalon
narrative: On 4/11/25, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Mariah Hawkins and Will Ea conducted an announced prelicensing inspection. LPAs met with Directors Kaycee Makalintal, Nemia Atendido, Cherry Agravante, Jasmin Nelson, and Claire Ascalon. During the inspection, LPAs toured the facility site and reviewed licensing procedures. LPAs observed the facility to be a single-story house in a residential neighborhood. The facility and grounds were maintained in safe condition. Kitchen and bathrooms are in sanitary condition. There are four single-occupancy bedrooms and two bathrooms. Bedrooms have personal storage and clean linens, including spare linens. Hot water measured within permitted range. Sharps and chemicals are locked away where they will be inaccessible to clients. There is locking storage for medications and confidential client records. Grievance procedures, facility sketch with emergency exits shown, and personal rights are posted in the facility. Using the CARE inspection tool, no deficiencies were observed and no corrections were needed. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Directors.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kellie McKinley conducted an announced Pre-licensing inspection on 4/16/2024 at 9:00 AM at the above location, as required for the Group Home (GH) licensure. LPA met with Jamie Murray - Partner. During the pre-licensing visit, LPA conducted a Health and Safety inspection using the CARE tool. LPA observed the facility was clean inside and safe. The outside of the facility has a pool in the back yard that is fully enclosed with a five-foot fence and locking gates. There is a pool house with pump inside. The facilities sits on about 3-4 acres of property, which also is fenced and enclosed. LPA observed that there are two floors to the facility; the upstairs room will be utilized as the staff office for storing inaccessible medications and chemicals, in addition to any other item required to be inaccessible to clients. LPA observed 4 of client bedrooms, equipped with appropriate furniture, bedding, and supplies for clients. Sufficient storage space for client’s personal belongings was observed in each room. The facility is requesting to be licensed for 4 clients. Staff will include eight to ten staff hired and ready for the first clients ranging in age from 13 to 17 years old. LPA observed a medication Lock box in the kitchen, which was empty, but locked, and accessible only to designated staff. The kitchen area was equipped with an adequate amount of utensils, dining supplies, and cups for client. No food was observed as there are no clients, and no pending placements at this time. Facility will verify required food on hand at time of client placement. LPA observed a staff office space that is locked and inaccessible to clients, where client records will be locked in file cabinets. The facility has a detached garage space which houses extra beds, frames, freezer for extra food storage and supplies which is inaccessible to the clients at all times. LPA observed a wood stove fireplace in the living room, and confirmed with the Licensees that they were purchasing a barrier to place around the wood stove. continued on 809_C page

The smoke detectors were tested and found to be functional during the inspection and there were functioning carbon monoxide detectors on each floor of the facility. Number of fire extinguishers were present with a recent inspection date of January 2024. A fully equipped first aid kit was ordered and will be placed in the kitchen area. LPA reviewed the First aid kits content list while at the facility. The Foster Youth Bill of Rights was posted in a conspicuous location. There are 2 bathrooms in the facility that are accessible to client use. The water temperature was tested and found to be 120 degrees. The facility is ready for licensure as an Group Home and LPA recommends that the facility be licensed. A signed copy of this report was provided to Jamie Murray and Jeff Curtis.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kellie McKinley conducted an unannounced Post-licensing inspection on 7/11/24 at 8:45 AM at the above location, as required for the Group Home licensure. LPA met with Amaya Chase- DSP and Cory Ranberg- administrator. During the post-licensing visit, LPA conducted a Health and Safety inspection using the CARE tool. LPA observed the facility was clean inside and safe. The outside of the facility is fenced in the backyard, and spacious, clean and well maintained for outdoor activities. LPA observed that there are two floors to the facility. LPA observed three client bedrooms, equipped with appropriate furniture, bedding, and supplies for clients. Sufficient storage space for client’s personal belongings was observed in each room. The facility is licensed for 4 clients and 1 client is currently in placement. An LIC 500 was received and the facility has 15 staff members not including the administrators. Staff to client ratio is 3-4/1 currently. During sleeping hours ratio is 2-1 for night staff. LPA observed the medication stored and locked in an locked office in a locked filing cabinet. The kitchen area was equipped with an adequate number of utensils, dining supplies, and cups for clients. LPA observed 2 days of perishable food and 7 days of non-perishable food on site. LPA observed a staff office space that is locked and inaccessible to clients, where client records are locked in file cabinets in a locked office. Facility has a garage used for maintenance supplies and is locked and made inaccessible to clients. The laundry room does have a door, but all cleaning supplies and chemicals are locked up high in cabinets. The smoke detectors were tested and found to be functional during the inspection and there were functioning carbon monoxide detectors on each floor of the facility. Three fire extinguishers were present with a recent inspection date of 1/14/2024. A fully equipped first aid kit was in the office area. Report continued on 809- C

LPA observed the following items posted:- Personal Rights, Emergency Disaster, Exit signs, Foster Care Bill of Rights, Facility Sketch with emergency exit routes identified. There are two bathrooms in the facility that are accessible to client use. The water temperature was tested and found to be within regulatory temperature. LPA conducted 2 of staff interviews and 0 of clients interviews. Client interviews could not be conducted as client is not verbally understandable to LPA. LPA reviewed 3 of staff files and 1 client files. This facility meets Interim Licensing Standards mandates and is clean safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPA recommends the facility obtains permanent license with management approval. A signed copy of this report was provided to Cory Ranberg and Jamie Murray. End of report.

On 5/15/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kellie McKinley arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Nicole Eccles- Facility Manager. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a Required Annual Inspection of the facility. The last Annual inspection for the facility was on 7/11/24 for a post Licensing inspection.. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the Annual inspection. The facility is licensed to provide treatment services for ambulatory children ages 8 to 17 years. The facility currently has one clients, all Regional Center placements. One client(s) was/were present during the inspection, yet left soon after for a scheduled appointment . The facility is licensed for a maximum capacity of 4. Staff to client ratio is 4:1. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant, and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility had no noticeable odor and maintained an acceptable room temperature. There are a total of four bedrooms available for clients, with each client having their own bedroom. LPA observed the client bedrooms, living rooms, kitchen, two bathrooms, the backyard, the garage, and the staff office to be clean and organized. LPA observed each client bedroom to have a closet, a dresser, and a clean mattress. Sheets, blankets, and pillows were in good condition. Every bedroom was decorated with the client’s personal items. LPA observed a locked staff office where files and medications are stored. Client files were stored electronically with password protection. LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hotline, menu, and continued on 809 C page

emergency disaster plan. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. The facility has no outstanding fees. LPA observed 3 days of perishable food and 7 days of non-perishable food in the kitchen and in the additional refrigerator in the garage. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions were inaccessible. LPA reviewed one client files. One client is currently taking parent approved medications and had current parental consent on file. Psychotropic medication logs for clients were written on separate Psychotropic Medication Administration Records. Clients were current on CHDP physical exams and dental exams. The client’s Needs and Services Plan/Individual Program Plan, were complete and up to date. LPA reviewed 4 staff files. Staff files had completed criminal record clearances and all required initial and annual training. First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for all staff. Administrators Certificate was valid. LPA interviewed 3 staff on site. LPA interviewed 0 clients, as client left to attend a scheduled appointment. No citations were given on this date.

Staff #1 stated there was a commotion in Child 1 & Child 2's shared room and upon entering room Staff 2 saw Child 2 on top of Child 1 in Child 1's bed. narrative: Confidential interviews revealed that Child #1 self harms as part of Child #1's behavior. It was reported to LPA Phillips that staff are taught to redirect client and hold Child #1 hands during attempts to self harm. Staff stated they are doing their best to provide one on one care. It was reported to LPA Phillips if available staff sit with Child #1 but still need to assist with other residents as needed. It was reported to LPA Phillips that funding is needed to provide one on one staff care to Child #1. It was reported to LPA Phillips funding request has been made by and will notify facility. Staff #1, Staff #2 and Staff #3 all state they make sure Child #1 is eating and try to make sure foods that Child #1 likes is prepared. Also Staff #1 said Child #1 like spicy foods and tries to prepare spicy food that Child #1 likes such as fries, chicken tenders and tater tots. LPA Phillips was provided a daily food log listing all food and amounts consumed by Child #1. It was reported to LPA Phillips that the facility is making every effort to meet the needs of Child #1 but admit Child #1 requires a higher level of care. During the confidential interviews it was reported to LPA Phillips that Child #1 is hard to place and lack of funding to being a minor. Due to inconsistent statements LPA Phillips was not able to determine if the above said allegations occurred, therefore the allegations were found to be Unsubstantiated meaning that although the allegations may have happened or are valid there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged incidents occurred. No deficiencies cited at the time of this investigation. Exit interview was conducted, and copy of the report will be left with facility administrator.

narrative:
On 11/03/2023 at 09:00 AM, (LPA) Licensing Program Analyst - Dennis Jarmin made an unannounced visit to Angeles Vista Children's Home to conduct the annual required inspection. LPA met with Danny Brown/DSP, who granted access to the facility. LPA then inspected the entire physical plant of the facility. The Group Home is licensed and provides care and supervision for six (6) children, ages 11-21 years Ambulatory only. There are no bodies of water on the premises and camera waiver is on file. State of California of license was posted. The Group Home Administrator confirmed that there are no guns or weapons stored on the premises. The facility is a one 1- story home with 3 bedrooms and 2 1/2 bathrooms. LPA observed the facility clean and sanitized with clean linens, appropriate drawer storage and closet available for clients clothing. The 2 1/2 bathrooms were observed clean and sanitary with the required hot water temperature within the regulation. The dining room and living room area had appropriate seatings, and furniture were in good repair condition. The facility has central air conditioning unit that provides suitable air temperature throughout the home with appropriate lighting. LPA observed all the windows in good condition including screens and blinds that are styled double hang with no bars in the event of an emergency evacuation. All passageway and porches were clear of obstruction and all required posting were met (meal plan, daily activities, required licenses and regulations, personal rights and emergency disaster plan) that are posted in the common area readily accessible to clients. LPA observed cleaning supplies solutions, bleaches and disinfectants are properly stored under the sink that is locked. Sharp knives were also observed locked and inaccessible on a separate cabinet opposite of the kitchen sink. CONTINUE TO LIC 809C

The clients are all nonverbal and prescribed medications that are stored in a locked, RED medication rolling cart located pass the kitchen area. LPA observed 5 hard wired and 3 battery operated combined smoke detectors and 1 Carbon Monoxide monitor, all system was tested by maintenance that have appropriate audible sounds and operable. The right side of the medication cart was the laundry area with no safety issues or concerns noted and an office for staff/administrator were on the rear exit of the home. The facility had outdoor area that are located in the front and back perimeter with no debris or hazardous materials noted. The facility has a working telephone and 2 mobile unit that clients can use unless prohibited by court order. The home accord clients with dignity in personal relationships with personnel and others. Overall, the licensee operates within the conditions and limitations of the license including capacity limitations. The facility has a current written plan of operation and all personnel are directed to report violations of Personal Rights. The Licensee reports any changes in operation that affects clients service and reports clients injuries that prompted medical service or treatment. LPA conducted 2 Staff interviews, zero client interviews due to clients nonverbal conditions and reviewed 4 client records. LPA also reviewed the administrator file and 7 personnel files with no concerns noted. During this inspection, LPA observed the facility clean, sanitary, safe and free of hazards, and there are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report will be emailed to Annielyn Dumas, Facility Administrator..

On 10/01/2024 at 09:15 AM, (LPA) Licensing Program Analyst - Kim Dear made an unannounced visit to Angeles Vista Children's Home to conduct the annual inspection continuation. LPA met with Linda Hudson, whom granted access into the facility. LPA then completed file inspections and CARES Tool input. The Group Home is licensed and provides care and supervision for six (6) children, ages 11-21 years Ambulatory only. There are no bodies of water on the premises and camera waiver is on file. State of California of license was posted. Based on CARES Tool completion, facility will be cited and has technical A and B advisories. LPA observed facility to be clean, safe and sanitary. Facility will be cited for non- compliance of personnel currently working at the facility without clearance, as well as health clearance violations and the lack of staff training in which poses a health and safety risk for children in care. . An exit Interview was conducted with the facility administrator, a copy of Appeal Rights were provided and a copy of this report was given to facility..

This is an amended report. On 09/27/2024 at 09:30 AM, (LPA) Licensing Program Analyst - Kim Dear made an unannounced visit to the Angeles Vista Children's Home to conduct an annual required inspection. LPA met with Kylia James, Direct Support Professional, (DSPII), who granted access into the facility. LPA was greeted by Rodtricia Brooks, DSPI whom stated the current census at this facility is 4. The Group Home is licensed and provides care and supervision for six children, ages 6-17 years of age, ambulatory only. The State of California license was posted. The kitchen has new refrigerator and stainless sink. Two of the full bathrooms have new shower stalls, new sink, vanity with mirror, toilets and newly installed tile flooring. The half bathroom has new toilet bowl and vanity with mirror, and newly installed tile flooring. The Group Home Administrator confirmed that there are no guns or weapons stored on the premises. The facility is a one story home with 3 bedrooms and 2 1/2 bathrooms. LPA observed the facility clean and sanitized with clean linens, appropriate drawer storage and closet available for clients clothing. The bathrooms were observed to be clean and sanitary with the required hot water temperature, (103 F) within the regulation. The dining room and living room area had appropriate seating, furniture cushioning and springs are in good condition. The facility has central air conditioning through out housing and lighting is appropriate. Wood laminate flooring is throughout the living room, dinning room, kitchen and hallways. LPA observed windows throughout the facility to be in good condition including screens. Passageways and porches were clear of obstruction and all required posting were met (meal plan, daily activities, required licenses and regulations, personal rights and emergency disaster plan. LPA observed cleaning supplies/ solutions, bleaches and disinfectants are properly stored under the sink, in cabinets as well as in outdoor storage unit that is locked. Sharp knives were also observed locked and inaccessible to clients. Washer and dryer appliances are available on service porch of the kitchen area. Kitchen has a double sided sink. (See 809C)

All of the clients prescribed medications are in locked rolling cabinet. LPA observed a total of (6) smoke detectors/ carbon monoxide units were push tested tested by maintenance staff to be operable. The garage has been converted in 2 offices; Administrator & Social Worker office and other portion used for extra supplies stacked neatly on metal shelving. An additional office for Staff is located behind the laundry set up, to the left of rear exit door of the house. There are no bodies of water on the premises. Facilities camera waiver is on file, however current licensee is unaware if the equipment is functioning/ recording or not. The facility has a working telephone and clients can use the telephone unless restricted by court order. Clients are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. The Facility operates within license conditions and capacity limitations. LPA conducted five (5) Staff interviews, no client interviews were conducted due to client's non- verbal abilities. LPA reviewed four (4) staff files and four (4) client records. LPA observed facility to be clean, safe and sanitary. Facility will be cited for non- compliance of personnel currently working at the facility without clearance, as well as health clearance violations and the lack of staff training in which poses a health and safety risk for children in care. Facility cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, regulation(s). An immediate civil penalty has been issued for sections: 80019 (e)(3). Criminal Record Clearance, 80054(b).Civil Penalty, 84061(e), Reporting Requirements, and 84065(h), Personnel Records. An exit Interview was conducted with the facility administrator, Lorrena Maloy and a copy of this report was provided.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Criminal Record (3) Request a transfer of a criminal record clearance as specified in Section 80019(f) The requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observation(s) and interviews, the facility failed to transfer staff 1,2, and 3 criminal record clearances to the facility which poses a an immediate health and safety risk to the clients in care.

Notwithstanding Section 80054(a) above, an immediate penalty of $100 per cited violation per day for a maximum of five (5) days shall be assessed if any individual required to be fingerprinted under Health and Safety Code Section 1522(b) has not obtained a California clearance or a criminal record exemption, requested a transfer of a criminal record clearance or requested and be approved for a transfer of an exemption as specified in Section 80019(e) prior to working, residing or volunteering in the facility.

(e) Effective January 1, 2000, the licensee shall notify the Department, in writing, within ten (10) days of any change in the facility administrator.The requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, the licensee did not notify CCL regarding the change of administrator.

Personal Records (h) The licensee shall develop, maintain, and implement a written plan for the supervision, evaluation, and training of all child care staff. The requirement is not met evidenced by: Based on records review, LPA was unable to verify whether sraff completed any training(s)

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Criminal Record Clearance " All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility: Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department or" This requierment is not meet as evidence by: Based on documentation and interview evidence collected the facility failed to obtain staff criminal record clearances which poses an immediate health and safety hazard to the clients in care.

Civil Penalty. Notwithstanding Section 80054(a) above, an immediate penalty of $100 per cited violation per day for a maximum of five (5) days shall be assessed if any individual required to be fingerprinted under Health and Safety Code 1522 (b) has not obtained a California clearance or a criminal record exemption, requested a transfer of a criminal record clearance. narrative: LPA received conflicting testimonies regarding the operational status of the facility phone. Witness interviews shared that the phone was not working during a specific visit. Witness interviews could not testify to why the phone was not working, for how long the phone was not working, or what the facility's response was. Staff testified that the facility phone was non-operational for a time, the facility’s response was to try and fix the issue with the provider Spectrum, and then when the issue could not be fixed the facility just replaced the phone. LPA also observed the new phone to be in working order. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews, and observation evidence, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met; therefore, the allegation that the “Staff did not ensure telephone was working properly” is found to be unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights was given to Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On7/22/25 at 1:59 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen arrived at the above facility and met with Administrator Larrina Maloy for the purpose of delivering complaint findings regarding the above allegation. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed involved staff and witnesses. LPA was unable to interview clients due to them being non-verbal. Witness testimony alleged that during a visit, staff shared that the facility phone was not working at the moment and would hopefully be fixed soon. Staff interviews admitted that there was an issue with the phones for a short period of time from 3/29-4/1 2025. During that time, the facility's response was to call Spectrum, the phone provider. Spectrum tried to do some resets and reboots remotely, which did not work. Staff explained that neither they nor Spectrum could figure out the phone problem. Spectrum shared that they could not come out to service the phone until 4/3/25. The facility did not want to wait, so they just replaced the phone, which is now in working order. Staff state that they were not able to receive a work order from Spectrum because Spectrum never came out physically to work on the phone. During LPA's visit, LPA called and tested the new phone and observed it to be in working order.

narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Alyssa Ng and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong met with applicant Mary Jane Cagadas via Microsoft Team Meeting to conduct a component II of the orientation process. The following items were discussed: - Physical Plant and the use of the facility - Facility will provide care for DD clients, Level 4I with Regional Center -Administrator will be working at the facility minium 20 hours weekly -Training for staff including topics on Medication, DSP 1 & 2, and Emergency Intervention -Reviewing and understanding of Title 22 regulations and Health and Safety Codes -Personal Rights -Supportive Services Component III and Pre-Licensing inspection will be scheduled by LPA Alyssa Ng when she received fire clearance. The purpose of this meeting was to discuss the facilities Program Statement and Plan of Operation. The following items were discussed: - Goal/Purpose of the Group Home -Training for staff (CPI, DSP, etc.) -Intake/Admission Process for future clients -Needs & Service Plan & how to incorporate the goals into the clients lives -Planned Social Activities -Emergency Intervention Procedures (COVID plan, ON-Call staff, Fire, etc.) -AWOL/Runaway Procedure -Incident Reports -Special Services offered -Fingerprinting/Guardian process -Behavior management -Visitation Procedure/Policy Component III and Pre-Licensing date is set for August 8th at 10:30 AM. On September 21, 2022 at 9:45am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection of the facility. LPA met and toured the facility with Mary Jane Cagadas, Licensee. This Group Home is a one story facility located in a residential area. The facility consists of 3 client bedrooms and 2 client bathrooms, living and dining areas, kitchen, and laundry room. There are two locked sheds in the backyard and it was discussed with the Licensee that Community Care Licensing (CCL) would need access at all times. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed and all doors open freely. There is no pool on the premises. Fire arms are not allowed on the facility premises. At the time of visit, the following was observed: Fire extinguishers are throughout the house. Smoke detectors are throughout the house and operational. Carbon monoxide detectors are located in the hallway, outside of the client bedrooms. Each bedroom has a bed, clean linens, and adequate drawer/cabinet space. Facility has a fire clearance. First aid kit was observed. Hot water temperature measured at 108 degrees Fahrenheit.

Staff and client files will be locked in the filing cabinet in the dining room. Medications will be centrally stored and locked in the filing cabinet in the dining room. Disinfectants and other toxic materials will be locked in the laundry room. Extra bedding and towels are kept unlocked, in the hallway closet. Sharp knives are kept locked in a tool box in the kitchen. Site location has a live in staff bedroom and bathroom that is kept locked, and meets prelicensing requirements. Site location has ring cameras at the front door and on the outside perimeter of the house. Per Licensee, they belong to the homeowner and are not hooked up. Licensee will provide a sworn affidavit from homeowner stating the ring cameras are not in use and will not be activated as long as this site location is a Community Care Licensing facility. Licensee agrees to meet current County safety COVID guidelines. Items to complete prior to licensure/placement. Send photos once complete. - remove or hang pictures that are currently in client bedroom closets - replace missing electric plate in dining room - lock toxins in laundry room and staff bathroom - child lock on mini-fridge in dining room (secure lock if meds are inside) - swing outside to be set up This facility will be ready for licensure once above is completed, Licensee submits Nonprofit Articles of Incorporation and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) has reviewed the application file. Component II: LPA Pavia discussed with the following, with Administrator: - Administrator on site required hours - discipline policies & house rules - facility emergency intervention plan

On 10/24/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Mary Jane Cagadas and informed of the purpose of the visit. The facility has had no placements (clients), as the vendorization is still pending with Regional Center. Administrator agreed to update LPA when the vendor certificate is acquired. LPA inspected the facility site and grounds and reviewed facility records with Administrator. LPA observed the facility to be clean and organized, kitchen and bathroom spaces to be maintained in sanitary condition, and bedrooms to be tidy and ready for clients. Using the CARE Inspection Tool, no deficiencies were found. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Mary Jane Cagadas, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 10/07/24, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Celeste Aparicio and Jonathan Medina conducted a unannounced required annual inspection. LPAs met with Administrator Mary Jane Cagadas and informed of the purpose of the visit. During the inspection the resident in care was present in the facility due to being on a Fall break from school. The resident was engaged in daily activities during the inspection. Administrator indicated that the resident is nonverbal. LPAs observed resident to be dressed in clean, well-fitting clothes, and to be closely supervised by present personnel. Facility Administrator indicated that the present personnel helping with the resident in care were the Administrators parents who would be residing at the facility for a six month period. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to conduct the inspection. At the start of the inspection LPAs conducted a walk through of the facility, inside and out. LPAs observed centrally stored medications maintained in a locked cabinet, three client bedrooms, two bathrooms , living room, kitchen, dining area, washroom, and garage that had been converted into a staff office/ bedroom. LPA's observed at least one-week supply of nonperishable and a two-day supply of perishable food. In the backyard LPA's observed two sheds. The larger shed was used as a storage space as the other smaller shed was used for gardening materials. Both sheds were locked. The facility is maintained at 77 degrees. Hot water temperature measures at 112 degrees. LPA observed the facility to be clean, organized, and to be maintained in sanitary condition. During the walk through LPA's observed two cleaning materials left out in unlocked spaces. LPAs asked licensee to keep these materials in locked cabinets, the facility Administrator placed these cleaning materials in the appropriate locations.

LPAs reviewed one client file and three staff files. After documentation review and interview with Administrator, LPA advised the facility converting into a Small Family Home to better satisfy facility licensing standards. LPAs identified areas in which the licensee could improve documentation regarding staff training logs, disaster preparedness, licensing forms, and complaint procedures. LPA is issuing six technical assistance advisory notes and one Technical Violation relating to the discussed topics. Additionally, LPA is issuing a citation Health and Safety Code, Section 1565(c) regarding the two uncleared personnel present at the facility. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Mary Jane Cagadas, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: 13On 6/23/2023, at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vaishali SIngh-Sood conducted an unannounced visit to the facility. On July 2, 2024, at 10:30 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley arrived unannounced at the facility and met with John Lieberman, Chief Executive Officer, to assess a Civil Penalty. LPA Linley conducted confidential interviews and a record review which indicted that there were two Adults (A1, A2) who did not have a criminal record clearance prior to working at the facility. LPA reviewed Guardian to ensure that the individuals had a criminal record clearance; review indicated that A1 was not listed on the roster and was not listed in Guardian, and A2’s clearance was pending. LPA Linley asked for any supporting documents the facility may have and they were unable to provide it or what they provided was incomplete. LPA Linley is administering two civil penalties during this visit. Based on record review and staff interviews, the facility is being cited for the violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, regulation 80019(e) Criminal Record Clearance. Record review confirms A1 and A2 have worked in the facility without a criminal record clearance. An immediate civil penalty is being issued for $1,000.00. A civil penalty shall be assessed for a maximum of 5 days for the first violation. For subsequent violations within 12 months, a civil penalty shall be assessed for a maximum of 30 days. An exit interview was conducted with John Lieberman. Due to printer malfunction, a copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to John Lieberman. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Criminal Record Clearance: All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility: This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and record review, LPA observed that A1 and A2 did not have a criminal record clearance prior to working at the facility. A1 and A2 were working at the facility without fingerprint clearances, which poses an immediate Health, Safety risk to children in care.

The following documents were reviewed during the investigation: Personnel Roster, Client Roster, Admission Agreements, Medication Logs, Centrally Stored Medication Records, Physician Reports, Nursing Notes, Master Treatment Plans, Needs and Services Plans, Degrees/Licenses, Timesheets, and employee schedules. On May 3, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received allegations that staff do not allow minors to ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE

narrative:
This is an amended report to amend the 809-D page regarding regulations Title 22 Division 6 Chapter 5 Article 6 84070(b)(16)(G) Children's Records, and Title 22 Division 6 Chapter 5 Article 6 84070(b)(16)(F) Children's Records (refer to LIC 809D). On July 17, 2024, at 2:20 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Ehsan Ebrahim, Program Director, to discuss information that was reported to Community Care Licensing and records reviewed by LPA on June 27, 2024. LPA conducted confidential interviews with nine staff (S1-9), LPA also attempted to interview one staff (S10), and was unable to contact them despite multiple attempts. LPA also conducted a record review for three clients (C1-C3), which indicated that on June 4, 2024, S10 gave C1 C2’s prescribed medication in error. The facility notified C1’s Physician; however, the facility did not report the information and submit an Incident Report to Community Care Licensing until after LPA’s visit on June 27, 2024. On June 27, 2024, while reviewing C1’s Psychotropic Medication Administration Record or equivalent (PMAR), LPA observed C1’s PMAR for May for medication #1 had an “R” (R = refers to a client refusal) recorded in the boxes for May 28, 29, and blank boxes for May 30, 31, and June 1-5. Records reviewed indicated that C1’s Physician discontinued medication #1 on May 28. Additionally, LPA observed on C1’s PMAR for June, C1’s medication #2 did not have the times of the dosages listed. Confidential interviews and records reviewed, indicated that there was a change in the Chief Executive Officer, and the facility did not notify Community Care licensing within 10 working days. Lastly, records reviewed indicated that C3 turned 18 years old and remained at the facility for four days after turning 18. The facility is licensed for children between the ages of 12-17 and the facility did not request an exception from Community Care Licensing for C3 to remain at the facility beyond the age of 18. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE

Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, the facility is being cited for violating California Code of Regulations Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1 80061 Reporting Requirements, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6 84070 Children’s Records, and Title 22 Division 6 Chapter 1 Article 2 80010(a) Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status, Title 22 Division 6 Chapter 5 Article 6 84070(b)(16)(G) Children's Records, and Title 22 Division 6 Chapter 5 Article 6 84070(b)(16)(F) Children's Records (refer to LIC 809D). An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were reviewed with Ehsan Ebrahim. Due to printer malfunction, a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were emailed to Ehsan Ebrahim. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80061(1)(E) Reporting Requirements: Any unusual incident or client absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, the facility did not report an unusual incident of S10 giving C1 C2’s medication in error and CCL did not receive an Incident Report until after LPA’s visit on 06/27/2024, which posed immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.

80010(a) Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status: A licensee shall not operate a facility beyond the conditions and limitations specified on the license, including the capacity limitation. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed: C3 remained placed at the facility after they turned 18 without an age exception, which posed potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.

84070(b)(16)(G) Children's Records: Documentation of each refusal....documentation shall include the name of the medication refused, date and time of the refusal, the reason for the refusal, who was notified of the refusal, and any observed results of the refusal. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed: The PMAR forms that were provided to CCL had blank boxes for the medication that was to be dispersed on 05/30-06/05/2024, which posed immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.

84070(b)(16)(F): Children's Records: A separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to the child documenting all the following…the date and time of each dose taken by the child. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on records reviewed: LPA observed that C1’s PRN psychotropic medication sheet for June did not have the times of the dose listed, which potential immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.

narrative:

A physical plant inspection was completed with Executive Director, Jackie Hoagland and included the following checks: The front house, one living room, three offices, two storage rooms, one restroom, one kitchen, and one dining area. The back house/main house, school room, recreation room, kitchen, pantry, dining room, staff room, two offices, medication room/nurse's station, group room, laundry room, pantry, supply closet, ten client bedrooms, three client bathrooms, one staff bathroom, kitchen, living room, dining room, Administrator office, outdoor garden, and laundry room. All required forms are posted including Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster, the Emergency Disaster ****Continued on Page 2****

Plan was also posted. Clients’ medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in the medication room. LPA observed eighteen (18) interior and nine (9) exterior cameras placed around the facility. No cameras are positioned in direct line of bedrooms, ,bathrooms, or any direction that would violate personal rights. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Fre extinguishers are properly charged and serviced on 05/18/2025. Fire inspection was completed on 01/14/2025 and LPA received a copy of the approved Fire Inspection to place in facility file. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. LPA observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable and two-day perishable supply of food. On staff chef prepares three meals a day tailored to each client. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattress in good repair. All ten bedrooms contain two twin beds. The facility has three client bathrooms and five showers. The water temperature was tested in one bathroom and met the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA reviewed five client files to ensure client records had all required documents per Title 22 regulations. Client records are stored in a secured office. LPA reviewed nine client medication records. LPA conducted two staff interviews and two client interviews. No deficiencies cited. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. The licensing fee payments are current. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, confidential names (LIC811), and appeal rights were discussed and provided to Ehsan Ebrahim. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

On June 13, 2025, at 8:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Stefanie Mutialu continued the unannounced annual inspection, which was started on June 06 ,2025. LPA met with Human Resource Director, Amanda Dicker via Zoom meeting. LPA reviewed five staff (S1-S5) files. Five out of five staff records reviewed have the verification of Department of Justice, Federal Bureau of Investigation, and Child Abuse Index Check clearances and were associated to the facility. Five out of five staff records reviewed have proof in file of acknowledging confidentiality and mandated child abuse reporting requirements. Staff files a kept on a secure online data base. No deficiencies cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, Confidential Names List (LIC811), and appeal rights were discussed and emailed to Human Resource Director, Amanda Dicker. A signed copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

On the above date a scheduled component II orientation was held virtually via the Microsoft teams platform. Present for the Department was Lisa Slusher, Licensing Program Analyst. Representing the Applicant were: Jason Christopherson, Alicia Alva, Devon Wayt, Jazmin Galvan and Christina Kiesselbach. Discussed review letter dated 7/1/22 and outstanding program items as well as status of the organization. LPA also discussed licensing environment and expectations. LPA stated that component III and pre-licensing inspection would be scheduled following program approval.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lisa Slusher travelled to the facility listed above to conduct a pre-licensing inspection. The applicant submitted an application on 2/4/2022. The Program Statement has been reviewed and approved as meeting regulatory requirements. LPA met with Jason Christopherson, Brittany Farrell, Alicia Alva, Devon Wayt, Jazmin Galvan and Christina Kiesselbach 1. Facility grounds inspected. Grounds are clean and free from observable hazard. No bodies of water observed on the property. 2. Adequate indoor activity space and materials observed, and outdoor activity space was observed. 3. Chemicals were appropriately locked 4. Procedures for Locked and centrally stored medications observed. 6. Adequate storage space observed. 7. Individual beds in good repair observed. A supply of extra linens available for bed changes. 8. The house has 4 bedrooms, a mixture of single double occupancy, located on two levels. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Facility will add appropriate supply of foods upon placement of youth in the home. A supply of nonperishable foods were observed on this date. 10. Sample menu posted. 11. All appropriate forms posted within client view. 12. Dining room equipped with large table and chairs accommodating of all clients. 13.Facility has three full restrooms, two for client use, one for staff use, all are operable. Hot water measured within 105-120 on this date.

Applicant does not have personnel associated through Guardian. Prior to initial license approval, the licensee (corporation owner) and Administrator must be fingerprint cleared and associated to the facility. Prior to accepting clients for care, the facility shall ensure that all personnel who will have client contact are cleared and associated. Discussed Guardian process with the facility. Discussed with the facility the process for changing the facility Administrator. The following documents are required: 1. LIC 308 (Designation of Facility Responsibility) designating new administrator. 2. Current Personnel Record for new Administrator. 3. Verification of Education and/or experience for new administrator. 4. Copy of current administrator certificate. 5. Current (within one year) health screening and TB test. 6. Board Resolution granting administrative responsibility to the new administrator. 7. Fingerprint association transfer request (if the Administrator is not already associated to the facility) 8. Exception request (if the Administrator does not specifically meet regulatory requirements, i.e. experience is in a facility with a capacity of six or fewer). Discussed Incident reporting. An initial report for all reportable incidents is to be made by the next working day to CCLFresnoIncidents@dss.ca.gov. A full report is to be remitted within 7 days and may also be made to the incident reporting email. The currently assigned analyst for the facility will be Wayne Aoki. Wayne.Aoki@dss.ca.gov or at (559) 978-9486. On this date, the facility will be approved for initial licensure, pending verification of guardian clearance and association for the Licensee and Administrator. Initial license will be issued on a provisional basis, expiring one year from effective date. License will be valid for up to 6 male and/or female youth ages 12 through 17.

investigation_findings: 13On March 8, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wayne Aoki was met by Program Manager, Aaron Vargas for the purpose of closing the investigation and providing the agency with the findings for the above-mentioned allegation. Based on confidential interviews and other documents obtained during the investigation, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be substantiated. The agency is being cited in Group Home, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6 Continuing Requirements, Section 84072 (d)(10) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84072(d)(10) Personal Rights -The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9, as applicable. In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights:To be accorded dignity in his or her personal relationships with staff and other persons. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Staff was inappropriate with minors in care which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the residents in care.

narrative: On June 28, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wayne Aoki travelled to Ascend Behavioral Health to conduct a Case Management Inspection regarding an Incident Report. LPA was met by Nikki Hill, Compliance Officer. LPA informed Ms. Hill that on the incident report it stated that the incident occurred on June 6, 2023 and Community Care Licensing received the incident report on June 19, 2023 which is past the 7 day reporting period. LPA also informed Ms. Hill that in the body of the incident report it stated that the incident occurred on June 12, 2023 which meets the regulatory standard for reporting an incident to the licensing agency. Ms. Hill explained that on the first page of the LIC 624 they provided the wrong date under the section of, "Date Occurred" and that the correct date should have been entered was June 12, 2023. Ms, Hill will correct the error and submit the amended LIC 624 to this LPA on June 28, 2023. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84072(d)(10) Personal Rights- The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9, as applicable. In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights:To be accorded dignity in his or her personal relationships with staff and other persons. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Staff shared personal information and crossed professional boundaries with minor in care which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the residents in care.

80075(b)(5)(B)Health Related Services- Clients shall be assisted as needed with self-administration of prescription and nonprescription medications. If the client's physician has stated in writing that the client is unable to determine his/her own need for nonprescription PRN medication, but can communicate his/her symptoms clearly, facility staff designated by the licensee shall be permitted to assist the client with self-administration, providing all of the following requirements are met:Once ordered by the physician the medication is given according to the physician's directions. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Staff did not follow physician's orders for PRN medication for minor and provided more medication than was presecirbed. which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the residents in care

narrative: An unannounced annual inspection continuation was conducted by LPA (Licensing Program Analyst) Reyna Martinez. LPA met with Aaron Vargas, Program Manager. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs 1 program manager, 1 clinical supervisor, 2 clinicians, 1 case manager, 2 LVN's, and 5 support staff. 5 records of clients were reviewed. Client files did not meet all regulatory requirements. Upon further review staff files did not meet (1) regulatory requirement. Facility did not have Disaster Preparedness Binder readily available with required documentation. Facility Residential Treatment Program Rules not consistent with Facility Program Statement. 2 staff were available to be interviewed. 2 clients available to be interviewed. Deficiencies were cited on today's visit. Technical Violation's and Technical Advisory were being issued on today's visit. A copy of this report was left at the facility, along with appeal rights.

An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by LPA (Licensing Program Analyst) Reyna Martinez. LPA met with Alicia Alva, VP Operations and inspected the facility, inside and out. Centrally stored medications are maintained in a locked closet in a locked cabinet. Sharps and Toxic chemicals are kept locked. The facility has a written emergency disaster plan. All facility smoke detectors were tested and appear to be in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and was last serviced October 2023. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. There is at least one-week supply of nonperishable and a two-day supply of perishable foods. The facility is maintained at 70 degrees. Hot water temperature measures 117.9 degrees. Facility has cameras outside of the facility only. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. No pools. 5 Staff files were reviewed and meet all regulatory requirements. Additional follow up required for annual inspection to complete client records, staff and client interviews. No Deficiencies were cited on today's visit. A copy of this report was left at the facility.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reyna Martinez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lourey Bartolome, conducted an office visit at Community Care Licensing Fresno Children's Residential Unit with Ascend Behavioral Health for an informational meeting to provide further clarification on regulatory language and CCR 84070(b)(13) with the Licensee. LPA and LPM met with Jason Christopherson, Clinical Director, Alicia Alva, VP Operations, and Aaron Vargas, Program Manager. Discussed was LIC-622B Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (MAR) and the Licensee's electronic medical record keeping system. Further discussion and details are needed. LPM will elevate this issue for further clarification. No Deficiencies were cited on today's visit. A copy of this report was provided to the Licensee.

On 4/8/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd made an unannounced visit to the Group Home. During this visit, LPA met with Program Manager Aaron Vargas. LPA discussed an incident that LPA was made aware of during confidential interviews, in which one client was able to bring a needle and a pencil into the home to make a weapon. Clients at the facility state that staff do not search them properly and they can bring items into the facility. Clients at the facility state that staff does not properly supervise them, allowing them to hide potentially dangerous items from staff. On the following page, the facility is cited under the California Code of Regulations, General Licensing Requirements for a Type A violation for 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. A copy of this report was left at the facility

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Responsibility for providing care and supervision. (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by; clients disclosed that they bring objects into the facility and hide them so staff cannot find them and staff will not adequately search their belongings to ensure they are safe, which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
