Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Yan Yeung and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Caitlin Chambers conducted a meeting with the applicant, Mr. Matthew Tatum, via Microsoft Teams for the purpose of a Component II discussion of the application. The virtual meeting was held due to this regional office being under renovation. The following pending issues were discussed during the meeting: · Bank information with adequate funding-applicant needs to provide LIC 404 with appropriate bank account information. Current funding shown is inadequate. · Revised LIC 401 (monthly operating statement) showing rate for each client and wages for staff listed on LIC 500 · Copy of lease showing monthly rent which should be matching the rent listed on LIC 401 · Fingerprint association or live scan for all staff names on LIC 500 · Proof of qualification for all staff listed on LIC 500 · Current CPR/first Aid and Health screening for all staff listed on LIC 500 · Copy of Component I with clear information of attendees · Organization chart that shows all line of supervision, with agency titles matching GH staff according to Title 22 listed positions · Updated protocols for infectious diseases · Handling of Cash resources and inventory according to Title 22 regulations 80026. · Revision of meal services and menu of a week according to Title 22 regulation 80076 · Revision of House rules to avoid blanket statements which could be personal rights violations. · List all visitation hours for clients. · List all reporting requirement to the Department. · List details of Runaway plan showing time requirement for contacting law enforcement and reporting timeframe for the Department. · List the writer and the qualification that wrote the emergency intervention plan · List who are the internal/external trainers used for the training of staff · Reorganization of table of contents to comprise with all the content of LIC 9106 (Table of contents for Group home program statement) Some of the above topics need a revision of the program statement which will be due to the department by February 7, 2025. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the applicant, Mr. Tatum for signature. Mr. Tatum will need to sign and mail back a hard copy and a e-copy of this report to LPA Chambers.

On 3/27/25, at 11:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Caitlin Chambers made an announced Prelicensing Inspection at the Ascend Behavioral Health Group Home. The LPA met with applicant Matthew Tatum and informed him that the purpose for the inspection was to assess the facility’s physical environment prior to issuance of a license. LPA Chambers along with Mr. Tatum conducted an overall visual assessment of the inside and outside the Agency's physical plant. At the time of the inspection, LPA observed a one story home in a residential area. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. The Community Care Licensing Hotline complaint number and the Fresno Crisis Hotline number is framed on the wall where the client have a room to take there medication, located next to the classroom. The Emergency Disaster Plan for Children Residential Facilities (LIC 610C), Fire Evacuation/Escape plan and the Agency floor plan (sketch, with labeled rooms) is available near the front of the home. To the right of the home is a room for the therapist and clinicians to work. There is a menu of the fridge, and due to no clients being there, there is just snacks in the fridge. The facility has room for six clients. There are six beds for each of the clients in the bedrooms.

Each bedroom has a dresser, night stand with drawers, a ceiling fan, and night lamps on the night stand. The bedrooms are as follows: Bedroom #1 has two beds, two dressers/ wardrobes. Bedroom #2 is a private bedroom meaning it has one full size bed, walk in closet, and a catty in the walk in closet. Bedroom #3 has two sinks, and a shower. Bedroom #4 has a private bedroom room meaning it has a full-size bed and shares a bathroom with Bedroom #2 and bedroom #3. The temperature of the water is in range in six sinks and 3 of the showers ranging from 111 degrees F to 119.3 degrees F. There is a full size bathroom outside Bedroom #2. There is a kitchen with 6 stools and a dining area for the clients to eat. There is a classroom/ multipurpose room where the Academic Case Manager will be. There are six large desks and six chairs with lighting for a classroom setting with windows. Next to the staff area is the medication room with all locked boxes and Medication folders to keep track of the medication checks. Outside of the classroom there is a closet for the clients to keep their personal items in security boxes. Next to the laundry room is locked closet full of colored coded towels of all sizes and well organized. There are two pairs of towels per client and two pairs of linens for each client. Also, inside the laundry room has the chemicals for cleaning clothes, and extra supplies for hygiene for the clients. Next to the classroom is for staff only area, with a shower, a sink, and a medication room. There is a garage that is turned into mobile workspace with new couches and new rugs and plenty of space. There are phones in the garage/mobile workspace to make phone calls. Outside there is a pool with a locked fence five feet tall. A ping pong table and space for clients to play in the grass, or cement. There are no firearms or ammunition in the facility. There is planned activities for the whole week. LPA Chambers checked the fire extinguisher next to the kitchen with current dates on the extinguisher and smoke detectors were checked in each bedroom. The home temperature is cool and comfortable at 70 degrees. Per applicant, written menus will be current and posted weekly in an area accessible to the staff and children, and the Planned Activity Schedule will be current and posted. An LIC 809 report was given to the Licensee. An exit interview was conducted

met_with: Facility Compliance Manager - Dave Trice and Director of Facilities - Zackary Hale
narrative:
On January 26, 2023, at 9:20 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Charmetha White arrived at Ascend Healthcare, for the purpose of conducting a 2 Year Annual Inspection. LPA met with Facility Compliance Manager, Dave Trice and the Director of Facilities, Zackary Hale and was granted access into the facility. The facility was toured at 9:40 AM both inside and out. The facility is a private pay therapeutic treatment program licensed to provide care and supervision services for six (6) children, ages 12-17 years old, ambulatory only. The census at the time of the inspection was six (6). The facility is a two story, 3-bedroom, 5-bathroom house which includes a Living room, Dining room, Kitchen, Laundry room, Staffing/Medical office, a Garage, and a Backyard. The facility is set up as follows: Living room: is furnished with sectional sofa, 2 chairs, and has an non-operating fireplace equipped with an iron screen. Dining room: is furnished with a wooden table and six (6) chairs. Kitchen: is equipped with a 4-burner gas operated stove, a microwave, refrigerator/freezer, a dishwasher, and a toaster. Laundry room: is located in the garage and is equipped with a washer and dryer. Staffing/Medical office: is located on the first floor near the garage. The office is equipped with a computer, chair, and desk. LPA observed the room to have a locked cabinet which are used to stores medication, PPE supplies. Additionally, medications that require refrigeration is stored in a double locked refrigerator located inside the office. The office is locked and made inaccessible to clients in care. Pool: is located in the backyard and is equipped with a fence that meets regulations. Garages: is attached to the home and is equipped with a desk, chair, and gym equipment. There are also two (2) small rooms used staff and client meetings. Backyard: contained a swimming pool equipped with a five foot fence with a self-latching lock, a ping pong table, ½ court basketball, and a sitting area. The backyard was observed to be free of debris and hazardous materials. Report continued on LIC 809C (page 1 of 2)

Bedroom 1: is named Warrior and it is equipped with 2 full size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. Bedroom 2: is named Sunrise and it is equipped with 2 full size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. Bedroom 1 & Bedroom 2 shares a Jack and Jill bathroom. Bedroom 3: is named Horizon and it is equipped with 2 full size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. The room also has a separate bathroom, and French doors, which remain locked at all times, leading to the backyard. All bedrooms were equipped with comfortable mattresses, clean linen, blankets, and pillows. Bathrooms: bathrooms had a toilet, sinks, tub/shower. The bathrooms were clean and in operating condition. Water temperature was observed to be within 105 – 120 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. The home has a linen closet located on the second floor which stores additional towels and sheets. Knives are locked in box located under the stove and made inaccessible to the clients. Disinfectant and cleaning solutions are locked in a storage closet located off of the entrance and made inaccessible the clients. The first aid kit is located in the staff office and was found to be complete with scissors, tweezers, gauzes, antiseptic, 1st Aid Manual, and a thermometer. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons located in the home. The smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. The home has 3 fire extinguishers. There are no security bars on the windows. There is a camera waiver on file. Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility has a current written plan of operation. All posting requirements were met. Clients are provided three nutritious meals and snacks per day. Clients in care are in accorded personal rights. Clients in care are supported, encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Clients in care can contact the licensing agency or Foster Care Ombudsman person in confidence without threats or punishment for making complaints. Clients in care are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Clients in care are not restricted in telephone use except by court order. LPA will return at a later date to review Staff and Client flies. There were no deficiencies cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, chapters 1 & 5. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

met_with: Director of Operations - Jacqueline Marshall Waldron

On June 20, 2024, at 12:55 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin conducted a Case Management - Incident inspection at ASCEND HEALTHCARE Group Home, met with Facility Representative and later with Emely Hernandez, Facility Manager and Jack Waldron, Facility Director in response to an Incident Report submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on June 12, 2024. The incident, reports in part alleged violation of personal rights as a youth was reportedly touched inappropriately by a staff member. During this inspection, LPA Martin informed the incident has been referred to CCL Investigations Branch, Investigator Lorraine Patterson for assignment. Upon completion of the investigation, the investigation findings will be delivered and discussed. LPA Martin requested and/or obtained the following documents from facility records and subject client files: Client Roster (obtained during visit), Personnel Report (Schedule) LIC500, Client Needs and Services Plan, discharge documentation and all incident reports concerning subject youth (if applicable). Please submit requested documents to LPA Regina Martin at regina.martin@dss.ca.gov The incident requires further investigation. Upon completion, the Department's findings will be issued and discussed. There are no deficiencies cited per California Code of Regulations, at this time. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Representative.

On 05/30/2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Andrea Aceves and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith, made an announced visit to Ascend Healthcare #1 for the purpose of a Case Management- Deficiency and met with Acting Facility Manager, David Hurwitz. While initiating a visit at the facility, LPA and LPM requested a copy of the LIC500-Personnel Report. LPA Andrea reviewed the Personnel Report and Guardian roster. LPA and LPM advised Acting Facility Manager, David Hurwitz that Staff #1 was not associated to the home per licensing regulations. In addition, LPM and LPA reminded Acting Facility Manager that all staff working in the home must obtain a criminal record clearance and associated to the facility prior to working in the home. Note: LPM informed staff regarding the Central Administrative Facility Waiver to designate one facility to associate all staff for clearance purposes. LPA will send instructions on submitting the waiver request via email. In addition, LPA will send Provider Information Notice regarding camera use in the facilities. Due to staff not being associated to the facility a deficiency is being cited. See LIC 809D. Exit interview completed and copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to acting facility manager, David Horwitz.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Request a transfer of a criminal record clearance as specified in Section 80019(f) This requirement was not met by evidence by Request a transfer of a criminal record clearance as specified in Section 80019(f) Staff #1 was working in the facility without being associated to the home which poses an immediate health and safety risk to clients in care.
Violation of Section 80019(e) will result in an immediate assessment of civil penalties of one hundred dollars ($100) per violation for a maximum of 5 days by the Department.

narrative: On 05/30/2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Andrea Aceves and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith, made an announced visit to Ascend Healthcare #1 for the purpose of a Case Management- Incident Report. LPA and LPM met with Acting Facility Manager, David Hurwitz to discuss an incident regarding the lack of supervision. The department received an incident report dated 05/22/25. The incident report disclosed that two clients engaged in inappropriate sexual behavior and staff was asleep during the incident. During the investigation LPA obtained copy of LIC 500, client roster, and interviewed Acting Facility Manager, David Hurwitz. Staff #1 was not available for an interview. Staff #1 will be contacted at a later date. LPA informed David Hurwitz that more information is needed. LPA will return at a later date to conclude the investigation. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Acting Facility Manager, David Hurwitz.

On 08/12/25, at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Andrea Aceves and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith made an unannounced visit to Ascend Healthcare for the purpose of conducting a Case Management for Incident Report dated 05/21/25 (#0001797-FN). LPA Andrea and LPM Lakescia met with Facility Manager, Stefan Zeljkovic. During the investigation, LPA Andrea interviewed all available parties, requested and received LIC500-Personnel Report and client roster. The incident occurred on 05/19/25 and the report was received on 05/22/25. Per Facility Manager and S1, LPA was able to confirm that a staff was asleep while on shift. However, due to conflicting statements, LPA was not able to confirm if two clients engaged in inappropriate sexual behavior as reported. No further investigation or interviews are required on the above incident. As a result, the facility is being cited (see LIC809D). Exit interview was completed and copy of the report and appeal rights were discussed and provided to Facility Manger, Stefan Zaljkovic.

Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. Exit interview was completed and copy of the report and appeal rights were discussed and provided to Facility Manager, Stefan Zeljkovic.

narrative:
On 01/31/2022 at 10:45am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting re required annual inspection. LPA Karnsrithong met with Facility Manager, who granted access and tour to the facility. The facility is licensed to provide care and supervision up to six (6) children ages 12 to 17 and non-minor dependents. There is a swimming pool located in the premises. The facility is a two-story residential home. During the visit, LPA Karnsrithong has reviewed three (3) client files and two (2) staff files. LPA Karnsrithong has interviewed two (2) staff and two (2) clients during the inspection. Administrator Certification is valid until 10/25/2022.All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detector were tested and operable at the time of inspection. LPA Karnsrithong observed multiple fire extinguishers throughout the facility that were fully charged. During the inspection LPA Karnsrithong has observed the following: Bedrooms: There are three (3) client bedrooms (Summit, Apex, Valor). All rooms are equipped full-size beds, adequate closet and drawer space, and sufficient lighting. LPA observed clean linens, blankets, and pillows. All client’s beds are in good repair and equipped with a sturdy spring mattress. All bedroom windows are in good working condition. Bedroom temperatures meet regulations at 69 degrees Fahrenheit. Each bedroom has a copy of the facility sketch plan and COVID-19 safety cough guidelines. Bathrooms: There is a total of four (4) bathrooms in the facility. There are two (2) located upstairs and two (2) located downstairs. The Summit Bedroom has its own bathroom that is equipped with a toilet, sink, and shower. It has a tub but is currently non-operational. The client bathroom upstairs has a double sink, toilet, and shower. Staff’s bathroom is located downstairs next to the Education Room. It has a toilet, sink, and shower in good working condition. Shower is not being used by staff but is available if needed. There is a half-bathroom downstairs that is used by guests, clients, and staff. It has a toilet and sink that is in good working condition. (Page 1 of 3)

Office Room: The staff office is located upstairs. This room is equipped with a desk, couch, and chairs. It has a computer and Covid-19 supplies to be used by staff and clients. The First Aid Kit and client medications are stored in this room. Medications are inaccessible to clients, and accessible to only authorized employees. There is also an office area located upstairs that are used by staff that has a computer and printer. There are cabinets next to the office area that are used to store contraband items, linens, and hygiene supplies and are always kept locked. There is a furnace in a locked cabinet located upstairs next to the office area. Dining Area: Equipped with a large table with 8 chairs and is connected to the Kitchen. Clients were observed to be eating meals in the dining area during the visit. Kitchen: There is a large kitchen located downstairs. It has four burner stove, oven range, microwave, and a dishwasher. It has a double sink and enough cabinet storage for utensils, cups, plates, pots, and pans. Knives and sharp objects are kept in a locked cabinet and is inaccessible to clients. There is a private chef that comes to the facility and prepares all meals for the clients. There is a refrigerator in the kitchen. There is a cabinet that stores the facility’s dry goods and non-perishable food items. Menus and snack schedule are also posted in the kitchen. There is also a chore list posted in the refrigerator. At the other side of the kitchen is a Kosher Kitchen space dedicated for clients who have a Kosher diet. It has a designated microwave and coffee maker and other small appliances and supplies designated for Kosher food preparation. There is a double door pantry that contains ample supply of non-perishable food in the facility. Therapy Rooms: There are two (2) rooms designated for therapeutic services. There are coffee tables and ample seating for clients. There is a rug and a computer desk and an office chairs for therapists to use. The facility has a therapy dogs that provides emotional support to clients that is being cared for by the licensed therapists. Hallway Closet: Cleaning solutions, disinfectants, and cleaning supplies are stored in a closet underneath the stairway and is kept locked and inaccessible to clients. (Page 2 of 3)

Creative Learning Space: This is a converted garage space that is being use for education and art. It is located downstairs. It has computers, tables, chairs, cabinets, and shelves. Cabinets are used to store art and incentive supplies for clients. This space is well maintained by staff and is kept locked when education and art activities are not in session. The electric and water shut off valves are in this area and is kept locked and inaccessible to clients. There is also another furnace located here in a locked cabinet. Indoor Common Areas: There are two (2) living room areas located downstairs. One is located next to the entrance that is equipped with ample seating, a coffee table, rug, and a television. There is a non-operable fireplace here that is kept covered and inaccessible to clients. Another living room area is located next to the dining room. It has couches, a rug, and a coffee table. Laundry room: There is a washer and dryer. Laundry supplies and detergent are stored in locked cabinets above the washer and this room is also kept locked when not in use. Clients are permitted to use the laundry room supervised with a staff. Outdoor space: The outdoor space is completely fenced in. There is gate that leads to the driveway. There are ample trees and shrubs throughout the facility. There is an enclosed patio area that is being used for group activities. There is a Ping-Pong table and exercise equipment located outside that is being used by clients. There is adequate patio seating furniture located throughout the garden. There is a Tennis/Basketball court located outside as well. There is a fenced in pool that is well maintained and free of debris. LPA Karnsrithong has observed the gate door to swing away from the pool, with self-close and self-latching device located no more than six inches from the top of the gate. The Gas Shut off valve is located outside. There are three (3) storage sheds located outside. One is used for facility supplies such as extra chairs and table. One is being used for storing client’s personal items such as luggage. One is being used to store extra perishable and non-perishable food items. This shed has a refrigerator and a freezer and is maintained by the chef. The outdoor space is free of debris and any hazards. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with the facility manager. A copy of this report will be provided to the facility.

On 04/26/2022 at 9am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong and Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Leosha Eves arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting required annual inspection. LPA Karnsrithong met with Jaq Waldron, Director of Operations who granted access and tour to the facility. Health and safety risk assessment was conducted upon arriving at the facility. The facility is licensed to provide care and supervision up to six (6) children ages 12 to 17 and non-minor dependents. The facility is located in residential neighborhood. It is a two-story home and is completely fenced in. Currently there are six (6) clients in care and five (5) staff at the time of the visit. During the visit, LPA Karnsrithong has toured the physical plant and observed the following: Common Areas: There are two (2) common room areas located downstairs. One is located next to the entrance that is equipped with ample seating, a coffee table, rug, television, and sports equipment. There is a non-operable fireplace here that is kept covered and inaccessible to clients. Another living room area is located next to the dining room. It has couches, a rug, coffee table, musical instruments, and art supplies. It also has a shelf that is use to store board games and facility activity supplies. Therapy Rooms: There are two (2) rooms designated for therapeutic services. There are coffee tables and ample seating for clients. There is a rug and a computer desk and an office chairs for therapists to use. Hallway Closet: There is a hallway closet room downstairs. This room is used to store cleaning solutions, disinfectants, and cleaning supplies. This room also has the main alarm box for the facility. This room is kept locked and inaccessible to clients. (Page 1 of 2)

Kitchen/Dining Area: There is a large kitchen/dining area located downstairs. It has four burner stove, French Door Refrigerator, oven range, microwave, and a dishwasher. It has a double sink and enough cabinet storage for utensils, cups, plates, pots, and pans. Knives and sharp objects are kept in a locked cabinet and is inaccessible to clients. There is a private chef that comes to the facility and prepares all meals for the clients. Menus are posted in the kitchen area that includes menus for lunch, breakfast, dinner, and snacks. There is a cabinet that stores the facility’s dry goods and non-perishable food items. There is also a chore list posted in the refrigerator. At the other side of the kitchen is a Kosher Kitchen space dedicated for clients who have a Kosher diet. It has a designated microwave and coffee maker and other small appliances and supplies designated for Kosher food preparation. There is a double door pantry that contains ample supply of non-perishable food in the facility. The dining area is next to the kitchen. It is equipped with a large table and dining chairs. School Room: This is a converted garage space that is being use for education and art. It is located downstairs. It has computers, tables, chairs, cabinets, and shelves. Cabinets are used to store art and incentive supplies for clients. This space is well-maintained by staff and is kept locked when education and art activities are not in session. The hot water heater and furnace are stored here in a locked cabinet. Office Room: The staff office is located upstairs. This room is equipped with a desk, couch, and chairs. It has a computer and Covid-19 supplies to be used by staff and clients. The First Aid Kit and client medications are stored in this room. Medications are inaccessible to clients, and accessible to only authorized employees. This office room also serves as a nursing station for the group home. Laundry room: There is a washer and dryer. Cleaning supplies and detergent are stored in locked cabinets above the washer and this room is also kept locked when not in use. Cleaning supplies are also stored in the cabinets here but is kept locked and inaccessible to clients. Toiletries and other supplies are also store in the laundry room cabinets. There is sink in the laundry room as well. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with Director of Operations, Jaq Waldron. (Page 1 of 2)

On 04/27/2022 at 9:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at the facility and met with Jaq Waldron, Director of Operations for the purpose of continuing the annual inspection. Health and safety risk assessment were conducted upon arriving the facility. During today's inspection, LPA Karnsrithong had interviewed two (2) clients and two (2) staff. LPA Karnsrithong also reviewed three (3) staff and three (3) client files. Facility conducts safety drill training for clients and staff once a month. LPA Karnsrithong had observed that all client medications are properly stored and is inaccessible to clients. Client's medication administration are properly documented in the facility’s medication binder and online database. The passageways and stairways are unobstructed. All clients are accorded personal rights. Clients are provided telephone service in the facility. Clients are provided with appropriate supplies when needed and have access to indoor and outdoor activities. Educational activities are provided to children regularly and is being supervised by staff. Cash resources and personal belongings of clients are locked and securely stored in a safe. The facility’s accreditation from the Joint Commission is valid until April 23, 2024. During the inspection LPA Karnsrithong has observed the following: Bedrooms: There are three (3) client bedrooms (Summit, Apex, Valor). All rooms are equipped full-size beds, adequate closet and drawer space, and sufficient lighting. LPA observed clean linens, blankets, and pillows. All client’s beds are in good repair and equipped with a sturdy spring mattress. All bedroom windows are in good working condition. Bedroom temperatures meet regulations at 69 degrees Fahrenheit. Each bedroom has a copy of the facility sketch plan and client schedules are posted. There are two (2) clients assigned per bedroom. (Page 1 of 2)

Bathrooms: There is a total of four (4) bathrooms in the facility. There are two (2) located upstairs and two (2) located downstairs. The Summit Bedroom has its own bathroom that is equipped with a toilet, sink, and shower. It has a tub but is currently non-operational. The client bathroom upstairs has a double sink, toilet, and shower. Staff’s bathroom is located downstairs next to the Therapy Room. It has a toilet, sink, and shower and is in good working condition. Shower is not being used by staff but is available if needed. There is a half-bathroom downstairs that is used by clients. It has a toilet and sink that is in good repair. Outdoor space: The outdoor space is completely fenced in. There is gate that leads to the driveway. There are ample trees and shrubs throughout the facility. There is an enclosed patio area that is being used for group activities. There is a ping-pong table, boxing and exercise equipment located outside that is being used by clients. There is adequate seating furniture located throughout the garden. There is a fire pit with patio seating throughout as well. There is a Tennis/Basketball court located outside. There is a fenced in pool that is well-maintained and free of debris. LPA Karnsrithong has observed the gate door to swing away from the pool, with self-close and self-latching device located no more than six inches from the top of the gate. Utility shut off valves are located outside. There are three (3) storage sheds outside. One is used for facility supplies such as extra chairs and table. One is being used for storing client’s personal items such as luggage. One is being used to store extra perishable and non-perishable food items. This shed has a refrigerator and freezer and is maintained by the chef. The outdoor space is free of debris and any hazards. The facility has at least two (2) Direct Care Staff that supervises clients at all times. Clients have regular outings and activities such as Equine and Surfing. LPA Karnsrithong has observed clients doing educational activities in the school room. There are no deficiencies cited at this time and exit interview was conducted with Jaq Waldron, Director of Operations. A copy of this report will be provided to the facility. (Page 2 of 2)

On 7/31/2024, at 2:35 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin conducted a Case Management - Incident inspection at ASCEND HEALTHCARE and met with Emily Hernandez Facility Manager, to deliver findings concerning Incident Report submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on 6/12/2024. The incident report reported that a youth resident, reported being “fondled” in their private area under their clothing, by an unidentified staff member while in care. The incident was referred to CCL Investigator, Lorraine Patterson for investigation assignment. The investigation revealed as of 6/12/2024, Youth #1 no longer resides at the facility following a voluntary discharge. The investigation further revealed a lack of evidence to prove the alleged as Youth #1 declined to be interviewed by CCL Investigator or provide additional information concerning the incident. Confidential interviews revealed no details, information, evidence, and/or witnesses to support the alleged. Based on the statements gathered, and records reviewed the Department has concluded there is not enough evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. The Department’s finding is therefore determined Unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies per California Code of Regulations cited at this time. Exit interview completed. A copy of this report was provided to Facility Manager during this visit.

Evidence obtained from records noted that C1 was admitted to the facility with a belt that was stored in a designated storage area. Evidence obtained from records noted that on 04/19/24, C1 was permitted to wear a belt when they asked for it in the morning but had to return it to staff before bed. Statements obtained revealed C1 was given their belt either on 04/17/24 or 04/24/24. However, statements obtained could not corroborate if or when the belt was collected from C1 at the end of the day. The investigation revealed on the evening of 4/24/2024, during a designated supervised shower time, C1 was monitored with verbal communication by staff during a 7-minute time span for C1’s shower. Statements revealed, C1 requested more time and was given an additional two minutes. After the two minutes passed, staff knocked on the door and did not get a response from C1. When staff opened the bathroom door, C1 was found unresponsive, with their neck hung with a belt on a shower rail. Staff on duty brought C1 down and performed cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) until paramedics arrived. C1 was resuscitated, transported to the hospital, intubated, and diagnosed with Hypoxia. Statements obtained did not determine the length of time C1 was unresponsive to staff’s knocks at the bathroom door, or length of time it took for staff to get C1 down. Statements revealed inconsistent accounts of staff conducting a search of C1 and bathroom areas prior to the incident. Statements revealed witness corroborating accounts of C1 wearing a belt the day of the incident and the days leading up to the incident on 4/24/2024. Based on confidential interviews, record review, and analysis of circumstances, the Department has determined that the preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore, the allegation that staff did not provide necessary care and supervision to C1 resulting in C1’s attempted suicide by hanging with a belt while in care is substantiated. This poses an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk of harm to clients placed in care. The facility is issued a citation in accordance with California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, 84078(b) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. See page LIC9099-D for the cited deficiency. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights discussed. A copy of this report and appeal rights was left with Administrator. An enhanced civil penalty determination is pending.
investigation_findings: 13On 10/15/2024, at 12:15 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a complaint inspection at ASCEND HEALTHCARE 2 to deliver findings concerning the above-mentioned allegation. LPA Martin met with David Hurwitz, Clinical Director and Emely Hernandez, Facility Manager and discussed the investigative outcome. On 5/13/2024, Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) received an allegation that on 4/24/2024, Client (C1) was transported to the hospital following an attempted suicide by hanging with a belt (refer to LIC811, dated 10/15/2024). The allegation was referred and investigated by CCLD Investigations Branch, Investigator Laarni Santiago. The investigation included confidential interviews with six former clients, including C1, nine staff members, associated parties, and witnesses. The investigation further included review of facility and medical reports. The investigation revealed C1 was placed at ASCEND HEALTHCARE 2 on 4/16/2024. Records reviewed revealed C1’s history of multiple hospitalizations and suicide attempts including a prior attempt made with a belt. (Continued on page 9099-C)

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision: The licensee shall provide those services identified in each child's needs and services plan and in the individualized health care plan for each child with special health care needs as necessary to meet the child's needs. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Confidential interviews and record review determined the facility did not provide sufficient supervision to C1’s documented assessment and did not provide proper procedure and communication resulting in C1 attempting suicide by hanging with a belt while in care. This poses an immediate health, safety, and or personal rights risk to children in care.

narrative: On 11/19/2024 at 12:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin met with Emely Hernandez, Facility Manager (Empress location), to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP). On October 15, 2024, the Department concluded a complaint investigation alleging that Facility Staff did not provide care and supervision resulting in Client’s attempted suicide by hanging while in care. The allegation was determined substantiated, and the Group Home was cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, 84072(b) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated 11/19/2024. Based on an analysis of the interviews and documentary evidence, the Department has determined that an enhanced civil penalty is warranted for Staff not providing necessary care and supervision causing a serious injury for which a child was hospitalized, required intubation, and was placed under extensive care. Serious bodily injury is defined in Penal Code section 243 as "a serious impairment of physical condition, including, but not limited to, the following: loss of consciousness; concussion; bone fracture; protracted loss or impairment of function of any bodily member or organ; a wound requiring extensive suturing; and serious disfigurement." Pursuant to the Enhanced Civil Penalty law, Health & Safety Code section 1548(f)(1)(C)(ii), the Department issues an immediate civil penalty of $2,500.00. An exit interview was completed, and appeal rights discussed. A copy of this report, the Confidential Names List, and a Civil Penalty Assessment - Serious Bodily Injury/Physical Abuse (Form 421-D) was provided to the Facility Manager and Administrator (via e-mail). The signed copy will be retained in the facility file.

narrative:
On 05/22/2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting a 2 Year Required inspection. LPA met with Director of Operations, Jaq Waldron who granted access to the facility and tour of the interior and exterior was conducted. Ascend Healthcare #2 is a therapeutic treatment program designed to accept Private Placements. The facility is licensed to provide care and supervision for up to six (6) children ages 12 to 17 years old; ambulatory only. Currently the census is six (6). The facility is set up as follows: This is a two-story home, located in a residential neighborhood and the property is completely fenced in. There are three (3) bedrooms, four (4) bathrooms, living room, dining room, kitchen, staff office/medication room, therapy offices, a laundry area, an attached garage, and outdoor/backyard area. Living Room: Is located to the right of the entrance and is used as a group therapy area. The room is equipped multiple chairs, a coffee table, rug, mounted television, and sports equipment. The room has a non-operable fireplace that is kept covered and made inaccessible to clients. Dining Room: Is located next to the kitchen. The room is equipped with a couch, coffee table, musical instruments, and art supplies. The room has a non-operable fireplace that is kept covered and made inaccessible to clients. Kitchen: Is equipped with refrigerator/freezer, a gas stove with four (4) burners, microwave, coffee maker, dishwasher, and a wooden table with six (6) chairs. The facility has a chef that prepares all meals for the clients. There is a Kosher Kitchen space dedicated for clients who have a Kosher diet. LPA observed the menu was posted and the trash can has a fitted lid. There were ample plates, cups, and eating utensils. Sharp knives are stored within a locked box kept in a locked cabinet under the stove. Facility had ample non-perishable and perishable food items. Snacks are kept in a locked double door pantry next to the kitchen. License ensures clients in care receive three (3) meals and snacks per day. Report continued on LIC 809C (Page 1 of 3)

Staff office/Medication Room: This room is located on the second floor. This room is equipped with a desk, computer, and chairs. The room has a double door closet that stores the First Aid supplies, client medications, and a small refrigerator for medications. The closet remains locked and made inaccessible to clients. Medications are accessible to authorized employees. Therapy Rooms: There are two (2) rooms designated for therapeutic services. Both rooms are located on the first floor. The rooms are equipped with coffee tables, ample seating for clients, computer desks and an office chairs for therapists to use. Laundry Area: There is a washer and dryer. Cleaning supplies and detergent are stored in a locked cabinet opposite the washer and dryer. This area has a door that leads the backyard. Attached Garage: The garage has been converted into the classroom. It contains computers, tables, chairs, cabinets, and shelves. Cabinets are used to store school and art supplies. The area also has a locked cabinet that contains the hot water heater and furnace. Backyard Area: There is a covered patio with a grill and dining table, a basketball court, a fenced pool (fence meets regulation standards). LPA observed the gate door to swing away from the pool and has a self-close and self-latching lock. There are two locked sheds, one contains extra food, and one is used for storage. 3 Bedrooms: There are three (3) bedrooms all located on the second floor. All bedrooms are equipped with two full sized beds, adequate drawer space, lighting and have windows. All bedrooms have comfortable mattresses, clean linen, blankets, and pillows. 4 Bathrooms: There are four (4) bathrooms. Two bathrooms are located on the first floor, and two bathrooms are located on the second floor. All bathrooms have a toilets and sink; three (3) bathrooms have a shower; and one bathroom room has a shower and stand-alone tub (the water supply to the tub has been shut off). All bathrooms were checked and found to be clean and in operating condition. The water temperature was measured and found to between 105-120 degrees. LPA observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Cleaning solutions, disinfectants, and cleaning supplies are stored in a locked hallway closet and made inaccessible to clients. The outdoor spaces were clean and clear of hazards. Passageways, open porches, and all exits were observed to be unobstructed. Licensee ensures that individuals supervising children in the pool area are Water Safety trained. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA discussed and advised facility staff to ensure the following: Children are afforded their Personal Rights. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency or the Foster Care Ombudsperson, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Report continued on LIC 809C (Page 2 of 3)

All posting requirements for Group Home Licensure, including the Emergency Plan, and grievance procedure were met and posted on the wall. The LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Licensee will ensure to utilize the Unusual Incident Report LIC 624, and LIC 624LE to document incidents. Transportation: The facility uses a 2023 Honda, Odyssey to transport children in care. LPA inspected the vehicle and found it to be in good repair. LPA observed the vehicle to have current registration and valid insurance. Facility staff provided LPA with a copy of the Personnel Report (LIC 500) and Current Client Roster (LIC 9020). Clients Records are electronically stored in the facilities online Portal with Kipuworks.com and Staff Records are electronically stored in the facilities online iSolve system. LPA will return at a later date to review staff and client files. There are no deficiencies observed or cited at this during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted with the Director of Operations, and a copy of this report was left at the facility. (Page 3 of 3)

On December 10, 2020 at 2:00pm Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Rosslyn Gray conducted a Tele-Inspection Ascend Healthcare 3 for the purpose of conducting a Post Licensing Inspection on the new Group Application. LPA was granted access to the facility virtually via FaceTime with the Facility Operations Manager Ascend Healthcare who provided a tour of the entire physical plant, inside and out. The Group Home is to provide care and supervision for six (6) foster children, ages 12-17 years Ambulatory Only. There is no pool are bodies of water on the premises. The operations manager confirmed that there are no guns or weapons on the premises. LPA-Gray inspected the facility via FaceTime with the S1 and observed the following: This is a 1-story four (3) bedrooms; 3 bathrooms Group Home. There is a fully furnished living room, and dining room and a kitchen. There an Equine Therapy farm. There is camera in view of the perimeter; common areas of house (living room, dining room and hallways) that has been disconnected. A waiver was granted in 2009 but the Administrator stated that the cameras are not operable; and will notify the department if they decide to activate the cameras. The outdoor perimeter front yard, side yard and backyard were inspected and found cleared of debris and hazards materials. LPA observed animals on the premises (two (2) Goats; one (1) pig and two (2) miniature horses. All animals are gated in a barn style white picket fence. LPA verify that the animals are used for Specialist Equine Therapy. The Administrator provided a liability document “ASSUMPTION OF RISK, RELEASE OF LIABILITY, AND INDEMNITY” for Guest and Staff. LPA observed two storage bins approximately 50 to 60 feet in distance. Storage bin #1 is utilized for the Equine storage animal food and supplies. Storage bin #2 is utilized for the facility chef to store food supply; it also contains an additional refrigerator. The two (3) chair swings; a Wood burning BBQ pit. All windows, screens and blinds from the inside and outside of the facility were observed to be in good condition.

The passageways and porches are unobstructed. All posting requirements were met, (food menu, regulations, licenses, emergency disaster plan and personal rights). All required posting is on the wall front entrance of the facility (Personal Rights and Grievance forms). Cleaning solutions, disinfectants, sharp knives are inaccessible to the clients (stored in the staff office). All the children prescribed medications are locked in the staff office and children files are store in a KIPU software system. LPA-observed a camera in view of the perimeter; common areas of house (living room, dining room and hallways). A waiver was granted in 2009 but the Administrator stated that the cameras are not operable; and will notify the department if they decide to activate the cameras. There is a wood burning double sided fireplace; operable but not being utilized. The facility uses NEST electronic combined Smoke detector and Carbon Monoxide. The Laundry room: The laundry room is enclosed adjacent to the kitchen. The laundry detergent is distributed to children individually according to the load of their laundry. Living Room/Dining room/Kitchen: Observed to be clean and organized; equip with living room furniture. The Kitchen stove is gas operated with 4 burners and a grill flat top. The dining table is designed with a bench and seats five (5), only four (4) chairs are used due to CDC-Guidelines for Social Distances. The sharp knives and chemicals are made inaccessible locked in container in the staff office. There are two (2) extra refrigerators in the garage used for extra storage. LPA observed coverage trash cans in the kitchen, bathroom and staff office. Bedrooms: There are three (3) Bedrooms each bedroom is occupied by 2 clients; Master Bedroom #1, Bedroom #2 and Bedroom #3 has two twin size beds six feet apart, with a mattress clean linen, adequate closet and drawer space. Bathrooms: The bathrooms were inspected and found to be clean. LPA observed S1 test the water temperature, bathroom sinks and ensured that all toilets flushed. Master bathroom #1 is shared by 4 clients; has 2 sinks; walk in shower and a separate tube that is not operable. Bathroom #2 sink toilet and a shower. Bathroom #3 identified as the staff’s bathroom equipped with a sink and a toilet. The First Aid kit has the required items inside (age-appropriate, and scissors, tweezers, thermometer, and gauzes, antiseptic and First Aid Manual Guide. The Garage has been converted to a school setting for the clients and school supplies are provided by the facility. Report continues on LIC-809-C 2 of 3

The facility has a working telephone and clients can use the telephone unless restricted by court order. The staff accompanies clients to local recreational facilities based on the rules of the COVID-19. Other outside extracurricular activities and social events that take persons into public or crowded places have been canceled. Clients are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. LPA recommended that staff ensure that CDC Guidelines are implemented in effort to prevent other from contracting the COVID-19 virus (i.e wash hands with alcohol based hand sanitizer, display colorful preventative hygiene posters, temperature checks, maintain social distancing (six feet of space), disinfect commonly used areas and items (remote controls, mouse’s, cards cell phones, practice “cough etiquette”. LPA suggest that the facility keep an inventory of the PPE supplies and to report when they are depleted. The Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility has a current, written plan of operation. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Licensee will report client injuries requiring medical treatment. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 12/10/2020 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit Interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report will be emailed to the facility administrator for signature 12/15/20200

investigation_findings: 13On April 26, 2022, at 1:30pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia Rosas made an announced inspection to Ascend Healthcare 3 for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegations and to deliver the findings. LPA Rosas met with Staff#1 (S1) and together discussed the investigation details. Individuals mention in this complaint are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated April 26, 2022. During the investigation, LPA Rosas inspected the facility, interview pertinent parties and reviewed supportive documentation. Based on gathered information, investigative interviews, record reviews and other supportive evidence the finding concerning program director does not work at the facility are unsubstantiated. LPA Rosas conducted facility inspection on 10/19/2021, 10/21/2021, and 12/17/2022. Report continues LIC9099-C

narrative:
On September 22, 2022 at 9:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White arrived at Ascend Healthcare 3, for the purpose of conducting a Annual/Required inspection. LPA met with Brenda Reyes, Facility Manager and was granted access into the facility. The facility was toured at 10:05 AM both inside and out. The facility is a private pay therapeutic treatment program licensed to provide care and supervision services for six (6) children, ages 12-17 years old, ambulatory only. The census at the time of the inspection was four (4). The facility is a one story, 4-bedroom, 3-bathroom house which includes a Living room, Dining room, Kitchen, Laundry room, Staffing/Medical office, Equine Therapy farm, a Pool, 2 Garages, and a Backyard. The facility is set up as follows: Living room: is furnished with sectional sofa, chairs, and has a operable wood burning fireplace equipped with an iron screen. Dining room: is furnished with a wooden table and six (6) chairs, and has a operable wood burning fireplace equipped with a screen. Kitchen: is equipped with a 4-burner gas operated stove with a flat top grill, a microwave, refrigerator/freezer, a dishwasher, and a pantry. Laundry room: is located next to the kitchen and is equipped with washer and dryer. Staffing/Medical office: is located inside the main facility. The office is equipped with a computer, chair, and desk. LPA observed the room to have locked cabinets which are used to stores files, hygiene supplies, and client medications. Additionally, medications that require refrigeration is stored in a double locked refrigerator located in the office. The office is locked and made inaccessible to clients in care. Equine Therapy Farm: is gated and houses 2 goats, 1 pig, and 3 miniature horses. There are 2 storage bins next to the farm; one contains animal food and supplies; the other is used for storage. Pool: is located in the backyard and is equipped with a fence and pool cover which meet the regulations. Garages: one garage is attached to the home and was observed to be used as a classroom; the room had multiple computers tables and chairs. The second garage was observed to have an extra refrigerator used by staff, a staff restroom, storage shelves, and two separate therapy offices equipped with desk, chairs, and a sofa. Report continued on LIC 809C.

Backyard: is equipped with a propane grill, a cement wood burning barbeque pit, a fire place equipped with a screen, volleyball net, ping pong table, yoga mats, a wooden table with seven (7) chairs, a swing, and multiple seating areas. Bedroom #1: is furnished with two twin size beds, closet space, two multi-shelve hanging organizers, and a working light. Bedroom #2: is furnished with two twin size beds, closet space, two multi-shelve hanging organizers, and a working light. Bedroom #3: is furnished with a twin-size day bed, closet space, a small three drawer dresser, and a working light. Bedroom #4: is furnished with two twin size beds, closet space, two multi-shelve hanging organizers, a working light, and has an attached bathroom. Bathrooms: All bathrooms were checked and found to be in good repair and working order. The hot water temperature was tested and found to be between 105-120 degrees (F). The carbon monoxide and smoke detectors were tested and found to be in working order. First Aid Kit was checked and found to be complete. The facility has 4 regulation fire extinguishers. The facility has a working telephone readily accessible. Menu is posted in kitchen area and facility has non-perishable foods for one-week, and perishable foods for two days. All meals are prepared off site and brought over the facility and clients are provided nutritious between meals snacks. Overall LPA observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. The front yard and outdoor recreation area were clean and free of debris. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches were unobstructed. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. Temperatures in client rooms and common areas were found to be between 68 - 85 degrees (F). Disinfectants/cleaning solutions and poisons are stored and inaccessible to clients. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA discussed and advised the Licensee to ensure the following: Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency or the Foster Care Ombudsperson, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements for Group Home Licensure and Emergency Plan were met. LPA observed a camera in the living room, dining room, hallways, and outside perimeter. There is no camera waiver on file and facility has not been granted the use of cameras. Facility Manager ensured LPA cameras are not activated. Facility Manager provided LPA with a copy of the Personnel Report (LIC 500). LPA will return at a later time to review client and staff records. There are no deficiencies observed or cited at this during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted with the Facility Manager, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On September 07, 2023, at 9:42 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White arrived at Ascend Healthcare 3, for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required inspection. LPA met with Jaq Waldron, Director of Operations and Brenda Reyes, Facility Manager and was granted access into the facility. An interior and exterior facility tour was conducted at 10:00 AM. The facility is a private pay therapeutic treatment program licensed to provide care and supervision services for six (6) children, ages 12-17 years old, ambulatory only, for a length of 45 to 90 days. The census at the time of the inspection was six (6). The facility is a one story, 4-bedroom, 3-bathroom house which includes a Living room, Dining room, Kitchen, Laundry room, Staffing/Medical office, Equine Therapy farm, a Pool, 2 Garages, and a Backyard. The facility is set up as follows: Living room: is furnished with sectional sofa, chairs, and an operable wood burning fireplace equipped with an iron screen. Dining room: is furnished with a wooden table, six (6) chairs, and an operable wood burning fireplace equipped with a screen. Kitchen: is equipped with a 4-burner gas operated stove that includes a flat top and a 2-burner grill, a microwave, refrigerator/freezer, a dishwasher, and a pantry. Laundry room: is located off of the kitchen and adjacent to the staff bathroom. The laundry room is equipped with washer and dryer and laundry detergent is individually distributed to clients per laundry need. Staffing/Medical office: is located off the entry way. The office is equipped with a computer, chair, and desk. Client and Staff files are electronically maintained on KIPU software system. LPA observed the office to have locked cabinets used to stores files, hygiene supplies, and client medications. Medications that require refrigeration is stored in a double locked refrigerator located in the staffing office. The office remains locked and made inaccessible to clients in care. Equine Therapy Farm: is enclosed by a gate and houses the following animals: 2 goats, 3 miniature horses, and 1 pig. There are 2 locked storage bins next to the farm; one contains animal food and supplies; the other is used for storage. Report continued on LIC 809C (Page 1 of 3)

Pool: is located in the backyard and is equipped with the required 5-foot fence, that does not obscure the pool from view, and a self-closing latch. The pool also has a regulation pool cover. Garages: one garage is used as a classroom; LPA observed the garage to have multiple computers, tables, and chairs. The second garage was observed to have an extra refrigerator used by staff, a staff restroom, storage shelves, and two separate therapy offices equipped with desk, chairs, and a sofa. Report continued on LIC 809C. Backyard: is equipped with a cement wood burning barbeque pit, a propane grill, a fireplace equipped with a screen, ping pong table, a swing, volleyball net, a wooden table with seven (7) chairs, a small chicken coop, and has multiple seating areas. Bedroom #1 (Denali is occupied by C3 & C4): the room is furnished with two twin size beds, closet space, two multi-shelve hanging organizers, and a working light. Bedroom #2 (Rainier is occupied by C1 & C2): the room is furnished with two twin size beds, closet space, two multi-shelve hanging organizers, and a working light. Bedroom #3 (Wasilla is used as a quarantine room): the room is furnished with a twin-size day bed, closet space, a small three drawer dresser, and a working light. Bedroom #4 (Everest is occupied by C5 & C6): the room is furnished with two twin size beds, closet space, two multi-shelve hanging organizers, a working light, and has an attached bathroom. Bathrooms: one bathroom is located near the staffing office; one bathroom is located along the hallway adjacent to bedroom #3; and one bedroom is located inside bedroom #4. All bathrooms were checked and found to be in good repair and working order. The hot water temperature was tested and found to be between 105-120 degrees (F). LPA tested the carbon monoxide and smoke detectors and found them to be in working order. There are 4 regulation fire extinguishers located in the facility. The first Aid Kit is located inside the staffing office and was found to be complete. The facility has a working telephone readily accessible. Menu is posted in kitchen area and facility has non-perishable foods for one-week, and perishable foods for two days and clients are provided nutritious between meals snacks. Additionally, the facility has a private chef, and all meals are prepared off site, at Ascend Healthcare #4, and brought over the facility. Overall LPA observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. The front yard and outdoor recreation area were clean and free of debris. The front yard contains a pond equipped with a security net. Passageways were unobstructed. Report continued on LIC 809C (Page 2 of 3)

There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. There are no security bars on the windows. Temperatures in client rooms are maintained through central air and heating and common areas were found to be between 68 - 85 degrees (F). Disinfectants/cleaning solutions and poisons are stored and made inaccessible to clients. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA discussed and advised the Licensee to ensure the following: Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency or the Foster Care Ombudsperson, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements for Group Home Licensure and Emergency Plan were met. LPA observed cameras in the living room, dining room, hallways, and outside perimeter. Facility Manager ensured LPA cameras are not activated. LPA was provided with a copy of the Personnel Report (LIC 500) and Client Register (LIC 9020). LPA will return at a later date to review client and staff records. There are no deficiencies observed or cited at this during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted with the Facility Manager, and a copy of this report was left at the facility. (Page 3 of 3)

met_with: Brenda Reyes, Facility Manager/ Jaq Waldron, Director of Operations
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the allegation that client was wrongfully discharged from the facility. LPA reviewed Ascend's discharge policies as written in their program statement and reviewed the admissions agreement and the discharge summary that were signed by both the complainant and C1, The facility states that C1 was discharged for violating the admissions agreement. However the complainant asserts that C1 was discharged due to a dispute between the facility and the insurance company. Due to conflicting accounts, LPA Jones-Steward was not able to substantiate nor disprove the allegation. Therefore it is resolved as unsubtantiated.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Reporting Requirements: The licensee shall report any unusual incident or client absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. The report is due on the next business day. The licensee failed to meet this requirement. No incident report was filed to report the AWOL of a C1 on March 2, 2025.

narrative:
Client interviews shared that while the facility is on a farm, the facility is not dirty nor does it have an odor. Clients testified that a professional cleaning crew come at least twice a week, and that there are no complaints of a smell. Clients also shared during their interviews that while the facility was prepared to evacuate in January, they never left the facility. The evacuation was canceled, the area was safe, and no clients ever left the facility. Clients also stated that the outside facility grounds are generally well lit even at night. LPA interviewed several facility staff members who also testified that the facility does provide onboarding training to new hires, specifically called the “Ascend Academy”. All staff shared that they attended the training prior to starting their work at the facility. LPA performed record reviews and observed that the training happened monthly and never took a break or was postponed. All staff confirmed that there are also monthly trainings provided by the facility, with reminders actively sent leading up to the trainings. LPA was also informed by staff interviews that mentor shadowing is provided beforehand for new hires to learn and ask questions about their work. Staff interviews also stated that the facility has professional cleaners come 2-4 times a week, while clients do chores regularly, and staff also perform general housekeeping duties. Staff interviews shared that there has never been a complaint or issue with odors in the house. Staff interviews testified that the facility has exterior lights all around the grounds, including the porch. LPA performed a facility walkthrough and specifically observed the porch lights to be in working condition. Staff shared that they have never heard of any on-the-job injury recently, and that there is no workers' comp case open at the moment. Staff interviews also corroborated that the facility never had to evacuate in January during the fires. LPA reviewed receipt records showing that the facility was prepared to evacuate to a local Hyatt hotel for emergency procedures, not an unlicensed facility. LPA received multiple conflicting testimonies regarding all the allegations against the facility. Interview evidence and records review of the roster for the previous “Ascend Academy” meetings show that the training was being provided and was never canceled or postponed. Interview evidence from the client and staff shared that the facility is free of odors due to weekly professional and general house cleaning. Interview and observation evidence showed that the facility's exterior lights were in working condition. Interview evidence and records review in the form of the hotel receipts show that the facility never evacuated to an unlicensed location, and if the facility needed to evacuate they were prepared to go to an approved emergency location. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews, records review, and observation evidence the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met; therefore, the allegations that the “Facility did not ensure that staff are trained, Facility has an odor, Staff did not ensure that facility has adequate lighting, & Facility served clients at an unlicensed location.” is found to be unsubstantiated.

An exit interview was conducted, during which LPA provided the Facility Manager with a copy of this report and a copy of their appeal rights.
investigation_findings: 13On 7/18/25 at 11:26 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen arrived at the above facility and met with Facility Manager for the purpose of delivering complaint findings regarding the above allegation. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. LPA also requested, received, and reviewed records evidence. LPA also toured the facility and observed the building and grounds. Witness testimony asserted that the facility was not providing the proper training to its staff, specifically the onboarding training, which resulted in ill-prepared staff and unsafe working environments. Witness testimony also alleged that the facility has an odor and is not properly cleaned. Witness interview stated that the facility is not properly lit outside, specifically the front porch, which resulted in an on-the-job injury. Witness interview also shared that during the fires in the area earlier in the year, the facility had to evacuate and did not evacuate to an approved emergency site like a nearby hotel, but went to another facility that had not been licensed yet to serve and care for clients. LPA also interviewed clients from the facility.

narrative:

The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the Plan of Operation, Program Statement and supporting documents due to the facility opening a Group Home. The Ascend Healthcare 4 is a therapeutic treatment program that’s designed to accept “Private Placement's” for a length of 45 - 90 days and will provide care supervision for six (6) clients, ages 12-17 years; ambulatory only. Attendees: Olivia Rosas, Licensing Program Analyst Effie Goldberg/CEO Jaq Waldron, Facility Manager The following matters were discussed: A Fire Safety Inspection Request (Form STD 850) was submitted on 05/26/2021 to the Los Angeles County Fire Department Schools, Churches & Institutions Unit. The fire safety inspection was completed on 06/23/2021 and noted “The facility renders no care to clients. This facility is used for drug and alcohol rehabilitation only. Garages are to be used for stated and vehicle use only, no habitation permitted. The Department is currently not accepting or approving camera/monitoring equipment waivers. Unless prior written licensing agency approval is received and approved no use of cameras/monitoring equipment can be used. PIN 21-03-CRP: Senate Bill 1264 (Committee on Human Services) Chapter 367, Statutes of 2020. Update emergency and disaster preparedness plan. (Continued on LIC809-C)

The following is needed for License approval: LIC 309- Administrative organization- Update section 10. LIC308- Designation of Facility Responsibility LIC500- Personnel Form: Update Administrator, Facility Manger LIC 999- Facility Sketch- Update to include pool, label rooms, name rooms be used by staff/residents/clients. LIC610C Emergency Disaster Plan- Update section V. LIC501, LIC503- Personnel Record: Missing CEO, Administrator, Facility Manager with Criminal Clearance Transfer Request for personnel (CEO, Administrator, Facility Manager, Clinical Director, Nurse Manager, Education Manager). Water Safety Certificate for staff is needed because a pool was added Mention of the use of animals for therapeutic therapy Personnel Requirements: Application, Resume, Health Screening (Form LIC503 / TB test) are needed for Administrator, Facility Manager, Clinical Director, Nurse Manager, Education Manager. Section 16- Update CCLD information Section 21- LIC500 update Section 22- Staff Qualifications Section 28- update facility sketches Community Relations and Neighbor Complaints- Update to include dates/times Facility Manger or Administrator is available for neighbors. Include contact information. Each section of the Plan of Operation and Program Statement were reviewed, and LPA discussed the changes and revisions that need to be modified to meet Licensing Standards. LPA Rosas and the facility schedule pre-licensing visit for Wednesday, October 20, 2021 and Comp-III. LPA Rosas provided a copy of LIC184 Notification of Incomplete Application with items that need to be submitted by 11/29/2021. Exit interview completed and a copy of the report was mail to the Administrator.

LPA Rosas met with Staff#1(S1), Staff#2(S2), Staff#3(S3) who granted access to the facility and an inspection of the facility was conducted together. The Ascend Healthcare 3 is a therapeutic treatment program that’s designed to accept “Private Placement's” for a length of 45 - 90 days and is licensed to provide care supervision for six (6) youths, ages 12-17 years; ambulatory only. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 10/19/21. The CEO states that there are no guns or weapons on the premises. This is a two-story home with four (4) bedrooms, two (2) staff offices, four (4) bathrooms, living room, kitchen, media room, group room, living room, dining area, outdoor space with basketball court, detach and attach garages, outdoor barn that be used for Equine Therapy farm. LPA inspected the following: The Laundry room: The laundry room is inside of the attach garage adjacent to the kitchen. The laundry detergent is distributed to children individually according to the load of their laundry. Living Room/Dining Room/Kitchen: Observed to be clean and organized; equip with living room furniture. The Kitchen stove is gas operated range. The sharp knives and chemicals are made inaccessible locked in container in the staff office. There are three (3) extra industrial refrigerators in the garage used for extra storage. LPA observed coverage trash cans in the kitchen, bathroom and staff office. LPA observed ample perishable food items in the refrigerator and the pantry is fully stocked with non-perishable food items. LPA observed enough perishable and Non perishable food items for seven (7) days. Bedroom #1 (upstairs): Is vacant. This room has two queen size beds, adequate closet and drawer space. A door chime will be install for balcony access. A door chime will be install for balcony access. Bedroom #4 (upstairs): Is vacant. This room has two queen size beds, adequate closet and drawer space. The First Aid kit has the required items inside (age-appropriate, and scissors, tweezers, thermometer, and gauzes, antiseptic and First Aid Manual Guide. Only staff has access to this room. Staff Office (downstairs): This room will be used for staff. Staff Office/Intake Room (downstairs): This room will be by administration to conduct intakes. Back yard area/outdoors: There is propane grill in good condition also observed to be secure and safe. The outdoor area has detached garage that be used for storage. LPA Rosas during the inspection conducted Component III with S1, S2, S3. LPA Rosas was provided with missing documents.
