On 01/27/2022, an unannounced SB484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tamara Melikian and Vanessa Galvan at 10:00AM. During the inspection, LPAs met with Nanci Luna, House Manager and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed two children's records and reviewed two staff personnel records for the facility at 10:15AM. A medication count was conducted at 11:00AM. LPA interviewed one staff at 11:20AM. LPA did not interview any children in the home as the children are at school and will be interviewed at a later date. No deficiencies to be cited at this time. LPAs conducted exit interview with Nanci Luna, House Manager at 12:00PM. LPAs provided the summary report to Nanci Luna, House Manager upon completion.

On January 21, 2022, licensee provided Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) with a closure plan for the Ashcroft Home effective February 5, 2022. At the time the plan was provided two clients were at the facility. On February 4, 2022, licensee submitted a waiver request to maintain a client past their 18th birthday pending transfer to another facility. Licensee wanted the request until February 7, 2022 and indicated the facility would move forward with closure once the client was moved. On February 8, 202 LPA contacted the licensee to confirm the client was moved. Licensee confirmed the client was moved from the facility on February 5, 2022. The licensee indicated they were unsure if they would be moving forward with closure and would provide LPA with an update of a plan with the facility; however, indicated they would not be taking any new clients. On March 15, 202, licensee sent LPA an email indicating they would be moving forward with the closure effective February 7, 2022. On March 21, 2022, the licensee forfeited their license to the Children’s Residential Office. On March 23, 2022, LPA Jessica Rodriguez arrived at the facility to confirm its closure. Upon arrival, LPA observed the property has a “for sale” sign outside. No vehicles were in the driveway. LPA knocked on the door and there was no answer. LPA observed all signage that was previously at the front door regarding COVID-19 had been removed. LPA will move forward with completing closure paperwork.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Robinson and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Cheraki Davis met with Licensee Angel and Karla Vivas to conduct a meeting to discuss and review the Group Home Program Statement submitted to Community Care Licensing. During the meeting, the following was discussed: Application and Supporting Documents, Plan of Operation, Program Statement, Prudent Parenting, Control of Property, and Administrator Qualifications. After review of the Plan of Operation/ Program Statement LPA Cynthia observed the following: Application and Supporting Documentation (LIC 281E) 1. Application for a Community Care Facility (LIC 200) Meets Standards 2. Orientation Certificate (Reference 22 CCR § 80018(b))- Meets Standards 3. Applicant Information (LIC 215) - Meets Standards 4. Designation of Facility Responsibility (LIC 308) (Reference 22 CCR § 80064) Meets Standards 5. Administrative Organization (LIC 309)- Meets standards 6. Affidavit Regarding Client Cash Resources (LIC 400) (Reference HSC § 15622 CCR § 80018)- Meets Standards 7. Estimated Operating Budget (LIC 401) (Reference HSC § 1520(c) 22 CCR § 80018- Meets Standards 8. Supplemental Financial Information (LIC 401A) (Reference HSC § 1520(c) 22 CCR § 80018)- Meets Standards 9. Surety Bond (LIC 402) (Reference 22 CCR § 80018(d))- Does Not Meet Standards Surety Bond form not completed- Missing Surety Bond Company signature with seal/laser 10. Balance Sheet (LIC 403) (Reference HSC § 1520(c), 22 CCR § 80018)- Meets Standards 11. Balance Sheet supplemental Schedule (LIC 403A) (Reference HSC § 1520(c), 22 CCR § 80018)- Meets Standards

12. Financial Information Release and Verification (LIC 404) (Reference HSC § 1520(c), 22 CCR § 80018) Does not Meet Standards. Not signed and returned from financial institution 13. Personnel Report (LIC 500) (Reference HSC § 1522, 22 CCR § 80018)- Meets Standards 14. Personnel Record (LIC 501) (Reference HSC § 1522, 22 CCR § 80018)- Meets Standards 15. Health Screening Personnel (LIC 503) (Reference 22 CCR § 80018(d))- Meets Standards 16. Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC 610C) (Reference 22 CCR § 80023)- Meets Standards 17. Fire Inspection Authority (LIC 9054) (Reference 22 CCR § 80018(d)), 22 CCR § 87018(d))- Does not Meet Standards. Missing fire clearance 16. First Aid Certificate- Meets Standards Section A: Program Description- Does Not Meet Standards Purpose, Methods, Goals – Section 3 1. Statement of philosophy, purpose, goals, and program methods (what the program will provide for the children and how this will be accomplished) Does not meet standard. Not detailed enough, please provide more of a narrative for this section. 2. How will clients be assessed for entry into the facility Does not meet standard. Please be more specific who will be conducting the assessment, what staff positions and how assessments will be conducted. 3. Days and hours of operation Does not meet standard. Please provide this information. 4. Description of basic services (description of services and treatments that will be provided in the facility) Does not meet standard. Missing information. 5. Description of optional services Does not meet standard. Missing information. 6. Procedures for medical emergencies Does not meet standard. Missing Information. 7. What type of treatment will be provided Meets standard. 8. How results or outcomes will be measured and how often Meets standard.

**Please provide this section in a more narrative read as right now it reads in bullet points. This section needs to be more thorough and detailed. Planned Activities/ Use of Community Resources- Section 4 Meets Standards 1. Plan of activities (indoor/ outdoor activities) Please submit a monthly schedule. 2. Who is involved (how is it determined what youth can participate?) Does not meet standard. Please include when discipline is applied and when clients are not able to participate. 3. Who conducts the activity Meets standard. 4. Plan for individual child and group interaction activities Meets standard. 5. Social, education, and recreational activity schedule Meets standard. 6. List of community resources used by the facility Meets standard. 7. Educational activities and services (special education, use of public/private schools, on grounds school and tutoring if applicable) Meets standard. **Please have this section be more narrative Special Services/ Programs Offered- Section 5 1. Describe any special services or programs which will be offered Meets standard 2. If the program provides vocational trainings, describe: Meets standard Medical/ Dental – Section 6 1. Medical assessment, physical examination requirements, including TB test Does not meet standard. Please be more detailed- refer to Title 22- 80069 and 84069.1 (Immunizations- children are to receive vaccinations within 30 days of placement if not provided)

2. Use of Medication Administration Records (MAR LIC 622A) and Psychotropic Medication Administration Records (PMAR LIC 622B) Does not meet standard. Missing. Please reference Title 22 80075 (Health Related Services). 3. Medication procedures (handling and assisting children with self-administered medications Does not meet standard. Be more detailed on what staff will be handling medication procedures and assisting children. 4. Medical, Psychiatric and psychological reports that identify special needs of children diagnosed as mentally disordered or developmentally disabled. Does not meet standard. Missing Title 22 80075 (Health Related Services). 5. Medical and dental insurance coverage information, or information regarding the agency or person responsible for medical and dental costs Does not meet standard. Missing Title 22 80075 (Health Related Services). 6. Consent forms, completed by the child’s authorized representative(s), to permit the facility to authorize medical care Does not meet standard. Missing Title 22 84070(b)(13) (Children’s Record). 7. Procedures for identifying/ handling medical, dental and psychiatric emergencies. Does not meet standard. Please be more thorough. 8. A copy of the current court order, or written authorization of the child’s parent or guardian, for each psychotropic medication, as defined in Section 84001 (p)(4). Does not meet standard. Missing. 9. A copy of the standard appraisal form, court order, or written authorization of the child’s parent or guardian, for each psychotropic medication Does not meet standard. Missing Title 22 84068.1 (b)(1)(C) and 84001 (p)(4). Transporting – Section 7 1. Describe arrangements for transporting children to and from school, activities provided outside the facilities and medical/dental appointments Meets standard 2. Specify how the program will ensure that vehicles used to transport children are maintained in safe operation condition Meets standard

3. Specify how the program will ensure that vehicle registration and insurance will be maintained Meets standard 4. Specify how the program will ensure that only appropriately licensed program staff and volunteers will transport children. Meets standard 5. Will the facility maintain a vehicle owned by the facility or will staff utilize their own vehicles to transport children Does not meet standard. Missing. 6. How the facility will ensure that no vehicle utilized for transport of client will have been smoked in (weather at rest or in motion) Does not meet standard. Missing. 84074 Transportation (b) The licensee and their staff are prohibited from smoking a tobacco product, or permitting any person from smoking a tobacco product in a motor vehicle that is regularly used to transport children, regardless of when the children are present. This prohibition applies when the motor vehicle is moving or at rest 7. How the facility is going to ensure the use of restraint systems as necessary (i.e. car seats for younger children) Does not meet standard. Missing. B: Admission/ Assessment Admission/ Intake – Section 8 Does not meet standard *Please refer to 84068.1 Intake Procedures 1. Staff position responsible for intake Meets standard. Please move this information at the top of the section to show that the Administrator will be the one to complete Admission/ Intake. 2. Persons accepted for care Does not meet standard. Please specify what type of population the Group Home will be accepting for care. 3. Age Range Does not meet standard. Please specify an age range that the Group Home will or will not be accepting. 4. Compatibility Determination Does not meet standard. Please provide information on how the client will be assessed for compatibility determination. 5. Criteria for determining appropriateness. Does not meet standard. Missing.

6. Clients' rights/ Personal rights (process of informing clients of their rights, providing copies to responsible parties'/placement/ families) Does not meet standard. Missing – Please refer to 84068.1 Intake Procedures. 7. Pre-Admission appraisal plan Does not meet standard. Missing – Please refer to 84068.1 Intake Procedures. 8. Sign in-sign out procedures Does not meet standard. Missing. 9. Admission Agreement – (Regional Center Agreement being used) Does not meet standard. Missing- Please refer to 84068.1 Intake Procedures. 10. Licensing Agency Rights Does not meet standard. Missing. Needs and Services Plans/Assessment - Section 9 1. Development, Review & Implementation Procedures (identification of needs and services to meet those needs, how initial and modified needs and services implemented) Please be more specific on what will the needs and services plan will include. Please review 84068.2 Needs and Services Plan. 2. How client and authorized representatives be utilized un developing, updating and modifying the needs and services plan Does not meet standard. Please be more specific. Please review 84068.2 Needs and Services Plan. 3. How the facility will ensure that the services meet the individual treatment needs Does not meet standard. Please be more specific. 4. How will the facility ensure that client’s voice is heard. Does not meet standard. Not defined enough. Please include 84068.2 (d) Needs and Services Plan - (d) The licensee shall ensure that the child and their authorized representative(s) are offered the opportunity to participate in the development of the needs and services plan. 5. How will the facility ensure that the needs identified are consistent with Regional Center IPP Does not meet standard. Missing. 6. Procedures for reviewing and evaluating needs and services (how often and what happens when it is identified that a change is needed). Does not meet standard. Missing.

Discharge/Removal - Section 10 1. Written policies and procedures governing child’s removal and/or discharge Does not meet standard. Missing- Please refer to 84068.4 Removal and/or Discharge Procedures. 2. Policies and procedures being provided to children and authorized representative(s) Does not meet standard. Missing- Please refer to 84068.4 Removal and/or Discharge Procedures. 3. Signed policies & procedures maintained in the child’s record Does not meet standard. Missing- Please refer to 84068.4 Removal and/or Discharge Procedures. 4. Emergency removal or discharge policies (timelines included) Does not meet standard. Missing specific timeline. 5. Planned removal or discharge policies (timelines included) Does not meet standard. Missing specific timeline. 6. Written Removal/ Discharge record developed and maintained by social work staff Does not meet standard. Missing- Please refer to 84068.4 Removal and/or Discharge Procedures. Visitation Rules & Policy – Section 11 1. How provider will ensure successful communication and visitation with family, friends and other involved in client’s life Does not meet standard. Missing. 2. When and under what circumstances are visits allowed in the facility by family/ friends Does not meet standard. Please refer to Title 22 CCR 84072 Personal Rights (d)(8) (8) To have visitors visit privately during waking hours without prior notice, provided that such visitations do not infringe upon the rights of other children; do not disrupt planned activities; and are not prohibited by court order or by the child's authorized representative(s). (A) The child has the right to private visits and contact with the following: 1. Siblings, family members, and relatives. Visits by the child’s siblings, family members, and relatives can only be prohibited by court order. 2. Authorized Representative. 3. Other visitors. (B) Rules regarding visitation hours, sign-in rules and visiting rooms can be established but shall apply to all visitors. 3. Home visits/ Overnight visit policies Meets standard. 4. When are visits NOT permitted Does not meet standard. Missing- Please refer to 84072 Personal Rights (d)(8).)

5. Visitation policy will be posted Does not meet standard. Missing. Please refer to the Title 22 CCR, 84072(d)(8)(A). 6. Visitation privacy Does not meet standard. Please refer to Title 22 CCR, 84072 (d)(8)(A) House Rules – Section 12 1. Policy of allowing children to be unsupervised away from the facility including issuing passes to children Meets standard. 2. Curfew (school nights, weekends, holidays or other times) Meets standard. 3. Dating other children in placement Meets standard. 4. Completing homework (engaging in tutoring, etc.) Does not meet standard. Please be more specific- will the GH have a dedicated time for homework? 5. Chores and cleaning of own personal space Does not meet standard. Missing chores. Please refer to Personal Rights 84072 – This is missing from house rules 6. Dress Code Does not meet standard. Violates Personal Rights- please refer to 84072(9)(A) and update. 7. Prohibited Behaviors Please include Child’s personal rights. 8. On December 6, 2024, at 9:40 AM, Licensing Program Analyst’s (LPA’s) Cynthia Robinson and Jessica Peete and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Cheraki Davis conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection. The Licensee above submitted a Group Home (GH) application. Presently there are no clients in care at the proposed new location. The pre-licensing inspection was conducted with Applicants, Angel Vivas, and Karla Vivas. The facility is located in a gated community that is required to enter a gate code. The facility is a two-story home with four bedrooms and three bathrooms, one loft and one nook and a three-car garage. There is one bedroom (bedroom #1) that will be used for clients and one full bathroom (bathroom #1) downstairs that will be available for client use. The facility has a living room and dining room in the kitchen area with a large dining room table. The nook is located by the garage entry and will be used as a staff office. There is one smoke detector and carbon monoxide combination located in the hallway adjacent to the kitchen and bedroom #1. There is a landline telephone that is in working order that will be available to clients. There was an observable hazard (balls, toys, etc.) in the kitchen sliding door exit leading to the backyard. LPA advised Applicants to remove the hazard. There were no observable hazards or obstructions by the other walkways and entries/exits. There is one sliding door exit in the dining room/living room and one sliding door exit in the kitchen leading to the backyard. There are no pools of bodies of water present. The backyard has a covered patio with a portable basketball hoop, a portable canopy, patio furniture, and two visible cameras. The central ac unit is in the backyard behind the house located on the left side of the house. The Applicant has a working fire extinguisher located by the garage entry. The garage will be made inaccessible to clients. The Applicants has sufficient dishes, cups and silverware for client use and the gas stove is in working order. The facility holds a loft upstairs that will be in use for client’s leisure and recreation space. LPA observed age-appropriate books, games, and puzzle for clients.

There are three bedrooms upstairs (bedroom #2, bedroom #3 and bedroom #4) and two bathrooms upstairs (bathroom #2 and bathroom #3 which is in bedroom #4). The bedrooms will be arranged so that no more than two clients are in a room, and there will be one client per bed. There is a laundry room upstairs that has storage space, and Applicants plans on putting a lock on the door to hold chemicals and cleaning products. The Applicants was advised that all individual beds must be in good repair, equipped with good springs, clean mattresses, and pillows. LPA tested the water and it read at 107 degrees Fahrenheit. The Applicants was advised that the hot water should measure within 105 degrees Fahrenheit and 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The following deficiencies were observed: The kitchen fridge was observed to have two bottles of alcohol that will be thrown away. There were cleaning supplies observed to be unlocked underneath the sink and knives were accessible on the counter tops and in cabinet drawers. Medications were observed in an unlock cabinet spaces and pantry closet. Applicants has planned to move the knives in a lock box paced in the kitchen pantry and medication will be centrally stored and inaccessible to clients in the lock closet under the stairs placed in a secure lock box. The bedrooms are not fully furnished due to missing dressers. Licensee advised to have appropriate storage space for client’s belongings before operation. There are cameras in the bedrooms and the facility has locks on all windows. Licensee was advised to remove all locks on windows and remove the cameras out of the bedrooms. There were missing nonslip rugs and paper towels in all bathrooms. The facility is missing all required posting, including food menu, foster rights, and complaint procedures to follow CCL regulations. Applicants was advised to ensure all posting will be posted in a visible location. Cleaning solutions were observed in the bathroom #3. There were missing pillows in bedroom #1. Applicants was advised to not have a locked facility due to the front door being locked from the inside.

It should be noted that the Applicants is still in the process of moving and a lot of personal belongings were observed. Firearms were stored in a lock safe utility box located in a closet under the stairs and will be removed as well. Applicants stated that they plan to remove all personal belongings by January 2025. The facility was advised that the plan of corrections is due January 31, 2025. After the above stated deficiencies are corrected in-person, a final file review will be conducted, and the facility will be submitted for licensure. Pre-Licensing inspection was completed, and a copy of this report was given to the Applicant, Angel Vivas.

On February 6, 2024, at 10 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Robinson conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection follow up. The applicant above submitted a Group Home (GH) application. Presently there are no clients in care at the proposed new location. LPA’s visit is to clear the previous deficiencies that was noted on the Pre-Licensing visit on December 6, 2024. The following deficiencies were notated on December 6, 2024. The kitchen fridge was observed to have two bottles of alcohol that will be thrown away. There were cleaning supplies observed to be unlocked underneath the sink and knives were accessible on the counter tops and in cabinet drawers. Medications were observed in an unlock cabinet spaces and pantry closet. Applicants has planned to move the knives in a lock box placed in the kitchen pantry and medication will be centrally stored and inaccessible to clients in the lock closet under the stairs placed in a secure lock box. The bedrooms are not fully furnished due to missing dressers. Licensee advised to have appropriate storage space for client’s belongings before operation. There are cameras in the bedrooms and the facility has locks on all windows. Licensee was advised to remove all locks on windows and remove the cameras out of the bedrooms. There were missing nonslip rugs and paper towels in all bathrooms. The facility is missing all required posting, including food menu, foster rights, and complaint procedures to follow CCL regulations. Applicants was advised to ensure all posting will be posted in a visible location. Cleaning solutions were observed in the bathroom #3. There were missing pillows in bedroom #1. Applicants was advised to not have a locked facility due to the front door being locked from the inside. (Continued on LIC 809C...)

The following changes have been made from LPA observations; the applicants have removed all alcohol from the facility. Additionally, the cleaning supplies, medication and knives have been moved from the kitchen and made inaccessible for the clients in locked boxes that are placed in the garage which has been made inaccessible to clients. The bedrooms are still not fully furnished due to missing drawer spaces. Licensee is made aware and will have the drawer spaces for the next visit. Additionally, there are no more cameras in the bedrooms and only in the common areas. All locks have been removed from all windows. All bathrooms had nonslip rugs and paper towels. The facility has the required posting, including food menu, foster rights, and complaint procedures to follow CLL regulations in a visible location. All pillows were present for the bedrooms. The lock was removed from the front door making it accessible for clients to leave facility. Previous visit Applicants had a firearm safe with firearms inside that was located in the closet under the stairs that has now been completely removed from the facility and there no firearms present. It should be noted that the applicants were still residing in the group home at the time of the first Pre-Licensing visit on December 6, 2024, and as of today’s date the Applicants still reside in the home and have created a move out date from the Group Home on February 21, 2025. LPA will return to the Group Home to verify that the applicant’s have completely moved out of the Group Home before issuing provisional license. Pre-Licensing inspection follow up was completed, and a copy of this report was given to the Applicant, Angel Vivas.

On February 24, 2024, at 10 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Robinson conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection follow up. The applicant above submitted a Group Home (GH) application. Presently there are no clients in care at the proposed new location. On 6/16/25 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen conducted the Component II - Face to Face Interview with Applicants Pamela Dixon & Luther Waters. Application and program statement was reviewed and discussed with Applicants. The applicants will oversee a Group Home Austin Place. The following documents were received and verified by LPA: 1. LPA verified the orientation certificate for Component I. 2. LPA made a copy of Licensee's ID for the records. 3. LPA observed that the criminal record clearance is pending for Luther Waters, and advised applicants that Pamela Dixon has not been cleared yet. 4. LPA reviewed the Program Design which was out of compliance with Group Home Regulations and General Licensing Requirements. Applicant will refer to application instructions to revise and adhere to Section B Documents: B7-B9. Licensee will provide more details when revising B7: Facility Program Description, including: adding more specifics about reasons for discharge and procedures, adding specific community resource examples for Activities, and adding the "maintenance of clients cash resources" in Basic Services. Licensee Licensee will provide more details when revising B8: Rules of Discipline including adding specific discipline tactics and practices for clients (Licensee can also include positive incentive structures) and specific reasons for discharging a client. Licensee will provide more details when revising B9: Admission Policies including, adding a sample admission form, adding a section about the pre-appraisal plan, changing the ISP's to be created by the Social Workers, and updating the program statement if needed.

Licensee will also add sections that cover "Visitations, Program Modifications, Transportation, Facility phone, Mail, Children's Rights, and Clothing/Incidentals." LPA application and Program Design and returned to applicant for revision. Applicant will submit updated Program Design by 6/20/25. LPA scheduled a Pre-Licensing visit for Austin Place for 7/1/25. A copy of this report was given to the applicants. Exit interview completed.

On 7/1/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting a Pre- licensing inspection for a Group Home License. LPA met with applicants Luther Waters and Pamela Dixon, who granted access into the home. The applicant and LPA toured the facility both inside and out. Applicant is requesting to be licensed for 4 clients ages 15-17 ambulatory only. The home was inspected and the following was observed: This is a one-story house, with a front yard, backyard, a separate unit and garage in the back. There are working duel smoke/carbon monoxide detector in every bedroom. They are synched throughout the house. Living Room: There is adequate lighting and air conditioning. There is a TV. There is a sofa with adequate seating. The living room leads to the kitchen/dinning area and to the bedrooms which are lined along the side. There is a decommissioned fire place with no gas line, no place for fire wood, and a blocked chimney. Bedroom #1: For clients. There is one bed. There is adequate lighting and a ceiling fan. There is a TV. There is adequate closet storage space and two dressers one small and one medium. Storage space is filled with extra towels. There are two windows in working order. There is a hamper for dirty cloths and a container with basic toiletries. Bedroom #2: For clients. There is one bed. There is adequate lighting and a ceiling fan. There is a TV. There is adequate closet storage space and two dressers one small and one medium. Storage space is filled with extra towels. There is one window in working order. There is a hamper for dirty cloths and a container with basic toiletries.

Bathroom #1: is located off next to bedroom#2. It is clear of all cleaning solutions with a working toilet, dual sinks, and shower. Water temp was measured to be 110 degrees F. Bedroom #3: For clients. There is one bed. There is adequate lighting and a ceiling fan. There is a TV. There is adequate closet storage space and two dressers one small and one medium. Storage space is filled with extra towels. There is one window in working order. There is a hamper for dirty cloths and a container with basic toiletries. Bedroom #4: For clients. There is one bed. There is adequate lighting and a ceiling fan. There is a TV. There is adequate closet storage space and two dressers one small and one medium. Storage space is filled with extra towels. There is one window in working order. There is a hamper for dirty cloths and a container with basic toiletries. There is a sliding glass door that leads to the back yard, the door will be kept unlocked. There is a fuse box that applicants must make inaccessible to clients. Bathroom #2: is located off next to bedroom #4. It is clear of all cleaning solutions with a working toilet, sink, and open shower. Water temp was measured to be 110 degrees F. Kitchen/Dinning Room: Is equipped with an operable 4 burner stove, dish washer, and refrigerator/freezer. Applicant locked sharps and cleaning solutions under the sink to be inaccessible to clients in care. There is dinning counter with adequate seating. There is an adequate amount of cups, plates, bowls, and utensils. Applicant stocked fridge and freezer with and adequate amount of perishable and non-perishable food. The First Aid is in the kitchen and was checked to be complete with scissors, tweezers, thermometer, gauzes, bandages, and antiseptic solution. There is also a first aid manual and 2 emergency kits. There is a fire Extinguisher fully charged and available in the kitchen. Extra linens and towels are stored in the kitchen. There is water access from the fridge and bottled water. Client medication, client & staff files, facility plan of operation & program statement will be stored in a cabinet in the kitchen. Laundry Room: There is a laundry room next to the kitchen. There is a washer and dryer unit. There is a fully charged fire extinguisher. Bathroom #3: is a half bath located off next to the laundry room. It is clear of all cleaning solutions with a working toilet and sink. Water temp was measured to be 110 degrees F.

Out Side: Front Yard: There is a front yard with adequate space for clients to hang out. Backyard: There is a back yard with a basketball court. There is a shaded area that will have outdoor seating. There is a side path that leads to the front yard. There is a separate unit in the back that applicants will use as an office and has been made inaccessible to clients. There is also a garage that applicants have made inaccessible. LPA observed facility vehicle to be in working order. The vehicle is up to date on insurance and insured by Berkshire-Hathaway specialty insurance. LPA and applicant discussed next step component three meeting. LPA will email applicants about meeting in person or having a scheduled zoom orientation. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to the applicants.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Lidia Tinoco arrived at the Autism Ashram AWAAZ Group Home for the purpose of conducting an Annual Continuation Inspection and met with Administrator, Brian Freitas. LPA Tinoco reviewed 5 staff files, interviewed available staff and interviewed 3 youth in care. On this date, LPA Tinoco observed that a deficiency cited on 05/30/25 had been addressed. As of todays date, POC are still pending for two deficiencies, POC due 06/06/25. LPA provided regulation section 80061 Reporting Requirements and 84065 Personnel Requirements. LPA also discussed supervision. LPA Tinoco issued 2 Technical Assistance and 7 deficiencies on this date. Plans of correction were discussed and developed with Administrator Brian Freitas. A copy of this report was provided on this date along with appeal rights.

narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Lidia Tinoco arrived at the Autism Ashram Awaaz Group Home for the purpose of conducting a Plan of Correction visit. LPA Tinoco met with Administrator, Brian Freitas. LPA Tinoco conducted a review of 5 staff files and 1 Client file to verify for completeness. LPA cleared 8 deficiencies on today's visit. 2 plan of corrections are still pending as of today's date and will be submitted to LPA Tinoco via email no later than close of business day Friday, July 11, 2025. LPA provided clearance letters for deficiencies cleared on today's date. A copy of this report was provided at the conclusion of the inspection.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Lidia Tinoco met with Administrator, Brian Freitas for the purpose of conducting a Case Management regarding an incident that occurred on May 22, 2025. The incident involving C1, C2 and S1 (See LIC811 Confidential Names List). The incident involved C1 and C2 escalating and exhibiting dangerous behaviors which S1 tried to manage as the only staff on shift. Per Administrator, the facility was within ratio as they are a 1 staff per two client facility. Administrator also expressed that they were actively hiring staff at the time but did not have staff to pull from. Due to this incident, Administrator developed a plan for Regional Center on how they would manage these issues moving forward which includes having two staff members present during waking hours while these youth are in placement. Plan was provided to LPA Tinoco on this date. Furthermore, agency has requested from Regional Center a one on one staff for C1 due to the behaviors. The plan is currently pending. All documentation discussed was provided to LPA Tinoco. A technical violation was issued on todays date. A copy of this report was discussed an provided at the conclusion of the inspection.

On Thursday 1/20/22 at 10:27AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. Safety precautions were taken, including screening call, N95 masks and face coverings, and hand washing/sanitizing/gloves. LPA met with Facility Manager Cesar Redoloso and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA used the CARE Inspection Tool to conduct the inspection. There are three residents in care, and all were at school during the visit. The facility is a house in a residential neighborhood and has three double-occupancy resident bedrooms and one staff room, two bathrooms, kitchen/dining/living space and outdoor activity space. Beds were observed to be in good condition and fitted with clean linens and mattress pads. The facility is clean and sanitary. There were no bodies of water or hazards, and per Facility Manager, there were no firearms on the premises. Room and hot water temperatures measured within permitted ranges, at 68 F and 112.8 F, respectively. The first aid kit was observed to be complete. During the file review, LPA observed that staff S1, S2, S3, and S4 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) did not have 20 hours of annual training documented and maintained in the staff records. Per FM, in-house training is provided, but the facility was not aware that this training counted toward the training requirement as Regional Center had previously informed the facility that only outside training counted. LPA read the Title 22 regulations on the annual training requirement. LPA issued a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 84065 Personnel Requirements. See LIC9099-D attached. See attached (4) advisories issued for the following: (1) 80071: Register of Clients was not current with current residents, including one discharged resident and excluding one admitted resident 80071; (2) 84072.2: Complaint procedures were available in resident records but not visibly posted in facility; (3) 84070: Psychotropic medications for residents R2 and R3 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) were properly documented but not logged separately for the month of January 2022, while they were logged separately on the Psychotropic Medication Administration Record in December 2021; (4) 80070: Resident R2's file was missing an inventory of personal belongings. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report provided to Facility Manager Cesar Redoloso, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

met_with: Licensee Filipina Cruz, Facility Manager Cesar Redoloso
narrative: On Thursday, February 17, 2022 (02/17/2022) at 11:30AM, a scheduled Office Tele-Meeting was conducted with the facility. In attendance were Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins, Licensee Filipina Cruz, and Facility Manager Cesar Redoloso. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the facility's recent age exception requests and planned transition to an Adult Residential Facility (ARF). Licensee and Facility Manager confirmed that the residents in care will be turning 18 soon and that they will remain in care. Licensee agreed to submit a formal letter stating their intent to transition to an ARF. The letter is to include Licensee's plan for the submission of the ARF application and the date by which they will have submitted the application. This letter will be submitted to LPA Hawkins by Tuesday 2/22/22. A copy of this report was provided to Licensee Cruz and Facility Manager Redoloso, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 12-9-22 10:45AM, Licensing Program Analysts(LPA) George Karkazis and Alyssa Ng conducted an unannounced Annual/Random inspection at listed facility. LPA's met with Jose Solancho, Direct Care Support, and toured the facility inside and out. Safety precautions were taken including screening call and mask wearing. The Group Home is licensed to serve 3 clients. At 10:55 Cesar Redoloso, Facility Manager arrived. Present during the inspection were two staff and no clients. At 11:03AM, LPA Karkazis and Ng reviewed client and staff files. All of the necessary forms were present, all files were complete and in order. At 12:21PM, LPA Karkazis and Ng toured the facility. LPA Karkazis observed four bedrooms and two bathrooms. LPA observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA Karkazis tested the water temperature and found it to be 111.2 degrees which is in range. The thermostat read 68 degrees which is within range. Sharps were locked and safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication was also stored and locked under the counter in a cabinet. The facility is in good repair and clean. LPA Karkazis interviewed two staff and no clients. At 1:39PM, LPA Karkazis and Ng toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. continued on LIC 809-C

continued fro LIC 809 At this time there were three citations and one Technical Advisory. California Code Of Regulations, Buildings and Grounds 84487(s)(3) LPA Karkazis witnessed two cans of disinfectant under the sink in a cabinet without a lock. California Code of Regulations 80087(g) Buildings and Grounds LPA Karkazis witnessed shaving clippers in client's room. California Code of Regulations 84072.2 (a)(3) Complaint Procedures- LPA Karkazis witnessed that Complaint Procedures were not posted in a visible area. Technical Advisory- 84470(b)- LPA witnessed weight record for client on the kitchen calendar, not in file. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of this report was given to Cesar Redoloso, Facility Manager.

On 1/25/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit regarding the facility closure. LPA met with Facility Manager Cesar Redoloso over the phone, facilitated by direct care staff, and informed of the purpose of the visit. A screening contact was prior to visit as well. The facility is transitioning from a group home facility to an adult residential facility. LPA confirmed at visit that the facility has completed their component 3 pre-licensing inspection but has not yet received licensure. Facility Manager agreed to notify LPA when the adult residential facility license is received so a follow-up inspection can be made. There are no deficiencies cited at this visit. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report provided to Facility Manager Cesar Redoloso, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

State training will be provided prior to being allowed to dispense medication to children in care. Page8-What is the accordion file system that’s being used for medical orders? Section3 Purpose, Methods and Goals- female & male? Under age 5? Application is for 6-17 years of age. IPP what does that stand for? Spell out. What type of treatment will be provided and how will results or outcomes be measured? how often? States what program will provide but does not state how it will be accomplished. Section 4 Planned Activities/Use of Community Resources- 1.Describe the program's planned SOCIAL and RECREATIONAL activities. Include: - The plan for indoor and outdoor activities; - The plan for individual child activities and group interaction activities; - Which children are involved in the activities; 2.Describe the program's planned educational activities and services. Include: - Special education; - Use of public and/or private schools; - On grounds school; and- Tutoring, if applicable. 3. Provide a SAMPLE DAILY ACTIVITY SCHEDULE for one week, including weekends and holidays. The schedule must include social, recreational and educational activities. Section 5 Special Services/Programs Offered 1. Describe any special services or programs which will be offered. 2. If the program provides vocational training, describe: - The skills taught; - Goals of the training program; Hands-on experience received; - Materials provided; - Number of hours per day/days per week training is provided; and How training is funded Section 6 Medical/Dental 2. Describe procedures used to identify and handle medical, dental and psychiatric emergencies 3. Identify staff position(s) responsible for dispensing and destroying medications.

Section 7 Transportation 1. Describe arrangements for transporting children to and from school, activities provided outside the facility(ies) (including attendance at religious services) and medical/dental appointments. 2. Specify how the program will ensure that vehicles used to transport children are maintained in safe operating condition. 3. Specify how the program will ensure that vehicle registration and insurance will be maintained. 4. Specify how the program will ensure that only appropriately licensed program staff and volunteers will transport children. Section 8 Admission/Intake 1.Describe the program's admission/intake procedures. Include: - Criteria for evaluating appropriateness of referrals for placement; Information required to assess referrals for placement; - Time frame for responding to referring agencies regarding acceptance or rejection of referral; - Staff position responsible for intake; and - Procedures for accepting emergency placement's on a time limited and/or trial basis. Section 9 Needs and Service Plans/Assessment 1. Describe procedures for developing a needs and services plan which addresses each child's needs and the services required to meet such needs. 2. Describe procedures for review and evaluation of the needs and services plan. 3. Describe procedures for implementing and modifying the needs and services plan. 4. Describe the policy regarding participation of the child and his/her authorized representative in developing, updating and modifying the needs and services plan. Section 10 Discharge and Removal 1. Describe procedures for planned discharge or removal. Include time lines. 2. Describe procedures for emergency discharge or removal. Include time lines. Section 11 Visitation Rules and Policy -When and under what circumstances the child is permitted to have home visits with parents and/or relatives; -When and under what circumstances the child is permitted to have overnight visits with parents, relatives, family members and friends; and -When and under what circumstances other types of visits are or are not permitted.

Section 12 House Rules 1. Describe the program's policy of allowing children to be unsupervised away from the facility, including issuing passes to children. 2. Specify other house rules. Include: -Curfew hours on school nights, weekends and holidays; -Smoking; -Dating other children in placement; -Completing homework; -Cleaning bedrooms and other areas; Use of entertainment equipment (the child's and the facility's); -Dress code; -Laundry. -General prohibited behaviors -Describe your reward system (you may give examples) Section 13 Discipline Policies 1. Describe the program's discipline policy. [Reference: Title 22 CCR 80072(a)(3), (7) - (8), 84072, 84072.1] Include: -Type(s) of discipline used; -Conditions under which each type of discipline will be used; -Types of discipline not permitted (corporal punishment and violation of personal rights); -Provisions for contact with parents and/or placement representatives (conferences). Section 14 Emergency Intervention Plan 1. Include a copy of your agency's approved Emergency Intervention Plan which must address the following areas: -Techniques of group and individual behavior management; -Methods for de-escalating volatile situations; -Alternative methods of handling aggressive and assaultive behavior; -Describe the physical techniques of applying manual restraints, if applicable; -Techniques for returning the child to planned activity following an emergency intervention; -A written test and evaluation criteria for the hands-on competency test; and

2. Include the name and qualifications of the individual who designed the Emergency Intervention Plan. *84322 EIP is to be designed and approved on conjunction with licensee by a qualified behavior management consultant Section 15 Runaway Plan 1. Describe the plan for responding to an incident of a child running away. Include: -Time frames for determining when a child is absent without permission; -Continuum of interventions; -Actions to locate the child; -Staff training plan; -Plan to involve law enforcement; and -Plan to notify the child's authorized representative. Section 16 Children’s Complaint/Grievance Procedures Describe procedures by which children or their authorized representatives are informed of their rights and permitted to file complaints. Include how children, their authorized representatives and staff receive copies of the written complaint/grievance procedures. Section 17 Handling Children’s Funds, Allowances and Salaries 1. Describe how the program accounts for and handles children's personal funds. 2. Describe the procedure for issuing allowances, including the amount. Section 18 Chores Describe any chores children are required to perform as part of their regular routine. Section 19 Nutrition/Sample Menu 1. Provide a SAMPLE MENU which includes: -One week's worth of planned meals, including snacks from the four basic food groups; -Portion sizes; and -Times meals are served. 2. Describe any provisions available for children with special dietary needs. Section 20 Clothing and Incidentals 1. Describe how the program ensures that children have adequate clothing. Logs? Inventory ? 2. Describe how the program provides personal hygiene items (for example, shampoo and deodorant).

Section 21 Staff Schedule 1. Specify the number of hours the program administrator will be at each facility each week. Section 23 Job Descriptions Social Work Staff from Regional Center? Reporting to Regional Center? Child Care staff listed in this section but not on your LIC 500 to be hired Section 24 In-Service Training for Staff 1. Describe the plan for providing initial and annual training for child care staff. Include: - Position or person who will do the training and his/her qualifications; - Approximate length of training; - Initial and annual training curricula; and - How special training needs are identified and met Section 26 Volunteers Describe how volunteers are utilized, screened and trained. Section 27 Control of Property - Unofficial no signature or seal on documents - Provide a copy of the Deed(s) or Property Tax Bill(s) as proof of property ownership. Section 28 Facility Sketch - Dimensions of all rooms and their designated use; - The number of children per bedroom; - Identify utility shut off locations and dimensions of all rooms. Staff Bedroom? An Exit Interview was conducted. LPA provided applicant a copy of the LIC 9106 group home program statement general instructions and the medications guide for group homes. A copy of this report and an outline of all revisions needed prior licensing was provided to applicant.

On 9/05/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Toni Castillo made an announced visit to A & A Heavenly Group Home for the purpose of conducting a prelicensing inspection. LPA met with applicant Irene Uribe and Administrator Marshall Tunstalle, who facilitated the inspection and the walk-through tour of the facility. A tour of the facility including outside and inside of the building was conducted. The group home is located in a residential neighborhood. This is a single story home which is 2,483 square feet. This home has 4 bedrooms and 2 restrooms. LPA observed the following: Visitors hours posted with visitors sign in/out log, medication closet which is locked containing client medication files, medication storage, and first aid kit, cleaning supplies are locked in a closet, a sufficient amount of linen supply in a hall closet, family room with seating area, side chairs and tables, a television and a fireplace which contains a screen. The kitchen area contains operable stove refrigerator, oven, microwave, and sink. LPA observed a pantry with food supply, a trash can with a proper lid, knives are stored in a locked cabinet, sufficient amount of cooking and eating utensils, dishware, pots and pans. Kitchen table with chairs for 6 to sit. Bedroom #1 is utilized as a staff office, which contains locked client files, desk, chair, computer and office supplies, Staff office has a bathroom which will be designated for staff and guest use only. Bedroom #2,#3 and #4 designated for one client in each bedroom. Bedroom #2, #3 and #4 each contain one bed, a chair, a night stand, a dresser, a closet, a television and a hamper. Each client beds has a mattress pad, fitted sheet, flat sheet, comforter and pillows. Bedrooms all contain adequate lighting. There are no locks on the bedroom doors. Windows are equipped with free of debris window screens. The clients' bedrooms were arranged so that no more than one client will be in a room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. (see next page for continuation 809-C)

There is one client restroom designated for client use only. This is a full restroom with shower, tub, sink, toilet and counter space. LPA observed all restroom appliances in operable order, hot water temperature was tested and is within regulation temperature. Laundry room contains a washer and dryer. LPA observed laundry supplies. A safety assessment of the front and back yard was completed. There are no bodies of water in the front of back yard. LPA observed the front and back yard to be groomed and landscaped. There were no hazards items. Backyard is furnished with patio furniture for recreation. Smoke detectors are in operable working order. LPA observed recreational activities for client use such as books and games. This group home has a land line which will be used for clients as needed. All required items were posted in a visible area of the home. The following items were posted: personal rights, grievance procedures, food menu, emergency, evacuation and disaster plan An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to applicant Irene Uribe via email. The application will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager Cheraki Davis once corrections in the program statement are submitted to LPA.

On April 6, 2023 at 12pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Required Annual. LPA met with Program Director, Dominique Baker and was allowed into the facility, This facility is licensed for a capacity of 6 children, ages 12-17, ambulatory only. The Bailard House program is designed to accept private placement clients with a length of stay of 30-90 days. The inspection is as follows: First Floor: The first level of the home is comprised of a garage/recreation area that contains a pool and ping pong table, two storage closets and a locked laundry closet with a washer and dryer. Detergent is kept in their as well. As you enter the house, The hallway contains 3 Bedrooms. Bedroom #1 and #2 are equip with a full sized bed and dressers for the clients clothing. Bedroom #1 also has a couch in the room. Bedroom #3 has a full sized bed dresser and an end table. Inside of bedroom #3 is a bathroom with a shower, sink and toilet all in good working condition. Bedroom #1 and #2 share the hall Bathroom. The hall bathroom has a shower, sink and toilet all in good working condition. There is a contraband closet at the beginning of the hallway. Second Floor: The kitchen which has a microwave, air fryer, toaster, coffee maker, stove, refrigerator and an island. The sharps are kept in a locked drawer and the key is kept with the Chef. The kitchen has 2 days of perishables and 7 days of non perishables. The nurse's office/medication storage area is in the hall outside of the kitchen. A nurse keeps track of the medication and the staff is also trained to administer medication. There is a first aid kit and ample supplies in case of an emergency. The clients medication is kept in a locked cabinet and in individual containers. The school area has a table an bookshelf. The common area has a large couch, a large seating area and a covered fireplace. There are two bathrooms on this floor in good working condition. There is a storage area where school supplies, laptops, and some cleaning supplies are kept. Cont 809-C

The third level has one Bedroom, staff office and a large bathroom. The bedroom has two beds, two dressers and two desks. The bathroom is large. There is two sides of the bathroom which are identical. There is a shower, sink and toilet on both sides. There is a large jacuzzi tub which is inoperable. Throughout the home, several fire extinguishers were observed in good condition and fully charged until April of 2024. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are hard wired and are in working order. Outside: The shut off valves are in the back of the house and labeled. There is a basketball court and a large area that is being transformed into a garden. There were no hazards or obstructions at the time of the visit. The vehicle is a Chevy Suburban. The registration and insurance was in the vehicle and current until 2024. There is a first aid kit in the trunk and the lights and signals are in good working condition. LPA discussed with and advised the Licensee to ensure the following: Children are accorded personal rights and the corresponding form is in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency or Foster Care Ombudsperson, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Licensee has received the Admissions Agreement, Needs & Services Plan and written authorization to obtain medical and dental care for the children and ensures these documents are maintained in individual client folders. Licensee acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. During the visit, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements for Group Home Licensure and Emergency Plan were met. LPA reviewed Staff and Client files. LPA interviewed one staff and no clients. Clients were gone on an outing. No deficiencies were observed or cited during this inspection.

Based on gathered information obtained and reviewed, the findings are determined Unsubstantiated. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There are no deficiencies per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, of at this time. Exit interview completed. Appeal Rights discussed and a copy of this report was provided to Facility Program Director.
investigation_findings: 13On April 24, 2024, at 12:50 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection at BAILARD HOUSE to deliver findings concerning the above-mentioned allegation. LPA Martin met with Dominique Baker, Program Director to discuss the investigative outcome. On September 6, 2023, CCLD received a complaint alleging Neglect/ Lack of Supervision leading to sexual abuse, as a youth was reportedly sexually assaulted while in care. The investigation was conducted by Investigator Laura Garcia of the Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Investigations Branch. The investigation, including confidential interviews of former resident (alleged victim), three staff members, complainant, other associated parties, and review of facility file review history revealed former resident (Client #1) resided at the facility for approximately two months. Confidential statements obtained revealed a lack of evidence to support allegation as statements obtained produced denial of sexual abuse or neglect and further produced no witnesses or corroborating evidence to the alleged. (Continued on page LIC9099-C).

narrative: On 07/15/2024, at 1pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Donald Martin made an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management – Incident Inspection. LPA spoke with AM Lead, Stephanie Miller and was allowed into the facility. A health and safety assessment was conducted. On 07/1/2024, the department received an Incident Report dated 06/28/2024, indicating that Child 1 (C1) reported to Staff 2 (S2) that On 6/3/2024 S1, while on an outing to the park, walked C1 to the bathroom. While C1 was using the restroom, S1 made uncomfortable gestures adjusting his pants. LPA interviewed S2 and C2 and has concluded that further investigation is needed to determine findings for this Case Management investigation. There were no deficiencies cited at the time of the visit.

The Bailard House program is designed to accept private placement clients with a length of stay of 30-90 days. The inspection is as follows: First Floor: The first level of the home is comprised of a garage/recreation area that contains a pool table and ping pong table, two storage closets and a locked laundry closet with a washer and dryer. Detergent is kept in their as well. As you enter the house, The hallway contains 3 Bedrooms. Bedroom #1 and #2 are equip with a full sized bed and dressers for the clients clothing. Bedroom #1 also has a couch in the room. Bedroom #3 has a full sized bed dresser and an end table. Inside of bedroom #3 is a bathroom with a shower, sink and toilet all in good working condition. Bedroom #1 and #2 share the hall Bathroom. The hall bathroom has a shower, sink and toilet all in good working condition. There is a contraband closet at the beginning of the hallway. Second Floor: The kitchen which has a microwave, air fryer, toaster, coffee maker, stove, refrigerator and an island. The sharps are kept in a locked drawer and the key is kept with the Chef. The kitchen has 2 days of perishables and 7 days of non perishables. The nurse's office/medication storage area is in the hall outside of the kitchen. Staff is trained to administer medication. There is a first aid kit and ample supplies in case of an emergency. The clients medication is kept in a locked cabinet and in individual containers. The school area has a table an bookshelf. The common area has a large couch, a large seating area and a covered fireplace. There are two bathrooms on this floor in good working condition. There is a storage area where school supplies, laptops, and some cleaning supplies are kept. Cont 809-C

The third level has one Bedroom, staff office and a large bathroom. The bedroom has two beds, two dressers and two desks. The bathroom is large. There is two sides of the bathroom which are identical. There is a shower, sink and toilet on both sides. There is a large jacuzzi tub which is inoperable. Throughout the home, several fire extinguishers were observed in good condition and fully charged until April of 2025. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are hard wired and are in working order. Outside: The shut off valves are in the back of the house and labeled. There is a basketball court and a large area that is being transformed into a garden. There were no hazards or obstructions at the time of the visit. The vehicle is a Chevy Suburban. The registration and insurance was in the vehicle and current until 2025. There is a first aid kit in the trunk and the lights and signals are in good working condition. LPA discussed with and advised the Licensee to ensure the following: Children are accorded personal rights and the corresponding form is in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency or Foster Care Ombudsperson, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Licensee has received the Admissions Agreement, Needs & Services Plan and written authorization to obtain medical and dental care for the children and ensures these documents are maintained in individual client folders. Licensee acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. During the visit, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements for Group Home Licensure and Emergency Plan were met. Note: The disbursement of allowance has been discussed with the Program Director, Dominique Baker. LPA will review the program statement for clarity before making a determination on how to proceed. LPA reviewed 3 Staff and 3 Client files. No deficiencies were observed or cited during this inspection.

On August 28, 2024 at 11:30am Licensing Program Analysty (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual Inspection Continuation. LPA was met by Lead, Stephanie Miller and allowed into the facility. LPA will be conducting interviews for clients and Staff during todays visit. LPA interviewed 3 staff and 2 clients. No deficiencies were cited at the time of the visit.

There was no evidence that staff did not prevent inappropriate behaviors between minors. The name of the minor involved was not disclosed. Documentation provided did not show any boundary issues with other clients reported by facility staff or C1. There was no evidence that staff did not administer minors medication. LPA collected all medication distribution documents. No days of medication was missed. There was no evidence that staff did not refill minors medication in a timely manner. Medication is handled by an on site nurse and is ordered a week prior to running out. There was no evidence that staff did not seek medical attention for minor. It was documented that client saw the Doctor once a week while in care. There was no evidence that staff threatened minor or that staff did not provide a comfortable environment for minors. C1 was not available for comment. Clients interviewed stated that they got along well with staff. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred; therefore, the above allegation is Unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies being cited at this time.
investigation_findings: 13On September 8, 2023 at 1pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of delivering findings for the above complaint allegations. LPA met with Program Director, Dominique Baker and was allowed into the facility. During the course of investigation the allegations for staff did not prevent inappropriate behaviors between minors, staff did not administer minors medication, staff did not refill minors medication in a timely manner, staff did not seek medical attention for minor, staff threatened minor and staff did not provide a comfortable environment for minors, interviews were conducted and documents obtained. The interviews did not produce corroborating evidence to support said allegations. Interviews revealed inconsistent statements and no witnesses to suggest allegations occurred. Cont 9099-C

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Raymond Canal conducted a case management inspection on 6/24/25 at 11:12 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 12 Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 6 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 12 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 6 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 6/24/25). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, and Trauma informed safety plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Canal observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Eli Wayne.

facility_name: BAUER RESIDENTIAL SANTA MARIA 3 GROUP HOME
narrative:
On 3/29/2022 at 8:50am Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Enrique Hernandez and Nancy O’Connell conducted a Case Management Annual/Required Inspection at the above facility. LPAs met with Jaime Staine Facility Administrator (FA) who granted access to the facility and toured the home in and out. This is a four-bedroom, two-bathroom, single story family residence that includes a living room, dining area, office area, kitchen, laundry area and an attached garage. LPA toured the entire facility and observed the following: Bedroom #1 is occupied by one male client, it has one twin size bed, adequate closet and drawer space. Wall behind bedroom door has a hole in the wall. Window screen needs repair. Wall outlet plug is cracked and needs to be replaced. Bedroom #2 is occupied by one male client, it has one queen size bed, adequate closet and drawer space. Window screen does not fit on window. Bedroom #3 is occupied by one male client, it has one twin size bed, and one full size bed adequate walking closet and drawer space bathroom was clean at the time of the inspection. [See LIC811 Confidential Names List form (LIC811), dated 03/29/2022, for names] LPA observed non-perishable foods for one week and perishable food for two days. Facility is clean and sanitary. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. Rules, regulations, licenses, emergency disaster plan and personal rights are posted at the facility. Menu is posted in the kitchen- an advisory notice will be given to direct facility to add date on menu. Outdoor space is free of debris and hazard. Bathroom #1 clean and sanitary. Water temperature was measured at 105 degrees. Continued on LIC 809C

Hazardous and cleaning solutions, disinfectants, poisons, medication and sharp knives are inaccessible to the clients. Bathroom #2 Bathroom shower has mold in grout. Meds are locked and accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. Home has working smoke alarms, carbon monoxide detectors and working fire extinguishers at the time of this inspection. LPA advised FA to add another fire extinguisher in laundry room. The facility has a working telephone/landline. There is no bodies of water on the premises. Kitchen/Dining area: There was one (1) refrigerator, microwave, one (1) stove one (1) with four (4) burners, and back right knob on stove was missing. There was a large dining table with four (4) chairs. A trash can with a lid on was observed in the kitchen area. Laundry Room: There was a laundry room in the garage equipped with a sink, one (1) washer and one (1) dryer during the time of the inspection. Per California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, chapters 5, the following deficiencies were cited at the time of inspection: Wall outlet in BR#1 is broken Window screen in bedroom #1 is ripped on bottom of the screen Window screen in bedroom #2 is bent and does not fit in window frame Window screen in bedroom #3 is bent and does not fit in window frame Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to the facility Administrator due to technical difficulties with LPA’s printer.

facility_name: BAUER RESIDENTIAL SANTA MARIA 3 GROUP HOME
narrative:
On May 11, 2022, at 09:15am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell, conducted an unannounced Case Management Deficiency inspection at Bauer Home located at the above address. Jaime Staine, Facility Manager (FM), granted access into the facility and together conducted a tour of the entire facility, inside and out. The facility is licensed to care for four (4) children, ages 12-17 years, ambulatory only (See confidential name list LIC-811 dated 05/11/2022). The purpose of the inspection is to deliver a deficiency citation due to information received on 3/29/2022 about an unpermitted garage conversion. During the previous visit, LPA O'Connell and LPA Hernandez observed that a portion of the facility garage had been converted into a dwelling unit, being used to house a facility staff (S1). During the inspection on 3/29/22, the FA reported that the staff member was residing in the permitted garage structure. Staff (S1) was cleared to work in the facility at the time of 3/29/22 inspection. LPA Hernandez informed the FA that a request for a fire clearance would be made in order to ensure permit of garage structure. On 4/5/2022, a Fire Safety inspection was conducted by the City of Santa Maria Fire Department and the report indicates the following: "Denial- Unpermitted garage conversion." Case was referred to Santa Maria Code Enforcement. Cont on LIC809C

Per California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 1 & 5, the following deficiency is being cited at the time of the inspection: Unpermitted garage structure/Lack of Fire Clearance LPA took pictures of the garage dwelling unit on 3/29/22 and on this day 5/11/22, showing garage conversion unit removed See LIC 809D. Exit Interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

facility_name: BAUER RESIDENTIAL SANTA MARIA 3 GROUP HOME
narrative: On 5-9-23 at 10:45am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell, made an unannounced inspection to the above-listed facility, and met with the Facility Administrator (FA), who granted access to the facility and provided a tour of the facility, inside and out. Tri-COunties Regional Center Quality Assurance Specialist, Vince Figueroa, was also in attendance. The purpose of this inspection was to conduct an initial complaint investigation inspection. LPA O’Connell conducted a walk-through of the facility with FA and Tri-Counties Regional Center QAS. During the time of inspection, LPA observed expired produce within the main refrigerator that was not stored in containers. When LPA asked about reason for expired food, FA stated that the staff forgot to clean out the refrigerator. Upon further inspection of stored medication and medication logbook, LPA observed that administered medication for C1 was not accurately logged on 5/8/23. LPA pointed out lack of signature in medication logbook and FA acknowledged documentation error and stated that she would speak with staff responsible for error. Upon inspection of facility garage, LPA observed a broken window that FA reports has been broken since 4/10/23 when a former client became aggressive and broke it. FA reports that she is unsure about when the window will be repaired. Upon inspection of bedroom #2, LPA observed that the wall near the client's bed has two three-inch holes in them due to bed pushing against the wall.The bedroom also has paneling that is detaching from the main wall in the bedroom. FA reported that the client was responsible for causing damage and making the holes in the wall with the bed. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, three deficiencies will be cited at this time. See LIC809D for details. Pictures of all deficiencies have been retained for department records. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the facility.

facility_name: BAUER RESIDENTIAL SANTA MARIA 3 GROUP HOME
investigation_findings: 13On 10/11/23 at 1:00pm, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Nancy O’Connell and Jhane Haynes made an unannounced inspection to the above facility for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation and deliver the finding.LPA spoke with S1 and together, discussed the investigative finding. During the investigative process by Licensing program Analyst (LPA), Nancy O’Connell, all relevant parties have been accounted for. Supporting evidence includes: interviews with formal supports attesting to client specific behaviors that would cause markings on C1's body. Further, record reviews indicate pressence of behavioral patterns that would account for discoloration on body. Documentation evidence was gathered from the facility to support policies that are in alignment with consistent supervision and "body checks." Lastly, photographic evidence was obtained that clearly shows markings on body that are inconsistent with signs of abuse. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

facility_name: BAUER RESIDENTIAL SANTA MARIA 3 GROUP HOME
investigation_findings: 13On 10/11/23 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell and LPA Jhane Haynes made unannounced inspection to the above-listed facility for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation and deliver the finding. LPA O’Connell met with Jaime Staine, facility administrator (FA) and discussed the investigative findings. During the investigative process, LPA O’Connell conducted confidential interviews with all relevant parties and collected information on the above allegation. Supporting evidence includes: staff records produced by the facility administrator reflecting inaccuracies in staff schedules. Further, the facility administrator could not provide records confirming the staff schedule for S1, in order to confirm S1’s presence within the facility during scheduled shifts. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations Title 22, Chapter 5, are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.
